Very easy to talk to, wonderful at helping students outside of class. Lectures are clear and condensed on what needs to be learned for the homework and exams, and include lots of examples. Would absolutely recommend taking him for Feedback.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things

comment: My favorite professor at mines. His lectures are incredibly useful and engaging. I've had him before and he consistently delivers great courses and material. The exams were hard for this class however, and I had to go to office hours quite often to do good on the exams. But he is more than willing to help you if you ask for it.
Hands down my favorite prof at this school. I swear he cares more about our learning than we do at times, I have taken multiple classes with him and every time I'm happy I have.

Professor Chris Coulston is a class act, an overall wonderful teacher than makes learning fun again. Coulston cares more that every student is fully understanding the material than rushing through it and relying on the homework to teach the student. In addition his labs every week are absolutely amazing, I have never taken a lab class I enjoy more

I've taken a few courses with Coulston and he is always very energetic, knowledgeable and probably the best lecturer in the EE department. One thing to note is that he can be pretty strict at times and can give a heavy workload. With that being said, I highly recommend taking his class since you get so much out of it.

Absolutely outstanding professor. Yes, this class demands a lot of outside hours but you will have all the resources you need to do well. Be ready to lean on your TAs and don't be afraid to go to him for help, he will help you work through any problem you have.

He's class has an unfathomable course load, which is extremely heavy. Every time you finish the stupid convoluted inlab you gotta worry about the actual lab, which takes at least 6-12 hours if done all alone. The TAs grade based on accuracy and are very harsh in terms of standards. No do-over's for the quizzes, which are basically homework...
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Others have echoed this sentiment... Dr. Coulston is the best professor I have had at Mines. I generally feel like professors are naturally against me, but Coulston genuinely seems to care about his students and their success. He is usually accessible, but some times EENG 383 at mines is fairly hectic, so be gracious with him. Coulston is great!

Dr. Coulston is one of the best professors that I have had at Mines. He is very charismatic and makes learning EENG307 really enjoyable. His explains topics very clearly and I always felt comfortable asking several questions in office hours and would receive great help. Also, he brings his pug in to class for the last day of lecture.

Dr. Coulston is the best professor/teacher I've ever had, bar none. When I was having trouble figuring out how to bring a 300 pound game cabinet from Colorado Springs to Denver for my final project, he didn't hesitate to offer to let me borrow his truck. He is a truly dapper gentleman, and his lectures made 8am class actually enjoyable. 10/10.

Great teacher, SUPER smart. I think the only thing is his office hours were pretty limited and in the morning, especially since he had lots of students coming to him. He tries to know everyone and their names which makes it feel more personal.... although that means he randomly calls on people during class to answer questions
The course load is extreme

I scheduled into Dr. Coulston's Intro to Feedback Control Systems class on the recommendation of a friend and could not be more happy I did. Dr. Coulston is engaging in lectures, and is able to lay out the course material in an incredibly clear way. Thoughtfully laid out lesson plans make it easy to understand topics. Can not recommend him enough

Prof Carney was a great teacher to begin Mines with. Although Math111 was difficult for me personally, she taught lectures in a way that was friendly to people with no calculus experience and people with some. Focused a lot on in-class activities and application of material.
Deb cares about her students and makes calc easier to understand. I would definitely take another class from Deb.

Dr. Deb was the only professor during my first semester at Mines who took the time to get to know all the students' names. She was incredibly approachable and a wonderful teacher. If you are struggling in her class, I am sure that she would be extremely willing to help you out.

Dr. Deb is my favorite calc professor so far (and I've had 2!). I failed last semester and had to retake it and I couldn't believe how much easier it was to learn from Dr. Deb compared to my first prof. She is so good at teaching and is super kind to her students.

Dr. Deb was one of my favorite professors at Mines. I took linear algebra with her and I really like how she set up the class. We had quizzes and worksheets every other week. There were no tests in her class and she dropped one quiz at the end of the semester. You can definitely get an A if you keep up with the class 10/10
One of my best professors here. She made the class enjoyable and easy to understand.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Lecture heavy

comment: Dr. Carney. she is the best professor at this college by a long shot. this is my second time taking calc II and it was a whole new world. she not only made the material understandable but made it fun. she is caring and understands outside life. she is like a mother. if you put the effort in she will do all she ever could for you. The best.
Great teacher. Cares about students and clearly passionate. Class is fun. Tests are easy.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Carney was an AWESOME teacher for Calc II. She explains concepts clearly and thoroughly, and is willing to go back and explain further if you do not understand. Additionally, she makes class very fun. It is clear that she cares about her students, she is hilarious, and puts on fun music during activities to keep things more exciting. 10/10.
She's a great teacher, explains concepts effectively!

Dr. Carney is very caring of her students and wants every student to do well in the course. Her lectures had good examples, but sometimes her attention to detail made it a bit slow. She really takes time to explain examples thoroughly down to each step if necessary. The best part was how accessible she was outside of class.

Deb is an amazing teacher & so so caring. She cares about the success & well-being of her students & does a good job of keeping students engaged during class. She's helpful inside & outside of class. Skipping class loses participation points, but they're only a small portion of your grade. Class notes are real helpful though. Highly recommend Deb!

I took Calc II Honors with Deb and she was amazing. She was a strong lecturer and knew how to break up the examples with the straight lecturing so I never got bored during class. Combined homework of MyMathLab and worksheets worked very well. She also works to give as much partial credit on exams as possible. Just take notes and you'll be fine.
Great math teacher, not much to say. Tests were easier than expected.
Deb was awesome !! She is so patient, caring, knowledgable, and I can tell she really cares about her students' success. Her office hours were awesome... she was so helpful. i recommend for calc 2 !

Dr. Carney is the best teacher I have had here. She is wonderful one on one and is always willing to help you on whatever you are struggling with. I can't recommend her enough. Great teacher who really cares about your learning.

Professor Carney recognizes me outside of class, is receptive of confusion, and recognizes participation. I've never seen her in an unpleasant mood, and she's the sort of professor that makes me feel bad about falling asleep in class (not because she's mean about it, but because I feel bad about disrespecting her).

Best teacher I've ever had. Explained everything clearly in short period of time. Little need for outside of class studying. Always holds office hours and will work with you if you have any questions. Overall amazing

Carney has a friendly personality and explained the material in a way that was easy for me to understand. Class time usually consisted of lecture half of the time and working on activities the other half. She is easy to reach outside of class and takes the time to connect with her students.
Great teacher !
Best prof to take calc 1 or 2 in, she writes the tests for the whole department, so you can be assured that in taking her section, you will be sufficiently prepared.
If you are the type of student who likes to focus instead of writing notes. Deb is the perfect instructor for you. She posts her notes in blackboard. She is very helpful. Like her a lot.
Too helpful

Absolutely awful, she will use extremely easy examples in class then the online homework she assigns is virtually impossible. I who had already taken the class previously at another school struggled immensely this course and her teaching.
Carney has a very poor, dull teaching style. She'll write a problem on the board, do it and ask if there are any questions. It's not interactive or engaging learning at all.

As long as you pay attention and attempt to understand the homework as you go along, you'll be fine. One of the hardest, but definitely the most interesting class of my semester. Probably the most useful class at Mines, even if you don't decide to continue with engineering.
Great professor! Tests are pretty hard, but if you do the homework and attend lectures you're fine.
Awesome professor! Most useful class at Mines!

Great teacher. I have the class at 7:30 AM and don't mind getting up for it at all. His examples are right on topic with what he is teaching. The tests completely reflect the work of the class. Relates the topics to the real world without rambling on about useless stories.

Excellent and most useful class I've taken at Mines. Felt kinda scammed having to pay for a required textbook that he wrote but him and his father have made large donations to the CSM athletic department
Made the brilliant decision to take Eng Econ my Freshman year, to this day it was my favorite class. Take this class/get Stermole, he is awesome.
Best. Professor. Ever.
Best Professor at Mines

If you didn't take Stermolnomics, you wasted your years at CSM.  Much more valuable than any A in physics or chem will get you, unless you aspire to be a cubicle rat drawing grating plans for the next 50 years.
Tough vocabulary, but overall a good teacher
cool guy, knows his stuff
It's been 7 years since I had this class with Dr. Stermole, but I can honestly say this is the only textbook I have at my desk at work and I still open from time to time.
Stermole Knows his stuff and is a great teacher

This class was not necessarily easy, and the material was not always easy to understand. Stermole was an awesome professor however, and was willing to help in any way possible. If you were willing to put your time into the material and ask for help, he was willing to help you in any way possible. Definitely my favorite teacher so far.
Good teacher, very motivated about the class, makes it easy.
The only way not to get an A in Eng. Econ. is to not do the work.  You do the work and you get a good grade.
Great teacher, great guy
no comments. Stay away from him and his father
He is an expert in making an easy class more difficult. There are many better books than his books. But: He keeps using his book. Totally terrible.
Good teaching style, easy to get along with
He is a business man who gives up a semester every year to teach this course. very informative specially with his real world experience which is what the course is really about
Good Class.  Learned a lot, and Stermole was a good teacher considering the subject matter.

many students like him, but i'm not sure why.  i believe he is an egotistical, money-driven teacher who doesn't care much about the students.  seems he cares more about how his stocks are doing that what the students are learning.
Stemolenomics was one of the best classes I ever took at Mines.
No Comments

He is not very good at explaining problems that you bring to him, he more or less just runs you around the answer and makes it very confusing on how he got the answer. Also, the homework is 10 times more difficult than the in-class problems, I spent 4 plus hours on each assignment the whole semester. He sucks.

Koubek would engage you the class and make classes fun and interesting! Like one time he let the class play a game against him and if we won we got extra credit. He bought white boards and markers for the 300 people in our class (not to keep) so that we could learn to draw Lewis structures. I enjoy his lectures!

He gets a bad wrap from people who want to show up to chemistry, put 0 effort in then complain when they get a 50 on the test. Chemistry is not for everyone and I am lucky to not have to study much but seriously if you put in some effort you will get a good result. The tests are a reflection of what we do in class, maybe even easier for some Qs.

Koubek has 0 understanding for students as people.
Make-up labs are god awful. I spent 2+ hours on one and got maybe 1/4 of the way through. A make-up lab should not be 3x longer than the actual lab.
I had to fight to get certain accommodations, and I realize now I should've fought for more than what I got.
Purdue students be warned.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment:
He is the type of teacher that enjoys making people's lives miserable. Recently, he messed up a due date and then changed the due date to an earlier date without notifying anyone students. So a ton of students got 
0s and emailed him and he basically responded with too bad. When it was entirely his fault. Needs to be fired asap.
absolutely horrid

Dr. Koubek is a terrible person and lab director (I don't know which of the two he is worse at).  Taking his chemistry lab is like a free 10% tank to your overall chemistry grade.  The best part of the semester is failing the qualitative lab (which can just be because of the departments terrible equipment).  Good luck, you're going to need it.
He blows
Takes points away without giving explanation. Really unfair with students, makes everyone hate lab.
I just feel bad for Purdue.

idk what people complaining about. His lectures are helpful. I asked about 4 questions every lecture and he happily answered them. He is very helpful during his office hours. I can see how he is a bit cut-and-dry, but this is a level 1 course, it should not be hard. Just took the second midterm. It was a lot of info, but not conceptually difficult.

this class is similar to an AP class. It's not easy, but it's not conceptually difficult like physics 1 and 2 at Mines. Labs are pretty chill. Only failed the infamous dye lab. Koubek's lectures are helpful. He answers all questions. He is rigid but willing to help you. Didn't have him for lab, only lecture. midterms are info-packed, so just study.
Idk what everyone is complaint about, I literally did nothing for this class and it was so easy, at the end I had an F but as we know F=MA and if we make M=1 I actually got an A.

Koubek is the reason I am depressed. He is very closed minded, assigns long and confusing pre and post labs,  and has no mercy. The labs he creates have very little if any connection to lecture and don't facilitate a conducive learning environment. He doesn't understand that students' lives don't revolve around his precious chem lab. #nomorekoubek.
He is the type of professor to get offended when he is corrected. Lecture is not enjoyable and he has a very punchable face

Take chem over the summer, go back to high school and pass the AP Chemistry exam. Do whatever it takes to avoid Joshua Koubek. A girl slipped on ice, was in an electric wheelchair for 2 months and couldn't make it down the hill to lab. Koubek stopped letting her do makeup assignments and she had to take 0's on labs for weeks. This is just the start

One of his "tags" is hilarious. He is hilariously dumb in the way he runs lab. We are all lucky koubek is a special breed because if not our world IQ points would drop dramatically. I used to look forward to the sunrise and fun things in life until I met Koubek. I hope he flips his pillow over at night and the other side is warm. Koubek bad

An absolute demon of a professor. Thank god he's leaving Mines after this semester; Purdue is in for a shitshow. He probably became a professor to make his students suffer. He definitely jerks off to the thought of his students failing chemistry and possibly dropping out of college altogether.

Pt 2 (continuation of my first review)
...His emails are passive aggressive. They make you feel like you've done something wrong before you've even started. Sorry Koubek. Sorry the administration hasn't put you out of your misery sooner. Oh, and sorry I couldn't be more precise with my rating, I couldn't give you the zero you wanted so badly.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: It’s very easy to demonize professor Koubeck, I’ll admit that I did so myself at first. However, after going to his office hours, I found that my judgements were false. In fact Professor Koubeck worked with me over the course of a half hour, and gave me 10 points back on one of my labs.

Hes a horrible lab professor. He has no idea what he is doing and is a total jerk with grading as well as assigning 20 hour substitute labs. He also threatens to report one to the Dean for academic misconduct if they do not do a lab.
Pre labs as well as labs are extremely vague but are graded on specific things you don't even know you should be graded on. And you best not be late for ANYTHING. Car broken down? 0!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: The content in the class itself is difficult but not impossible to learn, it requires a large amount of self teaching. About 40% of your grade is from labs designed by this professor and all of them have super strict guidelines and super tough grading and horrible makeup assignments. This professor will make sure you hate yourself and possibly fail
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Tough grader

comment: He is an awful lab director. Most labs have unclear pre-lab assignments, as well as one lab that has an average of 40% because it is intended for students to fail. In the case of inclement weather or absence the make-up labs are incredibly time consuming and are not equivalent to the work done in a 3 hour lab block.
Professor Koubek is very condescending and treats his students in a rude manner. He is very strict and annoying.

MEB with him was great, but Field Session was a different person. Maybe he was forced to be there, but I don't care. He would not talk to you outside of your GRADED prelab presentation and I had to ask students who did it before me for all the niche stuff he wanted. I couldn't use notes and needed to memorize a 30min pres. No help during the lab.

Professor Marr clearly knows his stuff, he is a good teacher when you seek out his help personally in office hours. In lecture, he is by far the funniest teacher I have had at Mines. Sometimes his explanations can be a little fuzzy in class, but he can easily clarify concerns if you simply ask. Building connections with your faculty is important!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Hilarious--Graded by few things

comment: Pretty good professor, funny guy for the most part. Cared about his students and knew all of their names within the first week. Might not be the best option in terms of learning but he for sure gets the job done.

Great person and made the class pretty engaging. Sometimes his explanations and way for explaining certain rationales in the problem solving was confusing and couldn't really the point across. Still a pretty good teacher though.

Professor Marr is definitely one of the best professors in the cheme department. If you attend lecture and go to his office hours you will no doubt succeed in the class. He is caring and very willing to help if you ask. I really enjoy his teaching style which is similar to Morrish.

Makes himself accessable for office hours when you need him to. Has some strict classroom rules, but those rules really helped me succeed in his classes. Really helpful when you're stuck on a problem. One time I was so lost on a simple concept and he approached the problem from multiple angles until I could understand, and never made me feel bad.
Dr. Marr is not caring for his students. It seems as though he wants you to fail. If you ever need help/assistance or for him to give you the benefit of the doubt he certainly will not provide it.

This was an elective course so it was definitely easier than his 357 thermo class. However, Dr. Marr truly wants everyone to succeed. In this class he made it clear that as long as you showed up to class and paid attention then there would be no problem getting a good grade. His quizzes are very fair and homework is based directly off lecture.
Professor Marr does not care much about his students and does not encourage success. It almost seems as if he doesnt want you to succeed.

Dr. Marr is one of the best professors I've ever had. He's engaging and actually teaches content during lectures - so much so that I've never had to use the textbook to understand the class. His quizzes test concepts directly covered on homework problems, and usually aren't meant to catch you off guard. Marr's the best - take his section!

Marr is one of the best professors at Mines. He is my favorite professor that I have taken, and one of the best in the Chemical Engineering department. He is very good at lecturing and only expects you to put minimal time into the course outside the class. This is because he actually teaches the content in lectures.

He was my advisor and I met with him one time in four years. On the first exam, the class average came back as a 55 or 65% and he blamed us for not studying enough (he did not reflect for one second on his terrible teaching). He was there for the research and seemed "forced" to work with undergrads.

He's cool and makes class interesting, but one thing he definitely can fix is the way he grades. He follows a rubric spot on, but that gets into situations where people mess up on parts of problems and gets marked down way too many points for little mistakes. Overall I liked him, but I can see why people would say he's condescending.
Marr is the MAN.
Probably the best teacher I've ever had I love him. LOVE HIM.
Marr really cares about his students and his lectures are easy to follow.

Dr. Marr comes off as very strict and uncaring in the beginning of MEB, but gets more tolerant as the semester goes on. He's a very good lecturer and explains things clearly, however, the class is somewhat difficult. I'd say it's about the same level of difficulty as Phys I or II at Mines. You learn a lot, but have to work for it.

Very fair class set up, homework sets you up for the quizzes and the quizzes set you up for the tests. Overall, he's a great professor who wants to see you succeed, which is great for such a hard subject like thermo. 10/10, would recommend.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Dr. Marr is tough and if you don't do the homework or pay attention in class, you won't pass. He is fair when it comes to tests, I have gotten points back through petitioning via writing. GO TO HIS OFFICE HOURS, you won't regret it.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Worthless...Does not care about undergrads
Amazing teacher for a ridiculously hard subject
Professor Marr only likes students that are as loud and obnoxious as he is.

One of the best profs I have here at Mines.  Just because the subject matter is difficult does not indicate a poor teaching ability.  He was availible for scheduled office hours everytime and did an excellent job of out of class instruction.
He was very difficult, but he really tested your problem solving ability.  Also, he kept you interested.  He was sort of an SOB, but that doesn't mean he wasn't an awesome teacher.
Good teacher.  Hard teacher, but you learned the subject very well.

Hellman is one of the good ones. He cares a LOT about his students, both as academics and as people. The subjects he teaches are hard, but he makes them fun and understandable. Few professors put in so much effort in *and* outside of class to help their students not only learn, but understand the material and grow. Lovely, lovely person :)

The new grading system takes time to adjust to. Content is great and taught well. Assignments are what you expect of a analysis based Comp Sci class. Exams are graded very closely, especially with the grading system but you do get multiple tries.

Keith's got good vibes and high energy that really helped keep motivation up throughout the semester. Was very timely with emails and general correspondence, and was super willing to help out both in class and in office hours. Not the harshest grader in the world either (at least for 220) and even provided exam review videos to help students study.

Engaging in lecture, told a lot of jokes and was enthusiastic. Did not like his office hours at all, he tended to be quite condescending. This class is taught in tandem with another professor, who I felt was much more patient/understanding when it came to questions. They made a good team
The CS professor of all time

Mr. Hellman is a little bit weird at first but he is really nice. If you are confused or stuck on the project if you come to his office hours he is super helpful and nice. Comp Sim. has a decent amount of group work/ learning groups but he weights it so that you won't be dragged down if you have a bad group. He is also pretty funny.
Keith is a G. Passionate and knowledgeable. Wish I could have him for anything, wish I didn't have him at 8am

Keith is one of my favorite professors of all time. A genuinely likable guy. Makes an honest effort to get to know his class, and puts real effort into his material. All his stuff is homemade instead of being copied from a textbook. If you need an extension, just ask him. I've never heard of him denying one.

A professor as honest as him was a dream. He will give you points if you misunderstood the question and knew the concept. He will give you an extension if you have 5 labs due on the same day and need some extra time to catch up. He goes out of his way to provide help with content. Too lecture heavy, but there's a lot of content to go over.
He's a funny guy, but don't take this class for your own sanity. The learning groups aren't very helpful and the content isn't that useful nowadays
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Keith is the best prof I've had so far at mines :)
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational--Group projects

comment: Keith is one of my favorite professors at mines. He acts like a mix between Alton Brown and Adam Savage, but with computers. He is always ready to help if you ask for it. He is very high energy, which turns some people off, but if you can handle that, you're in for a great class
Hellman is an awesome teacher and will help you learn your intro to comp sci very well. I highly recommend.
rating_tags: Respected--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Keith Hellman was a fantastic professor. My major was not computer science, but the class was fun and it was easy to be involved/engaged in lectures.
I didn't particularly enjoy the comp sci class but Keith is hilarious and one of the most invested professors I have had at mines. He is always willing to help and is truly invested in his students
This was by far my favorite class of the semester and Hellman is always a blast.
Awesome professor! Really enjoyed his class, looked forward to it every day.  Exams and quizzes are easy. Did not study and got A's.

He often goes off on tangents and doesn't teach very well. Tests and quizzes were on stuff that was poorly taught. His class will likely bring down your GPA no matter what you do or how hard you try. Nice man though.
Hes awesome. Easy but informative class.

Took his intro to comp sci class the first semester that is was available. The format of the class worked well (and introduces you to your fellow majors). The selection of topics was varied and interesting and I felt was a good intro to and survey of the field. I also felt that Python was a wonderful language for a 101-type class.
Homework is based on knowledge not taught in class.....
Awesome professor.  Explains material well and is entertaining.
Very easy tests and notes. This is coming from someone who has never programmed before.
Easy tests, and makes compsci entertaining and easy. This is coming from someone who hates computers.
Dr Morrish is genuinely excited to teach you thermodynamics, and she has tons of office hours. Go to them whenever you are stuck on a homework problem and this class will be a breeze
Great professor, but a little boring in the lectures. She loves the content and explains it great. She is super clear in everything, so it's easy to follow because the content can get a little funky.
Kind of boring, but otherwise a great professor. She definitely deserves some of the hype she gets.

I had Morrish for baby thermo and separations. Morrish is good at lecturing and explaining material if you think exactly the same way she thinks. If you cannot think exactly how she wants you to think, she sees you as an inferior being and will not try to help you improve. Her classes are structured well though.

I've had Morrish for MEB, ChemEThermo, and Separations and I love her so much. She explains everything so well and makes her classes low stress with the quiz structure and no exams. Best professor I have had and would highly recommend her to anyone. Would take her class any chance I'm given

I've had Morrish for Chem E Thermo and now separations and she is by FAR the best professor at Mines. The class is very well taught and has the same quiz structure as her other classes. Definitely recommend taking any course you can with her! I think most people that don't like her don't pay attention or put effort into the class.

Overall I enjoyed her class, but I feel like she makes a lot of assumptions based on what material she thinks you have learned. She is great at going through examples but has difficulty explaining things to people that are below her intellectual level. Her directions for the group project could use more explanation, as they are vague. TAKE NOTES
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Lecture heavy

comment: She is great at teaching the material in class, but isn't the best in office hours. Overall I got the impression that she sees you as a grade and if that grade isn't good enough has no interest in you, or helping you move forward.

I've had Dr. Morrish for 357 thermo and now for separations, she is hands down the best professor in the department. Not only does she teach exactly what you need to know, but the quizzes are very fair and the homework is managable.
She is ok at teaching. Not the best.

Ive had Morrish for MEB and ChemE Thermo and I love her so much. The way she teaches things just makes sense. She is easy to follow and points out what we need to know for quizzes. Best professor at Mines

Morrish is the best professor I have had at Mines. She went to Mines herself so she understands what we are going through. She made MEB so easy for me. The way she explained stuff just clicked. I barely had to put any effort into the class other than homework and the quizzes. Will take her any chance I get

I took Dr. Morrish for baby Thermo, big boy Thermo and mass transfer (before heat and mass were combined). She was awesome and I highly recommend taking her classes when they are offered. Just make sure to do good on the quizzes and be able to memorize equations for big boy thermo because we were not allowed a note card like baby thermo and mass

Professor Morrish is one of the best professors that I have had here. She does a great job at explaining things and is always really helpful. The material is tough, but if you show up to class and get help you can do quite well. I really enjoyed this class.

Professor Morrish is one of the first professors I've had that truly loves what she teaches. Her enthusiasm is very motivating and makes her even more approachable. She's a former Mines student so she knows what you're going through and the quizzes directly reflect the homework for the week. She really prepares you for what you'll be tested on.

She knows the material so well, and can answer student's questions extremely well. She teaches very straightforward, and the notes are very easy to follow. The homework load is quite large for this class though.

Dr. Morrish is amazing and should teach all courses in the Chemical Engineering Department. She explains things clearly, patiently, and at a good pace. It's complicated material, but when you are listening to her patient, calm, engaging style of teaching, it all becomes less daunting and actually seems achievable.
This was a hard class but morrish is very thorough and organized which really helps.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Morrish's lectures really helped me understand thermo. She clearly cares a lot about her students and was always helpful and friendly.
Great prof. Material can be tough, but she gives a lot of practice problems which are very helpful. Lots of lecture, but it's beneficial. Textbook is optional, they post notes online.
Class starts off slow, but picks up very fast. She does a great job of explaining everything clearly, and is always wiling to help students.
She does a very good job at explaining things.

Rachel has the most organized class structure I have seen at CSM. I took her classes in fall 2012-spring 2013, and I was in CBEN357 in Fall 2013 when she taught with Ely and Summer 2014 for Field Session. She does expect a lot of work out of you, but without the work you won't understand the class. She is extremely helpful during office hours tho.

Great professor! Loves to teach and knows her stuff. Occasionally miss-writes on the board; but very good at answering questions. She understands Thermo more than I will probably ever understand it. Fantastic at explaining things during office hours. Normally teaches DCGN-357 so 210 was very easy (perhaps too easy) for her. Will take more from her!
No grades or feedback at all. Easy A but terrible structure.

For starters, what everyone says about him taking a century to grade is right. That being said, he is still one of my fav profs. I thought his lectures were awesome and I learned so much. We did a lot of discussions and he seemed genuinely interested in what everyone had to say. I participated a lot which I think he cares more about grading wise.

No grades were posted until about 8 weeks after the assignments were due. Virtually no feedback and it was graded by a TA. I did not learn any writing skills and the first assignment was graded extremely harshly. I could never get ahold of Professor Horan, even when I missed class due to sickness. I would avoid if possible.
Very good NHV teacher, even though he didn't grade anything throughout the semester, he still was a good professor. I am not good at writing and I still managed to get an A.

Dr. Horan is the most unprofessional teacher I have ever had. I had nothing graded by the final. He never responds to email. He is never available outside of class. I had to write a research paper with the same exact prompt as the first one, without getting my grade back on the first one. He does not tell you anything about how he will grade you.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Lecture heavy

comment: Horan tried making things interesting, but his class ends up really boring with pointless discussions.

Barely got feedback on any papers, midterm was not graded by the end of the semester, half of the papers not graded at end of semester. Attendance is mandatory and class is very lecture heavy. Barely any communication from him during the semester, he also doesn't answer emails.
If you want the easiest A you'll ever earn in your life, then this is it

I think it's unfair to rate humanities profs at an engineering school because I'm not going to be interested nor put in the effort to those classes. I was in the environment section and it was just NHV all over again. I didn't like how little direction we were given for the research papers. The grading took forever. However, Horan was a cool guy.

Horan is an amazing lecturer. I always found them interesting. The place he falls short is more of the learning aspect. Hes not good at returning grades. Both research papers were pushed back by weeks and there was a few assignments he just gave us credit for. Only one of our midterms was graded before we had to take the final. Easy grader though

Great class but Horan's speed of grading/communication skills are among the worst I've seen at Mines. I know COVID posed challenges with course structure, but on multiple occasions, instead of emailing "hey students no remote class today, I'm working on uploading content" he just ghosted us. Disappointing given how much I enjoyed the class itself.

Horan is a good lecturer and it was nice that the 75 minute class was broken up by many small discussions. However, he is really bad at putting grades in, it took us 6 weeks to get scores on the first paper, and the midterm grades were put in the day before the final. He gave us all As on the final, probably because he didnt have time to grade them

Horan is a very intelligent man and he lectures in such a way he never gives his opinion so that students can form their own. Lots of class discussion. He also grades pretty hard, although maybe I'm just a bad writer. And I didn't know my final grade until the day before grades were due.

Horan is fair and equal with his students, and for a humanities class he does a great job of not so much stating his opinion as letting students draw their own opinion. Lectures were clear and the class discussions help with understanding the material. Grades could have been returned sooner.

If you have to take Horan's class you will survive but I would try to avoid him. He is extremely pretentious and condescending and has tons of lectures with terms he either made up himself or got from some obscure author, but he is clear about his expectations and treats (dare I say hates) all students equal.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: The majority of the class is based on his lectures and the readings in the textbook. Reading the book and attending the lecture is required for exam material. I like his style of lecturing where he uses accompanying images with what he is presenting with sparse words. He also breaks up lecture fairly often with group discussion.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: I took Human systems over the summer and it was a very easy class. Lots of reading but he structured the class well and the tests and papers were not hard. From what I have heard his summer Human systems is easier than any of the professors classes during the fall and spring semesters.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria

comment: Literally the worst, the class structure isn't set up to truly teach you, you don't get to delve into anything. He doesn't even grade the papers that make up 40% of your grade!
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Very helpful at office hours, and very straightforward on what he expects for tests and papers.  Lectures were boring but effective.  He is very knowledgeable about history and makes a lot of interesting connections, but he can be flat and sometimes lacking in energy.

This is my second time in Human Systems and I honestly really enjoyed it this go around.  I like the way Horan teaches and the things he emphasizes.  While I did not initially like the way he did his slides, I think it facilitated my learning by making me pay attention.
Good professor.  Keeps personal opinions out of lecture, presents the facts.  Everything is explained well.  Overall a great course with a good set-up.

He is full of himself and thinks that history is more important than it is. He is an incredibly boring lecturer and has a terrible method to running class by lecturing the whole time. Don't take his class if you get bored easily.

The lectures can get tedious at times, but he really emphasizes the main points to make note taking easier.  Essay prompts are so broad that you can write on pretty much any subject.  Not exactly the friendliest professor I've had, but he is fair and willing to listen if you want to argue for a better grade.

Unless you love history, sometimes his human systems class can be hard to focus in. He's a pretty fair grader though, and as long as you go to class and write everything down you'll do fine. He started getting strict about attendance halfway through the year though.
Bad, didn't explain things well, expected you to know things because it was "super" obvious basically. Rude to students. Was not a fan.

As already noted, he is difficult to approach and condescending but he does know his material.  He just expects you to know it as well.  If you are "needy" then pick a different instructor.  If you are not and are comfortable learning on your own, he is great and provides the steps to complete basic problems. I do not recommend class participation.
Had him for Summer Statics, he was awesome! Funny, very knowledgeable, and clear. Has a slight accent but easy to get used to. Recommended!

He does a good job of going over the material, he definitely understands the material and does a mediocre job of teaching it. However he's very egotistical and condescending. His accent can also be hard to understand sometimes so if you are the type of person who zones out when your teacher doesn't speak well, try to get a different teacher.
If you pay attention in class, one finds that he gives you all the tools you need to solve the homework problems. A bit condescending however. Dont talk in class!

His mannerisms are pretty funny when you get used to him. He explains things pretty clear in class as long as you keep up on what you're expected to know. He doesn't waste time on calculations in his examples and covers a ton of material efficiently.
Terrible at explaining solutions in class
Explains things well, especially helpful during office hours. Gives practice exams whose methods resemble the exam.
Great professor. Made class fun and even knew my name. Go to class, he gives quizzes and missing them can really hurt your grade!

So entertaining! Yelled at the stupid kids when they got questions wrong. Complained about students' incorrect methods. His actions and mannerisms were just so over the top! Very old school teaching style although class is very modernized. Very smart guy and has clever methods. If the homework and practice test are completed, tests will be cakewalk
This teacher is terrible. Not even a nice man.
Pretty good teacher. Accent isn't too bad compared to the other statics teachers. His examples are fairly helpful is generally a good lecturer.
He really knows the material and uses lots of examples. Make sure to sit close to the front so you can understand him through the accent, though.
Good lecturer but hard to talk to after class.
Dean is the best statics prof-- get him.
He came off as arrogant and unwilling to help right off the bat. He is very hard to understand most of the time. He knows the material but he doesn't explain it very well.
P Can be any Point!
He explains the material very well. I think he's doing a pretty good job in this class. I like his way of teaching.
He knows the material well but is easily misunderstood and arrogant. Overall a run of the mill prof
Definitely a "luke warm" professor. He knows the materials well but can be misunderstood frequently. As long as you attend class frequently and complete the homework A's and B's are attainable...
He is cocky and patronizes students in class, but if you can handle that and focus on what he teaches, he does a good job.  He is not very approachable either, but knows what he is teaching.
Crazy old man. Laughs at people in class...
No Comments
Good teacher, gives lots of examples and knows how to present difficult material well

Professor Wenham had straightforward lectures, and was very responsive and caring. She takes time to answer questions and pauses frequently. All lecture material is posted online and easily accessible. We had two main exams and a cumulative final.
I liked her teaching style a lot, however I wish that there were more studying resources given.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Wenham is a great professor in terms of making complicated subjects easier to learn. She does her best to explain and answer questions well, and posts all of her day's notes on canvas for easy review or missed class makeup. She doesn't make lectures particularly interesting, but she does make them helpful and practical.
Doesn't grade attendance, explains things well, really nice
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Online Savvy

comment: I have Wenham for Differential Equations, she provides a template for each lecture which helped me understand exactly the topics she was talking about. She is very concise and takes her time in the lectures which in the end helped me. If you have to miss class, she posts the filled-out notes every lecture which is very nice as well.

I took her as a first year and liked the class, overall it was a difficult class for me but she was quite helpful. I enjoyed how many times she asked if anyone had questions and how open to anything she was. She was pretty easy to meet outside of class and was always very sweet and understanding.

It felt as if I was able to do decent in the class without the lectures. All the completed lecture notes were posted on Canvas beforehand and she just copied it onto the board which enticed me to skip class just to look through the completed lecture notes as she did not cover anything in lecture that was worthy of showing up.

Good professor, she taught the calc well enough. She does seem oddly confused during lectures, and once or twice she got something wrong (though quickly corrected herself). Class is rather boring though, so not the professor for me

Dr. Wenham is a great professor that knows what she is talking about. You don't need to read textbooks-just copy what is written on her board along class and you are good. written homework can be tough, but frankly you can ace this class with having 70% in those. But exams are super heavy so make sure you solve multiple past exams.
Supper good lectures, gives you what you need to know for quizzes. My class was 6 quizzes and a final. Supper good teacher.
Kind of boring lectures, but she definitely covered the material well. Not much time is wasted in class and she covers lots of example problems.

The class is well designed, with a good structure for students to understand what is going on. But the grade is quite test-heavy(midterm+final is 70% of your total grade) so paying attention in class and looking through past exams are almost necessary for an A. With that being said, that is probably all you need to do for an A.
Great at explaining things. the class overall is structured very well and she made it very easy to understand topics.

Attendance is not mandatory and she keeps every section all on the same page so that you can go to any of her lectures throughout the day. She is fair, helpful, kind, and clear. Not a perfect professor but a very good one! Clear and consistent. I have absolutely no complaints.

I had her for calc 2 in fall 2021. I thought the class was very well designed with a reasonable workload. Her notes were super organized which I found helpful. Sometimes she didnt answer questions in a very insightful way but thats a small complaint compared to the perks of the class.

Professor Wenham is an overall solid choice to take Calc 2 with. She is helpful and you can tell that she wants you to succeed in the course. I can't say much about her office hours because I never went to them. She does excellent exam prep and consistently notifies you about upcoming quizzes/tests/assignments. Would take again.
I really enjoyed her Calc 3 class, and am so surprised she doesn't have better reviews! She is a great teacher, and makes very few mistakes. The in class activities prepared me well for exams.

Calc I with Wenham had a very consistent format, since several students were online and with how last semester with the pandemic went, we had a quiz every few weeks, homework every week, and only a final exam. The homework is always more difficult than the quizzes and she will even help heavily in office hours. I always felt prepared for exams.

I had Holly for calc III and I thought that it was very easy to get through the class. Most of class time was devoted to working in groups on activities and she was always very willing to help with any questions. She is very nice and seems to genuinely care about the success of students.

Had Holly for Calc I & III. She always made lectures easy for students to understand and provided plenty of examples. Notes were always posted online. Her review days were incredibly helpful as all important material was emphasized and example questions were very similar to ones on the quizzes/tests.

Genuinely cares about students. Attendance is absolutely not necessary (always post lecture notes and all assignments can be turned in online. However, attendance builds credibility with her to point of being incredibly lenient and understanding.
Makes frequent mistakes, seems out of it all the time, horrible at explaining

Good and clear explaining. Simplifies everything that is complicated and makes thing more clear to students. Does not make a lot mistakes. She tries to extend her office hours when students need her. She is very nice though even when student are not very capable. She makes very good notes that other professors use her notes when they teach.

Holly really cares about the success of her students, and is very accessible during office hours. Sometimes her lectures can be confusing, but the activities provided in class help to provide a great understanding of what is expected from you on the test. As long as you attend lecture and do the online/written homework, you will definitely pass.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Reads definition from book with very poor explination. Makes easy concepts hard to understand.

Not good at explaining anything. Makes everything seem so much harder than it actually is. Also, she makes frequent mistakes and her office hours are when most people have class. I guess she is nice though except when people fail "easy" tests that she cannot lecture well on.

Susan allows you to choose your own grading track (tests or projects) but there's not a lot of flexibility. I also found her pretty condescending and way less neuroinclusive than she thinks she is. She did a decent job teaching, but I personally didn't work very well with her style and she was really not willing to accommodate that.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Graded by few things

comment: Reynolds is a great lecturer and clearly cares about student wellbeing. Grades were 75% homework (which can be revised) and 25% final project. No flexibility for late homework feels a bit harsh. No textbook (all notes and homework is created by her, cool) and no exams. I felt quizzes would've helped me retain the content better than just homework.

She talks to you like you're a kindergartener. Will retaliate if you don't agree with how she teaches. Petty against students and other professors. Homework is useless but graded harshly. Grading system is awful and she pretends to care while being the rudest person you've ever met. Called my disability cute.

Susan teaches very differently from most Mines professor, which I really enjoyed. Lectures are very engaging and involved a lot of demonstrations to help solidify concepts. The homework is challenging but there are plenty of office hours and resources to help you out. Plus, no exams!

Professor Reynolds is a good professor who has worked very hard on the material for her class. If you show up to class and pay attention, you will most likely pass with an A. She is very knowledgeable and has great demonstrations for the material which makes it easy to learn. I would definitely take her class again.

The homework for this class can be a lot, but there are tutorials online that she (sometimes) posts. Reynolds is very available for office hours and is willing to communicate via email. However, do not expect much/any sympathy in terms of missing a HW due to an emergency, nor on any grading for HW/tests. "Fake nice" is how I would describe her.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: I respect how Reynolds created content herself. She is a good teacher but has trouble finishing the lectures on time. Also, she doesn't really facilitate a good learning environment because I felt judged when I went into office hours. Also, she discourages questions because it will disrupt her focus but isn't that was class is for?

This professor was absolutely amazing, I'm floored and annoyed reading the other ratings. One of if not the best professors I have ever had. Passionate, organized, clear, funny, smart, just excellent. She has high expectations but backs that up with an incredibly well designed course/course materials. Work 5% as hard as the prof and youll get an A
Treats her class like a high school class. Doesnt let you use the bathroom during class. Annoying, and is not a nice person. Structure of the class is good though.

Obviously works very hard to create unique course content for her students. However, does not create a very positive learning environment as she is very condescending and infallible person. This does not motivate students to have any interest in office hours. Pushing students to succeed is positive if you yourself set a good example as an engineer.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: She is an extremely condescending person and professor. She talks to student like we are 12 during lecture and way over complicates everything, but she expects perfection and for you to know everything. She thinks that her teaching method is the best when really it doesn't work well at all.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: One of my favorites. A lot of information to learn but easily digestible if you just do the readings and pay attention in class. Make sure to do the readings because the class is very interactive and you won't learn anything if you don't.

She is clearly a failed engineer. She takes that failure and uses it to be rude to students. The standards she has are nuts and she late with feedback as well. She expects you to be an engineer when you are still a student. She is also way too harsh at grading with standards that are unreasonable. Avoid this class she is condescending.

Has 0 respect for students break, gave a 20% of the final grade midterm the day after Fall break. Also, returned part 2 of a 3 part project 2 weeks after It was turned in on the Wednesday before Thanksgiving and said that I should implement her feedback and have a meeting with her Friday, Meaning she expected me to work on Thanksgiving.

Professor Reynolds is a good professor who is very qualified and intelligent. A lot of her takeaways come from the students putting effort into the class to get something out of it. Unfortunately, sometimes these ideas are muddled because the class is taught by 6 professors. This can lead to excessive work and miscommunication on the students end.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Susan believes she is much funnier than she is, and when the class doesn't laugh she gets upset.  She also over emphasizes the skill and importance of her teaching.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: One of the best profs I've had at Mines. It's clear that she enjoys teaching. Her class notes are very good and I often grab my binder from her class for reference instead of the textbook. Definitely the best I had in the civil department.
Great professor, due to material, usually short on time. Do your homework and you'll pass. Exams are challenging, but not the most difficult. Favorite class. Favorite prof. Attendance quizzes,
She is amazing. She puts in so much time for the students and helps when asked. She has made this course easier and better than it has been in past semesters. I would recommend her 100%.

Very condescending.  She may be better for a non-design-based class, but for SrDes (as a consultant, not an advisor) she had unrealistically high expectations, and ridiculed us when we didn't meet them.  Accused us several times of avoiding doing work, and that we "confirmed her suspicions" of certain (bad) practices.  Nightmare to report to.
Great teacher, clear, very understanding. She cares if you get the material. Always trying new things to try to help you understand. Probably my best teacher at Mines so far.
She is the rudest person I have ever met. Not helpful, extremely condescending,and just an awful lady even during office hours.

Reynolds is great if you come to class and pay attention. She really knows the material for mechanics of materials and is helpful if you have questions. She's not particularly easy, but the tests are standard across all sections and her class tends to get the best grades!

The class was good this professor was not. I could not believe the rudeness that she approached not only me but several other students with when asking her simple questions related to the class and projects. She was very condescending and spoke down to me like I was inferior. Not only do I not recommend her, I recommend not taking her.
He definitely cares and wants to teach, but he just isn't cut out to be a teacher. It is hard to sit through his lectures day after day because they are so unbelievably dry.
Uhhhhh, dry lectures. Expect a bunch of wordy slides thrown at you. The sad part is he has the potential to be an amazing professor but his priority is clearly sided towards his research.

Dr. Sellinger is a very knowledgeable professor and it is clear he knows and loves the subject of chemistry extremely well. Unfortunately his lectures are rather dry and slow, and straight from the textbook. A lot of reading outside of class- many students don't bother showing up to lecture and study on their own time.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Sellinger might be the most down to earth coolest guy on the planet. I absolutely love this guy. He loves his teaching job and has inspired me to want to teach Ochem 1 when I graduate. You know what? I might just graduate right now and teach it! I LOVE OCHEM AND SELLINGER!!!!

If you can help it, don't take his class. He doesn't actually teach, he reads off of slides with screenshots taken from the textbook. In office hours he just read the textbook to me and didn't answer any of my questions without mentioning or pointing to the textbook that he literally read to us in class. He does good research but is a bad teacher.

Sellinger is a good researcher but not good at teaching. His lectures were basically just copied and pasted from the textbook which don't really help you learn. To do well, you have to learn from outside resources. Grades basically come down to how well you do on the exams and the curve he makes up at the end of the semester.
His lectures are absolutely terrible. Just talk at you... no practice problems or questions allowed
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Alan Sellinger is a very inspirational lecturer. He is very passionate about organic chemistry and seems to like teaching. If you make an effort to learn the concepts and show him that you care you will get out what you put in. The tests are hard, and you need to put in lots of time to study for them, but if you do the practice, you will pass.

Sellinger is a really caring professor, but I didn't learn anything from his class. Lectures are dry (mostly just reading off the slide) and tests go way more in depth than the lecture slides would suggest. Read the textbook - his slides are just less detailed versions of it. Go to a recitation taught by a TA. Overall - nice guy, rough class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: For o chem 1, I would try not taking him, if you have the book just read and take notes from that his slides were just less useful version of the book chapters. He is at the very least an understanding person and will push back deadlines but he hardly responds to emails

If you think you are good at teaching yourself lecture material, then this should be an ok class for you. Professors lectures are very monotone and disengaging because he only reads a PowerPoint that is basically just a summary of the book. Had to teach myself the actual material and concepts/structures.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Ochem 1 is hard in general, but Dr. Sellinger makes it unnecessarily hard for you to pass the class. When I was struggling, and really needed help, he wasnt helpful at all and didnt seem to care. Ive never had a professor who didnt care about my success as much as him. Will be retaking the class with a different professor.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: Dr. Sellinger really dropped the ball on this one. He failed to capture any attention, and frequently messed up while using Canvas, requiring rescheduling of tests which vastly overloaded my schedule. This wouldnt have been a problem if he used the required materials correctly. Since he didnt teach well, I had to teach myself Organic Chemistry.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Sellinger is such a bad lecturer. Hes monotone and basically just reads from the textbook. I ended up never going to class, which was probably not good, but I felt like it wouldnt have helped me since I had to read the textbook either way. He also really struggled with online. He doesnt know how to use tech and it showed. He is a nice guy though
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: I get that teaching right now is tough. But jeez, Sellinger almost made students' lives harder. Having no idea how to change the course to be used on canvas and not curving exams as much as he said he would makes it hard to like his class. He is a great person, but a very monotone lecturer. I learned nothing from him this semester. He tanked my GPA
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: Didn't even sound interested in his own lectures. Had to teach myself through the textbook. Used Zoom Seminar so no interaction with other students. Made recitations asynchronous, so we couldn't ask questions. Refuses to learn how to use Canvas. Only professor that teaches OrgChem 1 at Mines, take it somewhere else.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: Sellinger is an amazing person, no doubt. He is so sweet and makes deadlines flexible. That being said, even though he is an amazing person, I do not like him as a professor. He is a research professor, not a teaching one, and it shows. His slides are the same as the textbook, I have to put him at 2.0 speed to keep my attention.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: Professor Sellinger is a great guy, but he is not a great teacher. The issue is that he takes his lectures straight from the textbook which means that learning the material is difficult and not much additional explanation is given. It would be better to have examples of the different problems you can encounter, but we don't get any of those.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: I didn't get to take the lab with this course which I don't think helped, but his lectures just drone on. I had the remote class so it was nice because you could sleep through lectures and watch them later but they aren't interesting and are pulled right from the textbook. Doesn't offer much help outside of class and exams are very hard.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: He's not the best lecture professor, but it is very clear that he wants as many students as possible to pass! O-chem is a tough subject in general and having it online makes it even harder. He's very understanding about homework deadlines (pushes them back 1-2 days if students are behind) and curves tests to make sure most students pass.

Online classes are rough, and it is great to have a prof who cares and tries. He is very nice and understanding about things that are not under our control. He also loves his cat, and when he heard we did too, he made sure to show us the cat every day.

I'm not sure if o-chem was just hard or if he didn't do well at teaching it. He definitely wasn't bad, but he could've made lectures more interesting and been more interactive than straight out of the book.

Professor Sellinger is a nice guy but a terrible professor. Lectures were extremely incoherent and often filled with tangents. On top of that he has a very monotone voice and tends to talk to the board. Even when students ask reasonable questions, he frequently struggles to give a straight answer. I feel sorry for those who have to take him.

Abby was down to earth, very knowledgeable, and taught the class more like a conversation than a lecture. She's very lenient about attending lectures times other than the one registered for, has popular office hours, and gives great exam studying advice.
Explained everything in a way that made sense to me and focused heavily on making sure we passed.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: She does not care about excused absences and does not work with athletes to make up missed assignments whatsoever. She is horrible at responding to emails and will give you a late score on your work even when you have been excused. Does not do examples in class that appear on homework or the exams.

Abby Johnson is a teacher who truly cares about her students. She makes lots of jokes, and really knows the material. She is available almost every day for office hours and tries really hard to respond to students and be available. She does lots of examples and explains the content well, while also making sure she isn't droning on about a subject.

Abby is one of those rare people that seriously love math and it shows in every one of her lectures. She's one of those professors that gets a sparkle in their eye when you raise your hand and excitedly runs on a math tangent of applications she thinks are cool. I've hated math since pre-calc but she single handedly made me love math again.

Abby Johnson is my favorite professor at Mines. As someone who is bad at math, I enjoy her humor talking about her past elementary students and making me feel not as stupid as Mines sometimes makes me feel. Her exams were harder than the other Linear Algebra Professor but the exam was not that bad. Definitely take linear with her if you are a CS.

I do not think I would have passed Calc 3 with a different professor. She is a very caring professor who convinced me not to drop her class and drop down to Calc 2. I got a C because I am very bad at math.  She also has experience teaching K-12 and is one of the most patient people I have met. Took linear algebra in Fall 2021 Also.

After a professor switch at the beginning of the year, Abby became my teacher and really made an impact in our class. She was very approachable and made class fun. Thanks to her I passed Linear Algebra. She is a very understanding professor that take time to make sure everyone understands the material. Also her homework was clear and manageable.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--Caring

comment: I started going to Professor Johnsons lectures and my test scores doubled. Shes open, friendly, and funny, and makes coming to class a treat. She uses fantastic examples and gives tons of tips. Her office hours are also incredibly helpful- you WILL figure out the homework if you go. Easily one of my favorite profs yet!

The lectures in this class are some of the best and Abby has been my favorite teacher in my college experience. I don't know if it was because of the teacher switch midway through the semester, but this class has been extraordinarily easy. As long as you take notes during class, do the homework and put in some time to study you will pass.
Abby has been my favorite professor so far at mines. She cares about the students that put in an effort. She makes getting up at 8 am enjoyable. Cant recommend highly enough.

She always makes lectures entertaining with fun anecdotes. The worksheets are thorough and help prepare you for exam questions, and in-class examples are helpful and easy to understand. Abby is probably my favorite professor I've had at mines so far.
She always has such fun anecdotes, and cares so much about our success. Her examples are super thorough and the worksheets are definitely set up to prepare you for exam questions.

Abby is probably my favorite professor I've had at Mines so far. She is always chatting with her students outside of class and really makes an effort to get to know you as a student. Her office hours are amazing, we just chat and she helps us one on one with homeworks. Going to class is SUPER important because a lot of examples in class are on exam

The best Calc Lecturer I've had in years. Often available for office hours and to help with the worksheets or just hang out and laugh about Mines. Makes lecture fun and engaging, simplifies complex concepts so people understand.

She does not really teach she has you watch the videos and come in with questions instead of doing a general overview. She takes way to long to grade and I just do not think she is a very good teacher in my opinion. She is a good person but teaching during corona is not her strongest point.
Keeps lectures somewhat interesting, moves pretty fast. Don't be afraid to talk to her after class if you don't understand something, she will be more than happy to help.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: At first, Abby seems like a good teacher but as the year goes on, her side comments get in the way of class. The tests are much harder than any of the homework so watch out.
Abby was the best professor I've had at mines so far. She's helpful and gives good shortcuts to make life easier when doing worksheets and homework.
Abby is a pretty cool teacher. She never goes on long boring pointless rambling lectures. She's also great about giving you helpful tricks to make life easier. Definitely a good call.
Very helpful and enjoyed the class
Nice teacher. Hot.

She can explain things pretty well, but sometimes she doesn't quite understand a question and goes on about something trivial. Also, some of her questions to the class are vague. Worksheets prepared students for the test. She was willing to help during office hours and she was quite nice.

Jeff is a good guy, but I think he assumes that his students will instantly understand Civil3D and that is just not the case. I wish he provided recorded lectures or more informative slides for when you are finishing up assignments outside of class.
Great teacher and he shows he really cares about the material and the students.
A great professor, and a great guy.

Jeff is the most amazing professor I have ever had. He cares so greatly about is classes and he is one of the most caring people I have met. If you have the opportunity to take any class with him do it! Go to his office hours if you are confused or need help; he is so willing to help and will also just talk to you if you are having a bad day.

Jeff only taught the first 5 weeks of Engineering Tools, but I thought he did a good job. The software is obviously challenging, and I don't think we were given enough guidance on how to use it. But he always had a good attitude and was willing to help.

Professor Holley was great for teaching statics. His lectures were relatively easy to follow and he was pretty good about answering clarification questions. Additionally, he was very accessible outside of class (email and office hours), and he even let me make up a whole exam after missing it due to some family stuff. Highly recommend.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Holley is a very nice guy and super flexible when it comes to helping his students. I think he is a master at what he does and knows a lot about engineering. My only issue is that his design class is a little disorganized and students often felt like they were on their own to figure out how to do everything. Not enough student guidance.
rating_tags: Group projects--Graded by few things--Online Savvy

comment: This class was a more difficult version of Statics, but Prof Holley was great at explaining the material and was very approachable outside of class. He has a dry sense of humor that many people found hilarious. He was very good about extending deadlines if he felt we weren't prepared to tackle homework. I have a slight suspicion that he's a stoner.

Class is pretty easy, basically just all the applications of phys 1. The only reason I didn't get an A is that I slacked off on studying for the exams and never really paid attention to the hw I was doing. Honestly, if you do the homework and make sure you understand how to solve those problems fast, you'll get an A.

I would take any class Holley is teaching. This is a man that cares about the students understanding the material. He understands the areas where students will struggle and has implemented tools to help students grasp tough concepts. If you're looking for a good professor, then you've found one.

He cares about students' success so much more than grades. He is willing to work with you and provide extensions if students show that they're trying. He is super intelligent and works on problems step by step, especially on ACAD, so students can problem solve on their own. He's a really cool and nice prof. overall.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Group projects

comment: Jeff is a great teacher for mechanics of materials. He mostly works example problems in class, which are very representative of test material. He is also very accessible by email or during his office hours. He is more than willing to help his students and it is obvious that he cares about their success!

Holley is very friendly and is probably the most laid-back teacher I've had. He seems a bit dull at first, but he actually has a great personality and is really funny. He is good at explaining things and is very helpful in office hours. If you take his class and do all the homework, you will have no issues doing well.
Holley was a fantastic teacher! I would take him for everything if I could. A little quiet, but get involved in lecture and youll be just fine.

Couldn't ask for a better statics teacher. Explains everything well. You can stay after class and ask him about anything and he will stay and explain it. Can't wait to have him for Civil Engineering Epics.
rating_tags: Participation matters--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: It's statics. Easy and he's good enough of a teacher
Super nice guy. Ask him all your weird random questions. Seem like you care and you'll do well

Holley is very friendly and willing to help even outside of office hours. He not only explains course material but also gives you good advice for school and for becoming a good engineer. Does not get frustrated by any questions easy or hard. The one problem was that half of class was just example problems. But it is statics so what else to expect?
Holley is an all around great guy and great professor. I can't say anything bad about him.

Holley is an incredible professor. He genuinely wants you to learn and he'll do everything to make sure you get the concepts. Everything was super straightforward and when things got tough he was ALWAYS available in office hours to give you guidance. If you have the chance to take a class with him don't hesitate! Do it!

I am so bummed out that I didn't discover Professor Holley sooner. I took statics with another prof and struggled the whole time. On the very last day of classes I finally went to Professor Holley's office hours and was blown away by how approachable he was and how much he was able to simplify things for me. I wish I had taken his class!

I generally dislike mechanics classes, E&M and mathematics is much more my world, but Holley teaching Mech Mat got my interest. He is easy to approach; if you come up to him with a question after class he will answer it. Many examples in class, almost an excessive number. This is a good class, and I would definitely recommend it.

He is a very helpful teacher. He explains material clearly. He is helpful and cares about the students. He tells you exactly what you need to study for tests. Definitely one of my favorite professors at Mines.

Baldwin was a fantastic teacher that was more than willing to work with me and it felt like he really cared about my success. The class is tough and really has the workload of a 5 credit hour, but I always felt like he had my back with it.
Boring lectures, extremely high workload. He seems pretty willing to give extensions on projects, but if you do this, be super careful not to get behind because the class moves fast.

Baldwin is a really interesting guy, to say the least. I think that he did alright as a professor and was generally pretty helpful with projects and was usually willing to give extensions or accommodation when needed. I think that being successful with him as a prof really just comes down to how you approach the class.

Baldwin is a knowledgeable professor with a unique background in the gaming industry. His assignments are well thought out and clear. He is an enjoyable lecturer also and helpful one-on-one. Prepare to do a lot of pair assignments. That is the whole class. You need 2 partners as you switch in the middle of the semester. Lots of assignments but fun.
rating_tags: Group projects--Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: He is a real expert in the field and is extremely knowledgeable. He is also willing to help you out and push back deadlines if you need it.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Group projects
