comment: Baldwin is definitely a character, he is a funny dude and his class is entertaining at the very least. He probably laughs at his own jokes more than the class does and he knows what he is talking about. Make sure you choose a good partner (probably look on piazza for who is posting about it early) because the projects are a LOT of work.

Prof Baldwin teaches a pretty decent class. The Clue project personally took up a lot of time that I didn't have due to other classes and work (pretty sure my partner for the project hates me a bit) but it's all together a decent class. Most of the material is covered by videos that are meant to be watched ahead of class.

As a lot of the comments have said, there is a lot of work in 306. However, the majority of it feels intentional and is not just busywork. I also agree that he does not teach you to code, but that is also not the point of 306, it is about the concepts. Overall, I think Mark is a great professor. He is very relaxed and receptive to feedback.

Professor Baldwin's Software class is a lot of work, however, he is a great professor. He is very knowledgeable and no-nonsense. If you put in the effort you will get more out of his class than almost any other class.

Honestly, This class isn't THAT hard. But the workload is probably the worst out of any class I've ever taken. Expect 2-3 projects weekly MINIMUM with very little time to get them done. Baldwin DOES NOT TEACH. Be prepared to learn java by videos and on your own. I will never take another Baldwin class ever again.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Group projects--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: If you are in Software Engineering, the workload sucks. There's gonna be a lot of projects piling up, you're gonna have to learn a lot, there's no way around it. Baldwin tries to help! I can't explain how helpful Baldwin and his TA's have been during office hours -- they want to help and make your life easier. Let him know if you get behind.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: His lectures are sometimes a bit rambly, but he is a fun professor. Definitely a character, but a fun one, I always enjoy listening to his lectures. I don't know about other classes, but for 261 he is a pretty good teacher and a funny guy.

This man will make your semester AWFUL!!! the amount of work he gives is beyond any professor I have ever had. Every class he assigns a new project... and they pile up quick! He makes you watch an hour of lectures every night before his class and then will quiz you on the lectures first thing when class starts. He does NOT CARE about his students.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Group projects--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Baldwin is definitely a bizarre character. He gives a short-ish lecture, and then gives you time to work on homework or projects. Always walks around the class with some sort of portable stool contraption that he sits on when he comes to your computer if you ask a question. Very weird presence on this man. Be prepared to work almost nonstop.

The classwork and material is fun and interesting to learn. However, I am not taking a class from Mark Baldwin, I am taking a class from Cyndi, the woman who recorded all the videos. Remove Baldwin from this class's process and the course is the exact same. Prepare to teach yourself, and try to get the TA to help instead of him. The TAs are better.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Group projects

comment: Software Engineering was structured as a flipped class, but there's not much of a point in reviewing the notes and lectures beforehand because you basically get the exact same thing in class. This makes staying current difficult since there's a ton of work and barely any time in class to do it. It essentially defeats the purpose of a flipped class.

I like him! He's definitely a character. He always walks around class with a hand-held chair over his shoulder, so it looks like he's carrying a hammer. So much to do though! Clue project nearly killed me.

He's not very good at lecturing, but that's okay for software engineering, since he uses Cyndi's video lectures. Classes usually have a short lecture at the beginning to review the material from the videos, followed by work time for group projects. His assignments are well written; they're a little challenging, but not prohibitively difficult.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Clear grading criteria--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: I was lucky I understood C++ easily and could learn it on my own. Baldwin is a nice guy and tries to help, but it usually doesn't feel like I got any help when I go to office hours. He does respond to emails quickly and can be very flexible with his schedule to help you out, so those are things I'll give to him. His email and piazza feedback helps

Mark very obviously knows what he is talking about, but he does not know how to teach it. He reads straight from the slides and doesn't give proper examples of work. He said "I haven't used Java in a long time, so I'll be learning it with you all" on our first day of class. Not what you want to hear. He also doesn't answer questions well.
If you have Baldwin, you're gonna be learning on your own. If he could give examples instead of reading off slides that'd be nice. Pretty nice guy, unfortunately not a good teacher.

Baldwin seems like a genuine guy who tries his best, but he is a terrible professor.. atleast for data structures. Just reads off slides, his office hours were a complete waste of my time as he barely helped. I know he is good at computer science seeing some of the code he's written, but teaching it he just cannot do.

I took this class during the summer in 6 weeks, and oh my was it tough. Tracy did a phenomenal job guiding me throughout the course. Her quizzes were tough and she wants you to lay out your problems in a goofy way, but otherwise was a great professor.

Tracy is the most caring professor I've had. She offers students multiple opportunities to succeed, and takes students' opinions into account when creating her course structure. She is flexible and understanding and truly apologizes to students when she makes mistakes. I wish she was teaching my courses next semester!

Honestly at first I was scared to take a class with her after rumors I heard from other people. But after having her as a teacher for Heat and Mass Transfer I felt that she was just misunderstood. Yes she is a difficult grader but she cares about her students and learning is more comprehensive with multiple ways to prove your understanding.

Gardner will push you and challenge you but that is because she really wants you to learn the material. She cares so much about her students. She is incredibly brilliant and has a hard time simplifying things sometimes but she always does her best. She honestly gave me the encouragement and support I needed to complete the degree program.

Tracy is great.  I have enjoyed all my classes with her and plan to take another.  The grading system where your exam scores can replace your lower homework or quiz score is awesome for those who are good test takers.  This results in outcomes that fit the strength of every student.  If you're ever lost she has screen casts for all the material. :3
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Test heavy

comment:
Gardner has a very specific class structure that involves a fair amount of homework/class activities (probably the reason for low ratings), but she's careful to present information in the best way for learning, and assignments match the work required to learn the material in her classes. 
Really cares about her students' health and well-being
This professor offers a unique class scheme that is whole designed to benefit the students.

Dr. Gardner is one of the best professors in the Chemical Engineering department. Her classes are structured differently than other classes with varying degrees of "flipped" lecture styles. Her structuring of both Fluids and Kinetics which I have had her for have resulted in me learning the material better than any other class. 6/5 rating.

Tracy Gardner is my favorite Professor at Mines. She really cares about her students. At the end of her class, you will fully understand the material. If you try in her class, you will pass it.  (She does do screencasts which I didn't like at first, but ultimately found really helpful.) I highly recommend taking her classes.

Dr. Gardner needs more people defending her. She's always there for her students, and she always does a great job answering questions. Office hours and Q/A sessions are extremely helpful. While her style fits certain types of students better, Mines is community with lots of those students. She also provides an estimate about assignment length.

I've had Tracy for Fluids and now Heat and Mass Transfer. She's really caring and tries her best to teach you. I found that her teaching style suits some people better than others. She gave us all that we needed to know with her screencasts, but then it was up to us if we needed any extra work. Overall good experience. Projects were a pain though.

Maybe a part of it was that the class was online but I struggled with the learning style. Most of the learning I had to do on my own and the lectures were not particularly helpful. I will give her though that she does care about the students even though her theory that her online learning style is better is her hill to die on.

Tracy was a solid fluids professor in my opinion. For online class, she structured it in a way where lectures were to be watched on our own time and classes were optional supplementary material. It was very important to attend the class since it improves understanding. Tracy is cool and easy to talk to.

I created an account for the sole purpose of defending Dr. Gardner. I took her for material and energy balances (C+), heat transfer (A-) and fluid dynamics (C+). She is a great professor and truly does care about students. Get to know her in her office hours. Tests are hard but she is the epitome of know the CONCEPT, and I liked that about her.

She cannot do well in her teaching and class structure design. But she is the only one teaching some of the classes at mines. Prepare for ambiguous problem statements, quizzes unrelated to homework, and all other no organization. Also, someone commented down here was right, she left out material to make things hard unfairly for no reason.
She is one of the best Chemical Engineering teachers at mines. She cares about her students, and challenges us both in class and on the exams. Take her if you have the opportunity.

Her projects are insanely long and are not even remotely helpful. In lecture, it seems like she over complicates everything even when it is a simple topic. She's nice, but this just isn't the best method for teaching IMO.
Tracy tries to make things harder than they need to be. In addition, she is vague in her grading criteria and her lectures are a waste of time .
Tracy is willing to help but you have to work hard to get a good grade. Overall she is a good teacher. Use her office hours as much as you can.

You'll hear a lot of bad things about Tracy, but she's not terrible. Use her office hours if you want to pass, though. Like don't be surprised if you're going a few times a week. I took her for MEB, it was her first time teaching so it was pretty rough. The other option was Pres Johnson who I heard bad things about. She does random attendance stuff

She is overly determined to prove she is smart, which is pointless for a PhD ChemE professor. It also seems she leaves out material to make her tests seem harder (which she is overly proud of, personally I think C average is always a good sign of a good test). I stopped attending class at end, no bad consequences. Other professor's class did better
tough, but fair, and very willing to help

A horrible professor that is extremely homework heavy and makes no accommodations whatsoever. Sometimes assigns homework due at 1pm on a Monday like lol when am I gonna have time to do that? Needs to get her act together, no wonder the computer science program at mines is in such disrepair.

To get a perspective of the type of person she is I got a C on the first exam and then aced the second exam due to changing study habits, and then myself and a few others receive a very hostile email stating that since we improved by two letter grades we are being monitored for cheating.. I switched majors cuz thats not how success should be reward
she isnt fantastic at all, too political

Tracy is a little hostile towards students--specifically male students for some reason. She had to bring in other professors to teach us how to code because she could not explain it well enough for any of us to know what was going on. It was a mess

She makes you work for your grade but gives lots of extra credit (at least 20 pts). Attendance isn't taken, but you'll miss lectures and participation if you don't show up. She tries to reasonably help her students, but some people didn't do their half and complained instead. If you don't procrastinate and actually work hard, you'll be better off.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: Tracy posts homework at the last possible second, is very hostile towards students, and doesn't post anything online from review question answers to class slides. 1 star. Avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: the class mainly consists of memorizing definitions and reading out of a textbook. Tracy is pretty cool and helpful

I thought Camp was great. She is very down to earth and is willing to help her students. She does go fast, but she's willing to answer questions. I wrote her a thank you card for one of those professor appreciation weeks, and she personally wrote me an email thanking me and how much it meant to her.

I got a question wrong on a test and after some research realized I was correct. When I went to her she told me that I was correct, but, that she would NOT give me the points back because the rest of the class wrote the wrong answer. I am unsure what kind of logic this is, but she is the head of my major's department and I have lost all respect.

Though she taught at a fast pace without being too clear, she is a very genuine down to earth person if you actually go to her for help. She does try to explain things, but I think in order to get the most out of the class you're gonna have to ask for clarification on a lot of things.
Heavy workload for the class and not much additional help provided
This class was very uninteresting. I've heard that at many other schools, this class is  usually one of the more exciting ones but when its taught by Camp, it just kind of sucks.

It's because of Dr. Camp that I transferred to Comp. Sci. and I am very glad I did. Tracy is now my u-grad advisor, I've been in two classes taught by her, and do research work overseen by her. She's a great teacher and person!
you do learn while taking tests, but staying focused in class can be hard. The projects are painful to do, but cool to have completed.
No Comments
One of the best teachers I've ever had at any college.  She is tough, but clear.  There aren't many tests you take that you actually learn while you are testing.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
Online version of the course was a little tougher than expected, but not too bad.
Lecture concentrated on easy material; students unprepared for projects

Had him a while ago but... no. If you 100% know what's happening the whole time his lectures are decent. If you are confused good luck because he goes fast even if you ask him to slow down and doesn't answer questions. "Do all the problems in the book" wasn't the help I wanted about what turned out to be a not terrible concept.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Knauss looks down upon almost anyone aside from the top students in the class. If you ask questions or come into office hours he will just tell you to read the book and try to get you to leave him alone. We all ultimately want to learn and get better but Dr. Knauss won't help you do that, he will just judge you for your struggles. Very Sad.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Rather than being friendly and explaining the concepts to you, Dr. Knauss will be rude to you if you come into office hours or ask questions. The only reason I got did ok is because he reuses test questions from previous semesters. Get a hold of some old practice exams and you will do fine in the course. Just don't expect any useful help from him.

To put everything to rest, this man is incredible. If you are intelligent and work hard you will do perfectly fine. He will expect alot from his students, but he is very good with helping students and gives great lectures. My favorite professor so far! Also he will probably make fun of you for asking dumb questions but it's really funny.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: (3) Other people in the class will literally have to raise their hand and point to the other people raising their hands that he is ignoring so he has to call on them. He lectures WAY too fast and does not care when people ask him to slow down. His homework assignments are to do "all" of the textbook problems but will not help you when you have Q's.

This man should not be paid to teach at Mines. He is actively rude to students, calling them stupid for asking questions. He does not give any homework, just tells you to do all the problems in the textbook. And when you finish those and still have questions, he recommends reading another textbook. His poor teaching actively made O Chem unbearable.

I loved chemistry until I took Knauss' class. He is condescending, and treats the pretty girls much differently than everyone else in the class. When asked if he can go over specific problems in the book, he replies with "Well it's in the book, YOU do the problem." He assigns "all" of the book problems, instead of saying which are most important.

Knauss is extremely knowledgeable about organic chemistry, and in general his lectures are decent and he cares about students. Sometimes, however, he can be really condescending when students ask questions, and he makes his tests as hard as possible.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Tests are tough--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He can be rude to students, but it makes lecture entertaining. Just pay attention and read the book, and you'll be fine.

Dr. Knauss is an excellent teacher that emphasizes the important things in organic chemistry - understanding of electron flow, why certain reactions occur or don't occur - instead of just presenting information to memorize. He expects a lot of his students, which is rewarding if the students put in the hard work needed. I'd recommend him for sure!

Don't be upset when he calls you stupid, it will happen. He is very full of himself and thinks his class is the only one that matters. He is very good at his subject and if you can follow all of his rules and expectations you might pass.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--TEST HEAVY

comment: While his tests are fair, he can be extremely rude to students, especially when they ask questions. His teaching mostly consists of parroting what the textbook says, but in a more condescending way.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Very energetic and passionate during lecture. He's really hard to ignore. He does not like to repeat himself and gets impatient when people ask things he already went over in lecture. His tests are hard but fair and he frequently extended the homework deadline to help us out. Very helpful during office hours. Doesn't hurt that he's hot either.
Fantastic professor. Really made it easy to learn as long as you read the book along with going to lectures. Probably wouldn't ask him any questions though.

Super helpful professor. First test i had at mines was didnt go so well because i wasnt paying much attention, but afterwards I shaped up and he was very willing to help me along the way. Some of the things he glossed over because he expected you to learn it from the book/it was fundamental knowledge, but very effective overall

Definitely someone coming from a chemistry background; hadn't taught O-Chem in 6 years.. Also doesn't take questions well (perhaps he doesn't like to think/answer in front of entire class). He did not show students much respect though; used ~60min of lecture explaining that it wasn't his teaching problem, so it must be that we don't understand.
Very good professor. The material is difficult but he presents it well.
Amazing teacher.  I feel very privileged to have had him for such a tough subject as O-chem.  He expects a lot of you but is reasonable at the same time.
Difficult course, he does a decent job at teaching it. I've learned a lot from him.
Very demanding, very good professor. Class was very hard, but learned alot. Can get quite angry, but never an issue in class.
Best professor I've ever had. Very demanding but explains the material very good.
Really tough, but you learn a lot.

Professor Fisher is AWESOME! She is super helpful and was always quick to respond. She make amazing online lectures, I took this course over the summer and it was manageable even with a full-time internship. Her course was super easy to follow and she was enthusiastic about the material she was teaching. Hope I have her again!

Dr. Fisher is awesome and sets a great example for what a professor in comp sci should be. She really cares about her students, is available for help, responds quickly to emails, and wants to see you succeed. I wish I could take the whole program through just her!

Some times felt like how to implement what we were doing was skimmed over, but for the most part, a very good professor and more than willing to grant extensions. Would absolutely recommending taking Wendy for Data Science.

I took Intro to Data Science with Wendy, and she is the best professor I have ever had.  She is understanding, and genuinely advocates for her students.  She is the most accessible professor in the department.  She is hilarious, fun, and brilliant.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Best professor at Mines. Every chance you get to have Professor Fisher as your Professor please take advantage.
She knows what to do

She is by far the most helpful professor I had at Mines. This course shifted my career interests closer to data science, which I totally did not expect. She is incredibly caring and helpful to her students. Asking for help never felt uncomfortable (unlike in other CS courses). 100% would take another course taught by her again.

Professor Fisher is a phenomenal educator. Took Intro to Data Science with her as well, and both of these classes were top notch. She's empathetic, passionate, knows her stuff, her courses are well-structured, she's available, is an excellent orator, and lets you know exactly what you need to do to be successful. HIGHLY recommend any of her classes
I don't think I learned much during her class, but so far she has been much better than my other professor at the school. I have not idea how they have the reputation they have.

Dr. Fisher is a wonderful human. I took both Data Science and Machine Learning online with her, and really liked it. She is a very nice person and super motivational. One thing I noticed last semester is that she does seem a bit disconnected with the online classes, but if you can get her for an in-person class, definitely go for it.

Wendy is a great professor! She really cares about her students, and is very responsive and understanding. Her classes are projected based, and pretty easy to follow along. Some questions can fluster her at times, but for the most part her classes are beautifully structured.

Data science with professor Fisher has been awesome. She truly cares about her student's success and will do what she can to enable you. Take this class if you're interested at all in data science, you won't regret it
Wendy is super positive and is always excited to help. She's very genuine and makes all of her classes as entertaining as she can.
Wendy is the bomb!

I love Wendy! So does everyone else! Wendy brings energy that is unmatched by any other professor I have had. I had CSCI303 at 8 AM and even though she claimed to be a morning person, we late every day LOL! Wendy is awesome, just make sure you are on top of things to get value from the course

Wendy's awesome! She made Data Structures my favorite class my first semester at Mines! She's very helpful and caring in her office hours. She can get side tracked a little in her lectures but she always brings an excited and positive energy!
Overall I think Wendy does a decent job teaching, however sometimes she says completely random stuff that makes absolutely no sense and it seems like she was out of town for half the semester.
She's more about you learning and putting work into your assignments/final project than remembering every detail. Just do the work and you'll have fun.

Highly recommend Wendy! The class is very straightforward. You may have to work a little harder if you have no programming experience before, and the lectures can be short if you are brand new to the concept. She is always so helpful during her office hours, she will help you do well in the class! She really cares about each of her students.

Wendy is wonderful. She's part of the reason why I'm considering switching to comp sci. She's kind, knowledgable, and very understanding. She also makes class time go by very quick because shes so enthusiastic and easy to listen to.
Wendy is good at teaching and very nice. Most of her assignments in Python are pretty easy. Even the final project (which is most of your grade) is an easy A as long as you put effort in.

Very no nonsense. Homework isn't graded, entire grade is from a few exams. In exchange, endless office hours and high accessibility. He is very up front about his style of teaching. Not recommended for people with crippling test anxiety, but his exams are straightforward and designed to be passed.

The course was 100% test based but Prof Martin did an extremely good job with preparing you for the material and was clear with what to expect. Lectures were old fashioned white board lecture. No online notes when I took the course so you should be expected to go to each class but he was easy to reach out to and was very accessible outside of class
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Paul Martin is a rare gem at Mines. Everything with his classes is done super old school. It is very clear to the students that he cares about their learning and is always quick with a joke. 11/10 recommend taking at least once!
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: A synopsis of a Paul Martin class is: great lectures, no grades outside of tests, and optional homework. Personally this format worked for me, but I can see how it can be difficult and dated. Professor Martin has beautiful lectures, but has little to no office hours. Also, he does not post his lecture notes which can be annoying if you miss class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Paul Martin is one of the most clear lecturers I have ever had. The notes from his class will no doubt help me down the road. A piece of advice: while the homework is optional, I do not believe I would pass the class without them, as they are extremely important to get practice with the PDEs. The class recordings had audio difficulties.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Amazing lectures

comment: A very old-fashioned teacher. Has pages and pages of notes, only writes on the white board, no posting of notes or lectures in online platform, have to go to the library to 'check out' homework answers, etc. I think he does a good job. It really helps how he tells us exactly what he wants us to know for the exams. 100% exam grades. Ouch

Don't be fooled, I think this class is a huge challenge given that 100% of your grade is based purely on exams (40% final, yikes). You have to go to class though if you want to succeed. The material I thought was difficult and complex. He does communicate exactly what the exam will consist of though, which is comforting.
His class grade depends only on exams. 30% for each mid-term and 40% for the final. HW are optional. Also, he does not post notes, HW solutions or exams solution.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria

comment: Paul Martin is an excellent prof. His gravitas is tangible, his humor subtle and quirky yet crippling at times, and his methods methodical and precise. Every lecture brings new ideas to light and he is always willing to stop and explain in class or talk with students afterwards. Note: He lectures mostly by example, and grades solely on exams.
Whoever said that he is the James Bond of Applied Mathematics got it spot on.

Took PDEs, complex analysis and integral equations from him.  He's good, but extremely clinical.  He has a tendency to focus on methods for solving problems rather than overarching big ideas.  He's quite rigorous which is a turnoff to physicists like me.  The grading is based solely on exams which can be extremely painful if you have a bad day.

The BEST math teacher at Mines. I've taken every elective he's taught while I've been here (Complex Analyis 1/2, Integral Equations, PDEs, Asymptotics), and he's consistently amazing. I worked so hard, but I left having learned a ton. Plus he has a great sense of humor.
He's like the James Bond of mathematics.

Don't let the numbers scare you. He's a hard teacher, but that's what makes him so awesome -- he treats his students like adults and lets us discover the math ourselves. I don't think I've had any teacher that I respect more than Martin. But do be prepared... his tests are certainly harder than the homework.
excellent teacher, i would make every effort to take a class with him
Awesome prof, I think he's a department head, so he knows his stuff.

He knows his topic, and is willing to help.  If you ask questions he's good about answering them in ways you can understand.  The material can be confusing and I think Palmer might be a better teacher for this class.
my favorite professor at mines
No Comments
blah, if you have to take this course, i feel sorry for you. if you don't .. DON T take it as na elective.. i made that mistake :P
No Comments

Good:
-Loves his job
-Available outside class
-Funny
-Practical

Bad:
-Confusing
-Mocking
-Cold, distant
-Unclear
-Disorganized Lectures
-Contradictory
-Impossible to pass class w/o office hours
-Puts things on exams and eqn. sheets explicitly to throw off students

There's more to D. Rod than I can express here, but he was my worst professor yet.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Worst teacher I've had. Expects you to read and work on the homework WAY before the due date, so classes are confusing and unhelpful if you don't. Goes on tangents and ends class early often. The worst is his assigned project. He will refuse to answer questions you have on the project and look over anything, then slap the class with a 75% average.

The worst professor I've ever had. The lecture videos are messy and hard to follow. The professor expects you to learn by reading from the textbook which is not efficient. I'm currently retaking this course with a different professor. I feel much better now knowing that this class wasn't too hard for me, it was just the professor's teaching style.

This professor is well respected for having a lot of experience teaching thermo well. Lectures condense the information and include lots of examples, highly recommended to not skip in order to do well on homeworks and tests. Fantastic professor to learn from and outside of class he is easy to talk to.

Had him for Thermo. He is great at outlining expectations and strategies for success, whether in class or career. Does not read from slides, goes off the whim, but always makes sure you have all the information you need to succeed. Unusual style for professor, very casual and not super professional but an overall good teacher.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Hilarious

comment: I took Thermo during the end of the COVID pandemic, so the class was reeled back a little bit on difficult. While Rodriguez's lectures weren't extremely useful, he does a decent job providing resources for students to learn and comprehend the material. He's very accessible through email and office hours, and is clear on what's covered on the exams.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: Dr. Rod really grew on me over the semester. At the beginning, I was scared of his lecture style because it didn't seem like it was going to help but then after the first and second test I realized his way of teaching really works and it actually helped me do better. Thermo is one of the hardest classes so considering that, he's a pretty good prof.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: It's clear that he is a very knowledgeable guy. However, his lectures are very disorganized and messy and he hand-waves away many of the confusing parts while he sprawls chicken scratch across the whiteboard. Thermo isn't a simple class so it's disappointing that you have to basically teach yourself. You will not pass without the textbook.

DRod is the best. He is very accessible in office hours and via. email. He is more than willing to help students succeed. He was also willing to help look at resumes and provide guidance outside of thermo as well. Thermo is definitely hard though, and you will still have to put in the work if you wanna do well.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: Rodriguez is easily one of the best professors I have ever had for a class. He is not only fair, but is easily accessible and willing to work with students. While he is not a department adviser many students will go to him anyways because of the insight and advice he offers Rodriguez also stated explicitly the textbook was optional for the course

Drod explains the material clearly and concisely and is very respectful of students' time. He always starts lecture on time and finishes early. You have to work hard, but that's the nature of the course, not him assigning busy work.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--Caring

comment: DRod is alright. If it's between him and Tabares I'd pick DRod, but in general he's not amazing. You don't get that much out of lecture, and homeworks require a lot of self teaching. He's available during office hours and will help you out, but not super helpful with actually trying to learn thermo
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Participation matters

comment: Clearly knows his stuff and has the students' best interests at heart. A bit too laissez faire in my opinion. So I understand he's not for everyone; but he's been effective in teaching me both Fluids I & II

He does a solid job at teaching, but he's not particularly engaging. He really shines at pointing out real world applications and making sure his students have basic knowledge that is critical in industry but isn't covered in the textbook. He's incredibly approachable in office hours and cares deeply about his students and department.

Yes, he is tough; but a teacher with more real-world prep included, you won't find. His lectures are crucial and he answers all questions to satisfaction. His tests are notoriously brutal; but he is incredibly generous with partial credit.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He does explain application of the concepts to real world problems and what you will encounter, only problem is that this isn't what is on the tests. When I try to review my notes later, they are useless because the problems aren't worked through or they are even different than the equations given in a different section. Plus no notes are posted.

He's a great guy for networking with and talking to. He's not very good at conveying information clearly. While it's clear he knows what he's talking about, his lack of neatness and his tendency to fly through topics without explaining them very well makes his lectures pretty worthless. Read the book and look at external resources.

Rodriguez is a great professor. He clearly explains topics in 30 minutes that would otherwise take 2 hours to understand. Never skip class if you have Rodriguez - you're only hurting yourself. He's also worked in the real world, so he has a better sense of the application of fluids. Plus, he has this dry, sarcastic humor that's just great.
Took him for a summer class. The material was hard but I found his tests to be extremely easy.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Can be very condescending in class. Handwriting and poor board organization makes following his lectures hard. If you are in his thermo class, you better like reading the book or attending someone else's lectures. DeCaluwe makes a much better thermo prof
Awesome Teacher!!

By far, one of the coolest professors. He's definitely what you would find in a work place colleague. Very practical and real world. He's not big on acadamia-land. Thermo was hard but it's easier when he's running the show. Had him for Fluids also. Taking him again for Fluids 2.

I was in Cohort 1 and had him at the very beginning of the semester. Out of all the assignments that were turned in, only one was graded and the rest weren't even graded till the end of the semester which sucks because the last day to withdraw classes is in November. The other profs graded our stuff in a week but it took this guy almost 5 months 💀

There was a lot of homework assigned for how much teaching he actually did. also all the assignment's were poorly explained so half the time you have to redo all your work because the assignment was not explained properly. He also had the most poorly organized canvas page I have seen to date. He also missed half of our classes.

I took Dr. Hudson as part of a 4 week Futures seminar. He cancelled class frequently, which meant we were rushed at the end of seminar and learned very little. His lectures were engaging and informative, but his Canvas page was very disorganized and poorly structured.

First half of the semester is extraordinarily heavy on reading, and there would be days where he would send an announcement at 9pm or later about the reading required for the lecture the very next day. Second half of the semester is virtually devoid of any content at all. Content taught in lecture was hardly relevant to any assignments.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Graded by few things

comment: He was pretty lenient on deadlines, but was extremely tough to follow along with. As a summer 6-week course, I struggled the entire time. He once stated: "I am an auditory learner, so I teach that way." You need to know everything he simply says and he gives little info about what to study. The assignments and canvas page are vague and confusing.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Amazing class, caring professor, very flexible.

Not exaggerating but Dr. Hudson is the best in his department. Nice, respectful, understanding. Light coursework (1 quiz, 1 midterm, 2 major papers, group final project, final). Extends deadlines for papers, resubmission is an option. Revise additional homework it will be in the exam. But heavy info.
I always recommend his classes to my friends!

Dr H is one of the most empathetic professors I've had at Mines. I've never had a professor that is so flexible with deadlines and prioritizes his students' well-being more than him. Lectures are very different from normal Mines environment, which I found to be a nice change of pace.

Overall, the due dates change and how your work will be graded is completely unclear. However, he makes up for it by being a ridiculously easy grader. His lectures are confusing by have little weight in the class. He cancels class quite a bit and the last couple weeks of class are just listening to presentations.

Hudson is an amazing professor. His recitations are always helpful but not stressful if you need to miss for any reason. He is very easy going and very understanding of all his students. I chose to take him for NHV because I had friends who had him and I couldn't be happier.
He is amazing! I took religion and security and African development with him. I like his easiness he is not strict and his classes are very enjoyable he is very flexible

Unclear with assignments, due dates, etc. That being said, Hudson is an amazing teacher if he's talking about stuff he loves. There wasn't much graded work, and when it was graded, he was pretty loose. Really enjoyed religion with him.
Nah, never again.  I was never sure when anything was due, how it was going to be graded or when I would be getting it back.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Yes you will be lost in lecture if you don't do the reading. As long as you are keeping up with class assignments you will find this class very interesting and you will learn a lot from Dr. Hudson
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: I can't understand what is going on in this class

Dr. Hudson might not be the clearest professor, but sure he is the easiest to get a good a grade with. Yes some of his test questions are not related to the lectures but he gives the test ahead of time so you can find the answers in the readings. He also lets you redo your paper to get a better grade. For me, he is the best Hum sys prof. Easy A

He was the worst teacher I have yet to have here at Mines and I hope he's the worst I ever have. No lectures. Talks in "stories" that make no real sense and if he draws to a conclusion I don't agree with him.  He must've never heard of the term logic. Assigns too many assignments so theres no way my grade is accurate at all. You get an A if you tal

He's probably the most confusing teacher I've ever had. He will assign you essays and give you tests over things he didn't teach you. Maybe his other classes are better, but as for Human Systems, I'll be happy when the class is over. If you get stuck with him, prepare yourself for a very vague and frustrating semester. Good luck.

Professor Hudson is incredibly vague. I never know if what he's saying is relevant to the course, or just a rambling anecdote. I never know what to review for quizzes or tests, because he'll include a question about a side comment he made in class once. Essays are nice because you can gather your own data, except when the prompt is also vague.
I thoroughly enjoyed his class. After taking his class I felt like I really learned something rather than just another class to complete a requirement.

Dr Hudson is a great professor.  Sometimes his lectures are all over the place, but he tries to give students a good survey of a subject regarded poorly by most of his target audience (i.e. scientists and engineers) and I think he does a great job.  He is flexible when it comes to teaching, and overall I am enjoying my time in his class.

Some people like Hudson's teaching style, I on the other hand absolutely detest it. He is very disorganized and his grading rubrics are very unclear and long winded. One thing that stood out the most was how he constantly assigned fairly large assignments at the last minute and graded them quite harshly.

Poorly written exams, HW, and quizzes, so get ready to be tested on how well you can interpret her thought process instead of the content. Multiple corrections mid exams. Said all semester she was going to curve final grades instead of each exam, took it back the day of the final to drop lowest 10 point quiz in a 700+ pt class and remove +/- grades

A lot of issues with CSCI341 come from the brutal structure of the class itself and less so Dr. Han's teaching. She reads off of lecture slides and sometimes adds details that may or may not be helpful depending on the situation. She was willing to give extensions to homework in some cases and dropped +/- grading, so it's not like she hates us.

Han is the worst teacher I've had to date. The coursework is not difficult but going to lecture is more confusing than helpful. This makes learning the material difficult. Han is uninterested in teaching and delegates her work to TA's. Get ready for convoluted lectures and frustrating interactions. She is difficult and unprofessional over email.

Dr. Han has a lot of material to cover, so I understand the amount of material required in each lecture. Yet, I feel like I had to do more outside work to understand the material than a regular class. This course overall needs some improvement as a whole. The lecture also left many students with questions that Dr. Han would simply disregard.

Great experience for 23 Spring, Dr. Han is a experienced instructor on this course, homework is a little bit more, but if you can finish them by yourself or with TA's help, and attend classes, it would be not hard to get an A grade.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: Professor Han's availability and promises to students are both spotty. The class was promised a curve due to a failing average on the exam, and this has still yet to happen. Reading the textbook is as helpful as going to the lectures, and exams do not accurately reflect material covered in class. Good luck...
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Professor Han's teaching is like stumbling through a foggy swamp. Her emails are as helpful as a broken compass, leading nowhere. Assignments feel like weights tied to ankles before a swim. Her lectures? More confusing than a maze with no exit. Avoid at all costs.

Professor Han's confusing and fast paced teaching style, lack of enthusiasm, and no resources makes learning impossible. Despite expressing concerns about failing, they offered no support, just advising to 'learn before exams.' Their dismissive and condescending attitude adds stress and despair to a hard class. Avoid at all costs!

Prof Han's class is basically run by TA's.  They write and grade homework and exams, all Han does is teach.  She lectures very fast and its hard to keep up without lots of self studying.  The quizzes and exams are ridiculous, 62% average on midterm 1 (no curve) and C average on most quizzes. She was the only option for me, so good luck!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Update 4/27/22. Midterms are a b*t&h. The average for midterm 1 was a 70 and I've heard the final is worse. Han is strict but very nice. Just avoid professor Read. The book is unbelievably dense and hard to read. Weekly quizzes are often hard and do some questions are obscure or cover topics we have not covered yet. just get ready to suffer.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Test heavy

comment: Update 2/9/22 As I said in my earlier post, I recommend this professor. She is miles better than professor Read, who is just a trainwreck. Lectures are fast, but she posts the slides and is very helpful during office hours. She is actually very nice. She answers all questions too. I have not had a midterm in this class so I will write again soon.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: I am writing this review because I have seen conflicting reviews about this professor. I am taking her this semester and we are in person. 1/20/22 She goes fast in lectures, so don't expect to write everything down. She posted slides for download though. She is always happy to answer questions in class and OH. There is a bit of reading each week
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Skip class? You won't pass.--Get ready to read

comment: AVOID AT ALL COSTS. This class was an absolute joke. Qi Han was not useful in office hours. At one point when I didn't understand something she said "I don't have time for this" and left immediately after. The lectures are comically bad, she just plays pre-recorded videos and when asked a question, responds with a question.... WOULD NOT RECOMMEND
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: I always had a hard time following Dr. Han in class. She goes through lecture at record speeds, often doesn't explain her slides enough for everyone to understand, and isn't personable whatsoever. I passed the class by reading the slides on my own time, as well as collaborating with other students. Try to avoid her classes if possible.

Qi Han did a good job of making a difficult topic easier to understand. Although her lectures went fast, they always helped my gain a better understanding of what was going on. Along with the homework assignments and quizzes, the class was structured in a way that was very conducive to my learning.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Uncaring toward student learning. Delegates most of the student interaction to TA's with the same attitude.

Dr. Han can be a little socially awkward, but she will help you do well if she sees you're trying hard. She can talk fast, but if you're paying attention it's not so bad. Show up to class. Ur paying for it, and it's hard to crunch the material by yourself. She notices when you're gone, so she'll have less mercy on you if you constantly skip class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--TEST HEAVY

comment: Worst professor I had as a CS major period. She's not helpful during her office hours on explaining things, and I get the attitude that she does not want to help me. I had to learn everything from YouTube, the books, and my friends. Also beware of the incompetent TAs who grade. I had to fight for my grade a couple of times.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--TEST HEAVY

comment: Her lectures can be pretty difficult to comprehend given her accent and very fast speech. She blazes through the material incredibly fast and her slides aren't very useful so you'll likely rely on the textbook or youtube videos from other sources. She's the only prof for CompOrg so you don't have a choice, but just be prepared.

Qi Han is by far one of the nicest professors at Mines.  She really wants you to pass and is always willing to help.  This class was a struggle for me, but with her help I was able to succeed.  Thank you so much Qi Han!!!
One of only a handful of classes at Mines where I actually felt challenged. Her difficulty calibration is superb.
If you're taking chem you want Jameer, she is amazing at her job. She does make you do a lot of ungraded work outside of lecture in order to keep up, but she covers everything she can very well.

Very nice and caring professor. Willing to answer any questions asked during lecture. Will sometimes get caught up on a question and not leave enough time for the rest of the lecture material, but she'll push it back to the next lecture to not put more pre-class work on us. Lots of Pearson/mastering chemistry homework.

Prof J is very passionate about the material and generally gives good lectures. She can get off topic at times, especially with unrelated student questions. Class participation matters, but it isn't a major part of the final grade.
Great at making difficult-to-understand content comprehendible.

I loved Jameer!! Her lectures were very high energy and engaging and she explained topics very clearly and concisely. Classes had a nice balance of lecturing and doing clicker questions/group work to practice calculations and conceptual problems. She was super kind and genuinely cared about every students learning.

Jameer is a great person and a good lecturer. I personally barely paid attention, as I'm strong in chemistry, but the lectures that I did pay attention to were high quality. As previous reviews have stated, she does tend to get lost on subjects not related to the class, but when covering concepts she explained things very nicely.
She's such a sweet and caring person and will go out of her way to help you if you need it! Would 100% take her again

I did enjoy how many examples were given and how open she was to answering questions during class. She was thorough in her answering and her lectures were packed with information. She did go fast somethings though and sometimes it felt like she'd rather be anywhere else, but at her office hours.

Professor Jameer really cares about her students and is a wonderful professor. She works with her students and cares about learning within the course. Any question I had, Jameer was able to combat with a elegant answer. Office hours were also super helpful and excelled my learning!
Prof J. really cares about her students learning and made me really enjoy Chem, if you have the chance-absolutely take her!

Would routinely go over time and leave an additional 45 minutes of material in a zoom recording that you would need to look over. Spent about 3 weeks teaching us her "personal diversity statement" and she spent 20 out of 50 minutes one lecture teaching students how to solve 2^x=4, which is completely unnecessary at a calculus-centric university.
I loved Jameer and her lectures are usually higher energy than other chemistry professors. She's really funny and I enjoyed her class a lot.
She is a very good lecturer and cares about her students. She will learn your name if you go to her for help. The problem with the course is how this is treated very much as a weed-out class.

Definitely lecture heavy, for better or for worse (kinda comes with the territory of a chem class). But, GO TO OFFICE HOURS. She was so sweet and always willing to help. It's obvious that she cares a lot about her students and is good at conveying tough subjects.

Amanda Jameer has been my favorite professor at Mines itself. The class was difficult, but I felt well prepared for exams. The lectures included many different examples did a good job connecting new topics to previous content, which helped me to develop an intuition for the subject itself. This class definitely didn't bum me out!
Great professor. Lectures may be confusing at times, but she is very helpful and accessible in office hours.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Beware of pop quizzes--Amazing lectures

comment: Amanda Jameer is an incredible professor. She gives engaging lectures, communicates with her students at blazing speed, grades fast, has frequent office hours, and made the course a lot more enjoyable. She's very kind, and one of the friendliest professors I've had at Mines.

Jameer is a great professor but her lectures can get a little boring at times. This class is lecture heavy, so unless you learn best this way, I'd recommend going to CASA office hours. She has a great personality and seems to care about her student's success. Jameer is a solid professor as she has detailed slides that she posts online on Canvas.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Jameer always presents impeccably in class including having a high energy level. She teaches clearly and quickly using short group activities frequently.
I had Jameer for lab. She is a really nice person and is always willing to help you if you are stuck. I do have to say she is a very tough grader, though that may just be how the class is set up

He doesn't completely work out examples and talks fast. When he writes down equations it is difficult to tell what he has written. He has a heavy accent which isn't necessarily a deal breaker, but he changes octaves when he talks from loud to whisper. If you don't sit in the front you will miss what he says. His tests are also extremely difficult.
Worst prof ever, please avoid. Lecture consists of circling every word on the slides and not elaborating and expects us to do homework with equations he has not mentioned in lecture.

While the grading criteria for the projects could be improved and his lecture notes are scribbles after you look at them again, he is a really caring professor and more than makes up for any shortcomings with his accessibility. You will absolutely need to go to lectures and read a textbook, but I have had far worse professors in far easier classes.

Had Zhang for both 315 and 481. Despite what others have said, he does actually care about students and wants them to succeed, you just have to try and ask questions. He grades very easily on tests, practice problems are very similar to exams, and overall the lectures are informative and helpful. Both classes are hard no matter the prof.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: I really liked Zhang, he cares about his students doing well and is super helpful in office hours. Answers questions asked during lecture and really wants students to understand the material. Also a ridiculously nice grader for tests and projects. The problems he goes over in class are very similar to exam problems.

He doesn't give feedback on exams, all he does is circle and scribble on it so you never know what you're doing wrong. He also doesn't explain the problems very well. This could partially be because i'm a civil forced to take a mechanical class but i can never understand what's going on in the problems making solving it 10x harder.
Man goes so fast during lecture. cannot follow and he does not post his slides

Zhang's lectures are very hard to follow and he doesn't explain things super well. The class is already extremely difficult and Zhang definitely doesn't make it any easier. He's not a rude or bad person, just not great at teaching.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: Idk why so many people bag on this guy, he does a good job and really wants to help students succeed in this class, even though it's tough. His office is open very often for students to just walk in while he works on stuff and gives huge hints to help on tests and quizzes, which were very similar to review probs he gave us

I took this professor last semester and just finished the first week of the next semester and I have never heard so many complaints about a professor. I guess everyone was mad that Zhang didn't really care about his job last semester or something.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: This professor is TERRIBLE! His lectures quite often are extremely hard to follow and don't make sense. If you go into office hours, sometimes he will outright refuse to help with a problem or won't know how to solve it at all. Tests are not similar to the homework problems either, making it very hard to study for the test. Do not take this guy!

Does not care about student success and is not willing to accommodate issues around any kind of external circumstances. He is difficult to understand and tends to overlook important details when solving problems. While he is very smart, he is not good at teaching. Also, the book is mandatory for tests. If you don't have the book, you fail.

First off, yes he has an accent but if you pay attention carefully you should have no problems.  The homework is fair but still challenging and his exams come straight from class examples and homework questions.  Excellent teacher and if you write down all examples from class the tests should look very familiar.

Disappointingly unclear and not engaging. A bit hard to understand to due accent (but obviously hardly his fault). Class was very monotonous and comprised to example after example... Needed more focus on overarching concepts. Homework, grading and tests were reasonably fair and moderately difficult. Final was curved
Very hard to understand

HE DOES SPEAK FLUENT ENGLISH!!!!! In China, to go to an american college, he had to be in the TOP 3 IN ENGLISH IN HIS GRADUATING CLASS! He just has an accent but so do we ours if from the USA where his is from China. he is a great and intelligent person
a great prof. while the class was hard he explained very well in easy to understand terms.
Terrible.  Doesn't speak fluent English.  Doesn't answer questions well.  Examples are choppy and not presented well.
Good professor.  All his examples and test problems come straight from the textbook.  He tries to help students understand the material and seems quite helpful.

I had this professor for my Mechanics of Materials.  He is VERY hard to understand, and has problems answering your questions in class.  The class really shouldn't be this hard, but through this teacher's inability to communicate, you will have a VERY hard time in class.
Definitely has a bad attitude when she tells people if they don't understand something, the best option is to drop out.

Dr. Rader is a great professor and tries her hardest to give you the tools you need to understand the material. About 5-10% of the grade in her classes ends up being participation due to how partner based her classes tend to be so don't skip.

Spent a LOT of time on Java for a 300-level class. Semester project was interesting but had a lot of hand holding. Homework/projects read like tutorials (add function x that does y, etc). Code swap provided interesting challenge but was more annoying than practical. Subversion, UML, and Agile were the highlights of the class. Would recommend her.

Very willing to help.  She explains things very clearly.  I struggled in software engineering but she never treats you like your stupid.  If you need help with code you can just e-mail her your code and she will usually respond in a couple hours on how to fix it. Great teacher!!!!

Fair and enthusiastic. More of a professional than an academic if you know what I mean. Notice how the people who rate her low don't really bother to write much, which indicates that they probably didn't try that hard. Was an interesting class; too bad she had to water it down for the slackers.

Had her for Data Structures, Web Programming, Web Apps, UI Design, CS Field Session, and an Independent Study.  Tests cover the material, but won't kill you. She's incredibly helpful, fair, willing to work with you, and passionate about Computer Science AND Education.  She's not just a computer scientist who happens to teach, she's also a teacher.
not bad
No Comments

Not the greatest teacher but very friendly and enthusiastic. If you ever have a problem with an assignment just shoot her an e-mail and you'll get one back within an hour. I swear she never leaves her computer. Expect to spend a lot of time reading your bo
Wonderful Teacher, was able accessible and competent.

I had a hard time, but she helped out a lot. She's very enthusiastic about programming, which is funny and helpful. I showed up to the final late and she let me have extra time to take it in her office. Overall good teacher.

Always helpful and prompt in responding in her e-mails.  This woman knows her stuff!  Those that give her a bad review either are not comp sci majors or just had a bad experience maybe.  Definite recommendation.
Never learned much from the lectures.  Don't go, and you'll learn more.  Uses way, way too much jargon.
Expects a lot from students, but will do her best to help you along. Definately a good prof.
Terrible attitude... terrible teacher
OK
No Comments
Always wants to help. Responds to email and is in her office when she says she will be.
she is soooo good for explaining information and stuff like that, totally go to office hours adn you'll do well in her class
She is a good teacher i would recommend her
Tough grader, but the class is super fun and Allison is so sweet!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: When it comes to HNRS105, Prof. Caster really knows what the class is about. She was always excellent at explaining the ideas and topic of the class, although some of the discussions seamed really rhetorical and hard to follow. The assignments in the class I found to be incredibly difficult to follow and very specific.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Group projects

comment: Knows a lot about a wide variety of topics, great lecturer and discussions were insightful. Has high expectations but cares a lot about her students and it shows.

Allison is a great teacher for IDEAS. She really really cares about every student and is always willing to help you out. She loves teaching and really loves her job, and you can tell. I enjoyed her smile and positive attitude, and she tried to make class interesting every day. Just make sure you do well on the very little amount of assignments!

I took Caster for IDEAS in fall 2021. Shes a great professor and makes everything engaging but overall I wasnt a big fan of the class as I felt most of the discussions were a bit trivial. There were a handful that were pretty insightful though.
rating_tags: Caring--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Allison is a great professor. She now teaches IDEAS and not chem, and initially I was very concerned about what I had heard about her going into her class, but I have found that she is indeed a great professor. She makes great projects and discussions and makes sure that the class has lots of extracurricular opportunities to have fun with classmate

Allison doesn't teach chem anymore, but IDEAS is in the Thorson honors program. She tries really hard to be upbeat and fun. This class makes you dive into the meaning of literally everything which got annoying sometimes, but this was an easy A class in my experience. You have to make art and be philosophical. A lot of group work though
Caster is my Chem 125 lab prof. She is very caring about chemistry and is good at explaining things to me if I have questions. She is also a very sweet and bubbly person.
I was shocked by how passionate she is and that she actually cares about her students. Tests are easy and I never actually read any of the assigned book, she would explain it in class.

This was my first time taking chemistry, and by the end of the course, I almost liked it. Caster is very passionate about what she teaches. She is willing to sit down and help you with anything you dont understand.

Dr. Caster is a very helpful person outside of class, and I think is a great option out of the professors in the 121 dept. The DIYs (daily homework) are stressful but they do help me learn important topics that I probably wouldn't take the time to learn otherwise. If you take this class and do all the homework, you can definitely get a C.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria

comment: I chose to take Caster again for ChemII, she is awesome, sometimes unorganized but often available for office hours and help.

A really nice and helpful teacher. She almost confuses you more when you go to class, but she may have gotten better because I had her the first time she taught Chem 1. Really easy to do well, don't need to do homework, just practice tests.

Caster is extremely scatter-brained. She's the kind of professor that teaches out of the book without much variation. Honestly, you'd be better off reading the book. She makes FREQUENT mistakes in class and often takes the first 5 minutes of lecture to correct mistakes made in the last lecture. She makes about 3-5 mistakes per lecture.
Average

She gets confused with her own calculations sometimes, but she knows the chemistry quite well. She is helpful and has many recitations and office hours, and comes to lab. If you do the book work and the extra credit quizzes the tests are fine.
Although Caster tends to ramble a little, she is very nice, open to questions, and willing to help. As long as you do the online optional quizzes and the book work you will do fine.

Yes, Dr. Caster can be confusing at times. But, if you just pay attention and attend recitation, as well as going to her office hours when you need help, you will do fine. She is very passionate about Chemistry, and teaching it to students. She makes class enjoyable, and the tests are not hard.
This was her first year teaching a large lecture so she was a bit disorganised. However, she is a really good teacher if you go to her office hours and recitations. Very passionate about chemistry.

Caster is very scatterbrained when it comes to her lectures. It's usually pretty hard to keep up with how fast she moves and she's always jumping around with topics, often going back to things that she had 'finished' with five minutes beforehand. The only bonus is that she gives extra credit on exams.
Very scatter-brained. Won't explain things thoroughly as possible.
Awesome prof.

Doctor Dean is one of the best math teachers I had in my life. She knows how to make calculus easy to learn. Plus she always replies to emails and does everything she can to help students. She is super nice. Overall, she is a perfect professor.
Dean is amazing! She teaches by using tons of examples which I found really helpful. She is always available for office hours to explain anything you need help with! Loved her

Agata is quirky and nice. She explains Calc 2 very clearly and does well to relate topics as much as possible. Office hours are awkward because Agata is a bit awkward, but its Mines so awkwardness is the norm. I wouldn't want to take Calc 2 with anyone else.
She is the best. If you can get her, do it. She is very clear in lectures and super super super helpful in office hours
She is literally the greatest and made me fall in love with calc 2. Definitely go to office hours for worksheet help to get an easy grade boost. I recommended to everyone!
Awesome teacher.
She does a lot of examples and will explain anything in greater detail if asked. She's amazing!!
I took MATH 111 and 112 with her she is really good and her method of teaching is awesome she writes everything down and she always try to help.
The lectures could get quite boring at times, but she explains the material very well. Overall a pretty good teacher.

I had never taken Calculus before and so everything was very new. She explains the subject well but very quickly so it is easy to fall behind. As long as you do your work and make a decent attempt you can do well in this class.

The BEST professor at Mines! She will help out outside of office hours and continue helping until you finally understand. Her notes are very clear and consist of extremely useful examples. She organizes her lectures very well--there will be a day of review before the exam to answer and questions. Again, she is the BEST instructor I've ever had.
Best teacher I've had at Mines!
Great teacher! Love Professor Dean, she is very helpful and her notes in class are very clear. Tests are not awful, her review sheets are wonderful.
Great calc teacher! Would recommend her in a heartbeat! very helpful and clear. She writes the tests too so she knows what to tell you to study
Very helpful teacher for calc 1 and 2. very easy to understand and good with notes. Definitely recommend.
So far she is amazing!
Ahhhh yeah
Extremely helpful, everything is very clear.

I love Straker and enjoyed his class, but I am someone who loves reading and writing. As a senior, I have missed heavy Lit courses like this and enjoyed them in high school. If you hate working hard and using your brain in a humanities class, you will not like this course. I find Straker to be very intelligent and this class thought-provoking.

He has zero interest in hearing your thoughts on the reading material unless they align with his own, and your grade will reflect that. You're given little time on the weekly in-class writing assignments and his grading is harsh, vague and discourages critical thinking. "Discussions" are an excuse for him to gush about his favorite books.

Prof. Straker's sense of self-importance seems inflated, and it is demonstrated in his teaching. The coursework is tedious, and his grading and criticism is borderline unintelligible. The choice of "literature" is barely more than exotic pulp novella, with a tendency toward stories of men who are portrayed as heroes despite their preying on minors.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: Really enjoyed the summer section. Hw could be a lot if put off, but it also allowed for a more laid back lecture/discussion. First few grades (i.e quizzes) could be a bit disappointing but he gives amazing feedback both in-person and on paper on how to improve grades, and he actually recognizes and grades accurately according to improvements made
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment:
Professor Straker genuinely cares about the material he teaches. His insights into the literature he teaches in class go far beyond what I have ever experienced in an English class.

His grading is brutally honest, but if you put forward your best effort, his class will be a worthwhile experience
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Gives good feedback

comment: A lot of people hate his class because it is a lot of work, but he genuinely cares about what he teaches. He's really good at getting you excited to read the books he assigns. I used to hate reading for school, but I loved every book assigned. I just wouldn't recommend taking this class if you have a heavy course load that semester.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment:
Ambiguous grading policy.
Lack of lecture quality
Class without canvas
No idea what he talking about
No guideline for student who enroll late but before census day
Lack of announcement

Plus HASS is not 5 credit hour, but workload will be

Seriously, if he mentioned and knew that majority of people do not show up or withdraw he have serious problem

The first week of class was motivating. Straker claimed weekly quizzes (worth 30%) were to give students prompts for group discussion and to engage the class. The class average on the first quiz was 25 percent. Straker gave poor and vague commentary in response, then boasted about the number of students he failed in the previous semester. Dropped.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Straker believes that a "collective" discussion involves him lecturing to the class, and picking out students to make a statement based on a very specific prompt he gives. People be aware this is NOT a discussion course. Tons of reading, only one book was truly enthralling. Grades very harsh on your quizzes and papers. Not an encouraging teacher.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Tough grader

comment: Straker is a tough, formal English teacher. He expects excellence and will not hesitate to grade you poorly if your ideas are not sound. While I did curse his name often I found that his course taught me a ton about how to interact with books and write about them in a sophisticated manner. As long as you keep trying, and get help you'll pass.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Straker is a formal English teacher who really makes you work. He expects full comprehension of everything that happens in the book, and grades extremely harsh on the first few assignments. But he loosens up and gives a ton of extra credit at the end, I was getting all C's and ended up with an A-. Don't panic over his grading, you will still pass.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Tough grader

comment: Okay I think everyone is being a little harsh on Professor Straker. Yes, he is a tough grader. Yes, it is kind of difficult to read his handwriting. Yes this is a lot of reading. No, it's not impossible to get an A from him (I got an A and I'm not the only one in the class to do so). It's a tough school and he is a tough teacher.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Tough grader

comment: He took off points for referring to the Yangtze River as "it" when it was named earlier in the sentence. He made several typos in his "corrections". He over-hyphenates and frequently comma-splices. His handouts cite sources incorrectly and he deducts points when you use the same format (italics for essay names). He HATES quantifiable discussion.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: This lad has an air of nonchalantness. His quizzes aren't an issue, nor are the readings. His essays though; all ye who enter here, abandon all hope. He's got illegible handwriting. Even if you can read it, his remarks aren't helpful. Use small words and simple topics if you want to pass (took off points for "quasi-"). So far, nobody's gotten an A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: We have three essays over the semester. Class period: 50 min. For the final essay, were supposed to give a presentation a few weeks ahead and get feedback from him/classmates. With 20 minutes left in class, he cut me off halfway through on a whim, moved the rest of the presentation 2.5 weeks away. No feedback. Ill now have barely one week.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Straker is how you get a C- while putting in A effort and work. He grades terribly and has yet to give a single A in NHV, a freshman level engineering writing class. He will give you a bad grade with little to no explanation and is a terrible writer himself. He wrote an example essay for us and it was one of the worst I've ever read.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: Straker is quite possibly the worst NHV professor at Mines. He is incredibly vague about what he actually want in his essays and quizzes, and his grading/feedback is incredibly vague and useless. Even when he tells you what he wants and you then do what he wants, its impossible to get a good grade. No one ever gets an A, despite how hard we work.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Straker is a very harsh grader on both quizzes and essays. For the first two quizzes, nobody got above a B. He gave us a sample essay to base our essays off of, and then said that he would've given it a B at best. He also assigns very long readings with quizzes on the readings every week. Would not recommend.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Straker is a great professor and loves teaching his material. He has high expectations for freshman composition and will grade harshly. Quizzes are frequent and the readings are long. His syllabus is well-planned (it's never a mystery what's due) but the workload can be cumbersome and overwhelming compared to other sections.
No feedback on graded material and inconsistent grading

Dr. Ramey is really nice and knowledgable, but the lectures are very slide-heavy and focus more on case studies, and tend to be fairly dry. The quizzes were very difficult and hard to study for. The lab reports tended to be hit-or-miss with the scoring. Be prepared for lots of math.
Good luck!
