Ramey is a great professor who truly cares about his students and the information he is teaching. However, don't expect him to ever email you back. I had to get in the habit of going in person to ask him everything since he won't check his email. Nonetheless, great teacher.

Josh is a real G. He truly cares about all of students and will try his hardest to make sure that you not only succeed in class but also that you are doing ok. It is really valuable to have a teacher like this especially at a school like Mines. Josh made IDEAS a very enjoyable class. 10/10 would recommend.

Dr. Ramey is awesome! He tried his best to make this semester feel normal in his class. He is super understanding, very fair grader, willing to round grades; he has everything you'd like in a prof. He is very knowledgeable in biology as well. Amazing professor, recommend him for any class you can take with him.
Very nice and funny guy. Lectures were pretty boring but they were ok. Constant homework and textbook reading, lots of group work.
Josh is a homie. He genuinely cares about all of his students, and will make sure your mental health is prioritized over content. He has great lectures and even better office hours.

If you have the chance to take a class with Ramey, take it. He is a very funny guy who is obviously passionate about what he does. He made having an 8 am class worth it. If you want to pass, make sure to do the reading guides before class and go to lecture every day. Trust me. It makes life so much easier.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious

comment: Ramey is an amazing professor and he definitely knows what he's talking about. He makes the class fun, which makes the learning process easier. Do NOT take the weekly quizzes and pre-classes for granted and maximize your studying from there.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Amazing lectures

comment: Although I don't like bio-related things, I would take bio classes just to take Professor Ramey. He is very easy to talk to and if you have any issues in the class, you should go talk to him. He will do his best to help you out. He's a bit unorganized at first, but if you let him know what you want, he will do as you say.
The class is great, but be prepared for lots of reading and tedious lab reports. You will learn tons of biology.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: Cares a lot about his students! It's pretty refreshing. His lectures can be confusing, but he's very open to questions, and his tests are a little easier than you'd think they would be.
Dr. Ramey is hilarious and really knows the material that he is teaching but sometimes he doesn't dumb down his explanations enough when you are struggling to understand something.

Ramey is nice but bio is hard because there's lots of memorization and structured in a way thats heavy on self teaching. It's rough if you prefer traditional lectures. That said, you'll be able to pass by making up points in labs and doing well on HW and explorations even though exams are challenging. Lots of clicker quizzes. Unit 2 is the worst!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Dr. Ramey is an outstanding professor. He, along with his TAs, does everything he can to make sure that all of the students are engaged and working. You are responsible for learning material from the textbook before going over it in class and if you choose not to the class will be much more difficult. Overall super caring guy who teaches very well.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Dr. Ramey had to take this class over after our other prof got cancer. He did a really good job maintaining the structure our previous prof had planned (some take home tests). He is incredibly knowledgeable in genetics, and did a good job explaining the material.  Lab for this class is a blast (use PCR to amplify human genes). Very kind and helpful
Great teacher! Very helpful during office hours.

Ramey was a super nice guy and would walk around the classroom and ask how peoples' days were going. He was also very open to suggestions about improving his class. He didn't always lecture the material very clearly in class, but he did review before quizzes which made them easy. Lab write-ups are also really helpful toward getting an A.

What to say about Dedi. Extremely hard to understand, and got upset if someone couldn't hear him or asked him to go over a topic again. Loved to mess around with students, and he's one of those professors who truly doesn't care about the students or teaching. What a homie. Lovely man.
Yelled at me for asking a question in class about why my mate was backwards (this was the first time we were learning this). Not enjoyable at all.

I feel like Dedi went way too fast when initially teaching Solidworks. I was so lost and had to rely on the TAs to find my place. However, in later labs, he was easier to follow. Dedi definitely knows Solidworks really well, and he wanted his students to learn; however, I believe he could have been more sympathetic to students' frustrations.

Tries to teach Solidworks way too quickly and acts extremely condescending when we ask for help. He also criticizes students when they ask him to slow down, and he loves to humiliate students in front of the whole class. I often have to figure out new techniques myself because he is such a bad teacher. Avoid at all costs.
Doesn't know how to teach
I don't recommend
NOT GOOD AT ALL    I DONT RECOMMEND HIM    VERY FAST, DOESN'T HOW TO TEACH
Avoid him at any cost. He doesnt speak English, so mean, rude and condescends on students and TAs

Dedi condescends to students at every opportunity. He has a short fuse and treats students and the TAs with a lack of respect. He flies through the material way too quickly so there's not a lot of value in showing up to class.

He goes way too fast. It wouldn't be that hard of a class if he would just slow down and actually help people when they ask for it. He can be demeaning and rude. Not a fun class to take if you've never worked with Solidworks before. It's not hard to pass though. Just leave a lot of time for homework.

He would never explain things directly to me, as a woman, but would instead assign some boy to teach me instead. Goes way too fast and will not answer your questions or even look your way if you are female.  The absolute worst teacher I've ever had at Mines.

He went VERY fast. I had no experience with solid works and it was very tough to keep up in the class. I feel that he sped through the basics and expected everyone to just remember it after he went through it once really fast on his own.
This guy embarrassed my friend by calling her out for cheating in front of the whole class without checking the facts first. Not cool.

Seems like a cool dude on the first day of class, but goes really really fast. Hard to catch up, and if you're behind, he'll say "HOW DO YOU EXPECT TO FLY IF YOU CAN'T CRAWL", which is amusing, but difficult if that person is you.
He was the professor for solidworks. He went really fast but was good if you could keep up with him.
If you are a quick learner and good with a computer. You will learn to love his class(Like me!) If not... Well....Good luck!
He's pretty helpful one-on-one, but when he lectures he moves a little too fast to follow.

Indonesian with an accent, but it's the clearest accent you'll hear.  Very helpful, and will answer any questions you have even during the exam.  Moves pretty quickly though, so make sure you do the homework if you can't keep up with him.
He is awesome. Plus Indonesian like me.

Evans is the harshest grader I have ever encountered at this school. It seems that he takes joy from grading students' work as critically as he possibly can, to the point where he ignores the given criteria for an assignment and will give zeros on sections where even any provided work would have yielded some points, but instead, he still gives a 0.

Easily the worst experience I've had with a faculty member during my time at Mines. Incredibly inflated ego, really bad at teaching (often trails off or doesn't finish explaining an example in class), absurdly harsh grader, and profoundly unhelpful. He would often ignore posts on Ed that pointed out any contradictory statements he had made.

Very clearly looks at his teaching position as an ego/resume builder. Absolutely zero pedagogic inclination. This class would have been better served by a rock in his place. Only positive is that he appears to be knowledgeable, although he seems allergic to communicating that knowledge in any meaningful way.

I had Sumner for Algorithms Fall 23 and he is based! He honestly knows his stuff, and he is an actual software engineer. He is a really cool dude, and he knows so much about computer science as a whole. Genuinely is one of the best CS professors I have had at Mines.

He is an okay lecturer, but he comes across as very condescending and never explains things in a way that is very clear. He is an extremely tough grader and grades based on what he thinks is right rather than being willing to look at things in a different way. He is an extremely unfair grader and an even worse professor.

Sumner's only redeemable quality is that he is an ok lecturer. However, he fails to explain things in more than one way. This is also reflected in his grading. If you do not answer a question with the exact reasoning he is looking for, he will mark you down regardless of if the reasoning is sound. I have never had a more egotistical grader.
Fun professor, very interesting class, can be sometimes hard to follow.

His arrogance and disrespect is extremely frustrating to deal with as a student. Avoid him if possible.

Here is a direct quote of his response to a students Piazza post.

Student: "Hi! Do we have any prediction on when the final exam grade will be put into Canvas? Thanks!"
Evans: "You asking about it is not going to make it appear faster."

Sumner is not really the professor for this class, rather he is just a TA that is filling in for Dinesh. However, when he does occasionally teach, Sumner seems a little inexperienced and comes off a tad condescending. Also, this class has a ton of work, and they grade pretty harshly. This the class a chore and not very enjoyable.
Avoid at all costs. Heard bad things about Sumner's teaching but didn't think it mattered. Turned out it MATTERED! Horrible at explaining things and does not want to see students succeed.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Sumner is Based as hell. Totally relaxed during class and not a tight ass like most professors. Cool dude and knows the material cause he works a job unlike most professors. Good shit would retake.

Basically was just a TA and didn't even teach the class. Each week we were assigned recorded lecture videos from last semester from a different professor. Instead of class we would just have office hours during our scheduled class time. Nothing I learned this semester was due to professor Evans.
He didn't teach at all. REALLY bad at explaining things. Mumbles and trails off.

It is absurd that one of the most difficult undergrad CompSci classes thought that it would be enough to just give us a link to some youtube videos instead of real lectures. Even then, we didn't even get lectures on all the content that we were expected to learn. Do not take a class with Evans if you can, he is an awful teacher and communicator.

This is a flipped course. Sumner is more like a TA than a professor for this class. Everything he does in the class includes printing out the homework problems and handing them out. There's zero teaching from him and don't expect your questions will be answered thoroughly. Not sure what's the point of having him here when a TA can do all that.

This professor does not promote a helpful environment at all, I've asked for help on multiple occasions to which he has provide no assistance. How am I suppose to learn and excel in a class where the professor isn't even willing to spare a bit of guidance?
His ego-inflated behavior is also something that I have experienced.

Sumner is a graduate, not a doctor, but he teaches at least as well as any professor that I have had. He is respectful, quiet, and obviously very knowledgeable. The course is relatively difficult, but it is one of two mandatory graduate classes, so that is not surprising. Sumner is not ego-inflated as another review mentioned, and is quite humble.
Sumner seems nice enough but this is deceiving. His ego is greatly inflated and often needs to reiterate he has an industry job and what he gives up in order to teach the class.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: An absolutely amazing professor. She is so nice and sweet. I am an okay writer, but the things I wrote for her class were exceptional. This is because she gives clear and concise expectations and allows you to choose the topic you want to write your essay.

Interesting person, knows the ins and outs of art so you can actually talk to her about that if you're into that. Wants to see you show interest and growth within the class more than she wants you to check arbitrary boxes.

Rose Pass is maybe the worst teacher I've ever had at Mines. She "went blind" and ended up not being able to grade our papers, which led to a random teacher grading them. Since LAIS classes are so subjective this made no sense. Also, she was very old and frail (100+ years old probably). She should definitely retire from Mines.

Her class was fairly easy but if she didn't like you then it became much harder. She made some people rewrite papers 3 times. She's very particular with what she wants but not very clear when she gives the directions. She is also condescending.

Pass is a fairly easy grader but she is really specific about the writings. So don't expect to choose the topics or the way of writing your papers. She doesn't give lots of homework and is laid back when it comes about the readings. Likes to talk a lot.

Professor pass is not a hard grader and she doesn't give lots of home works. But she is very specific about the writings so you will not choose the topics or the format of your papers. So if your jot into that register with a different professor.
Fairly pleasant just a bit condescending
Excellent professor! Very friendly and helpful. See her in her office hours for help with papers before you turn them in and she will make sure you're on the right track.

She is the nicest woman and is very helpful during office hours.  I recommend visiting her for paper revisions BEFORE turning in assignments. Peer evaluations are helpful, but she tends to point out more.  She does teach higher level Shakespeare courses, so I feel like she has a higher expectation than most teachers would for LAIS 101

Took Shakespearian Drama from her, and it definitely wasn't a fun introduction to Shakespeare. I can tell she wants the best for everyone, but it's hard to meet her expectations. She talks too much for students to get discussion points, and she gives vague prompts for papers but expects us to answer a specific question. Overall frustrating class.
nice

Very nice teacher, although she has some speech problem and talks slow (which is a plus, makes it so we don't have to talk as much). You'll be required to talk in her class, but she's a fairly easy grader of papers (by my standards, I got a 3 on both AP English exams), but if you have trouble with basic grammar, don't expect a high grade.

Mrs. Pass is very nice and her class is generally easy. She expects participation and asks specific conceptual questions about the readings. She expects whatever instructions she gives to be followed to the t, so read assignments carefully. Three papers and participation make up the majority of the grade.

I've had two classes with Rose, NHV and Literature of War and Remembrance, and both were great. On top of that, after a couple of non-academic problems that started affecting me, it's because of Rose (and Dr. Tracy Camp from MACS) that I not only stayed at Mines but in school in general v
Only grades are the three main papers and participation(adding/repeating one point in a debate or discussion) reading is "required" but never necessary. No writing journals!
She treats you like a child.  I found it condescending.  She is easy, but it didn't feel like I was in a college course..or even a high school course.
Mrs. Pass is really nice, teaches so the class is really easy, and lets you rewrite your papers for full credit if you butcher it the first time.
Course is a joke.  Prof does pretty good job though.  Laid back.

Dave is a very clear cut professor that will portray her material in a way such that you are rewarded for trying and caring about the class. You must show up to pass, and there are at least two homework assignments per week. Be ready for a large workload, but if you are willing to put in the work, you will be able to succeed.
Dave is tough but fair. Somewhat unfair that participation is graded by clicker questions, but labs are easy and tests aren't too rough.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: You can tell she has put a lot of time and effort into her Digital Logic class. Her lectures are very clear and she makes difficult concepts easy to understand. The lab portion of this class i found most difficult. She is a very reasonable professor and clearly cares about her students understanding the material.

Dave doesn't seem to know past what is given to her in her lecture notes. She never knows the answers to any questions. Her class and homework are redundant and useless. Then she gives us programming homework that she never teaches during class. The only good thing about her is she is fairly nice, but she is impatient and bad at teaching.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Unorganized. Hardly teaches any in class. She assigns tough, long readings every night, and in class we only review basic concepts, leaving us to wonder about the readings we just had. Poor at communicating concepts, we have been stuck on big O notation for weeks, same material everyday.
Eh. Not the best, not the worst.
The best circuits teacher at Mines
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Dr. Dave was a great lecturer, but as the other reviews state, she tends to be passive aggressive or just comes across as annoyed when you have simple questions that she said the answer to in class. She has a fairly large amount of homework.

Dr. Dave is a good teacher for this class because she is very clear when explaining the concepts and describes what is happening with the problems.  She tells you when to stop writing and pay attention so that you can follow her, then gives time to take notes.  Core class, so HW is the same across sections and the material is awful, but she is good

Clear lectures and in-depth homeworks for most of the course help with understanding. Labs are easy. Tests can be challenging, but are relatively fair -  beware of little details she may have glossed over in class.

She does more or less ok with lectures and class examples but come for office hours and she is very unfriendly with helping. She gets mad when you ask questions that to her are obvious but clearly are not that way for the students.
Cool teacher.
Dave very clearly explained the material. It was always clear what would be on the tests. She was a very organized teacher and easy to learn from.
She curved the rest of the class but not my grade.  Reasonably nice person but she doesn't like analog circuits and it shows.

Gets upset when you ask for help or goes to office hours. Generally seems annoyed with students who approach her outside of class. Not the best teacher and her test are to difficult for the time span.

Dave lights up the room when she comes in. Her uplifting presence reminds students why they work so hard and are so passionate about their studies. Her tests are fair and she is more than willing to help you out in office hours and outside of class.

She was okay although she skipped the main part of the course which was to design a micro-controller and the theory behind ISA. She was pretty mean although she graded super - easy. I'll attribute her bad attitude to a situational factor rather an a dispositional one because I understand she just moved to Colorado and is trying to make friends.

Very mean and not a good teacher. She put very little effort into class and argued with students who asked questions. I liked that the exams challenged me, but the only reason I did well is because I self taught myself everything and ignored her. Teaching style literally the opposite of my learning style.
Nice professor who cares about students, interesting books. Comparative Lit was one of the best HASS classes.

This particular class was relatively free form and discussion heavy. Work was not terribly difficult but grading criteria was not always clear and seemed a bit subjective. Certain assignments seemed a bit excessive for a three credit class. I would say participation is key with Dr. Farca, that will probably carry you the extra mile.
Great discussions and books. Dr. Farca is caring and fun. Highly recommend her literature classes.

Dr. Farca seems to care about her students well being but doesnt reflect that in the course load. She is understanding about needing extensions if you reach out to her. The amount of readings is insane, grading is tough, and standards are strict. Dont take her if you want a good grade. Feels like you are there to get a major in English...

Dr. Farca is a good route to go for global studies. She will definitely make you read more than most profs, but the books are pretty good. Exams are essay based rather than vocab and whatnot that other global studies teachers usually do. She genuinely cares about her students and wants you to succeed - she is very flexible if you reach out to her!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Caring

comment: Paula is a really fair prof. She's passionate and knowledgeable and she cares that you put in a good effort, but she also doesn't pile on irrelevant work. She tells you at the beginning of the semester that the class is graded out of X points so you know how much every assignment will impact you. And the books she picks are actually interesting.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria--Caring

comment: Very helpful and intelligent.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: I have never been treated so poorly from a professor.... I would never take her.

I've had Dr. Farca for 2 classes. I took the second class with her because I loved her so much. There is a lot of reading, but as long as you read and participate in class, you'll do well. The books are also enjoyable and interesting. I am not the best writer but she has graded easier than other professors at Mines.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Interesting class and books. She has many sample papers on blackboard.

Tough grader, and sometimes very unclear. Posts what seem like will be really good rubrics but just end up being full of junk that isn't helpful! She seems to be pretty arbitrarily giving points, that being said if you talk to her and take her feedback and participate in class she will be far more willing to give you a good grade!
Dr Farca is knowledgeable, caring, and fun. Loved the books we read.

She will give you the grade she wants to give you, regardless of skill/effort.  Also there'should no transparency on grading, and providing proof your wiring is syntactically/grammatically correct does nothing.  Just don't take her if you like your GPA.
Tons of textbook readings plus essay assignments.

International students please don't take her class. Spent a lot of time reading tons of textbooks and wrote huge amount of essays and still scored C+. Is that how you treat an international students without considering how much efforts they have put?

Farca is definitely one of the best teachers. There is very little homework, reading, or much of anything else. The only thing she asks for is participation in discussions [which isn't that difficult]. She lets you redo papers for better grades and grades pretty easy to begin with. She makes the class as interesting as possible with discussions!
Farca is the best NHV teacher at Mines!
An easy teacher. She grades well and allows you to redo a paper for a better grade. There are lots of free points for easy quizzes and rough drafts.

Course curriculum is severely lacking. Theoroms key to multivariate vector calculus are treated as trivial with no proofs. Mechanics of problems are stressed as opposed to concepts. Everything done in the course is elementary and lacks any rigor. Take Job just to get by, but take honors to fully appreciate the mathematical beauty of the material

She is awesome!  I did very well in her class because of her awesome examples and explanations.  Notes were very clear, although she is a stickler about discretionary points.  High test grades, but somewhat average or low discretionaries...
She is awesome. Had a lot of fun in her class. If you show up and take good notes, you will do excellent. Most fun I have had in a Calculus class!
Ms. Job writes the tests so she will tell you exactly what is on them. Her calculus 3 class was a breeze
Best math teacher at mines by far, take the class from her you will do much better!
Awesome teacher!
she is so bad don,t take calculas with her
Great teacher
Very good teacher. Take calc from her and you will get better grades
Go to her classes and Calc will be a breeze.  She is good at explaining and answering questions.  She is willing to help, and if you are polite to her she will like you.
No Comments
Be nice to her and she will be nice back
She is an excellent teacher.  Plus, she keeps class interesting...
Very amusing, has nice sense of humor that works well for the class material and a genuine interest in helping students learn.
No Comments
Awesome professor.  Always enjoyed her classes. Gave great examples and made everything very clear and easy.
Great professor, with just enough non-related math stuff to make the class interesting, including cooking and fishing examples.
Great teacher if you like cooking examples.
Extremely clear and helpful lectures, good for Fluids. Respectful and considerate towards students, made the extremely difficult content easy to understand through examples and notes.

My favorite professor by far. I am really going to miss her class. It was really hard tbh but she explained everything so well and she's also very kind and helpful in office hours. I wish she'd teach Fluids II.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Beware of pop quizzes--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. Rickey is one of the best professors in the mechanical department.  She is caring and gives lectures full of example problems that help for homework and tests. Very accessible outside of class if needed.

Kelly Rickey is very sweet and helps students understand why concepts work and what they can be applied to. Her teaching style is perfect if you like understanding derivations of why equations work so you know when to use them. Overall, one of the better teachers I've had, who is very open to questions and helps overall understanding.

Dr. Rickey did an amazing job teaching heat transfer in the summer. She provided a handful of extra credit assignments. She had a lot of office hours and answered all questions. Heat transfer is a tough class but if you take it with her and put in the time, you should earn a good grade.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. Rickey was a wonderful professor, and I would highly recommend taking a class with her. I got sick through the semester, and she sent me zoom videos so I could catch up. Dr. Rickey also did group quizzes, and she would give a change to correct our answers if they were wrong. Take the class you won't regret it.

Heat transfer is hard. Prof Rickey does a good job of making it as easy as she can (still hard). She's available outside of class, and is generally helpful. Class attendance is essentially mandatory between the gaps on the posted slides and the pop quizzes in class.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Dr. Rickey cares for all of her students and has a passion for what she does. She will answer questions in OH and class; she is so smart and will clearly communicate steps to solving a problem if you seek help.

Even though I really don't like her lecture style, easiest 5 of my life. She is able to convey the material in incredible detail while keeping it clear. You will rarely leave a lecture with unanswered questions. No brainer if she's an option.

If you can take a class with her, do it. The one and only thing that is not amazing is that she is not the best at responding to emails. Other than that, her lectures and grading criteria are clear and she grades easily in the first place.

Prof. Rickey's lectures are structured around example problems worked out by hand, making it easy to follow along. Even when I have trouble focusing, I'm STILL prepared for the homework. By some grace of her teaching, information will filter into your brain regardless of whether you pay attention or not. Would definitely recommend!

Really nice professor, tries to make the smoothest experience for students, but I never felt like our learning suffered because of it. Very clear with expectations and homework, made the class enjoyable and a bit easy.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: This is my 4th time taking a class with professor Rickey (both entry-level classes and higher level) and I would gladly take more. Always super caring about students' success and very accessible outside of class. Heat transfer is a hard class but she does a good job of simplifying the class as much as possible. Highly recommend any class with her.

Cares a TON about her students succeeding. The only problem is she co-teaches this class with Greg Jackson. He creates coding assignments that she and the TAs can't even understand with the answer keys. Take this class with her because she does everything she can to get you out of this class (that you probably won't use) with a good grade.

She is very caring and always does her best to be helpful and accommodating. She does a good job with providing a lot of examples in lectures, and she's always available for good feedback in office hours. Homework fits the course well and is straightforward and fair. All the info taught in the class felt relevant.

Heat Transfer is one of the hardest classes I've taken, and yet Rickey is one of the best professors I've had. She explained the material well, and seemed to care about students a lot. She did a good job transitioning to the online format, with all of the covid-19 stuff going on. I would recommend.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--Caring

comment: Rickey is one of the most caring and sweet professors I've ever had. It makes the world of a difference to have an instructor who genuinely cares about you and your success as a student.

In all fairness, this professors lectures are quite boring. However, the material in the lectures is AMAZING. Her lectures are very clear and concise and very rarely leave unanswered questions. If you can keep your attention focused on her, you would be hard pressed to find a better professor.

Pankavich's teaching is incredible! I took PDE's with him. He is very good at explaining concepts and making sure you understand the theory behind the course. He also gives practical examples that give deeper understanding into high level physics concepts. I would heavily recommend taking him for any course.
Great lecturer and personable

Great professor who really knows what he's talking about. I also appreciated that throughout the course he provided a number of examples showing how what we learned in the course could be applied in real life.

Dr. Pankavich has the answers to all of the questions. Probably one of the smartest people on that campus. If you have the opportunity to take any of his classes, do. It may be a difficult course but he will talk you through difficult material with a bedside manner typically characteristic of medical doctors. Also ask about personal questions.
One of the best professors I've had at Mines, great lectures and cares about your learning. Workload is very reasonable
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. Pankavich is a great educator and deeply understands the material. He is also caring for his students and is open to extensions. His classes are a joy, and the workload is manageable. His grading can be nit-picky at times, but nothing too crazy. Would recommend!!

He is such a nice guy with positive energy, he would do his best to deliver the ideas in the simplest ways possible.
Even at thanksgiving, he would reply to my emails helping me about a problem that i had in math.
Overall, he is a very understanding person that would not go out from what he explains in the board or the homework's. RECOMMEND HIM !

Pankavich is almost entirely inaccessible outside of class, which is the entire time because it's online. Unaccommodating to students who are unable to turn in on time or do an assignment when he would like because of circumstances beyond their control. Only upside is that his slides are usually easy to read and better than the required $160 book.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Amazing (!!!) professor! Goes at a really good pace and explains things thoroughly. He is also super available outside of class with office hours.

He is by far the best professor I have had at Mines. He explained things so well and his lectures were very structured. All semester he got so excited about bridges, it was just fun to be in class! Highly recommend.

I took diff eq during summer 1 and it truly was an easy A. The materials builds upon itself so you need to understand what's happening in unit 1 to unit 3. You get a good review of how to do integrals from calculus 2, but calculus 3 is moot in this class. Really don't understand how the profs could stretch this class for a semester.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Dr. Pankavich is a clear lecturer, and the class is a lot of fun.

He's honestly mediocre at best as a professor. He's not bad to look at, and seems to enjoy what he's doing, but I struggled to get anything out of lectures. Homework every week is usually fairly straightforward, and he's open to going over the problem type in class.
He is a great lecturer. He always seems to know the exact right way to explain things so that they are easiest to explain. His class is also pretty easy.
Pankavich was a very clear and straightforward teacher, so I definitely learned everything by attending his lectures. However, they were very boring.
Great prof.  Learned more in this class than previous two years of math classes combined. Lots of work, but fun and prof always available to answer questions.

Steven's really cool. Although I didn't actually enjoy his class (lectures are often VERY dull and he kind of just reads you the book with extra explanation), he is very helpful if you see him outside of class, and is overall very friendly and cooperative.
He's the best teacher I've had at Mines so far.  I learned a lot in Numerical and he was always willing to help with my code.  Def take his class.
I commend Professor Tolga, who taught this class this semester but was prevented from making any real changes, for trying to scrape the Dinesh Mehta off of it, however futile his attempt was.

The grading can be very tough and unforgiving with minimal feedback. Projects might seem straightforward at first, but they're actually looking for something more than just a working solution, even though this might not be clearly explained which feels like a trap. The lectures could use some fresh recordings, and the tests are difficult.

Dinesh is a nice guy and has a pretty good sense of humor. My primary issue with his class is that in-person classtime is almost completely useless - other than mandatory attendance on Mondays. 

This is probably because the he supplements with lecture videos, which can be a bit of a bonus during review, but is also something to be aware of.

Dr. Mehta does not appear to want to be in class, making it hard to learn. There was only one lecture a week, and he only talked for 20 minutes, and it was incredibly unproductive. When you ask questions, he beats around the bush and often leaves you just as confused as when you started. Class average on final was 56% during fall semester.

Dr. Mehta is a very good professor. The class is difficult, but it is not overly difficult. Programming assignments are easy to get good grades on, and the recorded lectures helped me to understand the material. In-person lecture was only once a week when I took it, but the online videos are good. If only he didn't start including +/- in grades...

Dinesh on the first day of class stated that Mines was a hard school, so his class is going to hard. The content of the class is not hard at all. He makes test extremely difficult to complete in the time allotted. He also has really bad "lectures" that are just online videos that he made in place of an actual classroom setting...

Lectures are excellent, class is very well organized. People who rate 1/5 are just salty that the exams are hard. Dinesh is also very understanding and this really became clear when COVID happened. His communication and organization have been much, much better than any of my other professors during the pandemic.

Dinesh is probably the best professor that I've had at Mines. His lectures are all well organized and he does a good job of explaining things. He's also very willing to help you out if you don't understand a topic. The class is difficult, but I would much rather take a good teacher with a hard class over a bad teacher with an easy class.

Subscribes to the classic mantra that because Mines has a reputation for being difficult, he can make his class arbitrarily difficult with zero accountability. In other words, this professor does not care if you succeed in his class because in his mind, any failure must simply be due to a lack of effort on your part.
Projects had unclear motives and exams were made difficult for little reason. Be sure to study for 10+ hours and not be able to finish the exams!

Dinesh is an excellent professor who's been teaching the course for 20 years now. The course isn't bad at all and is super interesting, but the final exam is extremely difficult. Make sure you have a good group and you all have a mutual understanding of what needs to be done to do well on the projects, do well on the projects, and you'll be fine.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Dinesh is a good teacher when it comes to lecturing, and has a great sense of humor too. However, the class structure itself was extremely challenging. Group projects were harshly graded, and a big portion of the grade was by peer evaluations. Exams were also extremely difficult, so studying is mandatory. Overall challenging class, cool professor.

I don't know if it was Dinesh himself or this year's TAs, but the grading was ridiculously harsh in many places. Group projects are severely graded based on group peer evaluations, and your project grade can drop as much as 30% with even small variations in "Percentage of work done" (30-30-40 vs 33). His tests are structured to be very difficult.
rating_tags: Group projects--Beware of pop quizzes--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Mehta is a very good professor. He can answer any question you have about algorithm development, even if it doesn't relate to the class.

Had him for Algorithms.  A class I was ready to hate I found really interesting.  It didn't make the subject matter too much easier but I always appreciated his clear, and often subtly humorous teaching style.  He's a smart man and you can learn a lot from him.
Good techer. Interesting tests. Helpful!
Material is sometimes difficult, grades very fairly.

Assigns way too much homework and records everyone's participation. She takes social studies way too seriously for an engineering school, whereas other professors understand why everyone is there. Dropped her class and got a normal teacher.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lots of homework

comment: The actual redundancy of the course content past week 10 aside, Heller is a great professor that is passionate about her subject matter. She gives great feedback and is entirely willing to work with you if you ever feel overwhelmed by the overabundance of tedious busy work that this course entails.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: The amount of work she gives just feels unnecessary and most things she has you read rarely gets discussed in class while making you write graded online posts about them. She doesn't grade any long assignments for months and is almost never clear on instructions for assignments. Not a bad person, but definitely not worth the headache.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: She's not a bad person and sometimes the in class discussions are great, but the amount of homework is incredible and it never gets graded until the very end. Feels like your putting in lots of work and you never get any feed back on it like she doesn't care. Much harder than other profs that teach the same material. One word: Ridiculous
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: The workload is overwhelming and she is not great at explaining what she wants in her assignments. However, she is always willing to answer questions or listen to your concerns. She grades fairly and teaches the material thoroughly. If you like a challenge (you should since you go to Mines), then she is a great professor to take for this course.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--So many papers

comment: Lots of busy work, but honestly as long as it gets done with passable quality, she's an easy A. If you don't like reading, writing, or debating don't take her class. Never gave anyone in my section less than a B on an essay if you turned it in on time.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: She is a tough teacher. She's caring, and understanding. If you're having trouble don't hesitate to talk to her outside of class. She is more than willing to work with you if you're struggling in her class. She is a tough teacher and definitely gives out a decent amount of work. She's ezier than Professor Horan for this course, but she isn't ez.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: This was the the worst course I have ever taken. We had to do more work and received lower grades than other sections.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: Heller does a great job of teaching the material and getting students to participate, however she is very unorganized and prepare to wait some time to get grades back on papers for weeks on end. Overall I enjoyed the class and I could tell that she was one of the few LAIS100 professors that actually cared about the class and the students.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Gives the most work out of NHV instructors, but she doesn't justify it, so you're left with a heavier workload than your peers who already have so much to do. Assignments have complicated instructions that she'll change at will. Told the class that her class should be a priority. Counted absent of you don't print and bring 20 pg/wk readings.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: If you love writing lots of papers, reading unnecessary texts, debating philosophy or if you are a master at pulling thoughts out of your rear, this is the class for you. The instructor takes her class too seriously, and I guarantee that anyone who has her will end up spending more time reading and writing than doing homework for any other class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: Very good teacher, she may seem hard but in reality it's just like an English class...which people at this school don't like. She's very nice and willing to help if you ask. She is understanding and tries to give you the benefit of the doubt. Fun discussions in class!

stay out of this class! not that she is a bad person, she just takes her class way to seriously. after all, she is a law student. tons of homework and reading, probably more than any other class. she gives a midterm and a final exam, as well as three difficult papers! all the while, reading tons of articles. don't get heller!
Difficult teacher, but gives out good material. Only take if you want a challenge, and are willing to work for your grade. Good person, but sometimes doesn't explain instructions clearly enough.
Recap of Midterm, 1 A out of 60, no curve. You do more work than any other class, avoid at all costs. Stay away!

She makes you read so much stuff, of which you mostly have to BS how its related to NHV. Not an easy grader and she doesn't give you directions about papers very clearly. I heard she's getting "softer" but still avoid her!

She is by far the hardest teacher for Nature and Human Values.  Avoid her at all costs.  40 pages of reading and at least 2 page journal repsonse per week.  Does not give out A's.  Hard grader, grades on participation.  I have done so much work for this class and she still gives me a B.
She is one of the most caring teachers on campus.

Mirna is a great professor and a great person. You could talk to her about anything. If you just buckle down and do your work, and don't turn anything in late, you'll be on her good side. Be careful with skipping class because you are working with groups so it's important to know the workload for the day and your assigned portion.

Mirna's a great person, not so great professor. She doesn't know what she's doing a lot of the time and it feels like class is a waste of time some days. She doesn't explain the assignments very well and it's not clear what she wants from you. Her grading is harsh without much feedback which kinda sucks. Mirna is super nice, but terrible teacher.

Previous ratings are buIIshit because this professor is the best design prof there is. Our group ended up working really well and I received an easy A+. All of the previous peoples' ratings must have had a bad team. Mirna is so kind-hearted and is a must-pick for design 1. Just do the work and you will be fine because she grades easy.
Nicest person in the world but terrible profesor sadly, doesn’t really explain assignments well and doesn’t tell you what she wants out if it

Easy grader, but doesn't really know what she is doing. She doesn't know how to use a computer, so all the assignments are everywhere, and it is confusing when things are do, and what she is looking for in any given assignment.

She is very kind and approachable, but is super confusing! All of her assignments are poorly explained and open-ended, which means that you'll have to ask her for clarification all the time. If you communicate with her frequently and ask clear questions, you will probably be fine.

Mirna is a great person and cares about her students. Unfortunately, her instructions and explanations tend to be extremely unclear. Grading is also tough, especially when combined with confusion about assignments. Avoid her for design.

Perfect example of great person, terrible professor. Her course goals and criteria were always so vague, and I always had to ask her on my own time exactly what she expected from homework assignments or group work. If you're not actively asking questions and keeping her honest, you will have a hard time understanding what she's trying to teach.

Mirna is not clear at all about what the grading criteria are. This class is based around a single project and she gives virtually no feedback throughout the entire semester on whether or not any group is on the right track with their assignment. She gets mad at the class when nobody turns in assignments even when she doesnt give us the deadlines.

Avoid this teacher at ALL costs. She is very unclear and her teaching style is unproductive and chaotic at best. She doesn't grade assignments in a timely manner, leaving students guessing on what to fix in the many writing assignments. Mirna pretends to be sweet and caring for all of her students but her grading style does not reflect this at all.

Prof. Mirna cares about her students and she wants you to succeed. But if you don't try in this class, it'll show at the end of the semester. EPICs is a lot of work, so try not to procrastinate so much. The grading is a little tough, but it's clearly outlined. And if you don't like your group, sorry.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Mirna is extremely nice and caring, but the grading seems to be way off from what is talked about in lectures. EPICS isn't a great class in general, so part of it isn't her fault.

Great example of wonderful person, terrible teacher. Numerous occasions where the day before something was due she would tell us, or worse - tell us the day after. When trying to explain things, she would make it more convoluted than it needed to be and had to spend twice as much time explaining things.  4/10 would not recommend.
Mirna always  wants her students to do the very best they can. Although unclear with grading criteria and what's due when, she is sweet and overall a good teacher.

I had Mirna as a faculty adviser for Senior Design. She wasn't bad at all - very easy, and willing to help students, especially if you go in to her office hours. Very friendly, too, and tries to get to know her students.
Has no idea what she is doing, completely useless when it comes to everything. Lectures really slow and rambles on about absolutely nothing.
Fantastic Prof. One of the best I've ever had. Tricky material, hard exams, still got the A. Not sure why I'm reviewing him though - he retired :(
Awesome teacher made class fun best teacher I've had at mines
An awesome professor.  Honestly, attending his class was not a class just in mathematics, it was a class in life.
Helarious, a great teacher, and very inspirational!
Helpful and excited about teacher, though he can be scatter brained at times.

He is a very interesting person to be sure. Quite quirky, but on the whole is a very good teacher who puts in the effort to teach from more than one perspective so as to make sure that material is understood.
Rocks!
Awesome person, great stories, but a little frazzled. He is a good teacher, but not for the type A personalities... he is way too unorganized and scattered.
Great stories along with a clear understanding of calculus as well
Professor Ott is excellent. He is extremely good at explaining the material and his love for the captain.
AWESOME TEACHER!
Great teacher， puts students first。

He's a little quirky (you have to take his class to see what I mean...) but he is very clear, and extremely articulate regarding the content and his teaching methods. If you don't mind a little weirdness, then get Ott!
My Favorite teacher. He made class fun and taught alternative to the book that made problems easier.
Doc Ott is DOPE
Great teacher.  Also can "be real", and very funny
The man love the captain!

Even though I found physical chemistry 1 to be an extremely difficult class, Shubham made it enjoyable to take. He was extremely prepared for lectures, communicated with students frequently, and had very helpful office hours. Only reason I am giving the class 4/5 is because the grading criteria was not very clear, especially for lab writeups
Extremely dedicated and knowledgeable. Really cared for students and was always willing to answer questions.

It takes three things to be a great professor. Know what you are talking about, know how to explain it to others, and be a nice person. Shubham is all of those things. Although physical chemistry is by far the most labor-intensive and hardest class conceptually I've ever had. But it's honestly all super interesting. The class is curved.

Vyas does a great job teaching the amount of content he has to cover in a semester for PChem. His lectures did feel a little rushed at times and he focuses on derivations which wasnt the most helpful to me. He really cares about his students and would answer every question diligently and would listen to us when we had concerns. Overall great guy

Vyas is one of the best professors I've ever had. His material is tough, but exams reflect content covered in class and his lectures are engaging. He listens to student feedback, and often pushes deadlines (or even exam/quiz dates) back if we ask him to. He makes quantum mech approachable, and it is clear he cares deeply about students' wellbeing.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: I do not like the course. Allowing students to replace that course with experiences from industry would be much more useful.
Awful

Vyas is the man. You gotta take him. Pchem is easily the hardest class I've taken. I understood nothing about quantum nor thermo, but he makes it seem like I did. Top tier professor. He makes everything seem interesting and I loved going to lectures. He was super understanding and often gave extensions. Quality person. Take Vyas if you get a chance
I do not like his teaching Style.

Dr. Vyas did his best to teach probably the toughest class I have ever had at Mines, and as a junior I have been through the works. The class is extremely abstract and tough to comprehend at times but he does care about the students and take time to help when he can.

Words cannot describe how much I adore professor vyas. He is 100% the best professor I have ever had and will ever have. He teaches one of the hardest subjects, and knows it. As such, he curves the class so that the average rests at a B. I have never in my life met a professor that cares about the health and happiness of his students as much as him
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational

comment: A difficult class taught decently well. He spends a LOT of time deriving equations that are not useful on the test, nor in industry (unless you take the PhD route). Very nice man, though.

Overall he is a nice guy, but not a great teacher. If you like professors who leave on vacation the week before test Vyas is the guy for you. He doesn't teach much in class and its kind of a waste of time. This class could be taught in a better manner and that would reflect with higher grades.

Dr. Vyas makes a hard subject enjoyable. Vyas loves when students ask questions and gives honest feedback. He is very fair and listens to student feedback and is very willing to make accomadations. Go to his office hours and you'll make it through his class -- it's pretty tough.
Vyas is an amazing professor. He makes quantum mechanics understandable. He really cares about being fair to his students and is always extremely willing to answer any questions.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--Caring

comment: This professor is the best professor I have had in my time at this school. He clearly cares about the students and puts a lot of time and effort into the class. His lectures allowed for the difficult material to be understood much more easily.

I had him for Pchem, and he is wonderful. The subject matter is difficult, but he makes it understandable. He's always willing to answer questions and is reasonable about extensions, moving due dates so that students aren't overwhelmed, etc. Just overall a great professor and made the class enjoyable.
You need to attend lecture to pass the tests but he is very helpful in office hours and really cares about students opinions schedules and mindset.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: Ian was an excellent instructor. His lectures usually included 1-2 really involved example problems, which helped one get used to that level of rigor before tests. He is always available for help. He answers emails fast and will talk to you for as long as he can after class. Great man, great teacher, definitely suggest you take him for Calc 3.
best math teacher ever!!!
Great teacher!

Very helpful during office hours and has great insight and lecture style. I appreciate the diversity of examples and how he sets up the motivation for what we are learning rather than just feeding us a bunch of information and theorems.

I hadn't taken him for calc 1, but I took him for calc 2,3 and diff eq. At least for those classes he had lectures that almost always went to the time limit, and lots of explanations. If you attend office hours, he will guarantee you know the content. Overall a fantastic professor if you pay attention and are open to office hours.

Calc III is tough, but Ian is a great professor who really helped me understand the material. He does write notes pretty fast, but he'll usually slow down and answer questions at least a few times per class. He also fits multiple review/homework days into the schedule. He's a respectable man, and I enjoy his dry humor.

I had Ian for Calc 1,2,3. He is kind and makes efforts to get to know his students; is very good at 1 on 1 help. He goes at a good, slow pace for learning new material and writes quality notes on the board that are helpful for homework and exams. If you prefer a faster pace, maybe opt for a different professor. Overall, I highly recommend Ian!
He is genuinely the best teacher. I have followed him through Calculus and will be with him for diffeq in the spring. His office hours are amazing, and he will always explain the content to you. We
Just a great guy outside of class. Pretty relatable and is willing to spend as much time as needed outside of class to help you succeed. Lectures can be dense but they are all clearly focused; we

I actually had him for Math112, and he's a decent professor. Wordy explanations for math, but gave a lot of examples to show the process. Very laid-back which leads to little to no feedback on homework or tests. Overall, a little over-hyped for his chill personality, but just a fine professor.

Wrote paragraphs on the board, not a lot of worked examples, expected everyone to understand what he was talking about right away, not a very concise lecturer, tests were nothing like the practice and homework, expected everyone to know what was going on. Hard to reach him outside of class.
Great lectures and flexibility with students
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Took calc one and currently taking calc two with him. Enjoy the more conceptual style of teaching over pure memorization. Very enjoyable over all.
He explains things very carefully. If you're having trouble he will try his best to help as long as you ask questions.

Even though he is a little on the boring side, he is kinda funny with how he writes everything on the board and says very monotone jokes that make them funny. I liked him a lot. Good at explaining concepts and encourages people to try.

Ian is a great professor. His class consisted of a short 30-40 minute lecture and the rest was used to do in class work where you could ask for help. This might not be the best teaching style for everyone, though. One thing I will say is that he can sometimes be very redundant in his lectures, and can take very long to go through a simple problem.

Ian is a really nice guy and was always willing to help with my million questions everyday. I personally like how he does a lot of examples in class because I am a visual learner but that may not work with some people

I believe he needs to improve his teaching style because he spends the entire lesson on one example and takes forever to conclude it. Math requires far too many examples to be fully comprehended. I wish him the best, however if this is your first time taking calculus 1, please do not take a class with him.
He is a great person, but not a good Calculus 1 professor. Forgot more than I learned.

Dr. Haddad is brilliant and also very funny. He somehow managed to make learning some of the driest math I have ever seen moderately entertaining. He also frequently checked in with us to see how we were progressing through the assignments and was flexible with providing hints or extending due dates when needed.
Professor Haddad is amazing, he's good-natured and funny and cares about helping his students succeed. His lectures are entertaining and he's really helpful in office hours.
He's a fun professor to have an makes a lot of jokes to engage everyone. Work was sometimes hard to follow but overall a pretty good lecture professor.
Laith is so incredible & cares so deeply about his students!

Laith is extremely smart and does quantum mechanics in his head faster than most of us can do simple addition. He is a very considerate person and values student learning. He gives thorough and informative answers to questions that have helped to further my understanding of physics and math topics. Also has a great sense of humor.
Laith clearly cares deeply for his students, and he is always super helpful in his office hours with homework and material.

Although he is occasionally funny and entertaining, I felt as if he wasn't the best person to have teaching. Sometimes it seemed as if he hadn't planned out the lecture at all and was seeing the slides for the first time in lecture. I have done physics before so I did alright in the end, but that was not due to his explanations and teaching.

Laith always incorporates some sort of humor into his lectures, which makes them much more enjoyable. He goes in depth on physics topics and asks the class for questions frequently. Each time we go through a problem together, he asks if it makes sense to everyone and looks for questions. Clicker questions are participation only, which is nice.

Professor Haddad is super funny and has a very dry sense of humor. Even though he doesn't always explain physics concepts in the best way, he still clearly tries his best and wants to help students understand. He always has a great attitude and tries to answer class questions to the best of his ability. Clicker questions are a little tough though.

Easily one of the most understanding and knowledgeable Professors I have had so far at Mines. While I will admit his lectures sometimes were maybe not the clearest, we has super approachable in office hours if you have a few topics you need cleared up, and he was accommodating if you needed extra time for homework's.
Didn't answer any of the questions I had and never made sure we knew all of our material making classtime basically pointless.

Easily the most accessible professor I have had at Mines. Can sometimes get ahead of himself in lecture which makes it a bit difficult to follow but he knows this much so he does his best to answer questions thoroughly and thoughtfully.
I see a lot of people saying they don’t learn anything from his lectures but that is honestly just all physics classes at Mines, overall he is one of the better teachers to have for lecture

Haddad is knowledgeable on Physics but not very good at teaching or lecturing when it comes to physics concepts. I often left his class confused as he goes through material very quickly and without through explanation. I had to learn concepts individually outside of class to pass. He has very dry humor and does not seem passionate about teaching.
Very dry humor but really funny. Lots of reef/iclicker.
Most things that were taught by this professor were inapplicable to actual assignments. Attending Alex Flournoy's lectures were far more beneficial for me.

Professor Haddad was awesome! His lectures are very entertaining. Although he sometimes takes too much time in lectures, and the class is pretty challenging, he really cares about his students and helps a lot at office hours. Would absolutely take him again if I could.
I think he's great, although the class really relies on how well you do on the exams. Your worst exam gets dropped though.

I took his Chem 2 class and the lectures were very hard to follow. Most of his lectures were mainly "trivial" things that did not matter to the specific course or exams taken. I had to attend a different chem teachers class to score a decent grade on the exams. He is funny and caring, but when I was quite literally fighting for my grade. He yaps.

I am a huge fan of Dr. Miorelli. He writes on the chalkboard throughout his whole lecture which makes note-taking much easier than trying to copy from presentation slides. I did well on all the exams with minimal studying because his lectures were detailed and easy to follow.
Does not explain concepts well for people who do not already have a solid understanding of concepts.

This is by far the worst chem 1 professor at Mines. His dorkiness and love of chem makes him go on tangents and cover material that isn't at all relevant to the course. His lectures are long and boring. He is not respected at all by anyone and will often get cut short by the class leaving 2-3 minutes early. DO NOT TAKE WITH HIM.

Dr. M is a great professor, especially for P-chem II! 

He makes lectures as intuitive as possible (which is often tricky for things such as statistical mechanics and quantum mechanics) and is always there if you need some help

This was Miorelli's first time teaching Chem 1, and so he definitely improved with his lecture quality as the semester when on. Overall, a very nice guy who is willing to go deeper into topics and make sure you really understand, and tries to make the 200 person lecture engaging.
Really wholesome teacher, always made my day Very clear with the content and straight forward. Very good about grading

Professor Miorelli's lectures included occasional trivia that would sometimes make the lectures more interesting yet also detract from the material you were supposed to actually learn. Overall, he teaches effectively, and I would take his course again.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: I never really saw this guy so I can only speak to his role as lab director. He is good at addressing issues brought to his attention and sending out reminders and tips concerning upcoming assignments. The canvas site for this lab is well organized and everything is easy to find.

I was in chem 2 with him for his first semester teaching the course full time, and while there was definitely a learning curve of him having to learn how to teach this class, by the end of the semester he was exponentially better. The tests are hard, but he is willing to curve!!

I took AP Chem and was taught by many professors, but none were as awful as Professor Miorelli. He taught me chem. 2 in my freshman year, and it was a disaster. The difficulty level of the exam questions is not comparable to the practice sets or materials taught in class.

I took Chem 2 the first semester that Miorelli taught it. I could tell he really cared about teaching his students and I could see him adjust to what best fit the learning needs of the students. He often cracked jokes in class and was always willing to help. He also made sure to curve the test grades if they were overall bad.

He's new and definitely doesnt know what he's doing. Had to curve 2 exams already because the averages were so low, and we havent even taken the final yet. He reads straight off of the slides, which are already disorganized and hard to follow. He is very unhelpful 1-on-1, doesnt care if you're lost. Coming from someone who did above average.

He was a mines student, which does not show in his teaching. He reads off of the lecture slides and does the bare minimum when it comes to teaching and doing example problems. His exams are extremely difficult compared to how easy his lectures seem. Study guides only cover the bare minimum compared to the exams.

I loved Dr. Miorelli! He is your stereotypical chemistry loving geek! His lectures can be boring, and I can see how his lectures are hard to follow. However, I think his tests are fair- especially compared to the homeworks- and he is a really easy professor to talk to. He's pretty new, and for his first semester, I think he's a wonderful prof.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious

comment: Professor Miorelli makes a tough course even harder. His lack of experience shows in his test writing, often having tests that are too long, and contain very difficult questions. In lecture he mainly reads off of slides, and covers the bare minimum of each topic. This however does not stop him from asking about the hardest parts on exams.
WORST PROFESSOR I'VE EVER HAD IN MY ENTIRE LIFE. He expects you to work more than 12 hours a week just for the Web assign assignments! AVOID HIM

Despite his fast-paced lectures, Thaler is still one of my favorite professors so far. He is always willing to help during his office hours and cares about your success. He is so in love with math that he will repeat a concept over and over for you with no problem.

Thaler basically does examples really fast for the entire lecture. For some, this might be okay. For me, this was mind-numbing.  An approach like this would be fine in normal math, but not Calculus 2 for Engineers. If you think you can stand the lectures he's not a bad guy, but otherwise I recommend you steer clear or gear up for some self-study.

I had to start attending a different Professors lectures because, Thaler would constantly rush through his material, never throughly explains what he did, or how something is correctly performed.  I am understanding the material better now that I have a competent professor in front of the room.  in my opinion avoid Thaler like the plague!

Math teachers can be very easily hit or miss, prof. Thaler is a hit. He may not have been the most exciting to sit and listen to but he was a fountain of knowledge. Whatever a students question was, he could formulate and answer that was clear, quick, and understandable. If you want a prof. who loves math as much as Newton himself: Thaler.

Professor Thaler does a great job clearly presenting the course material in a neat, logical order. Take advantage of his office hours! He is someone who you can tell really loves what he does, and will do everything he can to help if you ask for it.
He was pretty good at explaining calc one. He moved slow but kept the class an interesting as it could be.

Thaler is useless. He is by far the worst teacher I have ever had in my entire life. I barely passed his class, and had several friends fail/drop it. He is impossible to understand and an awful grader. My average homework grade was a 43%and I spent hours on it (worth 25% of grade). I would not recommend him to anyone in the world who I care about.

Had Dr Thaler for Calc 3. By far the worst teacher I have ever had. Does not post grades at any time of the year. Is difficult to communicate with. His notes are not very useful and are hard to follow. I have never felt fully prepared for any of the exams we have taken. I highly urge anyone to find a different Calculus instructor.

He was fully willing to work with students on homework and to help explain the concepts and problems further outside of class when I took Diff. Eq. last year. His grading is tough but fair; math requires more attention to details that others view "trivial," and I commend him for grading on it. Overall, I suggest him to all my friends.

Isn't good at teaching the material, goes on and on about meteorology(which nobody cares about). Grades horrendously (don't write f(x) in some intermediary step, -4 points. Disincentivises questioning. Horrible teacher. If you have him switch sections ASAP.

Thaler doesn't seem to talk to the people who write the tests, he doesn't teach what's on the tests, and he doesn't seem to respect the grades that students get on tests.  He counts off for insignificant mistakes, like typos, and his grading doesn't make sense.

He is certainly a tough grader. If you are willing to show a lot of work to explain what you are doing, though, then you should be fine. If you at least show the amount of work he expects, then you would do fine on exams. Getting to know him in person is a plus too.

Took him for Diff. EQ. Worst teacher I've had in my life. Went fast, didn't explain well, grades tough, lots of proofs, derivations, and theoretical unnecessary stuff. Class averages on tests were wary lower than all the other teachers. Nice enough guy, terrible teacher.
Lot's of proofs, goes really fast, hard to follow, learning was difficult for my whole class, class averages wayyyy lower in his classes than in sections taught by other profs

This was a really hard class due to the instructor's inability to teach the content provided.  Would teach straight out of the book, which I could have done on my own time, frustrating paying a lot of money for a class you have to teach yourself.  I would avoid this professor if you can.

He gave a lot of hard work sheets that lowered most of the grades in the class.  A majority of our class had lower homework averages then test averages.  He relates a lot of concepts to weather since he is a Meteorolgist.
Super passionate about what he does-- accessible outside of class, funny, welcomes questions.

I actually took MATH 301 With him not 300. But his lectures are incredibly hard to follow. The proofs you just have to hope that you can follow an extremely boring and long proof lecture. He is not the best at staying on top of grading or ensuring that his students are understanding the material.
My Goat fr fr fr

Griesmer was super responsive outside of class, posted his notes and some lectures, and cares about his students. He and the other differential equations professors obviously want their students to succeed, and made this course one of my favorites classes at Mines.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Test heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Griesmer is a decent professor for diff eq, but there are better professors available for you for this class. His lectures are sometimes confusing and go too much into theory. He is a very nice guy though and I still had an alright time going to his lectures.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I would strongly recommend trying to get another professor. His lectures are ok, but dont expect him to be remotely helpful outside class. He will sometimes post notes? Sometimes not. He also will not give extensions or anything and seems to enjoy doing so. Personally had him laugh when asking for 1 day extension due to a hospital visit.
Griesmer is a great professor, and he's super passionate about the material. The one quirk I have is that sometimes it feels like he's a bit unprepared for lecture or lacks confidence.

I thought Professor Griesmer was a fun teacher even though he could sometimes be a bit awkward. He explained concepts really thoroughly and seemed like he genuinely wanted to help students. My only issue is that he was very stubborn about curving tests, even when the class had an abnormally low test average.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Really great professor. He gets really excited when an algorithm does something unique or interesting, which is really endearing and makes you care about the material. Super approachable. Asked him if he could do something differently during lectures and he immediately changed. Strongly recommend.
Professor Griesmer was a great Calc 2 teacher, always willing to help you if you're having trouble and many opportunities for office hours. TAKE THIS TEACHER!

Very friendly and caring. Gives great feedback on assignments. Replies to emails quickly. Extremely accessible, with office hours and and other meeting times. Very helpful with debugging code. Lectures well and hits the main points, just make sure to follow along, since notes posted after aren't always as thorough. All in all, awesome professor.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Lecture heavy

comment: Lectures were easy to follow along with and detailed enough. Any complaints I had are about how the course was run, not the professor.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria

comment: John is a very caring and sympathetic professor that is willing to meet with you about the material or other questions. Rowdy students can overwhelm him at times, but he does really care about his students and the material. There can be large workloads at times, but he is very sympathetic with extensions.
Pretty good.

I learned a lot from Professor Griesmer's teaching. Expect a long lecture everyday with many examples. Calc 3 was difficult for me but the thorough use of examples helped me complete worksheets. He is also very nice and very accessible. He has a lot of office hours and is very willing to help when you need help.
I enjoyed having Dr. Greismer for Calc 3, I thought he did a solid job and always had tons of office hours.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Tests? Not many--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: John is an amazing professor. He explains things clearly. If something isn't making sense to you, you can go to his office hours, or just email him and he will meet with you. Before tests he would hold office hours for 5+ hours over the weekend. He really cares and makes sure you understand what is going on in his class. He loves math so much!

Cool professor, would definitely recommend the Future Casting course as it transitions from a special topics course to a permanent HASS elective. Leads engaging discussions, reasonable with grading, and  genuinely cares about your wellbeing. The structure is still being ironed out, but IMO the workload was quite doable.

I absolutely loved having Prof Tucker, he knows what hes talking about and you can tell he loved his job. For NHV, he was a professor that did require work and some papers, but they were easy and he was very helpful. I would honestly take any class offered by him.

If you are looking for a blow off class this is not it. I genuinely love creative writing and took this class in hopes of improving myself. There were two large assignments as well as weekly assignments and readings- The class is not difficult as long as you put in some effort and attend class. I took it over summer so it was quick paced.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: I really liked Seth. He is a bit of a hard grader, but if you work hard and actually try you should have no problem doing well in his class. He cares a lot about his students and he wants to see them succeed. He is very helpful in office hours as well.
