Gives constructive feedback and expects a lot of you. Don't ask stupid questions in class like "what's a metaphor." Just do the reading and try to use key vocab words in class and in your feedback and you'll do fine. Lots of reading every week, but not stupid book reports and essays if you take his creative writing classes. His NHV class is harder.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Gives good feedback--Get ready to read

comment: Definitely one of the hardest LAIS teacher at Mines; however, I feel like I got more from his courses than anyone else did from their LAIS classes. I've had him twice now and I feel as though my writing has significantly improved from both semesters. Definitely not the teacher you want if you are just looking for an A in your required LAIS credits.

Dr. Tucker is awesome. I got my first paper back and was appalled by my grade, so I went to his office hours expecting a battle, but what I found was a professor that cares when his students care. He showed me what I could improve on and exactly what he was looking for... Received A's from then on. Awesome class discussions as well.

Excellent professor. Lead engaging in-class discussion and really cared about pushing his students to make the best of a required course and actually improve. As he is a writer first, expect him to provide ample (helpful) critique on all assignments. If you are looking to further your writing style or technique, this is  a great place to start.

At the beginning of our semester, Dr. Tucker told us that his LAIS100 section would be the most difficult, and if we weren't up to the challenge we should leave. I'm glad I stayed because I became a much better writer and reader in his class. Dr. Tucker pushes his students to practice. The more quality practice you get, the better you will do.

NHV is a required freshman course that not many engineers are interested in. However Tucker led the class with interesting and engaging discussions and frankly it was one of my favorite courses at this school. He required students to think on a higher level and was always approachable for help on essays or content material. Great professor!

LAIS 100 is one of those classes that Mines makes you take, but no one actually wants to take it. Honestly, I wasn't looking forward to the class. However, I learned so much from professor Tucker that I ended up enjoying it. He is a great teacher. He is very relaxed and funny, but he will also push you to do your best.

I learned so much more from this poetry class, than I ever thought I would. Seth teaches poetry in a way that is both technical and artistic. Take this class if you really want to work on your craft. Don't take this class if you want to slack of; Seth holds his students to a high standard.

Dr. Tucker is a phenomenal professor and wonderful educator. He cares a lot about his students (that actually participate) and if you're willing to work with him on your writing, he will guide you down the path of success. His input helped me win an award for an essay I wrote in NHV and get nominated for another. 10/10 would recommend.

Of the LAIS100 professors, he is definitely the toughest. He makes you write more than any other teacher. However, he gives you feedback on everything and I can see how much my writing has improved. He makes you work hard and you have to participate in class (and be on time), but if you're trying your best, he will grade you fairly. Worth the pain.

Great poetry class that blended reading and writing new poems.  Some of the workshop students didn't give much feedback, but not sure teacher could control that.  Seth is a great scholar of poetry, knows how to give good feedback so we can improve.

Seth seems to truly care about his students, and he made writing and analysis feel like they were important for our futures.  Hes also really funny and really smart, and changed the class around in order to help us with specific things we were struggling with.  Awesome, awesome teacher.

I don't like him.  Not recommended.  For example, b/c we didn't submit something to turnitin.com once, he threatened to lower our grades by a full letter.  He is a harsh grader, and can be very uncomprimising at times.

Funny Belgium gentleman. I love his humor but is not the clearest. Averages are always lower than in other sections. Heavy lectures and difficult worksheets. Was in office hours a lot but got through it.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: The first two weeks students were forced to struggle through problems by themselves (IN FRONT OF THE ENTIRE CLASS), for upwards of 10 minutes. When they couldn't figure out the problem they were mocked by the teacher. He only teaches you "tricks", which make no sense to a student learning it for the first time.
Worst professor ever - didn't even know the course material
Literally does not teach Diff Eq.  Even the TA admits it.
The funniest teacher i've had since elementary school when i thought everything was funny
Worst prof I've ever had.  Boring, tedious, and useless.

I took an honors course taught by him, and while it was pretty challenging material, I thought he was amazingly enthusiastic and very helpful. His metaphors are a little "out there" but for me that made the class more interesting. He's a brilliant man and will explain something 50 different ways until you get it.

Be prepared to teach yourself everything out of the book. He teaches as though you've already taken the course, and his only job is to provide metaphors involving apples, clouds, catdogs, and muddy cows. Seriously, those were all lecture topics.
almost too smart to help students
Avoid Willy and the ****ing Kangaroos
No Comments
doesnt actually teach anything
Very entertaining and good at explaining things.  Sincere love of teaching.  Belgium accent helps.:)
No Comments
Excellent professor, just be prepared to work
No Comments

Dr Hancock is a strong lecturer. She is very informed on her lecture material and did not discuss personal bias. This class is super focused on energy politics, so if that's not your thing, find a different prof. The exams are in class due to her trying to avoid AI use, but they are pretty easy. She does use AI to make assignments sometimes.

I believe this is the only Global Studies course at Mines that has a midterm and final. A lot of the assignments given were toughly graded and it felt extremely tough to get an A. Most global studies courses at Mines are relatively easy A's yet this with the exams and grading make it pretty tough.

Hancock's HASS200 is a nightmare. In-class essays, random mandatory sessions, and the only common hour final set her section apart—in the worst way. Grades are painfully slow, requiring endless disputes, and lectures are useless tangents with no relevance. Her condescending attitude makes the class unbearable. Avoid at all costs. P.S: SHE USES AI
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: She has a midterm and a final, both of which are MC and have an essay component. She has slides posted but tends to go on tangents that make her political views/opinions on topics obvious and leave the original content confusing. She also lacks in classroom management when it comes to people's unhelpful or even racist comments.

Definition of an average professor. You have 3 papers throughout the semester each worth 10 percent but only ten points so if you get one or two points off, your grade tanks. However, the midterms aren't too bad.

I took her for HASS491 Energy Politics and she has been a more than fair grader. It's an accelerated 8-week course, and it still feels very manageable. As long as you turn in your assignments on time and give an honest attempt, you'll get an A. I was nervous about taking her course due to her reviews, but I think those are now outdated.
HASS491 with Dr. Hancock was the best choice I've made at this school

It's honestly disappointing to see so many harsh reviews of Hancock. In my opinion she's a good professor who assigns a reasonable amount of homework. I suspect many of the 1 star reviews come from students who put off a 3 week paper until the night before, and are shocked to do poorly. Participate in class to get on her good side.

If you are looking at taking Global Studies in your next semester, avoid Kathleen at all costs. This spawn of Satan will make you write papers or reading assignments every week, and grade them as harshly as she possibly can, all while being as lazy as possible when returning your grades weeks after she said she would. Don't trust the high ratings.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Hancock is a political scientist (with a special focus on energy issues) that really cares about what she teaches about. At first I was irritated because it's LAIS at Mines (and who cares about LAIS right), but I ended up growing really fond of her. She'll make you work for it, but it's worth it. Effort in  grade out.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Sitting in this class is just not enjoyable. The papers and the citations she makes you do with them make me want to die. I don't know what else can be said about this teacher.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--SO MANY PAPERS--Hilarious

comment: I feel like I've become less intelligent from her writing assignments which are rote exercises that are totally focused on citations, not on critical thinking. She is a great example of everything wrong with Mines' LAIS department.

Very rude & condescending person. I had family troubles & she was extremely unwilling to work with me. Overall a mean person to talk to. Her lectures are dry. Allows absolutely no technology. Tests aren't too difficult. Papers are pointless & unrelated & hard to write but she's not a terrible grader. Take Horan instead.
Made assigned seats, absolutely no electronics were allowed in class, no talking, asked for opinions then told you why they were wrong.

Most students dislike how she doesn't let you have side conversations and cell phones, but its for a good reason, she loves her job and loves teaching. And she is very good at it, and fun! She is fairly easy and fair on grading too.
Uses power points that can be kind of boring, but is very clear about what will be on the tests.
Solid professor, unfortunately he teaches a hard class. He cares about the material and is helpful when questions are asked. Kinda sounds like borat which is funny.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: Lectures are really long and dry, grading is fairly strict. He is good about meeting after class.
Great prof good at explaining problems and admits when he makes an error.

Dr. Karaivanov does a pretty good job with FEA. His lectures were clear and a lot of test questions were directly answered in his lecture slides. He is knowledgeable on Solidworks and is great at providing feedback. He replies to emails very quickly in comparison with other professors. Definitely one of the better FEA profs.

Prof. Ventzi does have an accent, and can be hard to understand at times, but he knows what he teaches. Sometimes his lectures are a little hard to follow but he does provide all the necessary information to pass the course. There are also a lot of TA hours available and weekly review sessions that I would recommend when confused or need help on HW

He's very monotonous and mundane during lectures. His examples are boring and take too long so it's easy to zone out before he does the novel part of the problem. He frequently stops to ask if anyone has questions but I had zoned out long before so I didn't even know where to start. He will take the time to help you one-on-one which is nice.

He is a great guy that cares a lot about your understanding and success. His lectures are boring but super useful because he really knows his stuff. I highly recommend him for Mechanical Engineering classes. Also his accent is adorable.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Before COVID as an in-person professor, he was pretty good. Knowledgeable and available outside of class, generally helpful. After COVID when we switched to online, he did not adapt anything and actually increased the workload. Many students sent him emails asking to reduce the work a bit, but he refused. Not very sympathetic. My opinion is mixed.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Tough grader

comment: Very solid professor. Lectures can be dry and hard to pay attention to, but he gives helpful handouts. Lots of pre-class work and readings, homework is very long and cumbersome, but that's the nature of the class. Grading policy is strict (no rounding). Available for office hours, helps with homework quite a bit.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: His lectures are very good. He usually has handouts before as well to make it easier to take notes. Homework and tests are nearly exactly what he teaches in class. He grades things quickly and fairly as well. I have no complaints, other than he will generally take a few days to answer emails.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Solid mech with ventzi is solid. Try and get him instead of any other professors. The exams are not too difficult, but the homework is so much work. His lectures are kinda lame, but very informative of what you need on the exams. Very helpful in office hours and a nice guy overall.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Participation matters

comment: Hes a nice guy, but his lectures can be really dry. I learned most of the material on my own because I couldnt stay awake in class.

Great teacher, great lectures, semi-difficult subject matter. His grading criteria is clear; and you know just what kinds of problems to expect on exams. Helpful with all questions. A bit of an eastern-European accent that I occasionally had difficulty understanding. Still a great choice for solid mech
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Professor Karaivanov's lectures are actually very good, though I can see how some people would say he's a dull lecturer. If you're like me and only care about how well the content is delivered, Dr. Karaivanov is a great pick. Concise in his lecture delivery and laid back in his demeanor.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: I believe that attendance was supposed to be mandatory but something happened with the clickers, so I stopped going. The reason I haven't gone is because lectures are mainly him completing a problem, and I learn best if I do the problem myself. I don't have the attention span to watch someone do a problem, especially because the homework teaches u.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Solid Mechanics in general is a work-heavy class with lots of homework regardless of professor. I though Dr. Karaivanov was sometimes a rather dull lecturer, but he really knows his stuff. Near the middle of the semester, when the material began to get harder, I realized his example problems and explanations were actually very good.

(Math modeling)  Tankelevich was a decent professor.  Very funny, kind, and always willing to help.  You HAVE to be awake in his class because he tends to draw graphs in the air.  We all found that rather amusing.

I didn't have any problem understanding his accent. Every now and then he might say a computer science term differently than we do in the states, but it was never a huge issue. And as for helpfulness: I went into the class not knowing the language AT ALL (had transfer credit from High School using Java). I left with a firm grasp of C++.
able and willing to help if needed. Not a very hard grader. Enjoyable class

Full disclosure: I came into this class as a much more proficient coder than most of the other students. Thus, I thought the challenge level was just right (I thought 261 was WAY too easy). I really appreciate Tankelevich's faster pace and overall knowledge. I'm looking forward to taking another of his classes next semester!
I took Roman's data structures class.  He's a nice guy, but speaks with a heavy Eastern European accent.  If you ask a question, sometimes his explanation does not answer the question you asked!
Has a noticeable Eastern European accent, but it's not overwhelming.

He really REALLY knows his stuff, and wants you to learn the material, but it's extremely hard to understand him.  I had a hard time in this class, and I believe the only reason I passed was because I spent an extraordinary amount of time in his office after class.  He's very willing to help you though.  (The book sucks, or should I say "pamphlet")
No Comments
Really knows his stuff but can't seem to convey it at all. Also there's an assignment due every class.
He means well but is incredibly difficult to follow
He was terrible, only got an A because I took it in high school
Greatest man I've ever met.  Comparable to God, Moses, and Billy Joel
No Comments
die if you have him. he talks more about stuff you don't need to know than what you do need to know. or go to rader's sections of the same classes. and cross your fingers.
He is very difficult to understand.  I dont like taking his class at all.
No Comments

Dr. Smith's lectures are ok, but not super helpful for content after the first unit of Phys 2. You will get penalized if you do the lectures remotely as she randomly has the whole class select one answer. Your best bet in this class is to know the homework inside and out, but she is prob your best bet for a professor if you're looking for lectures.

Phys 2 mostly consists of you figuring out what the hell you are doing in studio because which lecture professor you have really doesn't matter, just show up put in your clicker questions and call it a day.

Smith is a great lecturer-she encourages questions and fully answers them, often goes through the homework problems, and cares about the content. She's not super engaging, but engaging enough to make the lectures worth attending.

Smith was a kind professor who knows the content by heart. She's a little robotic, but mostly compared to the personality of the PHGN department. She goes over homework in class and had hands-on whiteboard activities that helped a lot.

Professor Smith was very kind and flexible when I took her class. She would also always have the patience and time to answer questions whenever I had any, and would always guide me through the homework and help me understand what to do. Would definitely recommend for E&M

I quite liked Professor Smith. Her lectures were generally good, certainly better than the ones I got in Physics 1. Her office hours were very helpful, she knew how to guide you through the problem without giving you the answer.
Overall pretty good. Go to class and the homework will be relatively easy.

I don't get why Smith has a low rating. Phys 2 is definitely really hard but I think she is a pretty good professor for how hard the class is. Her lectures are good as long as you pay attention she does explain things very well. The tests are rough but the reviews she does really do help out.

Never understood a singular thing after lecture or in this class- I took notes and never skipped class but the notes never helped with the homework. I always had to go to office hours with the TAs- thats what saved my grade.

Smith seems to have improved from last semester. I didnt have her but she seemed confident and like she understood the material better. I did sometimes feel like she didnt give us enough info in lecture to properly prepare us for studio but a little extra work to look at other professors slides or google doesnt hurt too much.

I thought Prof Smith was good overall. She seemed nervous at the beginning. However, by the end of the semester, she found her stride. With even more experience (she is new to Mines), I think she will be a great professor. As a transfer student, my impression is some people don't know how good they have it at Mines, hence the negative comments.

She really isn't that bad. She's not the best professor I've ever had, but by no means is she the worst. I feel like people are hating on her just because she's new. I payed attention in her lecture and was able to understand most of the concepts from that. You just need to put in a little effort in lecture. She's fine.

Professor Smith is the most unprepared teacher I have ever had at Mines. She constantly seems nervous and like she doesn't know the material. In lecture she often doesn't know the answer to students questions. If you can I world strongly suggest not taking professor Smith unless you are ready to reach yourself all the material needed for Phys 2

Do not take her for physics if possible. One time in a review session for a test she was doing a problem that a student asked about and said to the class "I'm sorry can you guys help me out I get nervous doing physics problems on the spot." She is also not helpful in studio and occasionally will tell groups to ask a TA for help instead.

She was pretty okay. At the beginning of the year, she went pretty fast through her lectures but slowed down soon after realizing that her classes were struggling to keep up. Overall, she provided me with the info I needed to pass the class.

Not a good professor by any standards. Consistently loses control of the lecture hall making it difficult to pay attention. Also consistently forgets or does not know the material. Which is not good considering how difficult the course material is.
Dr Mansur is the most flexible and understanding. He cares about his students and prioritize the attendance and take it very seriously
Got a great grade in the course, but I regret not choosing a different instructor. Mansur always put us on edge. He'd pose questions and single out students who didn't volunteer to respond.

This professor consistently exuded an air of anger, which created an unpleasant atmosphere for my classmates and me. The tension became so overwhelming that I chose to drop the class during the final quarter of the semester.
Ermila is definitely among the top professors I've had. His expertise and proficiency in his field are remarkable. I would highly recommend him to anyone seeking a great professor.

I was eager to connect with Mansur, but man, his teaching is like a chaotic rollercoaster! Lectures? Unpredictable. Questions? Prepare for a tangent-filled maze! Exams? A mind-bending battleground where tricks trump thought. Calling him one of the worst instructors might be an understatement.
Amazing Teacher

Boring lectures. Exams were 70% from the slides. Exams with incorrect information or answers occurred more than once. Homework was usually a little long but doable (follow slides examples). Expect him to assign a project that has a small part you never learned about and you are expected to analyze it.

Dr. Mansur is an awesome professor. I have taken all the classes that I need to take with him for petroleum engineering from Rock properties to Well logging and my tip, most of his exam questions come from class slides and things he says in class. Additionally, the professor cares about and takes the effort to memorize all student names.

I took both 308 and 312 , as well as well logging with Dr. Ermila. He is by far one of the smartest petroleum engineers in the department. The material is pretty hard but if you follow his logic in class youll be good. Mastering homework is key in getting an A.

Ermila is the worst instructor imaginable. The exams had problems that didn't make sense. Even worse, he argued with students upon being confronted about this issue. Class problems were unintelligible as well. This person has no business being in a classroom. He doesn't have a good grasp on the material he is teaching. It's just appalling.

Mansur Ermila is the most atrocious professor I have ever taken. His lecture slides mainly come from wikipedia and slideshare. You're better off not going to the lectures because he gives bad information in class. His lecture slides are full of mistakes but he expects students to know the correct information when tested on exams. Couldn't be worse.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: This course is overall, but he makes it easy. Going to office hours would really contribute to anyones success in this course.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: He is very caring about his students and wants them to become better Engineers for the future. He really encourages questions and wants students to understand the material. His exams are easy if you read the book you will pass and get a good grade.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Professor Ermila is a joke. He may be knowledgeable; however, he cannot teach to save his life. He says that McCain Ed. 3 is the same as Ed. 2 but the first sentence in Ed. 3 says that the book is significantly different from Ed. 2. He expects you to buy Ed. 3 but learn from Ed.2 since that's the only one he uses. Worst professor I've ever had.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Horrible choice of TAs. He continuously chooses TAs that arent well understood by the majority. Their homework questions have nothing to do with the lectures for the most part. They ask of you to answer questions in detail and when you do, you get points docked because you didnt cover the details and they had in mind. They give no hints.

Dr. McGuirk is incredibly engaged in lectures and makes understanding the concepts easy if you pay attention and ask questions. He has a low tolerance for stupidity and disrespect, so if you act like a middle schooler, he's gonna treat the whole class like middle schoolers for a little while, which sucks for those of us who want to learn
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: This is a difficult course however I feel as if McGuirk explains the concepts extremely thoroughly. He is knowledgeable and accessible through office hours, however not very many people take advantage of them. He gives great in class examples so would recommend attending them even though attendance isn't mandatory.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor McGuirk is a great lecturer. I attended almost every class despite attendance not being mandatory because he truly makes the material easier to understand. This class is very test heavy and requires a lot of studying, but he is very helpful in office hours and the people complaining about test difficulty probably never went.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I loved the lecture; it is in line with the textbook given yet he does not require outside textbook reading, and you don't need it to understand the material. He covers it super well and examples in lectures are straightforward and he explains them super well. Love going to office hours as he once again explains the concepts super well.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: The second exam was very hard and he said "The last exam wasn't that hard" and "You guys didn't study enough". The average was a 60.
Bro does not want to be here
Phenomenal lectures, tests were tricky though but the time limit is of no concern. He is not transparent on the grading scale, so do the best you can do.

He is leagues ahead of Sellinger when it comes to the lecture, so if you're worried about another Sellinger experience, don't be. The tests are quite hard and the class could very well be one of the most difficult on campus. The grading scale is not clear so you won't really know your grade until it shows up on your transcipt.

Don't take this class if you can help it. The test average on the first test was a 74, which was "too high" for him so he decided to make the next test even harder. His lectures are good but he isn't a very approachable guy and I honestly am scared of him. His tests are hard and students struggle in his class. He has lots of office hours though!
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor McGuirk is an excellent lecturer, but not much else. He runs his class in a stressful way, and creates an unwelcoming environment in his office hours.
Overall, great professor, lectures are understandable and straightforward. If you pay attention in class, read the book, and work hard you should be all set to pass the class.

One attempt on HW problems is frustrating, especially since they sometimes don't relate to what you learn in class. Office hours were very helpful, but they often didn't line up with when the HW was due. The way he curves grades is stressful, but overall his teaching style is MUCH better than Sellinger (OChem 1) and it's a more enjoyable course.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He was a good professor as he was there to teach and help you learn. If you wanted a good grade you had to earn it such as going to his office hours and reading the book. So don't expect an easy time in this class. Work hard and it will show on the exams.
I've never met a professor who curves grades down until Michael McGuirk.

Going into the 3rd exam I had a B with the current grade curve then after the class had a high average on the 3rd exam (75%) he changed the grade curve to make it HARDER. This new curve dropped my grade to a C+ with 1 week before finals. If students start to do well he will ensure they don't.

Had him for Environmental Communication and thought it was great. Definitely his bread and butter instead of what I have heard with NHV. He does discussion posts and reading, but only one paper about the Mines Museum. The final project is a creative whatever you want, I made a short film. Don't expect to get feedback on your May assignments.

This professor is easy but his lectures are mandatory and torture to get through. He grades petty and with almost no logic. He also takes so long you grade things that by 3/4 through the semester less than a third of the class had been graded. He literally never graded one of my friends final projects. Didn't even look at it. Take anyone else.

Eric is by far the worst educator I have encountered at Mines. He takes months to grade items, put all grades in near the end of the semester not allowing for proper regrade request/challenges and if you so even look away from the front of the room you are assumed to be on your phone and lose points. Avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Assigns too much work, doesnt grade it
rating_tags: Lots of homework--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: Hated the class, assigns so much work
He grades things very late and extremely petty for grading.

One of my hardest classes I've taken, Eric never graded assignments on time, he showed up late to most classes and grades participation, but doesn't put them into the gradebook. Would not take again, and if you get him, try to transfer out.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Participation matters--So many papers

comment: Did not like the class, too much busy work and no time to do it. Never grades assignments on time either.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Took class a while ago, He's a harsh grader and if you aren't on his good side, you won't pass.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: I really enjoyed Eric Siegel's NHV class. Discussions were engaging and interesting, and he really cares about our well-being. Assignments are clear in their expectations, and I believe they were useful for further analyzing the textbook reading and videos we have watched. Overall, his class was relevant and fascinating for me.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: He hasn't graded any major assignments or given any feedback for us to improve future assignments. He also marks down the smaller discussion grades for silly reasons. If there is a graded discussion in class and only a few people fill up the whole time talking he will give a 0 to everyone else for not having a chance to speak.

He never grades anything. We have 3 papers over the whole semester, I turned in the first one 2 months ago and still don't have a grade on it. I've even already turned in the second one and started on the third. Also, all his assignments are pointless, boring, and uninspiring. Going to class is a complete pain but you can't miss more than 4!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: I am writing over a week after the last class, and he just graded a paper we turned in nearly 2 months ago. On the last day of class less than 300 of the over 1000 points were graded. To me, that is unacceptable, as it makes it impossible to "rewrite a paper" for more credit as he says you can do. Avoid if you want to know your grade at any point.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: Eric Siegel simply does not do his job. He basically never grades anything.
He often makes class discussions difficult and uninspiring. I do not enjoy this class. I would not recommend this teacher

This guy was great! Totally passionate about language and ideas, and really open-minded and funny, also supportive. I learned a lot. He seems to know a lot about all sorts of random interesting stuff. Cares a LOT about the quality of writing. I had to re-write stuff to get a decent grade, but he made his expectations clear.  Made class worthwhile!

Professor Latici is not a bad teacher, but can be a harsh grader, as well as a somewhat intimidating personality. While I think he truly cares about students' learning, and I ultimately did grow a lot with him as my teacher, it can be very hard to tell what he thinks of you/your work, and constructive feedback often comes as very blunt critique.

Harsh grader and his feedback doesn't quantify why you actually lost points. A bit of an issue with the Thorson program is that there isn't standardized grading, so you may get a C on a paper in Latici's class that you would've gotten a B+ on in a different professor's section. Overall though, his office hours are helpful and classes are engaging.

Overall, he was an amazing professor, the ONLY thing that made it difficult was the constant errors on canvas with due dates and accessibility to information. Many times you had to dig through pages of files or modules to find an assignment description or rubric.

He was a fine professor. The discussions were engaging and the topics were interesting. My only gripe was he seemed to be a very tough grader. He would give vague and unclear feedback on papers/projects. I would take him again but I would stay FAR away from IDEAS/freshman honors. Waste of a year. Wish I had stuck to NHV/Design.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Justin is a super engaging teacher but a really tough grader. There is a very particular writing style that he looks for and he will pick any of your essays down to the core to get it into his favored structure. He runs his classes in a very systematic way but will also allow for student creativity and chaos to fuel discussions.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: Justin is a great professor for IDEAS. The man is absolutely hilarious and makes class interesting. For an hour and a half long class, IDEAS went by extremely quickly. I have made an effort to seek out Justin again for future classes, since he is an absolutely great professor.

Justin is such a fun guy and he really is engaging during lectures/ discussions. He is always available for you to talk to him and give feedback to help improve the things you have or had to write for the class. Easy A class as long as you participate and put some effort into your work.
Justin is such an inspirational teacher and helps you learn and grow as a writer and thinker rather than assigning busy work.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational

comment: A great teacher. I really understand the material. A lot of writing and reading but thats overpowered by him being a great professor

I really enjoyed having him for NHV. There was a lot of reading but it was manageable. He challenged my opinions during class debates. Also, he offered to look over all of our papers and give us feedback before we submitted them for a grade. Not sure if anyone else took him up on this, but I got high scores on my papers because of this.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Get ready to read

comment: Lataci is an extremely helpful professor who assigns a LOT of HW and Papers.  He is extremely funny with a slightly dark sense of humor.  He stays neutral in all topics from Gun Control to who will win the World Series.  You just can't get a read on him.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: Latici is one of my favorite professors at Mines. Compared to other NHV profs, it seemed like he gave a moderate amount of homework. He always gave feedback on every assignment, and tended to be quick on grading things.

One of the more laid-back NHV profs from what I've heard about other sections. Only 6 1 page critical responses, and 4 were done within the first month of the semester. The papers are easy to write and he grades pretty fairly, you probably wont get an A, unless you're a stellar writer, but i'd be surprised if everyone in the class didn't get a B.

Latici is a great teacher but grades assignments harder than some other NHV teachers. He gives great feedback on assignments and has interesting class discussions, but most of your grade comes from your essays so be ready to write.

Needed to knock out my lower level NHV credit while taking some of my more demanding upper division coursework. Peers who had chosen other professors had the typically course load for this type of class, whereas our class had no lack of busywork, readings, and critical responses to write between each class period. Who  has time for all of this?

I had prof. Johnson for MATH112 and MATH213 and she was amazing. Her teaching strategy makes her classes very collaborative and enjoyable. I learned so much from her and it saddens me that I won't have her for MATH225. She is, by far, one of the best math professors I've ever had.
Great teacher who cares about the learning of her students. It has been great taking her for all three calc classes.

Prof Johnson seems like she has no energy in the classroom. The lectures I found to be pretty boring and she spends tons of time on proofs and almost no time on examples, which are arguably more helpful. If you take Johnson, she is very helpful in office hours but lectures were not very productive.

Awesome professor, explains everything in great detail and even shows proofs and theorems to back up formulas. Answers emails fairly quickly and always makes me feel welcome in her classroom. Even though she's new to Mines she's been an awesome math professor and I've gone as far to take her class for calc I, II, and III.

Professor Johnson is an amazing human being. I felt super comfortable going to her office hours and just doing homework, and I never felt scared to ask a question because she would never treat any of my questions like they were silly. I'm not sure why everyone has said she treats students like children, I never got that from her at all.
BEST PROF EVER !!
best math prof ever!

I missed class for roughly a straight month and she still remembered my name. She cares a lot about her students and makes sure to remember names despite having a lot of courses to teach. The lectures were good and she posted lecture notes from the class and previous semesters. The review/study guides posted were also very helpful.

Math is really difficult for me, but Professor Johnson really went above and beyond to help me understand. I went to office hours almost every day and she sat with me and gave me extra problems to try on my own. I never felt rushed and feel pretty good about taking Calc 2 next semester.
I had a great experience with Professor Johnson, would take again.

Challenging but enjoyable. I found the notes easy to follow and liked that they were uploaded to canvas. We had extra quizzes to help us better prepare for exams. A little tedious, but overall helpful. I missed a few days due to sports and was able to meet up in office hours to catch up on what I missed.

Professor gave thorough lectures every class, helped with activities, and sent reminders of important dates. Always present at office hours and gave extra credit for attending CASA review sessions. A little bit hyper, but overall just cares about our understanding.
She talks like we are three years old. She has all of our notes are super sloppy and written so badly you cant understand. she doesn't write emails back to you when you miss class for being sick.
She can't really answer your questions all the time.

Kayla likes to treat her students as though they are children and take extended periods of time explaining things that everyone knows. She gives difficult practice, and then when asked about it consistently does not know how to do it herself. Towards the end of the semester she even stoped writing on the marker board.

Professor Amery's assignments lack clear rubrics, making expectations unclear. His feedback often feels harsh, and issues with using Canvas add confusion, with missing or unclear grades and assignments. Failure to provide you with a grade in class till the last possible moment.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: One of the few professors I've had that hands out extra credit (in college, weird?) solely because he can not figure out how to use canvas and it appears he feels that this is an acceptable way to cover up his mistakes. His quiz questions are poorly worded but at least he is a moderately interesting professor.

He is not good at writing quiz questions, they are extremely confusing and poorly written. The expectations for the writing papers are not super clear. He often doesn't explain things in a very coherent way. If it wasn't for the fairly lenient grading, he would have been a 2.

HORRIBLE use of canvas - grading criteria was very vague. Professor is generally 'a dick' when providing feedback. Information in class contradicted other, widely agreed upon facts found on the internet.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Amery is a very kind professor. 2 Easy tests, one 7-page paper, and bi-weekly two-page assignments make for a pretty low-work course. The class organization was not the best, and his expectations and those of the TA seemed different sometimes. Despite that,he is one of your best options for a global studies prof, and the class was interesting

Very inconsistent grading. Expectations for assignments are vague and grading is harsh. He is a very nice professor and is accessible outside class and genuinely wants to help his students. Readings take 2-5 hours per week and are more work than 400-level engineering classes.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: I do not recommend Professor Amery. Study guides get posted less than 24 hours before the test. He grades inconsistently and super strict. Class averages were C- or below. Readings would take hours if you didn't skim. He would cut off students, talk over them, and have a disrespectful tone. Class was so unorganized, and the canvas page was awful.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: Professor Amery is a caring teacher who seems like a genuinely good person. I liked all the topics he taught and thought the homework was fair. The tests were fun, and the papers were very self-guided. I would be happy to have him as a professor again. My only criticisms are that the Canvas page sucked, and the class was sometimes unorganized.

I enjoyed Dr. Amery. He cares, is approachable, kind. 2 tests, 2 5-pg papers, & wkly reading worksheets - a very manageable workload. Reading WSs took no time at all. Grading on the lenient side, tho I'm unsure whether he grades or TA does. Class avg 86% for 1st paper, test 1 96%, test 2 95%, extra cred for class part. Good guy, loves his subject

Vague about expectations but a strict grader, not clear where points are lost. Lost 15 points on an essay outline for not elaborating on one of my points (even though it was an abstract). Multiple readings per week, some are 70+ pages. Opinionated and doesn't listen to other viewpoints. Class is supposed to be geopolitics but only talks about China
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Amery was a great professor for Human Systems. He facilitated interesting but respectful discussions during class and his grading was always very fair. He made a huge effort to collect and respond to student feedback about the class throughout the semester. We also did much less writing than other human systems classes.
Gives good feedback
He was fantastic. He is very engaging and makes time fly by.
No Comments
No Comments

One of the best professors I've ever had. He's very helpful, usually available to give feedback, and is knowledgeable about most CS topics. He also explains topics in a way that relate to real-life scenarios, making it much easier to understand. If you're even remotely interested in computers, I recommend taking a course with him.
Excellent course

He's definitely the best professor I've ever met! Really patient, explained everything clear. You'll make an A as long as you follow his steps. Most importantly, he has a cool attitude and is absolutely the hottest prof. on campus
LOVE HIM. He so helpful and always willing to answer questions. The projects and lectures are pretty interesting, and most of the concepts are easy to grasp.
Makes computer science actually interesting, easily one of my favorite professors
Great professor if you just need an extra class. Does NOT prepare you for future computer sciencecoding classes

Very passionate and engaging. Class is typically hands-on. Very organized, but sometimes too ambitious. Moves quickly, but always willing to stop and clarify. Very good at making things understandable. Funny, and seems to accommodate students.
Best teacher I have ever had. Helpful, ad cares about students. Makes programming extremely easy. Would recommend to anyone, he is the best.

Very engaging and enthusiastic teacher, though I'm glad I was already comfortable with programming before taking his C++ class. Also, he's the nicest, most caring teacher on campus; I see him approaching students all the time to ask how they're doing, and 2 years after taking his class, he still remembers my name!
Awesome teacher, awesome class.  I understood programming better than I ever did in CSCI101. He has a cool attitude and a sense of humor.

He's a wonderful teacher, I can't imagine having a better professor. He's knowledgeable, passionate and most definitely the hottest professor on campus. You NEED to take a class with him if you're a comp sci, he's just that good.
always willing to help and gives great examples that help you remember the material. The Hoff approves.
Best professor I have had at Mines. He's a great guy and a great professor.

Usually willing to help you with what ever you need. In the beginning, he was very helpful with homework, but in the end he was not and it was hard to keep up with everything. Go to class and lab and ask questions!
Every CS major should take this class (elements of computing systems).  Amazing prof, amazing class.

Pederson is like the super cool uncle who knows a lot (but not everything), genuinely cares about you and wants you to succeed, and will occasionally give you a hard time. I began this class with a concerning realization of how little I knew, but by the end I can easily say I have a solid foundation for making economically reasonable decisions.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: The best professor i've had at mines. His lectures are very engaging and makes it easy to understand the material with lots of examples and visual representations. He is accessible outside of class and makes grading clear. The exams may be a little difficult, but the other homework and assignments are fair.
Very engaging lecturer and has very helpful office hours
Very very nice and relatable guy. The class was very interesting and applicable to engineering.

Pederson was a funny guy with a lot of good stories. I thought that this class would be super boring, especially as an engineer, but he makes the classes fun and engaging. I think that this is going to a super useful class once I'm in the workforce, too.

Professor Pederson is so funny and super engaging. I learned a lot in his class. His pace is a little too fast - he could probably teach more efficiently if he just slowed down. The required textbook readings were also way too high-level for what was expected in this class. But the homework and exams were fair, albeit sometimes challenging.

Professor Pederson is a really funny and engaging professor. His class is honestly a bit too easy and I'm not sure how much I really learned. He grades really easy, and you pretty much can pass if you show up and do most of the work. He's a good person but he never wore a mask and never enforced it for other students even though it was mandatory.

For an introduction course, this is a good one. Easy simple and fun if you like to participate in class. A little bit demanding but not so much. Andy is fun and energetic. You won't get bored with him.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Group projects

comment: Prof. Pederson is perhaps the best professor at mines. I wish he taught every class. He teaches the material well and has super helpful office hours!

Amazing professor, available and willing to work with any schedule (was willing to do 8 and 9pm as well as 5am office hours with me to help with my chaotic schedule). He lectures extremely well, cares about his students, and will do anything to help you understand material including extend deadlines to give you more time to get a good understanding
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Pederson is a super fun professor, the class environment is enthusiastic and his stories are both funny and relevant. You are required to buy his overpriced textbook, but at least it is utilized. Only one HW assignment between .5-3 hrs a week, which solidifies understanding of lectures.

Great lecturer, he can make even the driest topics entertaining! This class is probably the most useful for real world stuff that I've taken at Mines. The homework is somewhat time consuming but he has 20 office hours a week so there's no trouble getting help. Also you can use the textbook on tests.
Andrew is a real gem. He is a great professor. I've learnt a great deal from him. I wish he I can take more of his classes. I will really miss his personality.
Doesnt get better than this!

Easily my favorite professor at Mines. Engineering Economics felt like the most applicable class I've taken, it has real world applications. Andrew is the perfect person to teach it. Reading the book helps a lot but you'll get plenty from the lectures.

Really nice prof and easy class. Good amount of reading but eh that's NHV. The "Sci-Fi" feminist comment from a few years ago is real and you will understand when you take the class. Get ready for some crazy readings on insane topics that make you pick a side (both are insane). Class discussions where fun, just participate.

She is pretty easy and class is actually reasonably enjoyable. She takes forever to grade anything but she is a pretty easy grader and gives good feedback if you ask. Just don't expect to know where you stand in the class until after you have submitted your final paper. She hadn't even graded half of our assignments from the whole year until then.
Very hard grader.

Professor Leone was a very fun professor who often taught the class with her own engaging content. She does split her time between CU Boulder and Mines, so it can be difficult to reach her on certain days of the week. There were also large readings and writings, but they were engaging. The lectures were very fun.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Leone is a great teacher! I was a little skeptical of this class and the entire humanities department simply because most professors from the Humanities department have poor ratings/reviews on here. Professor Leone is the exception for sure! She is very welcoming of your feedback even if it seems a bit ridiculous!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: Professor Leone is AMAZING! She was consistently optimistic and enthusiastic throughout the entire semester and makes the exploration between engineering and morality very interesting and exciting. She has a very strong passion for "Sci-Fi Feminism" so prepare to do some extra readings and watch more clips than other NHV students. Awesome prof! (:

I was nervous about taking a humanities class at an engineering college, but Leone picks great literature (and even some shows/videos) to analyze and discuss in class. She encourages you to follow and research what you are passionate about and is overall just a great human.

I know everyone at Mines hates on NHV, but Shannon makes the class fun. She's actually really cool and I definitely enjoyed being in her class. She tries to make the subject more interesting than it is, which is good, and she talks to us and treat us like adults.
One of the most outgoing, enthusiastic, and hilarious.
Her discussions are deep dives into ethics and engineering. Can be intense, but she is really funny. My writing is better after her class.

Shannon has awesome recitations for NHV; she is hilarious, and leads really fun discussions. She is a very easy grader, and this was hands-down the easiest A I have ever received at Mines. Although I didn't learn much, I had fun and would recommend if you want an easy class to take!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Graded by few things--Hilarious

comment: She hardly puts any effort into teaching this class so you will not learn anything. But, she is very lenient on grading and will give A's for days. Very hard to reach if you have questions through email, lectures are kinda dumb and she looks for small things to grade by as told in class, but if you wanna get an A easy she is the way to go.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Shannon is so passionate and enthusiastic. Very helpful comments on papers, very funny in class.

Her feedback given on assignments is always very intricate and well thought out. Prof. Leone guided our discussions in a way that helped with open debate but also clarified the intentions of the lectures.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Professor Leone is effective in that she assigns multiple assignments that require students to read the course material and reflect on it. This fosters critical thinking in the students. Also, she provides in depth feedback regarding papers. She is a fair grader.

I took Levine for Constitutional Law and Politics (HASS485). He is literally the most caring professor I have ever met. He brought Pizza practically every Thursday to keep the class fed (the class went from 6-9pm). As long as you come to class and put in effort like a good student, you should pass his class no problem.

Mr. Levine is such a respectful professor and an excellent lecturer. But I would never enroll with him again due to vague grading, never receiving feedback, not enough time for quizzes and exams (expects you to write several essays in one exam). I am a senior, this is my first C.
3 quizzes/final/term paper/term project/participation/attendance.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Here I am almost 5 years removed from taking classes from Prof. Levine, yet every week I am greatful for taking his classes. He made me think outside my box, was interested in each student, and genuinely loves teaching. He makes you work on the papers, but his tests are very reasonable if you paid attention and did some out of class reading.
I was always depressed before I took this course.  I feel very good about myself now.
learned so much about world views!
I brought my dog to class once, and he left knowing to bark the Gettysburg Address!
If this guy wants a raise I'd take out more student loans.  This class was worth every Abe Lincoln penny!

Tell you what, I am a rocket science major and you had to a be a rocket scientist to appreciate this dude.  He plays chess too, wicked.  Once he taught a whole lecture on one foot just to prove some point about something someone said.
If Einstein had been a lawyer ... Loved this class.  Learned how to win and be nice.
Before I took this class if someone asked what I wanted to do with my life I'd say "date supermodels" but now I want to go to law school!
Great class.  This prof is demanding, but fair.  Lucky I took this class before I graduated.  Now I know it all!
Changed my life!  Great lectures.  Only two lectures a week - I'd have gone 5x!
Best prof I've ever had.
Worst Teacher ive ever had
No Comments
Ochem is hard, you have to study.  It isn't Dr. Cowley's fault that you did not read the book.  His exams are fair and he is fairly helpful during office hours.
He was extremely helpful during office hours. During lecture it was a bit sped up so I had to really review my textbook and notes from class.

Tests are challenging, but he does not lecture well. Puts trick questions on quizzes that only 10 out of 150 students will get right in the class. When asked to explain, he shrugs off and says "Learn it on your own". BAD TEACHER

He is a great Prof at his office hours. Lectures can be unhelpful sometimes, but definitely read the book!! I did almost all the learning by myself, his lecture was just to review what I had learned on my own. His exams are not super bad, definitely study a lot! He is also a great prof to get to know personally.

Mis-graded the ochem 1 final, but made no effort to tell people that did not pass into ochem 2. After badgering him for weeks, I found out in late Feb. that I actually passed ochem 1 and should have been in ochem 2. Too bad that it was so late in the semester. Also, almost gave an entire lab section incompletes due to TA issues out of our control.
Good professor.  A lot of people do not like him because his class is really challenging, but if you put in the work, the class and lab can be a lot of fun.

This guy can be an absolute jerk if you get anywhere near his bad side... He will give you zeros for labs even if you miss them for family tragedies.  Does not explain the material well... Pity he's the only O-chem prof.
A hard class.  The key to success is to do all the suggested problems at the end of each chapter in the text, but to also do all of the problems that are in the chapter.
Talks about his life instead of teaching the material better. Tests you on stuff you cover after the test.
He is very helpful in office hours. Organic Chemistry was one of the highlights of my semester.
His lectures are horrible.  He uses power points slides given to him with the text book and alters them slightly for his use.  Going in one on one helps a lot.
No Comments

Cowley was helpful on a one on one level, but his lectures are lacking. He spent a lot of time going over easy topics, and skipped through detailed mechanisms way too quickly. If you don't keep up with the reading, you're in trouble. Learn to love your book.
Really good at explaining things on an individual level. Good to come in for general class help, too.

Tyler is one of the best professors I have had at mines. His canvas is set up really well, he cares about his students and is very helpful in office hours. Typical class is a lecture and then a worksheet. While attendance is mandatory it is worth it.

I had Tyler for calculus 1, 2 and 3. He was an amazing professor who cared deeply about each of his students. He would always make the effort to learn each student's name, and was always accessible outside of class in office hours, and extra review sessions. While often taught in the morning, Tyler's classes have been some of the best I've taken.

Tyler didn't teach us; he points to chapters in a textbook. Workload is massive in this class. It'll consume your life for 8 wks. Grades tests very hard. You won't get time to study for tests, there were multiple things due the night before each exam. Finishing exams in time is nearly impossible. Avoid at all costs. Take in-person version instead.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: I've had Tyler for Calc 1-3 and have literally arranged my schedule around having him as my calc professor. His lectures have examples and content to help you understand the purpose of the math you are doing, and he helps you through activities in class so you know how to complete a problem by the time you leave. He responds to emails fast.

I took 111 and 112 with Tyler and will take 213 with him as well. He's the sweetest! His classes are half lecture half activity so it's really easy to learn the concepts since you're immediately applying them. He's great when you ask for help and does a lot of examples/walk-throughs. He also responds to emails quickly. Highly recommend!

Tyler was awesome! He has his own lecture format and does examples when he's teaching. He encourages questions and uses half the class for activities so you can do the problems for the firts time with him there to help. I didn't go to his office hours but heard they were helpful.
Nice professor, teach slower compared to other professors but would make sure you learned it.

Really a great person cares about how you do in the class, but also how you are doing personally. Knows how to teach calculus clearly, and has a well-developed understanding of what you need as a student to be successful.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: I took Tyler for 213 and enjoyed how he taught. The reason I can't give him a five is because I dislike the fact that he uses almost exclusively slideshows, when I learn better on a whiteboard. However, he was always very enthusiastic and kind and his lectures were very efficient in teaching me what I needed to know.

I took 111 and 112 with Tyler at 7 am because I liked his teaching style that much. I would have liked to see the whiteboards used since his lectures are mostly PowerPoints, but even so, the way he explains Calculus made a ton of sense to me and I would highly recommend him to anyone who struggles to grasp new concepts. Great Prof!

Tyler Reed Johnson was meh. I didn't enjoy how he lectured through slide shows and sometimes he seemed slightly impersonal. Although I learned a lot and he had many office hours and was very willing to help, he definitely wasn't my favorite professor. I think writing on the board during lectures helps a lot when learning math.

Tyler was a great professor. I struggled in the class and he was incredibly helpful and understanding. His delivery of concepts was also great. He is definitely one of the best and caring professors on campus and if you get a chance to take a class with him, you should.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Not quite a professor but that doesn't mean he isn't good. Really cares about students in class, and sets up many extra office hours before tests. In my opinion, he gets a huge amount of material across in a very short amount of time. Never sees a dumb question, and I've never felt more comfortable raising my hand in any other professors class.
I loved Johnson, he is my favorite professor I had while at Mines. He is always willing and ready to help his students. I took him for Calc I and II, highly recommend.

I really enjoyed learning in his Calc 1 class. He kept lectures plain and simple, and answered many questions with ease and accuracy. I liked him so much I took his calc 2 class, and I plan on taking another one with him!
Really as best as a calculus professor can get. Only complaint is harsh grading but i mean it is math
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: Ellie is by far the best teacher I've had at Mines. She explains every concept well with lots of examples, and is willing to help you understand things better. She engages students in lecture too, which helps you learn the material better.
Best proff. Had her for Diff EQ. Best class ever had at Mines to date.
Diff EQ teacher for me. She was great, taught fast but was always clear. Going to class should be mandatory, I fell behind. The book would help, but it was too expensive for me to buy.
lets just say that learning the material is only one of the reasons I had perfect attendance
Great teacher. Lectures are clear and informative, grading is fair.

Very eager to help. she answers any questions about the homework, tests, in class notes. she gives really good notes too with many different types of examples. she is by far the best math teacher i've had at mines
Good

Ellie always was positive and helpful during class. Every email I sent her was returned within a day most within hours. She was a good explainer, and a strict yet understanding and fair grader. Homework is mandatory but helped almost everyone's grade, you won't pass this class if you don't do the homework, and you shouldn't be in it if you can.
Very helpful teacher, very nice and humorous. It was actually a fun Calculus 2 class, even though I had to retake it.
Very clear about what you're going to be tested on.  Watch out for the tank problem.
No Comments
Really eager to help students understand and gives lots of examples.  Homework was not required but is highly recommended.
Textbook homework is required

One of the best professors in the EE department. Although her teaching style is a little different I found it to be more useful than just straight lecture. So far its been my favorite class this semester and she sympathizes that we are actual human beings rather than student robots. I would highly recommend for any class she teaches.
I didn't 100% love her teaching style, but by the end of the class I learned a lot and didn't have anything against her. She was very available for office hours

A great professor! She's very kind yet firm. Highly recommend for electromagnetics. Tests were very doable and she grades pretty easily, plus you can do re-work for some points back. Gives great guidance, very organized, and the really fosters a learning environment.
Great prof.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Honestly the worst professor I've had at my time at Mines. She tries to implement the "alternate learning" method where students read the textbook outside of class and come to class to work on problems. Really its just her wandering around the room not offering any help while kids struggle. She's also an awful grader and attendence is mandatory.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Dr. Claussen's lectures are focused heavily on example problems and in-class participation. She always preludes these example problems with working through a problem as a class and her own lecture notes that she prints and hands out so you can easily follow along. Thought she was an excellent professor for learning introductory circuits.
rating_tags: Respected--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Stephanie has a unique teaching style, which works for some but not for others.  She tends to speed through lecture and requests students to work through examples in class to get hands on work.  However, if you are lost during the lecture how can you work through examples on your own.  Her teaching style did not work for me.

Dr. Claussen is the best professor int he EE department. She clearly has a passion for teaching, and for helping students.  Class is not easy, but attending lectures and participating in class is enough to do well in class.  This is the first time in a long time I have genuinely enjoyed class, because she makes students WANT to learn more. 1010

Dr. Claussen was engaging with the students.  She did force group work (hardly, it lasted maybe 2-3min at a time) for a number of reasons, 1.) Learn to work with others 2.) Short breaks from lecture that can get monotonous 3.) Many learn better this way.  The short breaks were beneficial to me at least.  I would definitely recommend Dr. Claussen.

Claussen cares more about students understanding and learning than most EE professors at Mines. Lectures are engaging and clear, she gives a lot of extra material and practice exams to compensate for the text, and she is very helpful in office hours.
Great professor. Always helpful, organized, and cares about every student's success. She expects you to work for your grade, but if you put in the time, her classes are informative and very fair
Really helpful in office hours and good at providing well constructed notes.
Claussen is a pretty decent professor. Her teaching style might not be for everyone, but she's really smart and was really helpful.
Don't know if she's ever been in the field working as an actual Electrical Engineer...but she can't answer most practical questions. Find Ammerman instead!
Pay attention to lectures and you'll be fine. Start the labs early and ask questions in class. Semester starts easy but gets hard and dense towards the end.

Dr. Munson's class was always one I looked forward to. She was so passionate about teaching, very kind, and always excited to be there. Her energy made me excited to do the work, and she was so open to questions (even when my questions were stupid). Doing the work and making a genuine effort will get you very far. I highly recommend her!

Dr. Munson is my favorite professor at Mines. I have had her for Math 335 (Intro to Mathematical Statistics) and Math 324 (Intro to Statistical Modeling), and she is simply the best. Her lectures are unparalleled in quality! She explains things super well and gives lots of good practices problems. Her homework, exams, and projects are reasonable!

Dr. Munson is awesome. You can tell that she loves her job. The class has a ton of homework, but she gives time in class, and is very accessible and helpful in office hours. She is approachable, kind, and a great teacher. Her lectures are thorough and you can access them, and she makes sure you are prepared for exams.

Dr. Munson is one of the best professors at Mines. She is thoughtful, understanding, incredibly knowledgable, and always in a great mood. Her classes are actually relaxing and thought provoking. The tests are exactly what she teaches, the homework is exactly what she teaches. No busywork. This is how classes should be.
Be prepared for her to test on questions that are much harder than anything she prepares you for
She is the most caring professor I have ever had and it shows in her teaching style. She always checks to make sure you are understanding the content and is thorough with her explanations of topics.

Professor Munson is one of the best professors at Mines. She gives great lectures and assigns intuitive but challenging homeworks every week. She is also empathetic toward his students schedules and problems. There is really very little that Professor Munson does poorly as teacher.

Definitely one of the best math teachers I have had at Mines, and by far the best in the Statistics department. If you can take her, you will not regret it. Her class is not easy, but she makes her expectations very clear and always works to give you partial credit. You can really tell that she cares about her students.
professor munson really cares about educating the whole student, not just teaching you statistics. I would highly recommend anyone to take this class

Dr. Munson is the best professor that I have had in the math department during my time at Mines. She is very patient and is accessible outside of class and is always very helpful. I would definitely recommend her!

I joined this class 2 weeks in (I know, bad move) but Ashlyn was so sweet with helping me get caught up and I was able to get into the flow of things quickly. She's very helpful during office hours and the homeworks are easy and reflect what's on her tests. She also makes jokes, so you won't get bored in her lectures and she does a lot of examples.
Dr. Munson is a wonderful teacher for Pro-Stats. She is really good at getting material across in a simple and efficient manner.

Dr. Munson is really sweet and very funny. She is young enough to still remember what it's like to be a student and is very understanding. She also attended Mines as a student so she completely understands.
Sean is a goat
Profesor Sean is a caring individual amid a core required class that makes students feel invisible.
He is a great teacher, he goes at a fast pace but that helped because we finished sections faster and had a lot of in class time for questions and review.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Test heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Sean really cares about his students. His lectures are very entertaining and active. He gives ton of examples and reviews before exams. I strongly suggest taking class with him. He is the GOAT!
Sean Farrel is perhaps the best math professor I have known at Mines.

Professor Farell was very accessible to all of his students and made an effort to know all his students by name. His lectures were well paced and he provided good examples. Additionally, he made sure to give us with lots of review materials that helped me do well on exams. If given the chance, I would absolutely take his class again.

Sean T Farrell is very easy to connect with and have a good experience with. He made a point of getting to know each and every one of his students and made sure to have a good time throughout the semester. Although there are times he does go a bit fast, he is very good at answering questions and has many office hours throughout the week.

Professor Farell moves very fast which can sometimes be confusing. However, he offered lots of office hours and you can tell he genuinely cares about his students and their success. He makes sure you have the opportunity to be successful. Make sure you attend lectures and reach out for help if confused. 
He has a good sense of humor as well.

If you have the option take Sean's class! His lectures were not only easy to follow, but fast paced, which meant he did several review days before exams as he was ahead of other classes. He is very interactive in his help hours and will spend quality time making sure you personally understand the material.

I certainly have mixed feelings after taking Professor Farell's Calc 2 class. He is definitely a nice person and would be a good friend to have. However, I had such a hard time following along with his lectures. He seemed to misspeak a lot, and it made topics confusing.
He's the goat. Makes connections with his students and is actively invested in their learning throughout the course of the class.
Sean knows his stuff, and is hilarious. He is always willing to help people understand the content. Office hours are under a tree. Big hat.
Me and Sean are besties. He's a true homie, and he likes to teach, you can tell. He stops class and reteaches if anyone has questions. 10/10 would take again

Sean is amazing, he works fast but happily reworks problems if people have questions. Compiles practice problems, makes review videos, tells you in advance what you need to memorize for exams, and has his office hours under a tree. Plays Rihanna before class and has the best cats of any teacher at Mines. Also dresses up for Halloween.
Hacked my computer network and threatened me.
rating_tags: So many papers--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Dejun yang's class is 50% presentations, There is no other material after halfway through the semester. These presentations are long and arduous and expect him to ream you while you are presenting for no reason other than spite. Horrible professor. Avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Tough grader--So many papers--Graded by few things

comment:
DJ Yang does not know how to teach even remotely. Half the grade is just presentations in the latter half of the semester ALL OF WHICH YOU MUST ATTEND.

Avoid at all costs!

Dejun yang is not a good professor, his class primarily relies on presentations and papers instead of actually teaching you anything you will be instead teaching yourself and getting graded by other students on your presentations. Terrible. Would not take again.

His teaching style is by far the worst I have ever seen and wished that the school would do something about it. He does a flipped classroom, in which you watch prerecorded videos, that you can't ask questions during, and his handwriting is hard to read. He also makes you type everything in latex which is just busy work for no apparent reason.

Dr. Yang is an amazing professor, he had a deep knowledge of his subjects and his lectures reflect this. While he will have some hard assignments he is very fair and most of the difficulty comes from his desire to instill deeper thinking. He has prepared me excellently as a computer scientist and is one of the best profs at Mines.

DJ may be an easy teacher, but if you actually want to learn anything, I wouldn't recommend. The last 7 weeks of classes are only student presentations, and nearly everything is peer-graded on a scale of 1-5. Also, a three question quiz (also made by students) is worth the same weight as the final 5 page paper? Feels like lazy teaching.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Very nice grading scale 90 = A and 87 = A- Lectures are not needed to do well in the class but are still nice. HW and tests were graded somewhat fast (1-2 weeks after turning them in). The final this semester was somewhat brutal though. Oh and the 2 take home midterms were very nice.

My main complaint is about the homework. Not necessarily hard, but long. He refuses to accept handwritten work, which I frankly think is ridiculous. I would say that 75% of my time spent doing homework is spent trying to type my work into word and deal with his awful formatting. It is infuriating and genuinely ruins my day sometimes.

DJ was a pretty strong professor for discrete this fall. The class was flipped and hybrid, so you watched the lectures he uploaded to youtube and did practice problems in class (attended Tuesday or Thursday). The class grade is from 10 homework assignments, two midterms, and a final, but there is a generous curve. Pretty nice guy
