The pacing of that class is a little off and the last month had content put on heavy. It can be hard to understand what he's trying to explain, but you can be ready for the exam from homework and example problems.

DJ brings a calming and laid back presence to a classroom. Just note, if you sit towards the back, it can be pretty hard to hear him since he has a quiet voice, and sometimes it's hard to understand him with his accent (on rare occasions). Also has a funny sense of humor. The class itself was difficult, so be prepared to work.
DJ teaches the material very very clearly, and everything that is on the homework can be found through his slides. There is never anything hidden or "gotcha" when it comes to DJ
Nice guy, fine class.
Although a really easy class, the teacher and teacher's assistants are very nit picky when it comes to grading.
Awesome prof!  encourages students to think outside the box. I learned a lot in this situation.

For adLab he was never clear about what he wanted.  E&M is manageable due to the mandatory tablets that I play games on during class.  He's interesting cuz he looks like Skeletor, likes to talk about the big, big P, and makes funny sqealy noises while waving his hands in the air.
(Modern I, E&M, Advanced E&M)  -- Excellent teacher.  Clearly cares a lot about teaching.  I highly recommend all of his classes.

The worst memory I have of Kowalski was when I stopped by his POSTED off-hours to ask him a question, and he was in his boxers and "wife beater".  He was startled that I was there and told me to leave.  It wasn't a good experience as a student to say the least.  I left still confused since my physics question about circuits was never answered.
No Comments
No Comments

the problem with this guy is, he is very shy and will not motivate the class. When no one will answer his questions or respond to him in a class he has no idea what to do. so work with him and he is a good teacher.
Kowalski is awesome.  He generally wants students to THINK and approach difficult questions in a clever way.
Good professor, but he is hard.  He is very bright and understands Physics well.
Kowalski is a good professor, the rest of you just aren't smart enough to adapt to different teaching styles
Very hard, you just have to get past his hard shell. Goes by the motto: Always keep 'em guessing. Use this to your advantage and turn it on him.
One of the worst teachers I ever had.  I went into his office hours once and he immediately told me leave.
No Comments
No Comments
first teacher to explain physics in a way that made it understandable.
Overall good teacher. Teaches the material well and is not boring.
He is ok. He knows what he is doing, but sometimes has difficulties conveying his methods. Overall, an ok professor.
Has good humor.  Test are easy.  Tries to help students the best he can.
Good prof, but he left to start a business or something.
ok instructor, good with office hour help
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
Very nice and always willing to help.
Had him last year.  He was very good at explaining things and knew what he was talking about. Must have gotten over his "inexperience".
good lecturer and overall prof, but seems slightly inexperienced
Dude is too young but also is not that great at teaching to students, i guess because he went to school here

Professor Ganley is quick to respond to questions and is very open about helping his students. His lectures go really fast because he has so much material and coursework to get through in a short period of time. This can make mastering the material difficult, but do not stress over it because Ganley will help you out.
rating_tags: Caring--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: I started off with my doubts about Ganley, but he grew on me as the semester went. I definitely walked out of there knowing a lot more than I went in with, so he did accomplished his job. Most of the reviews on the site come from comp methods just being structured in an poor way, but if you know the content it's not that bad.

Ganley does a great job of explaining a lot of material in the short semester time frame. Covering four programs is not easy but he makes it manageable. Admittedly it is sometimes hard to follow along in lecture because he goes fast but its not hard to figure it out during the homework if you ask for help.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Lecture heavy

comment: Dr. Ganley always kept the lectures lively with his unique humor. I appreciated how he would take the lecture time to go over example problems in the software. The lectures lined up with the homework and exams, so if you pay attention and do the work, you should be golden. Would recommend taking this class with him as he also does the 375 lab.

CBEN200 is hard because we learn so many programs in such a short period, and students tend to blame Ganley for that even though it isn't his fault. He goes over helpful examples in class and is VERY accessible outside of class - more than any prof I've ever had. The class is based on few assignments, which can be tough, but he makes it doable.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: Took him for comp methods spring 2020. Didn't really understand too much of what was happening, but repetition helped me learn a bit. The TA office hours were very helpful for homework, and he allowed a cheat sheet on exams which honestly got me through the class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Thermo lab, online. No idea what I was doing the whole time. Labs really shouldn't be online. Not sure if I'd blame Ganley though because I've had zero interaction with him this past semester.
What are to be learn in the material taught are really essential to our career, but what good teaching if it is not been absorb well by most student.

Ganley is a decent instuctor but be prepared for dad jokes and meandering in lecture. Class can be easy with a one small mistake and you are finished for tests. TAs usually have habits of placing code on board without explaining it. Overall ok but nothing to write home about one way or the other.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Had him for Computational Methods and Thermo Lab. In comp methods, nearlythe entire grade was determined by four 15 minute quizzes, of which the averages tended to be in the low 60s. The homeworks were doable. In Lab grading criteria is vague and contradictory from lab to lab.

Jason is a really good guy and a great professor. He teaches a computational course which can be tough simply because 4 different programs are learned. In class he's genuinely a good guy and will change due dates/assignments if it a busy week for students. He's really chill and rocks some cool shoes. Make sure to get him whenever possible.
Ganley was entertaining and explained concepts clearly in his lectures, but he often went so fast that I got lost. He was really helpful outside of class though when I went in to ask about homework.

This was the first time CBEN 200 (Computational Methods in Chemical Engineering) was offered, so they're still feeling it out. Ganley did a pretty good job for the class being new. He can move a little fast and be a little quiet, but those things are easily fixed. He probably expected too much from us, though--the homeworks and exam were difficult.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Phil is the only teacher at Mines who doesn't make me hate everything about this school. He actually, genuinely cares about his students AND the topics he teaches (an unheard of concept for many other profs). His 1% per day late penalty is a godsend. If I could have him teach every single class I would do so in a heartbeat.
Roemig is a great teacher and a really good guy. Clearly passionate about computer science but also empathetic and easy to talk to.

Phillip Goatmig the Third is one of if not the greatest Mines professors in CS.  He has a 1% a day late policy which is amazing and never heard of.  Has some of the best/useful projects that apply to career (like implementing ping and trace-route from scratch).  People hating on CSCI250 are Geos and Physics majors that can't code in Python.

Professor Romig is indeed a nice guy and I truly enjoyed his class.  He does interrupt a lot though and talks for way too long.  My typical conversation with him in office hours was like 5% me talking and 95% him talking.  He's friendly and approachable at least which is more than you could say for the majority of the computer science department.

I took both his infosec and networks classes and he made them both enjoyable to learn. He made the classes very accessible, was transparent about the course material and tests, and his new late penalty policy was really helpful when I was overloaded with work at different times throughout the semester.

Don't believe the slander, Bromig is one of the best & most entertaining lecturers at Mines. Very chill guy, keeps the late penalty light, always around for office hours. Tries hard to make course accessible to students (uploads lectures, recently switched to free textbook).

250 was a train wreck from every angle, not really his fault.

Romig is a very good professor, he clearly knows the subjects and teaches them, he has programming assignments that are medium sized and while at times difficult are incredibly useful and relevant. He has weekly HWs which help understand important points about the lectures. Occasionally miswrites in the HWs and tests.
Dr Phil is the best! So helpful

Dr.Romig was extremely rude in office hours. He is condescending and degrades you. I went to his office hours once, and never went back. He completely ignores you when you ask a question, and then accuses you of not watching the videos or of cheating. He created an extremely hostile work environment, and doesn't value his students in the slightest.

His "lectures" are videos that are 1.5-3 hours per set, all recorded by a different professor. He never had a coding lecture durring the semester, it is very hard to learn to code (I started with no experience). I went to his office hours twice and I was he accused me of skipping "lecture", not watching the videos, and cheating off of someone else.

Had him for CS471 too, but I think his CS475 class was much better. Labs were sometimes tricky, but interesting. Lectures were alright & incorporated participation activities & quizzes, but were manageable. Class was consistent & straightforward, Romig is knowledgeable about InfoSec & motivates/explains content better than in Networks. Good overall
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Lectures are often hard to follow and seem very dry and rambling in my opinion. Has lots of office hours and had a good amount of extra credit, but it felt so hard to learn in his class. Teaches from the textbook, but seemed to make things more confusing/convoluted without providing much context or motivation behind content.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: His lectures are a bit dry and the homework can get a bit tedious at times. The projects can be a bit challenging but they're really fun. As long as you follow the rubric, you're pretty much guaranteed full points. Dr. Romig knows his stuff and he's super cool. If you're looking for a CS elective, I'd highly recommend him.
Ted Smathers is one of the best at the entire school of mines
this guy is the best. he cares, and is a true blue, smart, big heart, and very smart.  he is real and old school so whimps and phonies need not apply to his class
If words could describe how boring he is then the English dictionary would be complete.
No Comments
Draw a cool perspective sketch and he'll love you the rest of the sketching unit.
Ugh.. sooooosoooooo boring.
Tries to move to quickly and expects everyone to know how to do something in a matter of seconds.
He teaches and grades from a slanted POV.  Does a bad job of explaining the material, then slaughters up the assignments for grades.
I can not believe that a teacher could be that incompetent when teaching. The only saving grace is that he teaches an incredibly easy class

he has no clue how to use a computer, and he teaches a computer class. when he opens things he right clicks and then selects open. apparrently he has never heard of double click. This may be something simple but it is annoying to me
What D-bag. Seriously.

Unbelievably anal-retentive. At the sound of a pin dropping he'll stop lecturing and look around the room for 30 second before continuing. It's a good thing drafting is a piece of cake, so you can just fall asleep in this tool's class.

Professor Wong has been one of the best professors I've had at Mines. Although MEGN481 is challenging, he makes the topics more interesting. I appreciate when he brought in multiple real life parts so that we could have a hands on experience of how something worked or just to see one in real life. If Jim is the professor, take the class.

He is a funny professor and will try to keep you engaged as much as he can. But the assignments are rather difficult and quite time-consuming especially if you are not good with solidworks. The quizzes are "graded aggressively(told by the professor himself)" but there are couple extra credits here and there so a B should not be a problem.

Professor Wong is great! I definitely recommend him for this class. I had no interest in the lectures and found them really boring but he made them as interesting as possible. Definitely go to lecture though because it is hard to figure out on your own.

Wong is one of the best professors I've had at mines. He's the only professor who smiles during his entire lecture. Had him for 201 and FEA. He reads slides a lot which isn't ideal, but he is super easy going and very helpful in and out of class. He has a good sense of humor and knows his stuff.

I had wong for 201 and after taking that class with him I asked him to be my advisor because he is so knowledgeable and such an amazing guy. He will answer any question you have and he is always so energetic in lectures.

When it comes to explaining the more theoretical aspects of the class, Jim's only okay. Fortunately, he provides lots of tools for success on the homework and exams in the form of examples and advice, especially if you go to office hours. He also made it clear that the book would be critical for the class -- best textbook purchase I've ever made.

Wong is enthusiastic, but sometimes gives false confidence in office hours. Homework is very hard, exams are also hard. Lecture covers only overview, and maybe an easy example prob. Expect to spend most of your available time working on this class. YOU. WILL. NEED. THE. BOOK. Physical copy highly recommended. He does care about students and helps.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Tough grader

comment: Funny and caring. Wants students to succeed. Explains concepts well. Lots of office hours sessions and answers questions well. Probably my favorite prof at Mines. Takes student feedback well and is willing to adapt the course. Adjusts homework questions on the online system to make sure they're graded correctly (if they're messed up by default)

Jim is a great teacher. His goal is to teach you so he dedicated a significant amount of the time in every lecture to answering questions from the students. This was really helpful since people asked questions about the well-designed homework assignments. He's easy to get help from and is ready to answer anything you ask.
He's a really funny and nice guy and makes one of the toughest classes for Mechanical Engineers tolerable and enjoyable to attend.
Great professor. Really cares about your success! Sometimes his lectures were hard to follow, but he was very available outside of class for help. Study a lot for the GD&T exam.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Beware of pop quizzes--Caring

comment: Jim was a great teacher. Once you get into the GD&T part of the course, things can get a bit confusing, but that's not his fault at all. He genuinely cares about his students and he'll do his best to help you out.

James Wong is a great guy. He hasn't been teaching too long; and, depending on what class you get him for, he can be great. Very chill and always willing to help. He's best for field session, CAE, and labs. His skill in teaching machine design needs work (but then again, all of those instructors do).
One of my favorite professors ever.

Dr. Blacklock is an excellent professor and lecturer. Sometimes there is a lot of work in the class, but assignments are always graded fairly. Dr. Blacklock is super accommodating and cares about students and their learning.

Took her class last year online during the pandemic. After having an internship over the summer, I just asked for all her lectures and ppts since I used most of the content during my internship. If you want to learn the real-world, take a class from Blacklock.

Dr. Blacklock has been my favorite teacher at Mines and I love being in her classes. She cares about students learning and explains topics very clearly. She is an excellent educator and I will take as many classes as I can from her. Additionally, she is very connected to industry and promotes hands-on/project based learning.

Dr. Blacklock is extremely caring while always professional. She genuinely cares about and flexes to students' needs. She goes above and beyond to make sure that students learn in both theory and application. Just as great engineers take complex things and make them simple, Dr. Blacklock makes complex concepts approachable & easy to learn well.

I don't know where the poor ratings are coming from to be honest. Dr. Blacklock was definitely in my top 3 professors at Mines. Although the COVID semester was hard, she was always available, generous with deadlines/grades, and kind. I would highly recommend her myself! It was clear she wanted us to succeed and wanted us to pass the quizzes.

There is a lot of poor and misinformation within the lectures. If you bring these up they are not considered, just told that you are wrong. She relies very heavily on the TA, it seems most of the time that she does not actually know the material. From my experience I will do all I can to avoid her class' in the future.
Had to ask the TA questions on almost all problems. Does not inspire confidence as a teacher.
She was an average professor. Sometimes lectures can be a bit boring, but shes clear with her expectations for students.

Didn't really learn much in this class, but I believe that's more of a reflection of the course than the professor. Grades easily, communicates the requirements of assignments well. Overall, can't complain. Already signed up to take another class with her.

Professor Blacklock is by far one of my favorite professors. She is very clear in what she expects from you. She is great at explaining things in a simple way. She'll grade things based on how well you know the material and not just give you a 0 if you get a simple algebra error. If you go to class and do the homework you'll do fine on tests.
Blacklock is extremely nice and very open to helping students.  The lab reports, though slightly confusing, are graded rather leniently, as are the tests.  Highly recommended as a professor.
Blacklock is very helpful in and out of class. She is very knowledgeable and lenient on late homework. Grading on the lab is easy. Tests are fair if you go to class.
I took the Fuel Cell and Technology Class, Dr. Decaluwe teaches the second half of the class. He is a solid professor.

DeCaluwe does so many "participation" exercises in lecture it wastes more time than it's worth. Lectures are upbeat and homework is relatively easy. The exams are MUCH harder than the homework and the reviews are vague. Leads to false confidence. Seems nice but not very helpful in office hours. Too many derivations, not enough practical use.

I took fluids with Dr. Decluwe and it was the easiest class I've taken at Mines. The hardest part of his class was figuring out how to pronounce his last name. I'm not proud of this but I skipped almost every lecture and was fine on the homework.

Took his thermodynamics class and was immediately panicked when I started trying to understand the textbook. However, what he went over in class was what was expected to be known for the exams. He also gave easy to follow lectures with great note posting before/after each lecture. Also, really open to helping in office hours. Highly recommend.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Really good lectures with lots of definitions and examples. Blank pdf would be uploaded before class and the one he filled out on his tablet during class would be uploaded after. This was nice in case you missed class. The recitations for this class were helpful. The exams were content heavy but luckily a crib sheet was allowed.

Phenomenal. Great lecture pace (writes important info on his tablet as he goes, lecture slides are posted after with his writing). Covers everything clearly and thoroughly, connects the dots well. Homework can be tough but he answers questions quickly. Genuinely cares about well-being of students. Your best bet for thermo.

Gives great lectures, explains material clearly, and definitely aims to give students an understanding of the material, rather than just how to pass the class. Only downside is he can be a little condescending.

Professor Decaluwe is a great person! He is extremely caring, easy to talk to, and very accessible outside of class. Thermo was a pretty hard class and it is crucial to got to the lectures. It is really important to understand ALL equations. He lectures quickly, I suggest just listening and looking at notes following classes.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Caring

comment: Charismatic and clearly passionate about teaching thermo. I personally prefer professors that are more linear and methodical in their teaching, but Decaluwe is still great. His lectures can feel a little scattered/chaotic sometimes, but if you're paying attention you can keep up.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Caring

comment: Decaluwe did a beautiful job teaching thermodynamics. His lectures are fantastic at making the complex subject easier to understand conceptually. The class was hard, but Decaluwe clearly has a love for teaching and helping his students. I highly recommend taking him over the other professors because he will always do his best to help every student.

Dr. DeCaluwe is awesome. He takes an interest in his students and provides you with his exact notes for Thermo. The homework is standard, but he writes the exams so taking Thermo with him is a good choice. A great professor and one of the few I actually still talk to after taking their course.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: Amazing. He made Thermo one of my favorite classes

DeCaluwe is a great teacher. He teaches the material clearly and posts his class notes on blackboard. Really helpful and kind. You do not need the book except for the appendix ,and he made copies for us so you do not really need it. Overall, great Professor and would take him again.

One of the best instructors @ mines. Cares about students learning in class. Gives out speeches every class and prepares you for business engineering world. Very helpful. Just put a little effort into listening his speeches and you'll get an easy A.
Great teacher, was a fun semester working with him.  Definitely one of the best Epics teachers.
Very helpful. Explains materials clear enough and always able to answer questions. Well prepared for classes.
Dr. K Rocks. Very helpful and available to his students.
Great instructor, always willing to help. One of my favorites last semester
Had him for epics I, he was fantastic, always willing to help. He knows so much about engineering, it is great to listen to him.
Dr. K is the man!
Very good
Funny and had interesting stories.
Fun Guy, the best Epics teacher
Always has the best interests of his students in mind
Great teacher
No Comments
Biology with Shaffer was amazing. Quizzes were tricky but the final was very representative of the quizzes.
Shaffer is awesome. The class is great and he goes over examples very well. Not much else to say, would highly recommend.

I honestly wasn't the best student in this class; however, he was a great teacher and had great lecture that had slideshows posted online in case you missed class. He is very caring and charismatic which made going to class not feel like a drag. Taking a different class with him this semester, highly recommend.
Great professor but I'm not a fan of how little everything except the quizzes and final are worth. Lectures are helpful and informative but sometimes don't fully prepare you for the quizzes.
Overall a good teacher. Would not recommend missing a class, they are incredibly content heavy
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: I wish he wrote all the exams.

Dr. Shaffer was amazing. I have had multiple classes with him, and I will take every opportunity I get. He is very down to the students level when explaining problems, and uses a technique that resembles the EDGE method of teaching. I've never learned material better than in this class. Don't get too down if you struggle on a quiz here and there

Shaffer is one of my favorite profs. I took him for baby thermo in the fall, and am currently taking him for MEB. Overall a super cool guy, and very interested in helping his students succeed. He recognizes when he's made an error (with grading or testing) and does his best to fix it. Lots of helpful examples during lectures, and very tech savvy!

Took him for bio last spring. He makes it a lot more work than it needs to be, which really makes you learn the material. Labs were kinda lame at times, but Shaffer was a really cool guy. He tries to relate with you and talk to you. Bio definitely not my favorite but Shaffer surely is up there. And he was very helpful when covid hit out of nowhere.
rating_tags: Respected--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: I had Shaffer for bio and now A&P. He really puts effort into teaching. He has a flipped classroom and I get that his style of teaching isn't the best for everyone (I don't love it) but he does seem to make it work. He always tries to answer everyone's question and makes class seem casual and inviting. Definitely take Shaffer if you get the chance.

He is an amazing professor! I learned so much, but I had to work for it! It was lots of work but it was work that actually mattered. Shaffer is an amazing professor that is considerate of students and is great at adapting. Over all one of the best professors I've ever had! Best professor in the ChemE department!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Amazing lectures

comment: Dr. Shaffer is great at teaching the material but he is going to make you work for it. Despite all of the extra work, I honestly felt a lot more prepared walking out of class and keeping things interactive made it great. Definitely would consider taking a class from him again.
rating_tags: Respected--Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Test heavy was marked because the tests were incredibly difficult. Dr. Shaffer expects you to know the material going into class so it could be applied in a project. Top ten Dr. S phrases: "Well, what do you think the answer is?" He's difficult to ask questions of. On the upside, he's enthusiastic and loves his subject. Read the textbook!!!!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--TEST HEAVY

comment: Loved this class!  Group projects were the best part, he formed teams/startups with people with different expertise so I didn't feel like an outsider.  He was always talking about latest research and inspired me a lot.  I decided to do an MS in quantum engineering after taking this.  Not a typical lecturer - lots of self-study but it worked for me.

This was a really intense undergrad math phys course I took during the pandemic.  My favorite part was figuring out the entropy of the matrix from my selfie.  I liked that he proved things rigorously, great lecturer, but also had us apply the ideas to real data.  Be ready to work *hard* in his classes though.

This is a projects-based course where you build a quantum startup company.  I really liked this idea and even though its very non-traditional I think I learned more here than my lecture heavy courses.  We also worked out problems in class in teams and the professor sent us to a major conference.  Highly recommend.

The course lacks sufficient material to effectively prepare students for research in quantum, as the content isn't rigorous enough to bridge that gap. The TA's office hours were good and he explained a lot of the required stuff which needs to be taught in class and part of the curriculum.

Very much the case of a course where you teach yourself. It's a little on purpose but I think it puts students at a disadvantage for future courses. Be prepared to spend lots of time studying independently, and don't trust the grade as a measure or preparedness for future courses in Quantum at Mines.

Love the projects and this class!  We got to work in teams just like in industry and he was on top of quantum R&D.  The classroom was fun with breakout sessions so even though attendance was mandatory I actually liked going every week.  He wrote me a letter of recommendation after and I got the job.  Definitely go to his office hours!

I took this class last fall but I wanted to rate it now because it turned out everything he taught me I've used over and over.  Now I got a summer position and I'm really grateful to Dr. Carr.  At the time I admit I complained because he was always talking about things not in textbooks, but now I get it, the research is too new to be in a book.

He sent us to a conferences for a whole week of class like a field trip.  Quantum projects were hard but fun.  Very helpful in office hours.  Mostly did problems and class discussions instead of lectures.  I felt like he really cared about us and did everything to get us into research, which is great because I'm really into quantum.  Nice person.

I loved this class, it really helped me get back into quantum after being out in industry.  The prof was a great communicator and clear about my grades and how I was doing, very encouraging.  But he also gave us freedom to choose our own projects, which was great for me to figure out directions for my thesis. I wish all my profs were this good.

Pros: Best course I ever took, really launched my career.  A challenge but worth it.  I can't believe how much advanced material I took in over one semester.  Spent a lot of one-on-one time with me and others interested in the subject, from entropy of images to quantum math.

Cons: Used multiple texts and research papers, sometimes a lot of work.

While the material was fine and the open-ended projects were nice, the administration of the class was beyond subpar. We had weekly assignments, but we were not told how our work was graded. We had 3 big projects, which had multiple different conflicting rubrics. Oh yea, I didn't even know my grade until a week before finals.

One of the only professors you will ever have who will feel different.  He will challenge you to think ways that you have never done before.  He will bring out the absolute best in you, but it will not be easy.  Fairly lenient grades, but tough work.
The greatest professor I have ever had. Though demanding, he will push you past your barrier you didn't know existed. Full of original ideas and unique was to solving problems. Truly inspiring.
Wants students to do their best. Very demanding, but nice.

Dr. Arkadan was very restrictive with Canvas which made it nearly impossible to identify your mistakes and improve on future assignments. He did not provide any partial credit for work on exams and his lectures were disorganized and unpredictable so it was hard to establish any sort of regular study routine. I don't recommend Arkadan for EENG389.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Beware of pop quizzes--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Arkadan is a very straightforward teacher, he teaches off the slides but often draws on the board and explains the subject more in depth. The class definitely feels a little rushed but he takes time to make sure most people understand it. The homework is hard but not unmanageable, the tests are based off of the practice problems.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Arkadan is a reasonable professor who gives students a fair chance to succeed in the course. The tests aren't easy, but there are lots of practice materials that reflect the test fairly well to help prepare. The homework in the class was difficult because it's based on the textbook instead of lecture, requiring reading the textbook.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Dr. Arkadan is a good professor who's not too hard. He puts effort in to try to make sure we are learning the material, and did a decent job of running the class while it was online. His tests aren't worth too much, and they are super fair and not bad at all if you put in a little bit of effort on the homework.

Dr. Arkadan is the worst professor I have ever had. He is beyond unreasonable and incompetent when it comes to running an online course. It is appalling I have to pay full tuition to take this course. He has no interest in helping his students and it is clear all he cares about his research and his tenure.

He is kind of frustrating to work with, but after getting to know him throughout the year, he really does care about his students. He may be not as nice or warm, but that doesn't discredit him as a teacher or a fair person. His tests are fair and he gives similar practice exams plus lots of examples in class.

Overall a good teacher. He is pretty monotone so his lecture can be kind of boring but he knows what he is talking about. He asked the class for feedback halfway through the term which shows that he is trying to better his teaching style. I think he's a pretty nice guy too in general. He gives redos one some exam problems which is a plus.
Great but he talks a lot
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Took this class for a week. Every class he started early and ended late. By the end of the first week he was already behind schedule. His lectures do not cover sufficient content, are difficult to understand, and are incredibly boring. Avoid his classes if at all possible.

Dr. Arkadan's lectures are just him pointing at slideshows and saying "you can read the book and learn this". Frequently makes mistakes in class. When called on them, says "I do not care, you can do them yourself". Insane amount of homework. Sometimes students have to get up and finish a problem for him because he cannot. Worst prof I've ever had.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: What an awful introduction to the EE department at Mines.  I'm sure he was an expert in his professional career, but just because you can do doesn't mean you can teach.  Worst prof I've ever had. Dr. Ammerman's videos taught me everything this semester, whereas this teacher's lectures managed to confuse even PHY 2 concepts.  All classmates agreed.

Probably on of the worst teachers I have ever had. Like posted below he only uses power point and half the time his slides are inaccurate.  If you ask a question he will shut you down and say he already went over that. Go onto youtube and watch Ravel Ammermans videos(newly retired prof) He will save your life!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: The lectures comprised of screen clippings of the examples in the book pasted into a PowerPoint. Questions were answered incorrectly on a regular basis, and typos were rampant in the lecture slides. Explanation often devolved to pointing and saying, "you see what they did there." Absolutely the least insightful instruction I've ever had.

Probably the worst math teacher I have ever had.  Lectures weren't helpful.  I learned more about diff eq on Khan Academy than I did in his class.  He also made lots of mistakes during lectures (he even taught eigen values completely backwards).  Consistently had lower test averages than all the other teachers.  Nice guy but an awful teacher.

Very respectful teacher and enjoys helping students learn, but only covers a few example problems in class and doesnt have much homework to help your grade out. Most of your grade is tests. If you learn well studying on your own, I'd recommend. If not, I wouldn't.

He lectures in Calc using the white board instead of slides, holds a work day where we team up in groups to solve worksheet problems, and is available regularly outside of class.  His calc classes are amazing, but so far I have to admit that you may want to avoid him for Stats&Probability if possible.
Not that great of a lecturer. I just taught myself the material out of the book. But he seems like a nice guys who wants to help everyone learn.
Good professor, explains material well and is very honest with students.
He's really into teaching which makes him easy to connect with. As for portraying the material, his approach isn't the greatest. Overall he's awesome!

Lehman is one of the best math teachers Mines has right now. He understands every concept as a few teachers at Mines don't. I've had his morning class and quite frankly he prolly just smoked too much goody the night before

Not a very good calc 2 professor, his lectures (especially the first one of the day) are hard to follow and extremely confusing.  He is always willing to help students try to understand but it rarely helps.  The tests are awful!!!  Studying for the tests sometimes does not help at all.  Overall, he was a better teacher for calc 1 than calc 2.
He did not explain the material well at all, and he did not prepare you for the test.
Bad teacher, hard to follow. He just gives out 100s on the worksheets which is good in a sense, but it doesn't let you know where you're screwing up.

Very good. SOme people say he sucks in the morning, and I've been to his lectures and it's true. Try to get his 3rd lecture of the day, but his second is still very good. In his first he still misses some stuff sometimes.
He is very eager to help and offers many office hours to do so.  He is funny and easy going. Also, he is a nice grader.
Absolutely useless, taught from slides that had numerous errors. When asked questions in class, could not answer them on a few occasions.

I have taken 3 classes with her. Panos creates good content for her classes. She usually creates very detailed rubrics for assignments which is good, but I had points deducted multiple times for small things that were not in the rubric which is annoying.

I've been at Mines for 4 years and she is without a doubt the best professor at this school. She can break down content to make it fun and digestible, while also helping us learn a ton. This class really refined my technical writing. She is such a good human and phenomenal educator. I fell in love with hydro because of her. Highly highly reccomend!
Phenomenal.

Great, organized lectures and clearly outlines the course in the syllabus (quizzes, homework w/ automatic 48 hr extension, individual and group exams, mini project, final). Excellent Canvas page. I feel I really retained the course material. Guided notes (digital or physical), though you will need a textbook for hw problems (buy it used or share).

The way she does lectures is amazing and makes the content super easy to learn. My only issue with the class is that the exams were partially done in groups and there is not enough time to do it and explain it to the other people in your group. The class was still super easy and I felt like I learned a lot and have really good notes for the FE.
Homework is helpful, lectures and very informative, and class is interesting! Professor Panos has an excellent system.

Dr. Panos is literally the best professor I've ever had at Mines. Her lectures are super organized and she does a great job communicating the value of the content. The homework and exams were a fair assessment of what was covered in class. Also, she genuinely cares about her students and wants you to succeed. 10/10 recommend, such an amazing prof!

I wish Panos could teach all my classes. She is absolutely fantastic. I learned so much and I enjoyed every bit of it. Her color-coded notes are efficient for learning, and the class moves at a perfect pace. She has a bubbly attitude that is genuinely so contagious. The homework was never frustrating, and I always felt prepared. Super stress-free.

The best professor I have taken at Mines and my favorite class I have taken at Mines. Professor Panos is extremely caring of her students and very dedicated to furthering the education of her students. Her lectures are amazing and prepare you very well for the homework and exams. She color-codes all notes which is great too.

The best professor I have had at Mines. She is incredibly organized and has structured the class in a way that is easy to follow and understand. As long as you go to class and take notes, it is easy to get an A or B in the class.

Probably the best professor I have had at Mines so far. Panos has created the only positive learning environment I have experienced online and her class is the one of the only ones I've enjoyed going to on Zoom. Even though she is young and may be titled as "inexperienced" she deserves more recognition than most professors who have taught for years

Literally THE best professor I have ever had. The lectures are structured so well and as long as you show up and participate you'll do great. Homework is easy! She is so nice and understanding and is truly just great at explaining everything. She tells you exactly what she expects and she really wants to make sure you do well in her class.

She is genuinely the best professor I have ever had during my Mines career. She wants us all to succeed and her teaching style is so easy to follow. The homework problems are derived from in-class problems and exams are compilations of problems similar to the homework, so there arent surprises. She's amazing!

I LOVE PANOS!! She is an amazing teacher. She cares so much about all of her students, and will help you in any way she can. Her exams are fair and if you show up to class and study you will do great in her class. Would hands-down take another class of hers just to have her as a teacher. Highly Recommend!
he does a good job, very knowledgeable about the industry unlike many other profs in the department.  He needs better jokes, as if you take more than 1 class with him you'll hear the same jokes.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy

comment: Jechura is a really chill professor. I'd recommend taking any of his electives, as he tends to make things pretty easy, but educational nonetheless.
Chemical Process Safety is probably the easiest class you'll ever take at Mines. Jechura tries to keep it interesting by going over case studies and bringing in guest lecturers.

One can tell that he is experienced and understands what he is teaching, but he doesn't know how to teach it. He doesn't explain anything, he just gives you a very specific example for something and somehow expects you to know what he did in the example and why. The homework is impossible to do without going to the TA's office hours.

He moves way too fast in lectures and does not pause for students to ask questions. If you fall behind while he's demonstrating something because you had to figure out a step that he sped over good luck catching back up, as he has already moved on to something different. His communications are curt and not helpful.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: Awesome professor, always available outside of class to help and provides great feedback. I appreciate the effort he makes to explain where information comes from. He really cares about his students' success long as they put in the effort.

No matter how much you ask for help you are met with minimal effort in return from Professor Jechura. There have been multiple times where I have asked for help and he has given vague and incorrect answers probably because he doesn't listen to what you are asking. He needs to put effort into answering questions and caring for his students.

English units suck. They are not God given units. But Jerchura's cool even if he uses the wrong units. Always gives good advice and just an overall nice person. Every class in chemE is about equally as hard at some point. So putting "the usual" for field session.

This was the 1st time CBEN 200 (Computational Methods in Chemical Engineering) was offered, so they're still feeling it out. Jechura did a pretty good job for the class being new. His issue: spends too long on one example (if you get lost, it's hard to learn for the rest of class). Probably expected too much--the homeworks and exam were difficult.
Knows his stuff
Great professor, NO BS, straight to the point kinda guy
Excellent
No Comments
Dr.Bodeau was a great professor who could be a tough grader but was always fair. I respect her so much; her industry knowledge clearly shines during her lectures.

Best professor I've had so far at Mines. Donna makes her expectations very clear, is great with feedback, and is very personable and fun to have a conversation with. For EDNS 151, she modifies the curriculum from other professors to get rid of most of the busywork assignments which is very much appreciated
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Nice professor who is friendly and cares about her students. If you have to take design 2 take it with her.
Very helpful in all regards, full of interesting stories, and made me look forward to class.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: For two absolute technological/programming idiots, she was the perfect professor. She could tell we learned more than what we should've and didn't expect our final project to be as advanced as others who could've completed the class before the start. Very caring and spent extra time with us to make sure we finished everything and didn't fall behind

Donna was a great advisor for our field session team. We had a few bumps in the road with our client, and she really helped ease them out. Her meetings are very helpful and extensive, but they can be repetitive at times. Yet for the most part donna was a phenomenal advisor.

Donna is amazing. She genuinely cares so much about her students and never talks down to you. She does a great job teaching the material and overall just rocks in general. I wish she taught all my classes!

Donna does an excellent job of simulating a professional environment. She is always available for help, and gives out a reasonable amount of work. Super respectful to her students and is willing to help as long as you reach out. If you have to take any class in the design program choose her.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: Don't take ENDS 251 with anyone other than her, she is amazing. She gives good feedback and can help you for hours with your assignments if you have any problem. One of the best mines professors I have ever taking a class with if not the best.

Donna is wonderful. She understands that Design is required and that most people dont care too much about it. Shes a pretty easier grader and is willing to help you understand where you went wrong. She has fun lectures and really cares about us learning and having fun with the class. Shes also worked in industry so she knows what shes doing.

Donna does a great job showing that she truly cares for her students. She put in a lot of effort for our class making sure that everyone stayed caught up and was on the same page, especially during covid-19. She gives great feedback for any and all ideas, and realizes what work is important in the class and focuses on that over busy work.

Donna was a great instructor for Design 2. I took a condensed class in the summer, but Donna made the work load spread out as to not work us into the ground. She really cares about her students and the real world experience she brings to the class is very helpful. If you work hard in her class, you will do great.

Dr. J had solid lectures. We had online homework assignments each week with a recommended textbook reading. He offered extra credit quite a few times. We had 3 multiple choice exams and a cumulative final. The lab aligned well with our class content and all the material was manageable.
He acts nice during lectures but is so disrespectful during office hours
Dr. J. loves to give A's, 10/10, would take again.

This was Dr. Jensen's first semester teaching PChem, and you could tell. He made mistakes often while writing equations down. However, he was a good sport about it, and clearly cared about student's understanding of the material. He was accessible outside of class, and his LMEs (tests) were very fair given the complicated subject matter.

Don't get me wrong prof Jensen is a really cool guy. However, online teaching is not his thing. He covers easy problems during lecture then the homework is extremely difficult and you get huge deductions on wrong answers. The tests are weighted extremely high and he doesn't know how to use canvas so you don't actually know your grade until the end.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Dr. J rocks. Solid lectures, and he really tried to keep everyone engaged. Went out of his way to make sure my DSS accommodations were met throughout the semester. Definitely treated everyone like they took AP Chem, so class was difficult. But he always answered questions and tried to help.
Dr. J is a really nice guy and hes a smart prof. Sometimes I felt like he didnt know how to explain things to people who dont already know the subject, but he really does care about his students.

Mark is an all around good guy, he knows his stuff. Although that could be a problem, he approaches the lecture like everyone has taken ap chemistry before, this is not the case for many and can make some things hard.
Lecture is fantastic. Some material is not covered in class and might require you to read the textbook(very rare).
Super passionate about chemistry, and great lectures!
Dr. Jensen is a great professor! He obviously loves chemistry and he applies this care to his class and teaching style. Out of all the Chem 2 professors you could have Jensen's the best.

Not the most clear teacher and in lecture it is tempting to not go since he's pretty confusing about certain topics.  But I would definitely recommend going because its much more helpful than having to learn it on your own.  I struggled failing a test but focused on the final since it replaces a test grade and ended up with a B.

Dr. Jensen actually reached out to me when my grades started to falter, only prof ever to do that for any of my freshmen classes. Awesome professor and genuinely loves chemistry. He's pretty funny during lecture and will help you. I would recommend going to his lecture but getting in on Sower's blackboard, she posts all the lectures, he doesn't.
palmer sucks
Great teacher. I have always had good math teachers, and he is added to that list. He makes the course easy. Hugely helpful and just generally an awesome guy.
Undoubtedly the best MACS instructor @ mines. Strongly recommended.
Great teacher...turns a hard class into a piece of cake.
He was very willing to help and was good at explaining things.  Class is still not super easy, but if you go to all of his classes you could pull an A.
No Comments
Didn't find any lectures terribly exciting.  I think the ladies pay more attention than the guys.  I slept, a lot.
Makes the material very understandable.  Deserves to teach every Mathematics course at Mines.
Simply the man
No Comments
Hey .. whatts up .. he is the greatest .. !! cheerz
No Comments
Interesting coverage.  Doesn't teach the test which made me think more when studying.  Really liked office hours because we talked about what the material could be used for in the future.
Unable to clearly teach.  One of the worst teachers at Mines.
Horrible. Worst professor I have ever had.

Horrible Lecturer. He uses powerpoint, but beware, he also adds his own text and it's impossible to read his handwriting. His tests often have 3-5 errors on avg. and answers are changed or questions are completely thrown out. Don't slack off on the homework, it'll kill your grade in the end.
he is kind of boring in class, but if you do the work it is really easy.
If you keep up and do the work, everything works out fine.
No Comments
Amazing man, horrible, horrible lecturer.  Be warned.
Bad lecturer, but helpful in office hours
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

(Linear Algebra) Woodington was fantastic.  Knows her stuff, and knows it well.  This was the first intro to proofs I had and she did a fantastic job getting me ready for doing proofs in higher-level classes.  Pity she had to move.  She teaches at U. Missouri now, I think (but under new married name), def. look her up if you're there!
SHe's great
hottest prof at Mines
No Comments
She's tough, but a good teacher. Her pop quizes are a little tricky too. She cares a lot about her students.
gives good help at office hours
I wish all teachers were like her
An influential reason why I stay at Mines...It's a pity she doesn't teach more of my classes =/.
so very hot...
No Comments
No Comments
fairly helpful, but too many quizzes to promote fair grading, pretty good lecturer
He is a tough grader and really boring in lectures

Very unorganized lectures, frequently hard to follow. Every class was 50 minutes of rambling and not much else. Had his TAs do all of the grading, and there seemed to be a disconnect between his expectations and theirs. Had his good moments though; he remained impartial on many political topics and could be genuinely funny at times.

Nice guy; clearly loves what he studies. I love that he teaches ideas instead of dates. But his lectures are so scatterbrained that you never have a strong idea of what those ideas are. His TAs don't grade the way he does, so you definitely need to look at your papers and argue grades.

Lectures are incredibly boring and haphazardly put together. His power-point slides are full of grammatical, spellings and accuracy mistakes. The sentences are sometimes not even comprehensible. He did not grade a single thing, he made his TAs do all of it. If you ask him a question expect a rant.
Professor attempted to make the class interesting and cared about his students.
Nice guy. Interesting topics. Good lecturer
His lectures are incredibly dry, and his slides are difficult to follow. The course itself seems disorganized and loosely connected. You have to fight to stay awake during most lectures.

He was difficult to understand and the course jumped all over the place. He couldn't figure out how to open powerpoint so half the class was spent doing that.  Don't take if you're Asian as he'll expect you to give the Asian perspective on everything.
none
Boring as hell but easy B
Can't take notes because the slides have to much information or are just pictures. Incredibly boring lectures. Grading policy isn't set and varies between assignments.

Other HS sections put emphasis on remembering facts, dates, and names. JJ stressed the broad picture of international political economy. Sit in the front so you can understand him because his lectures are a constant dialogue of good material. He is an airhead and unclear on grading policy but just go over the lecture slides and he will curve exams.

Horrible, horrible instructor. Seems to be a cool guy, if a bit patronizing, but he cannot teach at all. Incorporates worthless things into the lecture, a tremendous amount of homework, and unclear to the point he confuses himself during lectures. Avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Best mathematician I have ever dealt with. The most caring instructor. If you like proofs and going conceptual with math, you must take him. If you're the kind of guy who just wants to practice the problems and do examples stay away from him (I.e. good at math? take him. terrible at math? don't)

From what I've heard, Molinari seems liked and personable to some, but as an instructor, he's undoubtedly one of the worst I've ever had. Didn't seem to know the material himself and several students with AP Statistics backgrounds repeatedly corrected him in class. FYI - you're better off reading the textbook and teaching yourself the material.

He is a teacher who grades his student's worksheets extremely tough, and will dock many points just for notation. His teaching style took a lot to get used to. He lectures a ton, and teaches every concept first through a proof, with little examples. Not a teacher for everyone. On the upside he is hilarious, and very willing to help in office hours.

He is the most confusing person to follow. He confuses himself a lot. I had not taken Calc. 1 before and it was absolutely impossible. He tries to teach by guiding you to the answer instead of telling you what you need to know. He goes into the background of the math when it does not matter at all. He's a really cool guy, but cannot teach.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Hilarious--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Calc 2 here is tough, i should have transferred in my concurrent enrollment credit, but i didnt and got stuck with this guy. He legitimately thinks hes like a new plato or aristotle when it comes to teaching math, but really his method of "guiding you" to an answer is stupid. Had to drop because the tests were so tough. Only good is the point BD.

He's doesn't teach like an average teacher were he hands out all the information and just wants you to absorb it- instead he guides you towards the answer.  It's more work than a typical Calc II class, but you'll understand the material better if you put in the effort.

He taught through proofs which made it really hard to actually understand what he was talking about. If I hadn't already taken calc 1 it would have been a rough semester. I do have to say though when I went in for office hours he was an incredible one on one teacher. Also right before tests he gave us hints of what was going to be on it.

He was pretty hot, and also hilarious. As a teacher, he definitely seemed like he didn't know how to teach. He basically taught Calc 1 all through proofs without any examples. I had to take Calc 1 again and I did way better with a teacher that actually taught. Avoid him if you can. Not a good teacher, but a really chill guy.
Molinari went out of his way to help out students. He is also hilarious during lectures and kept many students engaged. Students came to his lecture in place of their own time slot.
I've been blasted as hell at basketball games and chilled with this man. He is my idol, and he is everything a cool professor should be.

Molinari has good intentions, but he really doesn't know how to teach.  He wants to give students an "education" not a "degree", but doesn't actually teach us what we need to know.  Not only does he not give us important tools in order to do the homework, he also confuses himself a lot and makes a lot of mistakes.

[MEGN212; won't let me select anything else] I had Leslie Lamberson for Solid Mech. She is excellent. She gives very clear explanations and makes deeply understanding complex subject matter easy. She also has an infectious passion and charisma about her subject.

I took DL for MEGN212 and she was absolutely amazing. She made every lecture enjoyable and entertaining, and used plenty of example problems to make sure students really understood. She would also do brief reviews occasionally where we'd go over what was going on. The class itself has a good amount of homework, but she gives good feedback on them.

I can only choose 451, but she taught my MEGN212 class this semester and was awful. She was not lenient with students, did not care for their wellbeing, was condescending and way too harsh with grading and extensions. She doesn't lecture well, and offers no examples. She is mean.

Her class was hard (mostly because the material is difficult) but she explains things incredibly well and goes into intense detail. She will always try to meet with your outside of class and help you. Also on all of her exams she offers extra credit. Also if you are struggling on the homework both her and the TA's are a huge help.

I believe Dr. L is a nice person. This does not make her a good prof. Lectures in Fluids 2derivations with little examples. Homework is simple but time consuming (mastering). Large disconnect between lecture material, homework and exams. Exams are brutal. No curves. Expect trick questions, nothing like examples given. 5 projects, 3 exams, 13 HWs.

The teacher was unable to convey the proper solutions between her and another professor teaching the same course. One of the larger assignments given she was unable to understand how to do and the grading of them was harsh, to say the least. The tests were intentionally difficult with D averages on tests. Grading feedback took way too long to get.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Dr L is bubbly and enthusiastic. She is also condescending, assumes we know material we don't, and only offers *limited* help when a student is struggling. Have an email that says, "We've helped enough, finish on your own." VERY biased towards math and computer science. *AVOID* if you're not looking to do derivations all day. 2/10 never again!!!

Would highly recommend avoiding Dr. Lamberson (especially online). She moves very fast during lecture, doesn't provide much feedback on homework to learn from, misses office hours more than most professors, almost never fully answers questions about assignments, and the only examples she does in class are from the book or are extremely easy.

She does not give solutions to the homework and does not grade all the questions. This leaves students unaware of their level of understanding. Furthermore she looks down on students who use their resources to find answers to the homework. Finally, she is constantly tooting her own horn, and comes across as very self absorbed.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Test heavy

comment: Knowledgeable, enthusiastic, and qualified. Super responsive to student feedback. Goes fast in lectures but will always stop/go back for questions. Sometimes assumes we know things we haven't learned, but will explain if you ask in class or office hours. Hw is hard. Always accessible in office hours, explains things well, and never condescending.
Dr. L is clearly passionate about what she teaches and is open to taking feedback from the class. The homework can be very difficult and often has a lot of questions so start early.
rating_tags: Respected--Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Dr. Lamberson is extremely smart. She does talk very quickly during lectures. It is difficult to take notes and listen to her at the same time. She is caring of her students and wants them to succeed, but it is a difficult course.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: This class was amazing and I loved how Dr. Case set up assignments. The class was laid back but important and interesting. Reading heavy, but everything was a good read, and class discussions were always fun. Dr. Case is one of the best teachers at Mines. She is caring and always there for her students.

Dr. Case is both a wonderful professor and human being. She cares deeply about her students and the content she is teaching. Her classes definitely require time and effort, but she makes this worthwhile as all of the assignments are valuable. I didn't feel like there was any busywork in this class. I would recommend her classes to anyone!

Amazing professor. Extremely caring and attentive to the needs of individuals and the entire class. Her passion for the topic is evident but do not mistake her kindness as a means for an easy class. If you are equally as passionate the class will be amazing.

I had Dr. Case and have only positive things to say! I would take a class with her again in a heartbeat. She sets clear expectations but is willing to work with your needs as a class and as an individual. She cares about her students both inside and outside of class and looks for the bigger lessons that will help you beyond the class!!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: I had Dr. Case for HASS498. Dr. Case is incredibly knowledgeable and creates a great learning environment. Each assignment is up for interpretation, allowing creative freedom (any mediums, can work in groups for quizzes, etc.), while also giving good outlines if you would prefer to work inside of a rubric. Fantastic professor, mentor, and person.

She's super understanding, but won't hold your hand through the class. She's a tough grader, but so is most of the HASS dept. The amount of work is consistent with other NHV profs, and not unique to her. Put a minute amount of effort into the readings (Literally even just a skim), and work on your essays early, and you'll be fine.

You can tell she cares about her students but is a tough grader and assigns a lot of papers, so I wouldn't take her if you are there for an easy A. You can resubmit most papers and she definitely wants you to get something valuable out of the class but if you don't put in the effort your grade will reflect it.

Dr. Case was a great NHV professor. Her revise and resubmit policy on all writing assignments except for the research paper and portfolio allows you to infinitely revise every writing assignment as long as you show effort because she cares about growing and learning in NHV. Participation is self-graded.
definitely a good teacher and a good person but her class was twice as hard as any of my other classes.

Case is my least favorite professor here at Mines. She will take points off assignments if you follow everything in the rubric. Final is a portfolio that has no rubric and is worth 25% of your grade. Do not recommend, she is currently the only NHV professor without a 5/5 rating here at Mines.
She will take 50 points off because she didn't like one thing in your essay. NHV should not be my lowest grade at an engineering school

She was very understanding if something came up and was willing to work with you on due dates. The class led the pace of the class and you graded yourself on participation. There is a good amount of writing, but it is a writing-intensive class and she gives helpful feedback on all work. Highly recommend for Nature & Human Values!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Participation matters

comment: Warning: A patient from Arkham Asylum has escaped and now a professor at Colorado School of Mines. Beware!!! Traumatizing as I am haunted by the irrelevant personal details that made their way into class. I felt more like a therapist than a student. She has ridiculous standards which bear little relevance and transferring schools thanks to her.
She always talks about her personal things which is very awkward to students. We do not want to know what is going on with her personal life.

It is difficult to explain...but I think she tries way too hard. It's probably from her experience in construction, but the course is over-planned and uses fluff to keep the schedule OCD-satisfactory.

She needs to learn to become more laid back. Not everything needs to be super robot-level organized.

She is new. I know she will improve.

I feel bad for Gupta. She is trying very hard to make this class full of useful material for her students. However, she is still learning how to teach. She doesn't need nearly the amount of negative feedback she is getting nor does she deserve it.
Poor Gupta.

One of the worst professors I have had at Mines. There is no real teaching in this course and most of the time is spent discussing Gupta's personal projects. The assignments are many and extremely tedious, and the "lectures" do nothing to prepare students for the material. This class could be taught much better, and I am honestly disappointed.

Not all engineers are meant to be teachers/professors. Karen Gupta is a perfect example of this. From what she's presented so far she has a lot of experience in the construction field, but none of that seems to translate into an interesting or meaningful classroom experience. If you want a positive impression of construction, don't take this class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Gupta started as a co-professor of CEEN360, but she is now the sole professor. CEEN360 was recommended as interesting but was taught by a professor who has now "resigned", most likely due to the horrid way Gupta treats students and other faculty members. She treats everyone like they are inferior and assigns work that is barely taught.

Karen has a condescending tone, lectures about extremely basic topics like they are complicated, and makes students put their phones away. She has unironically given juniors and seniors a personality test and a area/perimeter/volume test. Takes points off for not simplifying fractions??? Haven't learned a single thing in over a month in her class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Professor Gupta is the worst professor I have had at Mines. She is treating a 300-level class that is filled with juniors and seniors like they are middle school kids. She is not accommodating, takes students' phones away, and two months into the semester I have not learned a single thing. If you have the choice to not take a class with her don't!!

Professor Gupta is easily the worst professor I have had at Mines. In a class designed for Juniors and Seniors she assigns assignments that sociology for area, perimeter, and volume. She treats her students like they are children even though they are adults. She also doesn't give lectures but instead has guest speakers almost every class.

Avoid Gupta at all costs. She gave Mines Juniors and Seniors an area and perimeter test... The average was terrible and not a single person out of over 100 students got a 100% because she formatted the test while she was drunk. She is a failed engineer that thinks she is way smarter than she is and she makes what should be an easy class very hard.
Judy was the most amazing professor I have had. She was so willing to help and genuinely cares about her students. There isn't a better biology professor at Mines.

The semester I took this class was the first semester BIO110 was offered. It was a hard class. Labs were pointless and there was little lecture. Mrs. J was willing to help, but came off very condescending and rude a lot. Tests were hard but the text book helped a lot.

She is passionate about biology; but she confuses learning with indoctrination. Not everyone wants to be in the field of biology; often it feels as though you are in the wrong class as an engineer. Biggest complaint is that her tests are much more difficult than what a fresh-man class should be; they're much more like sophomore (200+) level tests.
Fantastic Bio 1 teacher.  Though the class can be unorganized at times, I always learned something new from her.  Great class. Great professor.
Can definitely be rude at times, but overall effective at teaching the subject.
Condescending! Openly speaks of liberal views in class.

Fairly effective teaching style but very negative attitude toward students.  Gets annoyed when you try to ask a clarifying question.  She is technically a high school teacher, and so she treats us like high schoolers.  Book reading is required, and then the lectures are straight out of the book, but you have to show up anyway for clicker questions.
Difficult tests

She is very intelligent and passionate about her subject, but teaches class with arrogance and makes students feel stupid when asking questions in front of the class. She'd be a great upper level bio teacher, but if you can take Earth instead, I HIGHLY recommend it

she has every trait that a bad professor has: extreme arrogance, condescending to students and makes you feel stupid when you ask a question...if you get her for freshmen bells, drop it immediately!!!
Challenging but helpful teacher. She keeps her standards high but helps her students reach them.

Worst "professor" I've had here.  Not even a prof - she was brought in from a high school to teach this one class.  She wants to turn BELS 101 into BELS 300, which just isn't what the class is meant to be.  Mines should never have hired her, and you should avoid her if at all possible.

Nice person and can be funny in class. Equations necessary for homework often aren't taught until the day the HW is due. Exam grading was unbelievably harsh, but he gave me back over 15% when I pointed out numerous errors in grading. Biggest issue is how few examples are covered while taking many days to cover them, it leaves you unprepared for HW

Pros: homework was easy and fast, lots of extra credit available (hard tho), class was curved a bit at the end, fluid Fridays were fun.
Cons: final exam average was a 59%, a lot of hard projects, wastes a lot of time doing derivations, he sometimes yells at the class, in class example problems were unclear/unfinished, took a long time to grade.

Tests are extremely hard and aren't at all like the homework. Trick questions on exams, first exam average was low 70s and he wanted it lower. Homework doesn't line up with what we were learning in class. Project grading criteria is unclear and very harsh. Class is pretty much only derivations and and examples are uncomplete/skip large steps.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Group projects

comment: Beware, Sullivan's tests are very difficult in Fluids 2. He wanted a lower grade average after the first exam, so the second exam average was a C-. Took the final exam with 2/5 projects, including a group project worth 15% of our grade ungraded. Homework on mastering is nothing like exam problems, old exams won't help you prepare. Study hard.

Sullivan seems more interested on his research than students. He tries to be funny in some east-coast snide way, calling everyone "homie" and passing off his lack of preparation by claiming to not know the material (smokescreen). The lectures are unhelpful and derivation heavy, exams are very hard w/trick questions, and homework is barely useful.

Some days he's good, but usually not great. Gets confused and admits to not understanding things/unable to explain them (assumptions on derivations/outside supplemental info in lectures). Not very enthusiastic to help in office hours but he will help. Terrible at answering emails. The class falls behind a lot. Likes to give trick questions on exams
Has admitted to being unprepared to lecture multiple times so far. Lecture seems disorganized and frequently makes mistakes. Also cancels office hours at the last second when students are waiting.

Professor Sullivan is likely the best professor that I have taken a class from here at Mines. He makes the material clear, and cares about the quality of his classes. I have learned the material very well and enjoyed taking the class.
Likes to be an ass and shows off a lot about his research. If I hear the word fuel cell one more time...
No Comments

Very helpful specially in computer projects and HW questions, Do not miss his help sessions (very interesting and very helpful for exam), moreover, his lecture notes posted on Blackboard help you to avoid using the book.
He makes a tough class as easy as it can possibly be.  The rest has to come from the student.  Very helpful, sometimes hard to find.  Take this guy for fluids.

Professor Angeli is undoubtedly one of the best HASS professors on campus; her care for students and the material is extremely clear in the way she approaches lectures and feedback. If you have the option to take one of her courses, absolutely do it.
She is the best. The best class I ever had.
She was great person inside and outside the class
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Engaging and gives great feedback when grading
One of the best professors I have ever had. She is amazing, caring, and kind. She gives good feedback, and her class is so entertaining.

Professor Angeli was a great professor. She made sure that the assignments that were due soon were announced in a timely manner and talked about her explicit expectations of said assignments. She was very accommodating and helpful during office hours. I thoroughly enjoyed taking her class, she's a very nice woman.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Accessible outside class

comment: The best instructor that you may have. Super easy grader but with amazing feedbacks.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Very warm kind professor who makes an effort to get to know everyone personally. She assigns lots of online prerecorded lectures, some of them are fascinating, some are boring. Class time is always group discussion. Papers are fairly easy and graded reasonably. If you have a choice of prof for short form 100% go with angeli
Amazing professor. Caring, always gave great feedback, and made grading criteria clear.
Good teacher, pretty easy grader, very nice and helpful
I love Prof. Angeli! She is very supportive and really cares for her students. Gives great feedback along with meaningful discussions.
She's wonderful, very understanding, and kind.

Sarkar expects you to know all the concepts and foundations before coming to class. His lecture is spent on practice problem and some useless facts. Luckily this course has small exam percentage so as long as you do homework and attend labs it is not that hard to get a solid B. But for an A you will need to do it on your own.

Dr. Sarkar does a really good job of breaking down the hard topics into relevant examples from everyday life so that we can understand. He also always works through the homework problems, which is a huge advantage from other phys classes I've taken. I am really bad at physics, but he works with me, and I ended up doing really well in the class.

Don't walk into this class expecting it to be easy- it isn't, but Sarkar does a good job of making the content relatable to everyday life and walking through the really hard homework problems. If you have him, GO TO HIS OFFICE HOURS! They are so helpful, and he really cares about making sure you have the help and resources you need to succeed.

Take Sarkar if you can. Out of all of the professors, Sarkar is the most willing to help out students who need help.
