The slides are dense, but all of the relevant information that you could possibly need to know for a topic is on there, and he walks through the homework to make sure we understand it. He is extremely helpful in office hours.

Dr. Sarkar is one of the first professors I've had that has genuinely cared about me really learning this subject. He explains the theoretical physics and provides enough applicable in-class examples (practice problems AND homework problems) that I, as someone who has never been good at physics, feel prepared for studio, the homework, and the exams

Dr. Sarkar places a heavy emphasis on real life and experimental understanding of the material. This is very useful for those who learn best with some kind of real life model to guide their understanding. His exams are challenging as they focus on more realistic problems that one may find in research. Very kind and helpful in one-on-one meetings.

Professor Sarkar is interesting. He is a little difficult to understand because he has a foreign accent. He loves answering questions and encourages them (however that often does not persuade students to ask). I stopped going to his lectures and instead watched the online videos by Professor Kohl and have a very in-depth understanding of PHGN 200.

Professor Sarkar is extremely difficult to understand and crams his slides with information. I started going to a different section after 3 weeks. Everyone else also has the same idea because his lectures are empty everyday but a quiz day. Avoid getting Sarkar at all costs.

This professor is shockingly bad. You cannot understand what he is saying, and even if you could, it wouldn't help because he rambles about topics that have nothing to do with the class. I started going to a different professor's lectures after a few weeks. His lectures were almost completely empty because everyone went to the other professor.

Sarkar teaches using slides crammed with content and most of it is unimportant, incorrect and incoherent. He assigns homework without having solved it before and offloads all of the work to the TA. You quickly realize that reading the textbook is more informative than going to class. Take a different professor.

Sarkar is a great professor who is always willing to help students. I believe anyone- especially those who may have struggled with Physics I- should take Professor Sarkar into consideration when choosing a Physics II professor. If you are willing to put in the effort and extra work, the results will be shown. He is always willing to help students.

Sarkar is difficult to understand and not very loud during lectures. He doesn't explain things well at all, and often leaves you very confused. Often fails to answer or acknowledge students questions. The lectures themselves have little to no relation to the actual work assigned. They are often extremely useless tangents to the subject.

Definitely one of the best professors I've had. He engages the class with thought-provoking statements, and challenges you to think about your writing and critical analysis. He has a cool sense of humor, too. Five star rating.
You have to be really good at writing as well as reasoning if you want to get a decent grade in this class and Michael is a tough grader.

Michael Bowen was the worst professor I have ever had. He would try to summarize statements after student spoke in class but would use gross generalizations that were actually really offensive when he thought they were funny. 0/10 do not recommend.

This course is writing intensive, but Prof Bowen is extremely helpful through the process. I actually started to enjoy writing and the topics were much more interesting than expected. Prof Bowen is sharp, relatable, authentic. He knows how to fuel discussion and he uses a variety of activities in class. I highly recommend him.

NHV is about ethics, environment, and critical thought. Sound exciting? Well, I wasn't sure what to expect, but thanks to Professor Bowen, I have come to REALLY enjoy this class! With Socratic dialogue and quirky humor, Mr. Bowen makes class discussion both serious and fun - bringing a unique balance of challenge and charm to whatever the topic.

This professor genuinely cares about his students. He gets you to think outside the box and is excellent at teaching how to write. That said, you DO have to put forth effort in his class. Expect to read a lot and be ready to participate in class.
Condescending

I'm a senior getting ready to graduate. Looking over my time at Mines, I have to say that Professor Bowen was my favorite teacher. He teaches Nature and Human Values, a class known to challenge freshmen who don't enjoy writing, but Prof. Bowen's creates a comfort level that puts the class at ease. His wit and wisdom will have a lasting impact.

Bowen is a little out there at times, but he's hilariously entertaining. A pretty easy grader, if you participate and take the class kinda seriously. He doesn't really explain the assigned readings in lecture though, which comes back to haunt you when you're studying for the final.
Joke of a class. First two papers are graded fairly easily. Third paper is a little more rough.
Note: in future textbook will probably be mandatory for NHV, but when I took it I never used it.

Really fun and interesting labs. I recommend enrolling in the lecture (203) as well. I think you'd still learn a lot without it but the lab is so much better with it. Go to office hours if you need help, Danica and the TAs are great.

Roth is a nice and caring individual, however the class itself is not the best. The lectures have way too much material stuffed into them and so it is hard to decipher what you are meant to take away from each lecture. The tests are half conceptual and half math based and we have almost no practice with the math so the tests are very rough.

Danica is a great person and she genuinely does care about her students. Lab assignments are fun but make sure you have a good group. Lectures sometime are very hard to follow and do not connect well to tests. Tests are the hardest part due to no practice exams and little clue as to what is going to be one them. She can also be hard to reach.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Danica has done a lot of restructuring for her class and really listens to student feedback. Her lectures aren't very helpful and she doesn't provide much in terms of study guides or practice tests for exams, but there is a lot of extra credit and she seems to care about her students.

GEGN 203 is pretty difficult, but the class has undergone significant changes recently. I'd recommend disregarding the older reviews for Professor Roth on this page. She is an amicable person and wants her students to succeed. Her exams can be frustrating since they often contain material that was not covered that much in class. Do the extra credit

Above all else, the grading in this class is very harsh. I didn't find the lectures to be particularly helpful, as most of the material is just memorizing equations and plugging things in on exams and homeworks. The associated lab course was much better, as the TAs were both super nice and helpful, and you get to see some real-world applications.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: I really enjoyed this class. Incredibly interesting and I loved the labs. Lectures don't always connect well with homeworks, but Danica genuinely wants you to learn and listened to feedback to improve the class a lot over the semester. You'll have to work for an A, but grading was generous with lots of extra credit, so I think it'd be hard to fail.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Caring

comment: Test heavy and lectures are bad, the labs are also bad, the content she teaches does not reflect the exams or assignments. Too high level of a course tbh. Needs a complete restructure.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Go to office hours. I suggest blocking them into your schedule and attending them regularly. Taking notes on the readings helped on the midterm, but Ctrl+F is your friend for quizzes. Danica is nice and so are the TAs. They want to help. Also, everyone is just as lost as you are- reach out to people early on so that you're not doing this alone.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: This is the worst class I've ever taken. It's worth 2 credits, but there's 2 quizzes/week, homework, and lectures that cover way too much material. Danica Roth explains things terribly and expects us to figure everything out ourselves. She doesn't understand that lectures go way over our heads and wants us to spend all our time on her class. :'(
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Tough grader

comment: Literally the worst professor I have ever had. When I asked for help because I was confused, she blew me off at least three times. The class content is way too high level for the class she teaches (she didn't even know the prerequisites for her own class). Her tests are also too high level and do not relfect the content of the class.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment:
I've taken this professor twice, and both times he taught exactly the same way. Lectures are monotonous and long, and the required canvas discussions are worse than just "reply to 2 classmates posts". At least the projects are pretty lenient in terms of grading.

By the end of the semester, "There is no free lunch" will be burned into your skull.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Lecture heavy

comment: He gave us a quiz and a homework on finals week. That should be all you need to know.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--So many papers--Graded by few things

comment: Hua Wang is a terrible CS professor. His class is extremely lecture heavy which wouldn't be too much of a problem if 1. the lecture slides were at all helpful and 2. he wasn't one of the most boring monotone research professors at mines.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: His lectures are very hard to sit through. It seems like he talks in circles. I felt like nothing I learned was significant since I stopped showing up to class and still maintained a good grade. This is a weird class to teach since it seems too specific for a conceptual subject. Easy class, but a waste of time for most. Proceed with caution.

Dr. Wang does not deserve as low a rating as he currently has. While it is obvious his passions lie more in research than they do in teaching, he is very willing to help students pass and learn the material. Super chill class, and a good prof.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: He doesn't seem to care about teaching at all. You need to remember every single detail from lectures to have a chance at the homework and projects. Don't go to him outside of lecture cause he might just try and make you feel bad for asking instead of helping. At least he's accommodating because he doesn't care.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: Hua is obviously more interested in being a researcher than a professor. However, He is relatively accommodating and his lectures cover most of what is on homework. The projects are difficult to do without help but lots of help is online. He also offers a lot of extra credit.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Lecture heavy--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: You won't be prepared for the homework, and especially not the programming projects. You will mostly be teaching yourself via google, as this class has the same assignments and lecture slides that you'll find online from other schools.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Group projects

comment: I took Machine learning and he was out of town for the first 2 weeks and a grad student taught. Fair enough. Then, he came back, give 3 lectures, THEN NEVER SAW HIM AGAIN. Nothing literally disappeared from lectures. Class was messy and disorganized but the grad student did what he could (and did a good job with that!) Avoid him you can.
Should've taught more in the class instead of just student presentations.
I don't know why he teaches classes. Doesn't seem interested at all. He is an amazing research professor and knows a lot about his field.
Greatest to ever do it
Great teacher! Make himself easily accessible if you are ever confused or struggling & is very helpful in his lectures. Good memes too
Drew is amazing at teaching.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: mad chill
Drew is an amazing teacher and provides stellar information for all required quizzes, worksheets, etc.
Great teacher, it was my first class ever coding and I had a great understanding of the material at the end. Drew is super helpful in office hours and willing to help outside of office hours as well.

Drew excels in teaching complex concepts with clarity. Their use of real-world examples fosters critical thinking. They create a supportive environment where students feel valued and empowered. With a passion for their subject, Drew inspires excellence in education. never wanted to be a comp sci more as a chem E
He's lit!

Drew is my favorite teacher of all time. In CSCI 128, there are a TON of assignments due every week, and Drew allowed us to turn in things up to a week after it was due and didn't take off points. The homework is easy, but time consuming so his leniency really made a difference. He is very accessible outside of class.
He is very personable and cares about your understanding of the course material.

Drew is a graduate student teaching CSCI 128 for the first time. He is very caring and also very honest during his lectures about what you actually need to do to be successful. He has a great sense of humor and makes lecture enjoyable.
She was scary, also a traitor to mines since she left after 1 year...

Dr. Wilcox is an absolutely amazing professor. Physics 1 was my hardest class freshman year, and (despite not actually caring that much about physics) she made me want to do well and I ended up getting a better grade in her class than any other. She gives clear (albeit somewhat math-heavy) explanations of concepts as well as awesome demos. Amazing.

If you enjoy physics you will enjoy Bethany Wilcox. That's the short of it, but to me Wilcox almost seems to fanatical about physics which is kind of annoying to me. Personally I dislike her teaching style because of this, but many students love her for it.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I loved taking her class.
Awesome professor
Professor Wilcox was great!! She explains things very clearly and is very helpful! I did my homework in her office hours and she really helped me understand the material
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: She changed the phys 100 curriculum without consulting the other phys teachers, changed her lecture style, and now the majority of the class if failing. Avoid if you can if she doesn't get fired.
She is a teacher that truly cares about her students. She goes the extra mile to make sure we learn. She is patient and a great explainer.

Prof. Wilcox was clear with explaining concepts. I found that the lectures did not help. The homework, studio, and office hours (TA's and office hours) helped a lot. While the tests are heavily weighted of problems you've practiced and done before, understand how to reason through a problem and you'll be fine. Stay positive, my friends :)
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--TEST HEAVY

comment: Wilcox gives solid physics lectures and seems pretty reasonable.

Professor Wilcox has a strong voice and she is a very clear person. Personally, I think she's great. This class comes with strict rules, but none worth complaining about. Wilcox herself recognizes me outside of class, occasionally makes a good joke, and can quickly answer or clarify most anything. She is everything needed from a professor.
Not a great lecturer but she is pretty understanding when it comes to grading

Doesn't really seem to put a lot of effort into the class. Relies on students to calculate values to get through examples she hasn't reviewed. Doesn't want to help students outside of class, just tells you to go see her grad student if you have questions. Definitely not the quality you expect from Mines, but her class isn't hard so whatever.

Not good. Slides put together by grad students & she doesn't seem to review them for class (she's just as surprised as we are!). Writes on the smart board like it's a football game plan. Use of technology in the classroom leaves something to be desired. Find someone else.
Caring, but strict. She is demanding, but well worth the time. She is very driven.

She is not very nice.  I liked the time of her lecture better than the one I was registered for, so I started going to her class.  I know a lot of people that did it in her class before, but she didn't like the way I looked, so she found out my name and called me up to the front in front of everyone and told me to leave.

I really appreciated the lesson plans she created for the class, just don't forget to have her take of the paragraph marks.  ;)  She's GREAT with using different examples, which is a MUST in this statistics class.  Definitely go to every class, because you can't rely on that piece of junk book, even though you do all your homework out of it.
No Comments
No Comments

She's the best math teachers I've had at Mines. She was one of the best DiffEQ teachers (along with Strong) who knows exactly what she's talking about. Her research outside of class is in math education. She's tough, but good.
She was worse than most of my middle school teachers.
Very good Diff Eq teacher...one of the best

He teaches the material pretty well for written stuff but man the polymath sucks. The take-home exams took 4+ hours and you need to do them in the comp lab because only the professional version can graph. He doesn't check his work so don't expect solutions to be correct. Assignment dates overlap with senior design to make November hell.

Diego is actually a very good teacher, but he refuses to check his work, he constantly assigned things on days not possible on the academic calendar, or gave us impossible or incomplete exams. His mistakes were my suffering.
Diego talks really fast and his lectures come straight from his notes which are sometimes impossible to decipher. Grading by him was okay, but not worth the bs he puts on the tests and quizzes.

Took kinetics with Diego. I didn't understand too much the latter half of the semester, and the final was really tough and brought my grade down from A to B+. I probably would recommend taking a different prof for kinetics.
He is not helpful at all, and he doesn't respond to his emails. He makes the lecture harder than it supposed to and he doesn't encourage questions during class.

Diego's lectures are clear but he tends to miss the broader picture when explaining stuff. Often I would get to the homework and not know how to apply what we learned even though it made sense in class. Make sure to pay attention to the details since he likes to test these on exams. He will usually point it out many times and mention it's important

Diego is a knowledgeable professor, and his exams/quizzes/homeworks are very fair. The group projects are tough, but really helped me to learn the material better. He cares about his subject and his students, but the projects do have an element of freedom/creative choice, which makes them more difficult and sometimes slightly intimidating.

The professor assigned large group projects that seemed difficult for everyone in the class. When asked questions about the project, the professor would ignore or provide no help relating to said project. The class time was nothing but lectures and quizzes, a very difficult way to learn. Lecture heavy, hard to learn from

Dr. Gomez was generally friendly and knowledgeable about the material, at times however his lectures were very disorganized. Frequently had to make corrections to his notes in class. With a little more organization the class would have probably been better but I feel he was a fair grader.

Took Diego for Process Dynamics. He's is a good professor, but tends to ramble. He explains how we're suppose to do things, but he doesn't really explains what those things really are. His handwriting during online lectures was chaotic, but he would upload neatly written work. I feel like he'd be much better when we have in person classes again.

Diego is the nicest professor I've ever had at Mines. It feels like he's always in his office for you to ask questions, gives a ton of hints about what will be on quizzes/tests, posts all his lectures and a lot of extra material, and just genuinely seems to really care about you.

Excellent professor! Diego is really passionate about teaching and will make a solid effort to help you with any problems you bring to him outside of class. He won't make you feel bad about any questions or feeling clueless about what's going on in the class. I will definitely take him again if he's teaching any of my future courses!
The Moose is one of the best professors I've ever had. He is very personable and gives great lectures. The tests are also pretty easy as it is all just memorization from the lecture slides.
Awesome guy and hands down one of the most personable and interesting lectures at Mines! The tests are a lot of memorizations, but most of my friends got an A if you just study a little.

I had the pleasure of having Matt (moose) as my prof this semester, and I couldn't be more grateful. He is always there to help out if you are stuck on something. In addition, he is a fantastic teacher and truly cares about the content he is teaching and the students in his class.

Musso has been my favorite professor here at Mines. He provides an inspirational and positive learning environment. He is incredibly passionate and always willing to help or answer any questions in office hours or not. He is very easy to reach and truly wants all of his students to succeed. I highly recommend taking a class with him if you can! :)

Professor Musso, or as they call him in his hood "Moose" is one of the best professors I've taken at Mines. You can tell he deeply cares about the material he teaches and would rather you understand the material rather than constantly quizzing you on it. His class is fairly fast paced but he explains everything well so it is easy to follow.

Moose is so passionate and loves sharing his wealth of knowledge about geology. He makes the lectures fun and interesting. I always finish class with tons of new fun information about such a variety of geology things. It's such a fun class and you will learn so much. Just go to every lecture and listen :) -Charles

Moose is definitely one of the best professors I've had. His passion for geology is evident and he encourages his students to share the same passion he has. He is very accessible outside of class and even schedules optional review sessions before exams. I feel like I learned a lot in his class and I never worried about my grade.

Professor Musso has to be one of my favorite professors at Mines. He is always super pumped about his lectures and gives great feedback on homework and exams. The course is well planned, so there were never any surprise assignments either.
Professor Musso is by far one of the best professors I have ever had. He seems to really care about his students, going above and beyond to help his students.

Had to take a geology course from scheduling mishaps in computer science and I'm very glad it happened, because getting to take a class with Professor Musso was a great experience. Wonderful professor who taught the class well and made sure the students got the feedback and info they needed. Would happily take another geology class for his course.

One of the most chill and interesting profs I've ever had. Matt is super passionate about planets, moons, asteroids, basically anything in space. He makes you genuinely want to learn without worrying about grades. nothing is too boring or too difficult.

Jim Studhome worked with me day after day when I was struggling to get my papers done on time. He was always willing to extend the due date and give any feedback I needed. I highly recommend him if you're willing to communicate and ask for help.

He doesn't actually care. If you put a lot of effort in or like no effort at all he gives you the same grade. I went to talk with him about one of my papers, changed EVERYTHING he told me and then I was given my lowest grade on that paper. He doesn't actually care about your work, or improving your writing. The teacher only cares about birds.

I literally slept every day and he said I was one of his best students. He talks the entire class period about his own opinions. Kept mixing up the names of nonwhite people in his class. LOVES birds. Also likes poetry. Poetry about birds, even better.

Jim is the man. Absolutely loves birds, which makes class that much better. Very relaxed, but keeps a structured and interesting class. You get to choose your own topics for your essays unlike most NHV classes. If you can get Jim, do it. Less work than other classes, more meaningful work, and birds. Lots of Birds.
Really awesome and easy. Talks during recitation and is mostly for people who know how to write. If you can't write it might not be a good fit. Super chill and doesn't mind when you miss class.

Studholme is a great NHV prof. He's pretty into bird. He is also pretty lax and understanding. Discussions in class are interesting and fun. We were allowed to write about topics of our choosing unlike most other NHV classes. 1010 would recommend.

Studholme was amazing for NHV. Really nice guy, and he loves birds. We were allowed to choose any topic we wanted to right about which is different and so much better than any other NHV class. Discussions are fun and interesting. 1010 would recommend.
Good NHV teacher! Pretty liberal, makes class discussion interesting.
Awesome Professor!! Was an amazing professor for NHV. Great and easy discussions in class.

NHV's not my favorite class, but Studholme is definitely the one to get. Great discussions, generous grader, will look at rough drafts and give you good pointers (FOLLOW THEM). Bit set in his views, but that only makes the discussions more interesting. Like all NHV profs, will attempt to insert "relevance" into irretrievably LAIS topics.
Studholme is FANTASTIC! Super easy grader but very fair! Respect and fun- that's his class! Its great! BTW- I dont know the class code- its just Nature and Human Values...

There is no reason to go to prof. Bialeckis lecture. He reads through the notes word for word, so it is more time-efficient to try to decode them on your own. However, theyre written like wikipedia math articles. During COVID, all classes were online so tests and quizzes were open note. Copy the methods from the notes EXACTLY to succeed.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: If you go to lecture and take decent notes, the quizzes are nothing to worry about. Even the tests aren't too bad. I took him remote and everything was open note, so that may have made a large difference. Conveys information clearly and in a way that's easy to understand. Only complaint is he goes very slowly, might also be the remote format though

Dr. Bialecki is a good professor, and his class is relatively easy to pass. It's one of those courses where you get out what you put into it, especially since the only grades in the class are quizzes and exams. Is it obvious?
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Bialecki is the reason you go to Mines, to be taught by geniuses. If you take notes and do the COMPLETELY OPTIONAL homework, all assessments are beyond easy. He teaches the class from a theory standpoint, which makes entitled soyboys whine about not having everything handed to them. He's kind, and willing to help during office hours. Is it obvious?

Do you like not understanding what your teacher says? Do you like completely illegible handwriting? Are you ecstatic about a professor that is more interested in looking at the floor that at his students? Then this is the class for you! Have fun throwing your thousands of dollars of college tuition at a professor that has no joy in teaching.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--TEST HEAVY--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: If you can change, do it. Literally the worst teacher ever. Why they had him teach a class which is taken by a lot of non math majors is beyond me. All he does is look at the floor and copies from the textbook. I couldn't understand him half the time.
Pretty much just rewrote the chapters of the textbook on the board.

Took real analysis from him. His lectures completely prepare you for homework and tests, as long as you take fast notes and can read his (less than ideal) handwriting. The grading is really fair, borderline easy. I really wish he would smile once in a while though.
Very Nice and willing to help! He sometimes can be a little hard to understand but you get used to the accent really fast.  Tests are exactly like his review! One of my favorite teachers!!!!
One of the best mathematician in the department. Excellent lectures!!!!

Brilliant mathematician, horrible teacher. Should be teaching grad classes only if anything at all.  Skipped teaching Matlab language.  At times handwriting on the board is like chicken scratch. Always available for office hours, but condescending and not helpful if you go, it's like your presence annoys him.  Never reports grades, even if asked.

This teacher does not actually teach any of the material,he just explains how important the material is. If you ever go to office hours to ask questions,he will not answer them but instead tell you about his bowling trophies. He also said don't worry about not understanding, you're too pretty to get a bio degree, just get married to someone smart.

Overall taught horribly. I learned most of the material while doing the homework (which there is a lot of). Just go to class at the first half of the semester because he teaches those topics well and then don't for the second half.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment:
Von Herman gets too much hate. 
We love Von Herman.

I had him for calculus 3 and diff eq. He was an absolutely fantastic professor who not only cares deeply about his students and their success but about the content itself. He's an absolute mathematical genius and often brings snacks and his support dog to class. Absolutely one of the best professors I've ever had.

Von Herrmann is a nice guy, but his lectures are terrible. For context, he was deaf until he was 22 and only after that was able to hear, not very well either. He is great at math, but not at teaching it. His slides for lecture are poorly made, his handwriting is difficult to follow and its tough to know what he's saying. Avoid if possible.

Avoid Von Herman at all costs. He is deaf and struggles to hear students questions. Half of the time he answers with something completely unrelated. His handwriting is awful and he spends more class time talking about the importance of topics than actually teaching them. There were HW questions never covered in class. Prepare to self study!
He's very hard to understand and does not teach the material at a level that can be understood if you have no previous experience with it. Very nice guy, but can not answer questions.

This is probably one of the worst teachers I've ever had. You can't understand him, his writing, or anything he does. He does not respond to emails, and makes attendance mandatory (although not everyone may think its bad). He lashes out on students for the smallest reasons and makes a big deal out of it. If I could fire this teacher I would.
impossible to understand
He is very nice and tries to help as much as he can but he is hard of hearing so he is very difficult to understand during lectures a lot of the time
Very nice, hard to understand but wants to be as helpful as possible.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Group projects

comment: Prof. Alan is a great guy. He is ready to meet in office hours and is helpful. He is difficult to understand sometimes but he is someone to be respected. He is funny and encourages students to work harder. Exams are not easy but he provides good enough resources to prepare for it.

While Dr. Li clearly knows his stuff and cares about his students, I didn't find his teaching style helpful. He would reiterate very basic points while skipping over more complex material. He was good at explaining specific questions, though. Overall I felt lost in his class, but pulled through because of TA office hours.

Dr. Li is a very caring professor who will go out of his way to help you with your projects/coursework. He made a point to make the class more straightforward than the previous professor, and it is clear by his attitude that he wants everyone in his class to succeed.

This course was very easy and straightforward. Dr Li is very knowledgeable in the design of PCB's and he wants us to learn that skillset. This course provides a very unique skill to real life that I can see being relevant for many electrical engineers. He genuinely cares about each student suceeding!

Professor Li cares a lot about his students and makes sure to give out resources for this class that make the students lives 100x easier than previous professors who have taught this class. He cares about our learning, emphasizes creativity, and prepares us for industry. Great Professor and the people in his class have been so entitled and rude.

Unlike prior professors in ES who leave hardly any hints or first steps to solving the difficult labs, Dr. Li spends the time and energy creating templates to help focus on the core learning outcomes of each lab. His lectures may be a little disorganized, but it makes sense since he's new to Mines. He's a great professor who really cares!

Li brings a unique enthusiasm to Embedded Systems, a notorious yet beneficial course at Mines. Entitled students complain when they are challenged hence the bad ratings. However, approaching it with the right attitude helps students grasp fundamentals and apply them in a valuable final project, crucial for impressing employers.
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. Li, while perhaps having an incohesive lecture that can be difficult to follow, works really hard at making embedded a genuinely useful course. He puts a lot of time in that other professors won't into giving templates and helpful additions to maximize learning on the most important parts of labs, the center of the course. Great for real world.

Dr. Li is a very knowledgeable and caring professor gearing our learning towards real world skills. He is fair, as he decided to gear the class towards a more final project based course, he cut labs/lectures/exam in order to give us sufficient time to complete a resume/interview worthy project. He just needs to work on is more cohesive lecture.

Dr. Li has quite disorganized lectures, teaching off the homework problems rather than the prescribed course curriculum, resulting in his section falling behind by multiple lectures of content. It feels as if he forgot that his students are not experts and teaches as if the content is common knowledge, glazing over key concepts.

I enjoy Dr. Li's lectures. I like how he relates everything we learn to real projects and his actual experience working with circuits. The homework is hard, but the textbook is a great resource if you're struggling with a concept.

Professor Li has disorganized lectures, doesn't focus on topics that are crucial to understanding the content, and fails to give enough material for students to practice concepts that are important for both labs/exams. While grading isn't harsh, it is frustrating to learn in this class because the lectures barely teach us anything important.

This professor was clearly not prepared to teach this class. His lectures feel extremely unorganized. The extent of his notes and materials each class is 1 to 3 pieces of printer paper that he scribbles onto with a sharpy. Many of us have been using the previous professor's website for notes. Thank god we are because we are multiple lectures behind

Bridget was my favorite professor this semester. Unfortunately, I got stuck with a pretty bad group and was left doing all of the work but she was incredibly understanding. She gave our group extensions when needed and adjusted my grade to reflect the work I was doing. I found the class itself to be very fun. However, be prepared to put in the work
A little difficult at times but she has clear grading criteria.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Group projects

comment: This professor went above and beyond. She does everything her own way. A lot of the experience is dependent on your group so getting one with people you can work with is very important. You keep the same group the entire term.

Look, EPICS is a bad class, but Wetzel is your best bet. She is willing to work with your group and it is one of the few professors that it is possible to get an A from for this class. This isn't because she is soft or easy, but she clearly communicates what she wants from the group.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: The class isn't well designed, but she cuts out extra stuff and sticks to what matters. Has lots of insight and experience that's helpful in the project. The grading criteria is a bit odd, but that's the case for all the classes, so not her fault. Does her best to give fair grades based on the criteria. On papers, prefers quality over quantity

Dr. Wetzel is a great professor who is really invested in student success. If you are looking for EPICS to be a blow-off, do NOT take Wetzel. She will make you work for your grade, and is a tougher grader than most. That being said, you learn a lot in her class and it won't feel like a waste of time at the end of the semester. Would take again!
On a two point assignment, I received a 69 percent. I'm not sure how this grade was determined but it seemed arbitrary.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: EPICS is a poorly designed and implemented class, but she did her best to make it easy. She was very easy to talk to and offered help even with homework that wasn't related to her class. She also gave everyone the opportunity to make suggestions for overhauling the course. She would skip over a lot of the slides that were useless which was nice.

EPICS is a terrible class, lets establish that. However, she tries her absolute hardest to make the class at least a tiny bit interesting and will try her best to help out your group members on the design project. Even at 7:30 in the morning, this class is nowhere near as bad as it could be. GET THIS PROFESSOR FOR EPICS - you will NOT regret it.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Would take again

comment: Really nice teacher, really connects with students and wants everyone to do well and understand more than just what it takes to pass. The entire class is one semester long group project and she doesn't have a lot of control over when things are do. She tries her hardest to make the class an enjoyable experience, even at 7:30 am. Would reccomend.

While a good guy that could be funny sometimes, he talked a lot about unnecessary things that wasted a lot of in class project time. He never answered an email of mine but was very approachable in person.
Easy to talk to and gives good feedback on project ideas and helping with your arduino. Gives leeway for athletes and/or students who miss class.
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Dr. Ackerman is a great professor that knows how to teach students with little to zero experience unlike many professors at Mines. Class is very well planned and the help is available a LOT, so as long as you hit a couple office hours you are fine. Just make sure to go ask him what's wrong if your gadget doesn't work-he will know how to fix it.
rating_tags: Group projects--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Ackerman is a good professor. Because I have him for MEGN200 there is not much he had to lecture about. If you don't want to go to class you can take the attendance quizzes at home. This class is project-heavy, make sure you manage your time wisely. Professor Ackerman is really good at helping you troubleshoot your code.
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Jeff is very knowledgable and inspirational. Most of the grading is done by TAs who are nitpicky sometimes. For someone who is new to programming his class was overwhelming at times. His exams and quizzes were more difficult than anticipated. Be prepared to spend A LOT of time on programming and projects. Get help from TA's and office hours.

Excellent knowledge and experience in the class, but understands students and their busy lives enough to try to make the class enjoyable and fun. All quizzes and tests were open note and open internet, which reduced stress, but their difficulty came from the time limits you had to finish the quizzes/tests.
He is an awesome professor. He is always available to help students.
Very friendly, compassionate, and capable. Gives the students all the tools to succeed and tries to make the best experience for everyone.

The class starts out with not much work and then skyrockets into a ton of work once you start making your project. Ackerman is great and I'm pretty sure his design suggestions at the beginning of our project saved it from failing later on.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Group projects--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Ackerman is a great teacher. He is very enthusiastic about teaching and is always willing to talk with students about projects, whether for class or personal. He is a great addition to the mechanical engineering department at Mines. He keeps students enthusiastic when the homework gets unreasonable and lectures on the important topics.

Maybe she's better in upper-level classes, but in CBEN 110 she was not very informative. There was one question on a quiz that everyone misread due to poor wording, and she stood up front and laughed about how everyone got it wrong. Quizzes are only 5 questions and missing that one question brought my overall grade down 2 points. Not very funny.

Do think she would be good in higher level courses however in bio100 was very frustrated with how she handled the material. Think she was a fine lecturer for some concepts yet confusing and hard to follow for most. Expected a lot of out of class time for this course and ended up learning a lot not from her lectures yet out of class materials.

Dr. Beeler is a great teacher. She really makes sure that you understand the material, while letting you learn on your own too. She has tons of office hours, and makes sure you leave recitation with what you need to succeed. She made a huge effort to learn everybody's names (100+ students), and you can tell she loves her job and what she does.
dr beeler is one of the best professors i've ever had.
Good at explaining problems, bio lectures, and any other concept. Does all the tech work for the class. Math and biocomputational bio focus area.

Dr. Beeler is one of the best professors at Mines. She is super easy to get a hold of outside of class, cares about her students, and does a great job teaching. BIOL300 is not easy but show up and complete your assignments and you'll get a good grade.

BIOL 300/301 is very coding heavy and as a biology class/professor, she did an absolutely amazing job teaching. She is one the best professors I've had at Mines. She has an amazing lecture style and I genuinely feel like I learned a ton. I did have to put in the work for this class, but grading/HW/exams were so reasonable.

My friends and I refer to Prof. Beeler as Doctor Baller. She is in fact baller. I technically had 3 teachers for lecture but Dr. Baller was my lab instructor and she made lab easy to understand, fully answered questions and made lab somewhat fun. She also lectured really well on the days it was her turn. 10/10 recommend.
Dr. Beeler is super nice and really tries to be understanding of all the other things you have going on. As long as you try, it won't be hard to do well in her class.
Dr. Beeler really cares about her students and always made time for students outside of class.

Dr. Philtron is awesome. She has amazing lectures and is always available to help via canvas and out of class. She is really nice and relatable in her teaching and she makes material easy to understand. Homework and studios were manageable especially with the class time she gives to work on the studios to get help right there.
Moves very fast in lecture. Is not very understanding in terms of extensions or late work. Is knowledgeable if you ask questions or need help, but is not super nice.

Provided excellent materials for studying outside of class, definitely understood content and was great at explaining in class. My one complaint is the coding portion of the class is not accessible outside of lecture and a little difficult to get. Homework is steady and doable and prof. is available to answer questions during lab.
I found dr philtron to be a super chill person and a good professor.
Labs cover content before lecture material. My homework grade is great as a result and lab grades are hardly passing. Lab grading is also very harsh.
Strict with grading. Moves very fast with lecture material.

If you ever watch an Amy Schumer stand-up, you'll notice that internally you root for the comedian, but they are just so unfunny, uninspiring, pretentious, and boring. That's how this class was. I rooted for "Dr" Philtron but she never surpassed even the bare minimum expectations. Terrible lecturer, unfunny person, 1/10 overall. Shame ): I rooted):
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Prof. Philtron deeply cares about the material and is a great educator. By the end of her class, you will know the material. Yet the course was oversaturated with work. With 3 midterms, weekly difficult homeworks, a final project, and a final test, the class was challenging to keep up with. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on this class.

I liked professor Philtron. Her lectures weren't hard to sit through and what she lectured on was very similar to what you would find on the tests/ quizzes. My only issue is there is a huge grading discrepancy between her class and the other professors. The other classes are easy A's while this one is not. Very harsh on lab grading for no reason.

Dr. Philtron was a fantastic professor for 201. Because it's just an intro class, the class as a whole is pretty boring, but her lectures are really great and she's really passionate about the course content. If I get the chance I'm definitely going to take her again in the future for 424.

Slouka is a great person but not my favorite prof. The lectures were 1 or 2 examples, without any explanation beforehand or afterwards. Exams were significantly harder than homeworks or the provided practice exams and any conceptual questions were challenging for me as we never talked about them in lecture. Not a bad prof but would not be my pick.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lots of homework

comment: Slowka is super sweet but honestly an average professor. She goes through ~1 example per lecture on the topic you are learning about (and that's the whole lecture). She usually responds to emails within the day but doesn't have a ton of office hours available. Will definitely meet you in the middle if you need points back on something though.
Slouka is a caring teacher and explains concepts slowly and diligently
Very work heavy class, Slouka was very kind and excited to teach, but often we only got around to one or two examples which made the content much harder to understand

Very vibrant personality and provides a good classroom environment too. In class, they provide very good notes which is what I find most valuable in lectures. My notes were almost always enough to be able to do the homework problems later.

Slouka really cares about her students and takes a lot of time to make sure that everyone understands the content. The one downside of this is that we rarely get through more than one or two examples in class.

Prof. Slouka has made statics a great experience. She makes a tough subject enjoyable, and is super funny. She is still kind of new, but she is very knowledgeable, and she brings a lot of passion to the class and is very receptive to student input. She makes the classroom inclusive and her lectures have a great structure + consistency to them!
Overall cared about the students and tried making every lecture easy to understand. Prepare for a lot of homework but the exams are a good opportunity to boost grades.
I really liked taking Statics. Pretty easy class if you just do the homework. You can tell she may not be as experienced as some of the other professors but that does not really inhibit you much.
She is very enthusiastic and passionate about the material and her students definitely the easiest 8am class I've had to wake up for

Dr. Erdmann is one of the sweetest, most thoughtful professors I have ever had. While she definitely can seem a bit awkward and not confident at times, she overall does a good job of conveying the material. She is always open to questions and is very available outside of class. I took her for Calc III and Linear Algebra -- highly recommend her!

Professor Erdmann is a really nice person who learns students' names and is helpful during her office hours, but often gets confused and/or makes mistakes while teaching. She doesn't give off an air of confidence about the topics, and there are some concepts she just didn't explain. But for the most part, she will get you through the class.
Do not take Erdmann for stats. She is an awful at explaining any concepts and will make this class much more difficult for you.
I leave every class crying

She is awesome, took her for calc 2 and 3. Can be a little awkward and ditzy as first but truly cares about the material and your success. Takes the time to learn about each person in the class; knows everyone's name and where they are from.
Amazing Professor, makes advanced math concepts seem easy

She is one of the nicest most respectful not just professors but people you will meet. She always tries to make class fun and includes all students in lecture. She was so good I messed up my entire schedule and got 2 bad teachers just to get her.
Professor Erdmann is one of my favorite professors I have ever taken. She is extremely kind and helpful. I would recommend doing homework in office hours.

Professor Erdmann clearly cares about her students and is always happy to be in class. She is outstanding in encouraging class participation, and it makes the class more enjoyable and easy to understand. If you do not want to participate/talk in class, don't take her.

She has a very nervous energy, but she makes little jokes and there and cares about students! She makes very useful worksheets for in class and is very useful during office hours! She may not be for everyone, but she was a great professor to learn Calculus 2 with!
Poor teacher, not familiar with canvas, takes a long time to grade
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: D
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Refer to the other 1/5 reviews. Her lecture structure, knowledge with canvas, and assignment explanations are non-existent. Every class is a 50 minute rambling  session that goes on many tangents, full of opinions rather than facts. She expects note taking, but she rapidly bounces arounds slides, and often reads word-for-word. Easy class tho.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: Teaches this class as if anyone really wants to be taking it. Does not understand she is teaching to engineering students that do not have any interest.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Interesting lectures and course content (our section was world religions and globalization), but sometimes lacking in communication and organization. Canvas was not fleshed out. Fairly long readings that weren't always relevant to class. One paper, two group projects. Despite criteria and expectations being murky, grading was generous.

Dr. Raymond is extremely vague with grading and assignment expectations, often makes out-of-left-field comments, and is a very wordy/rambling lecturer. Hard to follow unless you're entirely invested in the content, but most of the work is completed outside class. Watch out for surprise group projects.

Her class seems intimidating, but she is kind, grades very reasonably, and happily gave extensions and made assignments easier when needed. Also, she is very passionate, making her lectures quite interesting, if a little long-winded. However, she still taught during a family emergency for a few weeks, but was very scattered, which was annoying.

She lacks canvas proficiency, and cannot give clear expectations for any assignment. Usually contradicting herself. She assigns an order of magnitude more homework than should be expected and her lectures consisted of her reading verbatim off the slides or launching into seemingly unconnected side tangents. Look at other reviews. this is a pattern.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Raymond's assessment expectations are very unclear, which is a considerable problem given that 85% of your course grade comes from three projects with poorly communicated criteria. What we were told in class and what was posted online were quite different and led to confusion over what mattered in a paper and what could be excluded.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: I created this profile just to warn everyone. Prof. Raymond lacks Canvas proficiency, leading to misinformation, disorganization, altered assignments, and unclear expectations. Her lectures are often unprepared, delayed by irrelevant personal anecdotes, and tangents. Emails seeking assignment clarity receive ambiguous and unprofessional responses.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Professor Jackson has no ill will, but he was never helpful with questions, constantly messed up equations in lecture, and didn't do many in-class examples. He doesn't show many practice problems in class, so homework is harder to approach. If you do have him, you might want to attend a different lecture section.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Dr. Jackson was not only barely prepared for his lectures, but his equations were often wrong on the slides, he did no practice problems, and he was very petty. He would always try to one up the other professors,  complain, and blame our section for why our test averages were 10 percent lower than every other section.

The class average at the end of the semester was a 67%, I received a B with a 65 in his class. He is incredibly difficult to follow in lecture, and is far more intelligent than your average student. However, he is not out to fail anyone and will go as far as curving the entire class to avoid doing so.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Tough grader

comment: Professor Jackson is an incredible intelligent individual, but his teaching ability is non-existent. He has difficulty explaining complex topics simply, which makes learning basic topics impossibly difficult.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: There is such an astounding disconnect between the professor and his students it is unbelievable. His expectations are unrealistic, lectures are useless, and there are nor references to get help. I cannot stress enough that this course with this professor should NOT be taken
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: This is the worst professor I've ever taken a course from. Professor Jackson is an incredibly intelligent individual and I can tell he wants students to learn. but unfortunately he is just not cut out to be a professor. He's so smart he cannot explain the material clearly and often skips large portions of advanced math because they are "trivial".
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Expects students to have lot of background knowledge.
He is a very good and smart person. He has great knowledge but has difficulty to teach it through. His tests are not easy.

Professor Jackson is a very tough teacher, he expects you to learn everything right away and be able to understand it. He is to smart to be teaching undergraduate students. On the bright side he is very willing to help if you show the initiative and can take criticism. He will be blunt to the point when giving you feedback and will not sugar coat
He does not explain thing very well during lecture, and the examples he works out in class do not usually apply to the homework
Bob can't conduct. He is probably great for choir, but doesn't know a whole lot about band. If you want a valuable music experience at Mines, take orchestra or jazz ensemble instead.

Bob is more concerned with making a captive audience listen to him playing piano than he is teaching music theory. This is the single worst explained class I have ever been in, and I've been in some bad ones. The textbook itself sucks and leaves one wishing for more help.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Inspirational

comment: Bobs a great guy and a friendly teacher. Hes good with music and his class is fun to be in. I do sometimes wish we would sing less Christmas songs/more modern songs in the fall semesters though. Highly recommend.
Poor leadership and bad advice.  I wouldn't take him again

Bob is the most understanding professor at Mines.  He will work around your schedule and needs, and as long as you show you are committed to the music program, he will go out of his way to help you.  Great guy.
Musical Traditions of the Western World is the absolute best LAIS elective at Mines. Writing is minimal, and the class is thoroughly interesting. I actually looked forward to class every day.
Took music theory from him and learned more than I thought was possible without much effort. The class is both easy and fascinating. What more could you ask for?
Awesome.
Dr. Robert is very personable and a great teacher. He is really passionate about what he teaches and he is just a really nice guy. I looked forward to his class rather than all my other classes.
A really easy class.  The amount of effort it took was really small, and getting an A in the class was really easy.
Not a particularly clear or engaging lecturer. Tests were fair and not too hard. Expect to learn from the textbook. Overall perfectly OK but not amazing (though he is very funny).

Explains chemistry in a fun way. Class is fun to go to- especially on demo days. You'll need to teach yourself a lot from the book. I'm not going to lie and say it's an easy A, but tests are fair and multiple choice.

Reallg helpful teacher and i love the fact that he is straight forward.  He does expect you to read the book and he WILL not teach you all you need to know because this is college.  Good teacher overall.

Dr. Racicot has a philosophy that you are to learn the class on your own, and he will help guide you.  Much of the class is spent with demos of reactions (usually explosive ones).  He's really a very kind, understanding guy though, and he's very helpful if you talk to him after class.  He tells you what you need to know for the test; study it well.

Fun teacher in class, but make sure that you have read your textbook ahead of time so you know whats going on. Very helpful if you ask; he saved my ass when I had a few issues in lab section. Under appreciated.

Great professor.  Very straight forward on what was expected from us and what was going to be on the tests.  Loud music and explosions almost every day!  Always go to the study sessions before exams and you'll get an A.

He's a great teacher to take if you had a good chem teacher in high school, but if you're not solid in chem, don't expect him to teach it. He's pretty funny, tells a lot of jokes in class, but overall, wants to be there less than the students, especially on fridays. He's really easy though, so if you think you got chem down, go for it
This guy doesn't really teach you anything but his class is entertaining.  He blows stuff up, tells outrageous stories (that aren't real but funny), and cancels class a lot
Awesome guy, sometimes not the best at covering information in lecture. Great teacher and good guitar player though.
He's a great teacher, he enjoys his work and explains everything you need to know for your tests. Also, he's really funny.

I've taken her again! Unlike many professors on campus, she is equipped to recognize and provide help when such is due. Still bad on emails. She is consistent and extremely accommodating/helpful. It's hard to explain, but I just feel comfortable/relaxed in her classes comparatively. I just feel like I have a chance.

One of the least engaging lecturers I've ever had. She finds ways to make even interesting topics bland and boring. She made this mandatory 100-level humanities course harder than it had any right to be with her weird, overly harsh grading criteria. Also was just generally unpleasant and seemed annoyed to be there or to answer questions.

Not a good teacher. Lectures were very repetitive. Did not respond to emails. Consistently forgot to assign homework then would give us less than 24 hours without a notification to complete the assignment. Constantly talked over the class in a discussion based course. She seems great at first until you learn her ways
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Normal amounts of homework. She is understanding if one of us is going through hard times and tries very hard to make sure we learn and do well in this class. She does not respond to emails very well, so go into office hours if you need to discuss something. Consistently showing little effort to be given in the class will hurt one's grade.

Lots of lecturing with some really weird tangents/perspectives on history. For example, she had an entire lecture about how conflict over oil was the entire reason for WWII...? Would take everything she says with a grain of salt. Easy homework, I just skimmed the readings and did well on the discussions. The paper wasn't too bad.
At Mines these LAIS classes are great information but some professors take it way to serious, Osgood is one.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: She consistently assigned online group discussions without telling us about them in class.  She talked down on us like children and regarded opinions other than her own as wrong.  She made incorrect comments about Christianity and clearly showed bias against those who did not see eye to eye with her, including me.  I got an A though.
She doesn't know what she's saying, reads us the slides and STILL gets facts wrong, treats us like we're 12, and has awful group projects. Do not recommend.

Didn't enjoy the class, very repetitive and talks to us like we're children. Group work is also annoying, but its a fairly easy class. She really tries to be a good professor, but she talks down to us and thinks she's better because she's not an engineer.

Challenging, but much easier than several of the other NHV professors. All of her papers revolve around the same topic (of your choice)<-- very helpful! Gave one "research" day per paper (you don't have to do anything that day)

Honestly Tim was kinda bland for studio. He would help if you had questions and all that. He was not responsive to emails which was annoying for absences. Test grading was a joke but thats a department policy so good luck guys. I wouldn't pick him again given the choice but hes a fine enough teacher.
I had Prof. Ohno for studio and he was pretty chill. He explained the content from lecture briefly at the beginning of studio and would be available for help during work time.

I had Ohno for PHGN 100 Studio. He's always just there. Knows what he's talking about at the beginning, and will go around with the TA's to answer questions. Try to get him for studio, but I can tell his lectures will be crazy boring

I had Ohno for studio and I thought it was nice that he would go around with the TAs and answer questions as well. I thought that his explanations were really easy to understand and helped the content make more sense. Would recommend :-)

Ohno is extremely disorganized in his specialized classes but is a very easy grader. We didn't have a single assigned task on Canvas, and yet he passed everyone based solely on a few presentations and participation in class. Overall, he's a fun prof to talk to but will talk straight for an hour about R-values if you don't stop him.
I had Dr. Ohno for PHGN100 studio. The professor's role in studio is small, but Dr. Ohno is a solid choice.

I took this class because I wanted to get a minor in Energy with my ChemE degree. This class was so poorly structured that the projects all slid to the last two weeks of class. He could not keep his mind made up about how he wanted the projects to look like, and failed to provide his ideas before we submitted. He should stick to physics.
I had him after PHGN200 went online due to COVID. He handled the transition better than most other professors and was on time, responded to emails, and very helpful.
Never responded to email, difficult to contact. His lectures are monotonous and I don' t feel I actually learned anything from them. Overall disappointing.
What can I say? He's a Stud. You will never fall asleep. Lectures are both useful and entertaining. Looks you ask? He has all the gains.

I had him for Intro to Energy once a week during a three hour time slot.  He always spent time on new topics each week, although lots of the students had a hard time paying attention during lectures (although who doesn't with 3 hour lectures?). The class was super easy, I ended up passing without going to 2 of the classes

Great teacher, optional homework. Homework is worth doing to at least study for the tests, turning it in minimally impacts your grade though so whatever.   People hate her but if you stay ahead and study for the tests a couple weeks in advance you will be fine. Good TA's, make sure to get all your labs checked before you turn them in.

Easily the hardest class I've ever taken.  You have to teach yourself all the material.  Test averages are 50%.  My biggest recommendation is to find an upperclassmen and get advice/ look at their lab papers for the formatting, look at previous tests.  And whatever you do, do your work early enough to get the TAs to check it.

Jealous of all of you that took rock props before it was a weed out class. Dr.  Graves is very knowledgeable and does not put up with any non sense from students.  Overall a great learning experience.

Extremely knowledgeable, however completely open about her intent to fail students. She actually was upset when the TAs reported that our class average at the midterm was in the high 70s. Make no mistake, if you are not one of the smarter people in the class be prepared to receive a C or a D depending on your level of effort.

3 Credit class that has a 3 hour lab.  The workload is very heavy as a 5 credit class.  Exams are very fast paced with no that much time to think. Outstanding professor, but Petroleum department grew too much so this is another weed out class.  Good luck if you can get a B in this class.

Extremely full of herself, and generally insulting to the students.  She knows her stuff, but is not interested in dealing with students problems.  Be prepared to rely on undergraduate TAs for any help you might need.  Overall, a typical Mines professor.
Dr. Graves is one of the best instructors I have ever had.  This is a professor who knows how to command a 100+ person classroom!
easy class. everybody got A or A-. wasted something like 5 classes to explain Darcy law. she is funny. thinks USA is the best in the world
No Comments
Amazing lady, pure Grade AA Cougar....

Prof. Prahl was amazing. She made difficult content easy to comprehend and explained it in ways that were easy to understand. The last 10 minutes of her lectures were usually up for questions/homework help, which allowed some one-on-one time for any lingering questions/tricky homework problems. Overall her lectures are incredibly well structured

Professor Prahl is amazing. Her lectures are well structured and she does a great job of breaking concepts down. She encourages questions and is great at finding new ways to explain things. She is also very caring and easy to talk to. I did not necessarily love the content of the class, but she made it interesting and enjoyable.
Great teacher, really conveyed the content well in a way easy to understand

Professor Prahl was a great teacher and covered the content very well for Calc 3. She talks pretty quietly but is easy to understand and talk to. I don't really have anything to dock her on, so I would definitely recommend.
Good professor, clearly cares a lot about teaching
She is the most hilarious teacher Ive ever had. Makes the funniest jokes and has such a positive attitude!!!!!

Prof. Prahl is quiet but super funny and a great teacher! She is respectful and really easy to talk to! She also encourages questions and will take time to clarify any uncertainties you have with her examples :)

Professor Prahl is very sweet although she is fairly quiet sometimes. She definitely cares about her students and is always open to conversations and questions before or after class. She is passionate and enjoys what she does and is a very sweet and chill prof to have for calculus.
Very supportive!
She is awesome! She wants you to succeed and is relatively lenient on late work. I felt very prepared for the exams after just attending her review classes and doing provided practice.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Amazing lectures

comment: Group projects were out of control. The professor would never deliver unbiased ruling. Like virus.

I would ignore older 2019-2021 ratings as they don't seem accurate anymore. In my most recent sed strat class, I found Prof.
Piret to be engaging and interesting to learn from. She always checks in throughout lectures to make sure everyone is understanding her content. Her slides can be a *bit* of a web to follow but that's about it :-)

Very knowledgeable and pretty good at lecturing. Her lecture slides can be a bit confusing and sometimes the class content isn't organized very well, but for strat, most of the quizzes are basically open note. The lab is difficult and frustrating sometimes and it doesn't help that much with understanding the class content. Overall, not a bad prof.
The professor seems not well prepared with the class. Worst organized class that I have ever taken.
She was overall unclear and difficult to deal with. I appreciate she has a big job in teaching a lot of students stratigraphy but that does not justify her disrespectful approach.
Great class, tough field projects. Came away learning a ton.
great!

Would suggest taking a class from a different prof for your sedimentatolgy requirement. My experience was that she was an ineffective lecturer, and was also condescending and seemed to enjoy humiliating students.

Didn't quite care about students. When we asked questions, she didn't guide us with any geological thinkingg or reasoning... it was like interpretation A was ok, interpretation B was good, and C was nice as well.
I didn't think she is a good professor or instructor. When something went wrong, she would just let it go worse without doing anything. I didn't think she has any character in leadership.

Dr Aaen cares about his class and ensures that his students have a good fundamental understanding of the concepts. What really stood out to me was his reception to feedback, quickly implementing changes into his course and office hours. While I found the class difficult, his office hours were a fantastic place to help expand my knowledge.

Aaen is a boring instructor and a very awkward professor. Instead of focusing on improving his own teaching style and helping students learn the subject, he blames the students instead. Whenever you approach him about a circuits specific question, he puts you through an investigation about other professors in the department. Avoid at all costs!

Aaen cares about his students and always helps outside class. However, EENG282 has SO MUCH math in the lectures that I rarely ever got the concepts. Peter assumed we already knew complex numbers so I really struggled. The final was HARD and heavily swayed toward the 2nd half of the semester. Labs took forever and made no sense. Prepare to struggle.

Aaen is the best professor I've ever had at this school so far. His lectures don't skip around, and he tells you exactly what you need to know, but sometimes gives some insight as to when you might use it in the real world. He also held weekly zoom calls outside of lecture where we could ask him anything and he'd help us personally. 1000/10.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Wow, I really could not recommend Prof Aaen enough. He knows how to teach, his expectations are clear, and he is really understanding of real life. If something comes up he gets it and can make it work. Instead of teaching "just know it" he teaches why you should know it and how the "it" came about. (Derivations, explanation of where...)
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: By far the best professor I've had at mines yet. If you email, he will extend homeworks, labs, anything. He knows students are busy, and he will go above and beyond to help. He personally helped with a circuit I needed to make for a design class. And on top of being a good person, he is very good teacher, takes feedback well, and personates well

Wonderful professor, that has been more than accommodating during the pandemic. Professor Aaen provides intriguing lectures with hard, yet manageable homework and labs due every week. It is not an easy class but if you show up and pay attention you will do just fine. I highly recommend Professor Aaen to anyone looking to take electrical engineering
rating_tags: Respected--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Excellent professor. One of the rare few that are technically proficient and good instructors. Mines has a lot of professors that are great researchers but poor teachers. Peter is definitely not one of them.

He always explains the topic clearly and explains what it is actually used for in the industry. This extra context makes the topics a lot more accessible and gives better motivation toward why you should learn it. He's also always available and provides great help and feedback.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Dr. Aaen does a great job at introducing the electrical engineering major at mines in circuits for electrical engineers. Throughout the pandemic, he has been continually understanding and a great lecturer. He is very easy to understand and connects the topics to the pragmatic world in a very engaging manor. Would absolutely recommend and take again
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--Caring

comment: Great professor!  She moved quickly through the content but always got through everything that she needed to for the day which was extremely helpful.  When asked questions, she slowed down and provided good explanations. I organized my schedule next semester specifically so I could have her for chem II.
Allows students to make the best notes (post fill-in-the-blank slideshows). Very understanding of circumstances. Prepares students very well for the tests.
Just a solid lecturer.
Moyer literally read from slides all semester. Every once in a while, she would give is 30 seconds to do a problem that would take me 5 minutes. Lectures were not very engaging.

honestly puts most of the other mines professors to shame. she's so organized, she actually knows how to use canvas and her teaching format is perfect. I changed around my schedule specifically so that I could get her for chem 2 also.
Dr Moyer suffers no fools, but is always willing to help if you put in the work.
Dr. Moyer is very helpful outside of lectures and is very clear about what is expected in her class! She is super nice and she can move fast but it's Mines so most profs do.

All the people who say she goes fast don't understand that she is going at an amazing pace. She barely completes the material everyday and if she does she lets us out a little early. At mines you will quickly learn a professor that can get through the content efficiently and consistently everyday is the best type of professor you can have.

She is good at explaining things and would recommend taking her class. The only concern I have about taking her is how quickly she moves through content; it's hard to keep up if you want to write everything down (she encourages you to download her slides and fill in the blanks, and doesn't leave much time for those not choosing to do this).

Dr. Moyer moves fast through the presentations but stops to answer questions and slows down when needed. The presentations were also posted after lecture. She was available outside of class and answered questions well. The in-class examples prepared me well for exams/hw. The textbook helped but the presentations talked about the same concepts.

Dr. Moyer was good. She goes very fast during lectures, it is very difficult to make it through with a physical notebook. Is very available however, and offered to meet with us any time/come to a private study group.

A very kind guy and knowledgeable on what he's teaching. The only problem I have is that his lectures can be pretty monotone and boring. I still recommend him as a teacher. He is also normally very lenient and will curve grades more than they should be. Not saying that's a bad thing though :)

This class is vague, can be hard to grasp. Lectures are boring, but you can figure out most of what you need from the lecture slides that are posted. Homework is tricky sometimes, but he's helpful in office hours. Grading is really lenient so it's easy to get an A. Quizzes and tests are all open note but that doesn't make them too bad. Decent prof
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria
