comment: So, so boring... His tests are open everything, so naturally, they are very hard. I should have gotten below a 50 on a test but ended up with an 88 because that's just how easy he grades. Long story short: boring professor, easy labs, difficult exams but grades so easily, medium-ish homework.

The only reason I went to class was to get other homework done. The exams, more in particular the final, I thought was stupidly hard and unfair. Thankfully he grades way too easy... but still. You have to be a super dedicated, super eager to learn student if you're gonna be awake in this class and get something from it.

I can't count how many times I dozed off during his class. He explains material in a monotone way, and half of it never made sense. It wouldn't make a difference going to or skipping his class, because he never explains anything more than what is on the slides. The only positive is that you can retake an exam and get half the points missed back.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: He started one lecture discussing diodes and ended the class discussing engineering mistakes that ended in civilian deaths. It was very grim.

Napping was a better use of my time than sitting through his lectures. He is very ineffective at explaining material. In a review lecture before an exam, he could not answer several questions in a row as he was not familiar enough with the material.
All the hype about him comes from how nice he is which I agree with. But his lectures are pretty disorganized and hard to follow. He jumps all over the place and it's pretty boring honestly.

This class is difficult to understand fully, yet you can get an A without truly understanding the material. Schowalter definitely needs to find a way to become a more engaging lecturer, and present more general methods for problem solving rather than doing specific circuit problems every class. He also does not follow the textbook.

Class was difficult but the exams were graded so easily that people slacked off and got complacent with only a moderate level of understanding. Schowalter was friendly and helpful with questions, but needs to be more clear, direct and organized, and address the difficult parts of the material before they arise in lab or on exam.

She seems to lack a lot of confidence. She generally goes well over the alloted lecture time and speaks to students like they're idiots (unintentionally I'm sure). She lacks energy and charisma. The class is already on a less than exciting topic and she doesn't add much to ease the boredom.
She talks to you like you are a 5 year old sometimes

Excellent lecturer. Provides tons of examples that really help students understand the process and concept. Easy to take notes cause board is organized. Uses games for review and gives winners extra points on the exams. Very willing to help students at any time.
Gives really good examples - easy to learn Calc III from.
meant to b a calc instructor..organized and professional
Thorough lectures and sound mathematics.
No Comments
No Comments
Grad student teaching freshmen Calc I basics = disaster

I have never been more disrespected by a human being in my entire life. She will take every opportunity to publicly humiliate you over simple mistakes. Always comes into lab with the worst attitude which makes for a really lovely learning environment.

She was discriminatory towards me and my latino heritage. She made me wash someone else's equipment  and I lost part of my grade because I could not finish my experiment while cleaning someone else's mess.

She treated me badly because I don't speak english very well. She does not deserve to be in a position of power because she takes advantage of this and humiliates people. She also made a classmate clean other people's mess because she did not like him and he could not finish his experiment.
She does everything in her power to make your life harder than it needs to be. This already stressful class was made worse by her presence.
Lovely human being who really cares about the learning and well-being of her students. Just don't be stupid in lab (by stupid I mean unsafe) and you will have a wonderful time!
Literally just dont be a chemE, and have common sense in the lab. she's nice after ochem 1

One thing she knows for sure is how to make one dislike been a chemistry major. Unfortunately, she is the only one to be a lab coordinator you will see the most . A pro at evil eye too, which is not a useful Skill.
OH MY GOD!

Ramona does not know anything and grades on how well you clean stuff and how organized you are because she is anal and has no excuse for why. She makes OChem lab a bad experience where even the TA's are afraid of how she will treat them.

Williams has it easy when he only has to lecture for 30 mins. The remaining 45 mins is reciting your reading homework (8-40 pages each class) to your group of 6. Teaches and tests on papers he wrote. Final assignments graded one day before final grades are due, so it's almost impossible to submit a regrade request. Teaches woke ideology as fact.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: This course is not worth taking. Wasted energy, time, and money.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment:
As an individual, I want to say he's about a 3, but passion for the subject bumps him up from a 3 to a 4. He's fun to listen to.
With the class, way too much technical reading, but you can scrape at least a B with 30 minutes, a basic understanding, and ctrl+f.
5 pages in reflections, and two other big papers. Even worse if you're grad.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lots of homework

comment: The material for Robot Ethics was fairly broad, and for the CSCI section, more technical than HASS. I felt like each topic was given due time and was relatively well explored. The participatory nature of the class seemed to lend itself well to keeping people engaged, especially given that ethics pairs well with discussion.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: Literally the worst teacher at Mines. Someone remove this guy because he does not deserve the job position.

Robot Ethics was a cool class if you like debating/psychology.

To the other raters, this class isn't hard. Sure it might be if you write like an 8th grader. I always got decent grades on my papers for putting in a resonable amount of work. Mediocre effort equals mediocre grades, especially since this is a Senior level or Graduate level course.

Requires more pages to read than a HASS class, and the course is only based on papers/how many times you talk in class/presentations/and a final 12-page essay. Turn around time for one-page reflections happens after three are already due. No chance to take feedback to make other reflections better. Grades all essays as if they're PhD documents.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Tough grader

comment: To the user below me, how the heck were failing Robot Ethics course?

Worst I've ever had in my entire college career. You may be looking at taking this class to fill your schedule. If so seriously consider looking elsewhere. Took nearly the entire semester to get grades back on papers and for a course based on papers that's pretty bad. Had one office our a week and was no help outside. No respect for students.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Beware of pop quizzes--Tough grader

comment: Dr Petruska is incredibly intelligent and a great teacher. The material is very difficult and he can be intimidating to approach when you need help. His office hours are very helpful and I recommend not missing them. If you are putting the effort into learning he will put effort into helping you.

Personally found him to be largely condescending. I felt like he was picking and choosing the students he helped based on how much he liked them. Not sure he showed up to one office hours session on time the entire semester. His lecture notes in person are unorganized, and the notes he posts on canvas are not helpful.

Dr. Petruska is incredibly intelligent, and it's clear that he understands the subject matter. However, he entirely lacks the ability to clearly teach this information to students. He seems to think students already know the material and employs half-lectures and then tries to prompt students through example problems, most of which go unfinished.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: When I asked for help on a group project, he never actually gave us any help; unless telling us we're just wrong is helping. He also never answered us for extra office hours, dancing around the question every time. I've never received a lower grade on an exam than through him. No explanation for my errors, no partial credit, no mercy.
Never completes full examples. During office hours he is hard to approach with questions. Pick somebody else

One of the few professors who teach their subject by lending an intuitive understanding. He is one of the most approachable professors and loves out of the box thinking for a solution. If you want to get into robotics, he is the man!

MEGN544 is one of the basic courses in Robotics at Mines which requires basic knowledge in Dynamics, Matrix Algebra, Control Systems and Matlab &Simulink. Dr. Petruskas homeworks and quizzes are great, requiring substantial efforts. He is very helpful and patient when it comes to answering questions. Teaching could be improved, contents are great!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: The most caring professor I've ever met. If you know what you want, he will make sure you achieve it. Everything that I have learnt at Mines, it is because of him.
Would be much better if classes were planned a bit better.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Dr. Tenorio has all the style of the old-fashioned professors when he lectures. His lectures are rigorous and well-structured. If you do not have a solid mathematical background, you may not enjoy his course as much as he does rigorous math. That being said, the two courses I took from him were two of my three favorites at Mines.

Dr. Tenario is a very funny professor who is very passionate about his teaching subject. His lectures entertaining but very fast. Since he is writing so fast, he also makes a lot of notational mistakes which sometimes makes his notes confusing. His homeworks and tests are not too difficult, but it is difficult to learn to material at times.

By far the worst experience I have ever had at Mines or in school in general. Everything is "easy" and we should have learned graduate level linear algebra in linear algebra 101. If you do manage to go to office hours be prepared to be told you are stupid, and he cannot help you with the homework. Class average on the midterm was < 30. Atrocious.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Luis Tenorio is very smart, but he shouldn't be teaching this class. Extremely unorganized, hard to follow, doesn't know the prereqs to the course, gets frustrated in office hours and class if you don't understand what he thinks/claims is 'simple', has extremely high expectations of what students should know. Hardest class I've taken at Mines.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Tenorio gets some flak for being a difficult professor, and while this class was one of the harder ones I've taken, I've also learned more in it that I have in any other class. He emphasizes student understanding instead of just regurgitation, which I really appreciated. A little intimidating at first, but super helpful in office hours.
Very fast paced and not lots of explanation. Even office hours were difficult to understand material. We used R for the class and he didnt know how to use R so he couldnt help much with code.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: He explains things in lecture rigorously. Expect it to be heavy on mathematical notation in his lectures. He explains things well in class and the homework is excellent preparation for the tests. He has a notable accent, but it never seriously conflicted in my ability to understand him.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Luis is a great teacher if you enjoy math.  He goes through material from the point of view of a mathematician in order to teach you to make logical conclusions for yourself.  He also has a lot of insight to how the math is used in application - either in analysis or in engineering, which is hard to come by.  Would definitely recommend.

His notes are unorganized, confusing and only provided via lectures (don't miss a class!). The book is dense and he deviates from it frequently. He will help you if you ask, but will normally just give you the answers to the problems because he can't be bothered to explain the concepts. He teaches both the primary graduate stats courses at Mines...

His lectures were pre-recorded from 3 years ago but had relevant information. When speaking one on one he is helpful and detailed with his explanations and will figure it out if he doesn't know. His email response rate is terrible but he makes this clear. Gives good study material. Overall, good professor but you have to do your part.

Geer's lectures are mostly just example problems, nothing special. He does work through the example problems from scratch, so he isn't just reading off an answer key. He works through examples with the students and answers questions as needed. He also provides very good test/quiz prep material.

Don't expect to get emails back from him but other than that I thought he was a rather good professor. Taught material well and easy to follow for the most part. Homeworks were very long, usually due to hand calculations, but the solidworks parts were relatively easy. Get started on final project early because it is long and a little challenging.

Though I have heard good things about Dr. Geer in the past my experience this semester was anything but. With an all online class that heavily used both SolidWorks and Mathcad, you think he might be able to respond to your emails. Solidworks crash during your exam? Well guess what he doesn't really care. I would not recommend Dr. Geer.

Professor Geer is a wonderful teacher, and he makes sure to keep himself accountable. He actually grades tests, which is becoming a more and more rare occurrence with research teachers passing work to others, and he really cares about the learning of the students. I would take this class 100% with Geer.

Very caring and always incredibly helpful in office hours. A mediocre lectures who stumbles around a bit and makes plenty of errors to keep you engaged enough to catch. His test/quiz questions were generally very elementary problems. Want an easier A? Take him. Want to understand the material the best? You may want to look elsewhere.
Geer is great! He's really understanding of students and teaches the material well. Very approachable with questions and gives grades students deserve.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LECTURE HEAVY--Would take again

comment: I really enjoyed his class. He is super helpful during office hours and has plenty so all students can get help during this time.
Professor Geer is great. He's a new professor and this is apparent during lecture some days, but he really cares about his students and their success.
Best prof ever.

Thanks to all the dumb petroleum engineers taking this class. It's because of their lack of intelligence that I managed to get my only A at Mines simply by showing up. She explained everything very well, literally dumbs it down to students athletes' level. Very helpful and accessible during office hours. Plus she's pretty hot too.

Only two tests (not including the final exam). They're not too tough, but don't blow them off. People will tell you that "Earth is an easy A, you don't have to study" but those are the people that make 60-80% on the tests. Ria gives loads of extra credit though that's super simple-- even if you don't need it (yet) it's great to have a safety net.
Loved Dr. Ria, loved the class, the professor everything. Finished with over 100% and lots of extra credit, want to take more classes with her
Greatest professor at the Colorado School of Mines!
She is a good teacher.
DOPE !  best teacher at mines ;)
She's DOPE!
If you want an easy A for your science requirement, take this class. If you want to actually learn the material, take another class. She seems to be too hung up on the definition of "theory."

Horrible teacher. Cannot explain anything, but she will try and end up having to say “Oh I'll get back to you next class.” Had her for studio too and couldn't explain what I needed and word for word she has said “Well I'm not sure, this should be working,” and we ended up having to ask a TA. The slides she makes are next to useless as well.

Malespina is a very nice person and all my interactions with them personally were good. However, I learn very little from lecture and find the teaching bad. Oftentimes taking far too long to go over easier concepts and leaving us to figure out harder ones on our own. There is an opportunity for 2% of extra credit at the end of the semester though.

Avoid Professor Malespina at all costs! She sounds like she's reading off a teleprompter, she does not appear to know what she is talking about in lecture, she does not answer emails promptly, and the way she presents the material makes it hard to connect concepts. I made an effort to go to other professors' lectures whenever I could.

The lectures were fairly boring, and she was not available to answer emails. She makes multiple mistakes during lectures and has a difficult time explaining concepts. Beware her lecture, avoid it at all costs!

Professor Malespina is a relatively new professor here and it shows. While it is clear that she cares for her students and the topics, she simply does not have the experience to be a good professor. The lectures were very boring and hard to engage with, she is not equipped to answer very many questions and often times cant answer at all.

They changed some things about the course prior to this semester and from my experience phys 2 was great. It was very well laid out and the structure of lecture, studio and homework was rather fun. Prof M. Did a good job covering all of the topics and any questions. She is also enthusiastically available for office hours and during studios.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment:
Somehow made very interesting concepts very boring in lecture. She doesn't know what she's talking about, and it's evident in lecture.
I also had an issue with my iClicker and she refused to give me the points for coming to lecture despite ITS emailing her it had been broken.
She does not know what she is talking about. Her lectures do not connect or help with the homework or studio problems at all.

Seems like a very nice person, but covered the class topics in an unhelpful surface-level way, and asked for "questions, comments, or concerns" after every single thing she said. I have heard that they are making some changes to the course this coming semester, so hopefully the lectures will improve. I did not find them useful.

Though Prof. Malespina was kind and thoughtfully explained the majority of questions presented in lecture, I didn't feel that any of the more challenging nuances of major topics were ever covered in an informative or helpful way. The easier facets of each topic were presented in lecture, leaving students extremely confused with homework problems.
One of the best professors I've had at Mines. Very good professor and an even better person. I would've had him for all my classes if I could.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: I loved Prof Allam but sometimes he did go a little fast in lab. What helped me was to read the slides just before lab or as it was starting and try to do what I could before he gave us instructions. Otherwise his lectures are super helpful and he gives good tips and insight. He leaves time do the homework in lab while he's there to help!
This man was a solid 9/10.

Good professor, but his grading criteria is sometimes unclear which can be frustrating. How hard he grades varies quite a but sometimes from assignment to assignment. Overall, a good professor besides that one caveat.
Took him spring 2020. Design was kinda a lame class, but we all had to take it. Despite that, professor Allam made it interesting and it wasn't too bad. Definitely a good professor for this class.

Really great professor. Had him when Covid hit and he handled the online transition so well especially with it being a project based class. Funny jokes every class and just really easy going. Doesn't force you into doing something specific for your project and is just really open to ideas.

This guy is great! He makes a lot of dad jokes and is overall a fun person to be in class with. His lectures are a little slow which is awesome if you're learning solidworks for the first time. He is really nice and has a sunny demeanor. He is really passionate about what he teaches. Lastly, he is always happy to help you and answer any questions.

Great professor. Down to Earth, humble, smart, and an overall good guy. He helped our team make it to the finals for the competition and never gave me a hard time (I was often late because I commute and they were doing construction). Overall a great professor.
The class that Dr. Allam teaches was definitely not my favorite but he made it much more bearable by being one of the most down to earth and reasonable professors I have had.

I took Yosef Allam during his first semester at Mines, and I thought he was very caring and helped to give feedback in Epics. Epics itself was a very stressful class, but with him as a professor, I was not quite as worried for my grade. In the end, most people in my class ended up with A's. In a subjective class such as Epics, you want Yosef.

I had Prof. Thompson for MTGN202 for the Fall Semester of 2023. His lectures were interesting and a little hard to follow. He does his lectures by writing on paper instead of using a more formal method like slides. He encourages hard work from the students, and it is hard work to do well in this class. His office hours are very informative.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Lecture heavy

comment: Steve Thompson was OK. He taught the material well enough, and would work through examples sloppily in class, following a handout. Sometimes he would get lost and need help from a student. There was like 1 homework a week and on there would be 1 problem that he just didn't teach. He was great in office hours and explained everything there well.
Steve is the worst prof. I have ever had at mines, I have never had a grade below a b- with over 90 credit hours at mines.  Does not teach, impossible to learn the material yourself.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Even though I like professor Thompson and he is a nice guy who likes teaching the material, he doesnt do a great job explaining things. I think half of it has to do with the material being very difficult to explain in general, but his lecture methods are weird and his note taking is hard to follow.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: AVOID THIS TEACHER!!!!!! Basically all the ratings below sum it up but there was no structure and is horrible with canvas. If he is the only professor available for this class, save it for next semester and take it with a different professor. Trust me.

Quite possibly the worst professor I have ever had. His lectures are all over the place and often lack content. He teaches how to do the homework after its done, and does not even know how to use canvas. If you can save yourself choose literally anyone else. He grades extremely hard considering he doesn't even teach the content you have to find it.

Dr. Thompson does a good job of clearly explaining material and telling you exactly what you need to know for the test. Sometimes lecture content gets a bit random, but it isn't too bad. Get ready for some spongebob references.
Kind of strange; but he's passionate about the subject matter and he makes it very clear what he expects you to know and be able to do
Prof Thompson makes corny jokes and wants to see people at office hours. I am in the class right now and it has been pretty easy so far. The syllabus says there is a text book, but I didn't buy it.

Beren began the semester teaching too slow and had to cut material, disappointing but okay. The content that was taught was very clear, possibly due to the slower class pacing. You will walk in on the first day and be like "this guy is cool", probably would be even cooler outside of class.

The class was structured in a very strange way where the pacing didn't really make sense at times. I still think he taught the content well, which isn't very hard, but his teaching style has some flaws. He is a cool guy, and always teaches with a positive attitude.

Prof Beren is an awesome chem professor to have. He always had applicational examples to the real world and he would explain the content very clearly and concisely. Respect to him as well for making light of his near-death incident of breaking his femur during 2023. Always got the most out of lectures as well.

Dr. Beren is the greatest professor. He's the modern-day Jesus Christ. I had both Chem I and Chem II with Dr. Beren and I wouldn't have it any other way. He's very chill, listens to class feedback, and values your time. Both these Chem classes were difficult for me but thanks to the light that is Dr. Beren, I was able to succeed.

For just the lecture section of 121, Beren was a solid professor for the content. I enjoyed going to his lectures, and he seemed to have a good time teaching them. Attendance isn't mandatory, but your IClicker grade is mostly based on attendance. Would take the class again with him if I had to.

One of the best Chem 1 Professors at this school if not the best. The class size is huge, but his lectures are thurough and well planned. He's a very funny man. I've always hated chemistry but I loved his class.

I actually took Thermodynamics with Dr. Beren in the summer. He was teaching it for the first time. However, he looks like he used to teach this course for years! Very helpful (especially in Office hours), clear, respectful and generous with grades. Best teacher ever!
Professor cared deeply about his students success and was open-minded to problems during the semester. Can be a hard class but he makes lectures interesting and fun to go to
Gives good feedback lecture can get tedious but there is a fair amount of iclicker/reef questions

I thought the class was challenging but also rewarding Very math and coding heavy The Text is helpful and has most of the equations that you need Lectures showed how the math was being applied to problems. The quizzes are essentially the same as homework Exams would be what I'd expect in a grad class Homeworks were ~30 pages ~10 hours Use TA hours
Did not care about students and made the class much more difficult than needed. I would not recommend taking any of Dr. E's courses.

Professor Eliasson made every effort to make the lives of her students far difficult. She does derivations for an hour, gives a half worked example, and then complains when students don't understand. She often bragged about her lawsuits with other staff and about how much she enjoys “taking away students degrees.” STAY AWAY
rating_tags: Tough grader--Group projects--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Dr. E prioritizes research over teaching, offering little help during office hours and often redirecting questions to the textbook or her notes. She discourages questions, belittles students, and relies heavily on TAs for office hours, homework, and exams. If you're interested in composites, consider another class I've lost all interest.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Shouldn't be teaching undergrad courses.

The lecture was very heavy with derivations instead of examples that would help us on the midterms and final. The other sections use mastering but they use their own homework that takes several hours to complete. All the problems do not have numbers with them, so it is just variables, which makes it very hard to know if a mistake was made.

The best way to describe Dr E. is that they are a challenging but fair teacher.  They convey the information required in class, but to do well on homework/exams, office hours are a must.  By far they are one of the best professors I've had at CSM.
This is someone actively looking for reasons to accuse you of cheating and misconduct. If you can't offer multiple defenses of your work you will be sent to the Dean. Avoid at all costs.

Very knowledgeable but not always the best at conveying information. Few examples in class. Not many homework assignments but they they were hard and took several hours to do. Accessible outside of class and responds well to feedback. Listened to our feedback as a class but it's late in the semester so things likely won't change until next semester
rating_tags: Respected--Accessible outside class--Graded by few things

comment: Veronica is very lecture heavy focused more on derivations than going through problems we might see on quizzes or exams. She did not give us the mastering that the other 2 sections had rather her "own" hw problems that insufficiently prepared us for the midterm (avg of 48%). She reported 1/2 the class for academic misconduct for even viewing chegg
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Good personality and person but did not like her teaching. Focused more on derivations rather than examples and the quizzes and tests were difficult(average on midterm was 50% initially). I gained more knowledge from a textbook than her and avoid Chegg completely. She will ding anyone for academic misconduct just for viewing a Chegg solution.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Energetic during his lectures, sometimes went a bit off topic. Even though lecture wasn't mandatory, you're kinda screwed if you don't go because he lectures on the whiteboard and rarely uses lecture slides that are posted on canvas. He was always open to help outside of class
Decent professor. Makes the material pretty clear, and grades easily on tests. Is extremely available outside of class, he gave his personal cell # to everyone so they can text/call with questions.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr C is a fantastic professor. First time I had him as a prof, and I was intimidated by this course. He made some very difficult concepts seem not as daunting, which made me feel comfortable with the idea of succeeding. He was not a harsh grader, and his feedback was helpful. Also, his small jokes in lecture and hangman drawings were the best.
Absolutely amazing professor. Always available to answer any questions 7 days a week and literally 12 hours a day. The man is a genius and is extremely caring!

The actual concepts taught in Dynamics are not particularly challenging, but Dr. Ciobanu certainly found a way to make them so. Half the time I had no idea what he was trying to explain, and the other half he was erasing the 'example' problem he'd made it halfway through without seeing a mistake near the beginning. Chegg was a better professor.

Didn't get the textbook ordered until 6 weeks into the class, no homework assigned before then, two homeworks unrelated to lectures before the exam, pop quizzes with a quarter the time actually needed, thick accent, unavailable, doesn't respond to emails, terrible handwriting, doesn't grade any assignments before the exams, I'm out of characters
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Very Passionate and knowledgeable. When he comes to class, he's sure to dedicate that 50 minutes to your learning. Other students didn't care for his teaching style, but it was right on the mark for me.

Easy to understand, keeps office hours, offers help that enables you to think about problems and concepts.  Does not talk over your understanding level.  I am an EE major and he didn't hold that against me.  Great Professor!
Great teacher.  Comes from research background, approachable and knowledgable.  Works our tons of examples, homework required buy applies directly to tests.

I actually had Professor Rickey for 471, and she is great as well, but Dr. Ringler is an amazing person and an excellent professor. I learned the most from her office hours and she is extremely knowledgeable about what she teaches and is super understanding of her students. I recommend for anyone to take her courses if they have the chance.

Ringler takes the time to get to know all her students and their interests, she truly cares to make students feel welcome and seen. I often do homework in Office Hours just to hang out and chat if they're not busy that night.

Professor Ringler has been my favorite professor at this school so far. She is passionate and extremely knowledgeable on the material and does an amazing job explaining what the students need to know.
Ringler is really good at teaching this hard class. Probably the best professor I've had at Mines

Would recommend anyone take this class if they had a chance. If you do the work, it is an easy A. The class is about vehicle modeling and the semester long project is turning an off-road RC car into a drag racing car. She is an awesome professor who cares about her students and what she teaches about.

Professor Ringler is really good about getting the information she wants out of you, by explaining the expectations and possible ways to reach that goal very clearly. 
She also is really good at making the class fun and feel worthwhile as you learn what you need to while also working on a fun project

MEGN391 is by far the best course I have taken at Mines. Prof Ringler does a great job with the class and it is extremely interesting and entertaining if you are even slightly interested in the automotive industry. Cannot recommend Prof. Ringler and MEGN391 enough.

Heat Transfer is one of the hardest undergrad courses, and Brodsky made it digestible. She takes the time to offer plenty of office hours and answers emails quickly. The course is heavy with homework, but it's designed to help learn the material. She is approachable, friendly and outgoing. She wants to see us all succeed. Best prof @ Mines IMHO...

Dr. Brodsky is the best professor that I have had at Mines. She is a good lecturer, and is very helpful in office hours. She is understanding and open to feedback on exams and HW. The class is very challenging, but each assignment helps with understanding the material. 100% would take a class with her again, and couldn't recommend her enough.
He is the best professor in the department, no question.
terry young is the best teacher i have ever had.
Terry was great. If you had any problems with assigned work, he made sure to help you if you asked.

Terry is extremely helpful especially when you go in after hours.  He always makes time for his students and grades fairly as well.  Even if you are not great at the particular project or course, he acknowledges showing a good effort and rewards you for it.  I highly recommend him.
Excellent professor.
He is very helpful only if you asked for help.. but he is very interesting teacher.. I would highly recommend him
Young is the bomb. If you have to pick between Strong and Young, get Young. Smaller homeworks (but more in depth), beyond fair on exams (no surprises, ever), entertaining and honest in class.

He teaches well but makes up HW and tests the day before, so you get no review. He also likes putting really hard content on the HW and tests that he doesn't cover sufficiently in class. If you like the subject hes the teacher for you, if your just trying to get the class done DO NOT TAKE TERRY YOUNG
No Comments
He explains complex concepts in a way that's easy to understand. :)
Such a lad
Best TA
Very Funny, best TA. Explains things very well
Good TA best for chem labs
He is funny and he gave students good grades.
The chillest TA.
Good TA at grading.
Nice TA

I took Agarwal and it was his first time teaching the class since 2008, which showed. His lectures usually had plenty of mistakes, but it was still relatively easy to follow most of times. His test questions were usually straight forwards but the tests could have been longer to pad any inevitable mistakes.

Nothing special about his teaching style, but there aren't really many drawbacks either. The content can get pretty complex and involved, but as long as you stay on top of it, its pretty manageable. The test questions were either hard or easy, and they are so short that one small mistake can really screw you up.

Awful. Take anyone else. Exam did not include any numbers (???) and had complex derivations that he struggled to even write on the board without taking several moments to stare at his notes. Does not explain things well.

For lectures he writes the examples from the book. He struggles to come up with answers when people ask questions. The quizzes somewhat reflect the homework but the exams look nothing like anything in the other graded work or lecture.
Hes sooooo cute!
While he tends to stand in front of the board while he's teaching, he really knows his stuff and the exams aren't too bad compared to some of my other classes.
If you are quick and smart you will like his teaching, otherwise he can go over the material really fast.
Very unprofessional.
Great teacher.
Prof Miller's lectures are very clear and concise- made the content super easy to understand, best professor I have had at Mines thus far!

She is super caring and ready to make sure students learn. She is always available during office hours and willing to stay after class or schedule another time to meet. One of the best profs I've had at this school.

Kristen is an awesome statics teacher. She explains material clearly, and is very accessible during office hours or by email. She also prints out notes that help to organize the material you learn in class. The class is very homework-heavy, but that is just the nature of the course no matter which professor you get. Great prof.

Prof Miller does a nice job at being caring and very motive to teach, but sometimes does not explain small important details very clearly. Can go very quick during lecture so pay attention the whole time. Is a fair grader and understands/cares for students very much. If you can get Guerra, I would try but Miller isn't bad.

I really enjoyed the structure that was provided throughout this course with the note format. However, it would be nice to see the notes posted online. I have heard stories about the other statics professor at Mines, and I am very glad I had this teacher instead of that one.

She's good, but doesn't stand out as great in any way. Lectures are easy to follow, but rarely very engaging, and she can get monotonous. She's approachable and helpful with questions outside of class. She could be disorganized and sometimes didn't finish lectures entirely, especially early in the semester. Overall, a standard professor.
Shes a good person and always easy to understand in class. But never makes it through the days notes and doesnt post them online.
Great professor who cares very much about helping her students learn. She gives out her own note sheets for you to fill out every lecture, and explains everything super clearly.
Great prof, no surprises or tricks.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: so much fun and a really caring person. absolute gem and very easy class.
You will not learn anything unless you study by yourself
Try to avoid taking his class.
Very bad teaching style.  Does not communicate well when talking to a person about almost anything

Norm was friendly and happy to present the material in different ways when people were confused.  For such a math-oriented class, it seemed  low on technically analness.  There were a limited amount of practical examples.
Not very clear, but very helpful and always available. Will be missed.
Confusing teaching style and the class is usually lost in his lectures.  Do what you can to avoid any of his classes.
He was pretty bad at teaching feedback, get Vincent if you can.
No Comments

I had Dr. Domaille for Ochem 1 and am upset he won't be here for the spring 2025! He was a very friendly and knowledgeable professor who explained tough concepts very well. While not mandatory, the lectures are very important for understanding. The exams were fair and I enjoyed the few chats we had in office hours. Would absolutely recommend!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: I couldn't ask for a better Ochem professor than Dr. Domaille. The material is incredibly difficult, as anyone who has taken the course knows. Domaille's lectures are quick and dense, but are still interesting and easy to follow (very mechanism-heavy). He lets you know what is expected of you for exams, and is accessible outside of class.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Domaille comes across as truly genuine, is often quite funny, and he actually teaches. It seems like he really wants his student to learn and enjoy Ochem. He will curve exams and is more than happy to share anecdotal knowledge or, when asked, go over things that might not necessarily be in the textbook. I will remember his kind enthusiasm.

Domaille was a breathe of fresh air after Ochem 1. He understands the subject and does a great job portraying the material. He goes through it slowly and makes sure to explain it thoroughly. He made sure it was clear what was expected of us on the homework and on the exams. If you go to his lectures (which I did a little) you can easily pass

Dr. Domaille is a great professor, he knows what he is talking about and he knows how to teach it and he seems like a good person. Had him during the pandemic and he still made a hard subject understandable, honestly easier then o chem I

Took him for Ochem 2 spring 2020. Loved him and loved his lectures. He made ochem 2 easy and that was after I struggled in ochem 1. He is actually a really cool guy and the way he teaches is extremely effective. You guys have to take him if you get the chance!

Dr. Domaille is a great lecturer and breaks subjects down into sections that allows you to understand how reactions occur and why. He is very clear on what will be on the exam and takes the class performance into consideration when grading.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Domaille is a great professor in terms of lecturing on a difficult subject. He takes the time to go through reactions with you and is an overall great teacher. I would love to take a class from hime given the opportunity.

Great teacher, knowledgeable, adaptable, and able to break down confusing concepts into their understandable simplifications. Still a difficult class that requires 100% attendance not for participation reasons, but because the subject will be overwhelming otherwise
Nice guy. Easy A so long as you pay attention and complete assignments on time. Material kinda interesting.

He does not put up with stupid people, which I admire, but his class is fun. So long as you go to office hours or see him in the writing center, you'll get an A. He's awkward but really funny once you get to know him.
I took his environmental communication class. So knowledge and fun.

He's just an adjunct who teaches a gen ed. required writing course. I wonder if he ever thinks about the fact that no one sitting in his classes wants to, or chose, to be there. We're simply required to take the class. Plus I can confirm, its nothing more than high school ELA all over again with a slight engineering twist, taught by a non-engineer.
not a nice human
super passive aggressive and arrogant

This was a fun ethics class. The writing sucked but you have to do that in every section regardless of the teacher. I liked Lambert and will be taking his 400-level Media Studies class this summer. I've also registered for his technical writing class and his graduate-level communication class (I have to take that as I'm a 4+1 in geophysics).

He asked us to write RMP reviews for him which, I guess, isn't a bad thing, but the way he asked felt like pandering. Ryan Lambert teaches a freshmen writing course at Mines and nothing else. I earned a 700 on the written portion of my SAT and had AP English credit from HS. This class was a pointless roadblock that I wish I could have tested out of
Lectures were always interesting, it was the one class I didn't mind attending.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Amazing lectures --Graded by few things

comment: He is great as far as HASS teachers. I felt less stress than my friends who had other professors.
Solid prof and really funny! Takes time to get to know you.
Such a nice guy. cares about us and is clear and helpful. Take Lambie if you can! He knows a lot about many different fields.

I found Adjunct Lecturer Lambert to be a very underwhelming and disappointing teacher. I suppose that goes without saying considering he teaches a required freshmen writing course as opposed to a topic any of us came to Mines to study. He basically teaches high school senior English part 2. Plus he's super passive aggressive and arrogant.
One of the best teachers at Mines.

Second time taking Dr. Berger, first for Mechanics of Materials, then for Advanced Mechanics of Materials. Still the greatest professor on campus, extremely knowledgeable, approachable, and can easily explain things in a new way so that you understand.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Inspirational--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: With out a doubt the best professor I have had at Mines. He taught Mech of Mat so well that I am thinking of changing my major. Will be taking advanced Mech of Mat just to have him as a prof again.
He is an amazing Professor. I loved school of Mines because of him. I highly encourage you to take his class, you will benefit a lot. After I took his class I was able to pass my comprehensive exam.
An incredibly enthusiastic, knowledgeable prof. Very willing to go out of his way to help students. Lectures are full of material, well organized.
best teacher at mines
Very interesting and enthusiastic
No Comments
No Comments

Most of the previous reviews are clearly the instructor rating himself. If he is still employed at CSM and you have the option to take another professor: DO SO. Pointless lectures, vague instructions, and the assumption that everyone has in depth knowledge of electrical components/sensors. The grading is easy. Good man, Terrible teacher
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Great professor really appreciate his attention to detail in making sure that each student learns something every day. The bad review given about him is obviously by a lazy student who just wants to take the easy way out. If you're reading this you should leave mines if thats how you wanna act.

The previous rating of this professor is absolutely ridiculous and disrespectful beyond belief to me. This professor is a caring person who cares about his students learning the material while at the same time makes it easy for you to get a good grade all you have to do is TRY. His instructions are very clear and he gives you every tool you need.

2) actually, sometimes I am getting too specific with my instructions as it is. Part of the learning is figuring out how to do it - and you may have better way than I could do. But the reading material gives descriptions of the test to be done, sometimes schematics, etc. Other than a complete video of every experiment, I'm not sure what you desire.

Had him for MEL 1. He likes to talk and basically repeat word for word of the pre-lab reading. Provides helpful non-confusing hints whenever you have a wiring error without directly giving you the answer. Other than the long lecture early in the class, he is cool. Highly recommend!

At best I understood the labs at an high level before coming to class, then his lectures and personal notes made everything clear. MEL 1 could be frustrating without him. Very fun lab and a TON of VERY cool experiments. His lectures are informative and insightful and he is helpful as long as you don't ask a question that was covered in the reading.
His name means The Hammer... nuff said.
Likes to talk, but is very helpful with labs.
Good overall teacher though he likes to talk for nearly an hour straight at the beginning of each lab...

Kevin is one of, if not the best, professor I've ever had. His teaching skills are highly refined, and his empathy toward his students is exceptional. His teachings are clear, and he is very available to meet after class.

He is such an amazing professor everyone in this class loves him. He understands the material is a lot and adds in a good story every once in a while of the perfect length to give us a break. Overall an amazing human

Kevin is very well prepared for lectures - puts filled and unfilled notes online for study. He cares so much about his students. Always reminds us that if we don't understand something, it is probably his fault (so he does a really good job of stopping during lecture to clarify). Very open to student ideas. Drinks 1+ cans Coke Zero every class.

Kevin is truly a phenomenal professor here at Mines. His lectures were super easy to follow, and it is clear that he cares about the students; he always responds to emails as soon as possible, and is always ready to help and explain material if someone doesn't understand it. Overall, he made the class much easier and straight to the point.

Truly a fantastic teacher. Super accessible outside of class, responds to emails in less than an hour usually, explains material very clearly and in multiple ways, very good guy in general. I can't say enough good things about this professor. I'd take more classes with him if I could. He took a hard and boring class and made it easy and enjoyable.
Kevin is the best. His enthusiasm and investment in students really makes him a pleasure to work with.

I've had Kevin (he goes by his first name) for both Calc 1 and 2, and he has been an amazing teacher. He is always trying to improve his teaching skills, and actually cares that you learn the material.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: He is able to effectively explain a topic in multiple ways so if you don't understand the first way you may be able to another way

Kevin is a brand new teacher at mines as of fall 2017. He's a quirky guy, fairly young and slightly awkward at times. But his jokes are pretty funny and he is very easy to talk to. Doesn't go by Dr. but rather Kevin. His calc 2 class filled up almost instantly , if i could i would take more classes taught by him. Really nice and interesting teacher
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Wheeler is a great professor and is very good at explaining material. Is helpful when you ask him a question and guides you on the right path with your assignments. Great with allowing extra time for athletes and is an all around nice guy.
Good guy all round. Had the pleasure of taking MEGN200, MEGN300, and will take 301 with him. Also super knowledgeable about industry; he's been a better career advisor than the career advisors.

Amazing teacher, I have taken 2 of his classes so far and he is my favorite teacher. He is very clear with his instructions, and provides a lot of feedback. His lectures are fun and interesting. The projects are fun and teach you how to apply your knowledge in a variety of ways.
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Overall, really good professor. He's a little awkward when asking for feedback but in general very good with his lectures, explains things clearly, and is helpful when needed.
Cares about students, super knowledgeable about all subjects he teaches and makes it a good experience.

Really great professor. Cuts the unnecessary stuff from the class and only focuses on what we need to do. Always helpful and gives good feedback. Very friendly and explains everything in the class clearly

I took Wheeler for MEGN300. He did a great job of keeping lectures short so we had ample time to finish the in-class assignments. He grades fairly easy, he explains the content well, and he's an overall solid professor. I rarely worked outside of class. With Wheeler, if you focus while in class you should pretty much be fine.

Wheeler is a great teacher. Whenever possible I try to take classes taught by him (so far 200, 300, and 315). While he is young, he is super knowledgeable about many topics and is very eager to help out students. He is easy to listen to and always explains the material in an easy to understand way. If you ever have the chance to, take his class.
Dr. Wheeler is a great professor! For MEGN200 he makes things easy, and if you are ever hung up on something he will spend as much time as necessary to help you understand.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Has terrible organization for class. Over half of his presentations had reused slides with no new information. His test/quiz questions were generally really obscure or not discussed points in the slide (if he even included the information. Needs significantly more training in effective professing/organization.Terrible in regards to academics.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Super interesting content and you can tell he really knows what he is talking about. Plus he is a kind and fast grader
Dr. Richards is really generous with grading and relating lecture to the real world
The quizzes are you,r friends! Overall a nice guy and knows what he is talking about

Richards is an amazing professor. His class was very test heavy grade-wise which terrified me at first, but he is very understanding and will make sure that if you know the material, you will pass the class. His teaching style is very lecture oriented so if thats something you do well with, take his class.

Dr. Richards was a great and understanding teacher during these hectic covid times. You can tell he wanted the students to do well. You'll likely get a lot of quizzes, but the average of the top 10 quiz scores can replace your lowest exam score. Only complaint is he never made study guides for the exams.
Take someone else that can teach the material better.
Dr. Richards is a great professor who is easily accessible and is very understanding of student situations. He has quizzes at least once a week but they can only help you.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Beware of pop quizzes--Caring

comment: Dr. Richards does a good job of teaching his nanoscience class. I think that he makes the subject interesting and gives great lectures. He is not always the clearest on what he is looking for in quizzes and exams but in general he has an enjoyable class.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: Professor Squier is incredibly kind and likable. He's great at answering questions and explaining concepts.

One of the best professors I've had at Mines. Clearly explains the material, and lectures are actually pretty fun most of the time. Gives awesome real world examples of when the stuff you're learning would be used. Labs help greatly to understand and apply the course material. Always available and willing to help in office hours. Great prof!
An awesome guy! I would extremely recommend him as a professor! Very helpful, very clear, and very good at explaining concepts, extremely nice guy I would absolutely recommend

Digital Circuits.  He is the nicest professor I've ever met (except maybe Lusk).  His presentations of material are extremely clear and he is super useful in the lab setting.  He is one of those professors who you really want to go to his office hours because he's so unimposing.  Not too clinical, not too off-the-cuff.  Just right.
Really clear. Highly recommend.
Pretty sweet dude, I must say.  Not the easiest class, but he's an awesome teacher.  One of my favorites for sure.
Awesome professor, frequently goes off on tangents related to a topic in order to provide relevance.  Have used this techniques from his course to make several other courses much easier.

Squier is a terrible teacher. Rambling, poorly organized notes. Lectures wander all over the place. Class lacks any meaningful cohesion. Gives extremely simple examples, then assigns extremely difficult problems. One of the worst professors I've had here.
Very awsome professor. If you ever get the chance take his class.
Excellent teacher.  One class from Dr. Sen is worth 3 classes from other professors.
He is a responsible professor with years of experience in the power industry

Don't expect a usual classroom lecture when you take P.K.  He is a mediocre teacher when it comes to material but he cares about students.  He cares more about the real world than the material in the book; for instance he reviewed my resume.  His lectures on the material are quite sporadic so it helps if you can follow along in the book.

The class was ridiculously easy.  Showed up 50% of the classes because he gave the same lecture 4 times in a row.  Got up and left several classes because of boredom... not just the subject matter, but the repetitiveness of the lecture.  Got an easy A because the test was literally regurgitating the same problem we went over in lecture 1M times.

Not a good professor for Intro to Circuits.  Especially if you don't have much interest in the topic initially.  PK doesn't teach in any specific order.  He jumps around a TON, and doesn't use the same sign conventions as the book.

Final is very conceptual and part of it is the same as the quiz given on the first day of class. If you ever get a class with PK Sen, you are in for an experience. He is as humorous as he is good with explaining the machines. He could be more organized with the grading but it doesn't matter since he is so awesome.

Grading is not objective or consistent. PK doesn't streamline or formalize the grading scale and makes it obvious this is to make us work harder. That said, PK is one the greatest professors around. Not only does he present some difficult material well, he makes you see the meaning behind the equations and the intuition behind the concepts.
PK is the MAN! He almost makes up for the fact that the rest of the EE department is stagnant and thus treated as low priority by the school. There's a quiz on the first day so get ready!

Amazing teacher. Very intense but keeps the whole class laughing and in a great mood. Everyone i've talked to that has taken this class agrees. The tests and quizzes are tough, but he doesn't do a 10 point grade scale so it's not like a 50 means an F.
Definitely knowledgeable, but lectures are boring as he reads off the slides and knows little about C++ (knows more about Python).

Professor Wang is clearly very knowledgeable in the subject but that does not translate to his lectures. While it is clear he knows what he is talking about, he oftentimes reads directly off the slides and has a hard time understanding questions when they are asked. If you have questions, ask another professor or in office hours.

Good, knowledgable professor... in python. He knows his way around coding, and knows the course content. But anything more, he can't answer, because he doesn't code in C++.
He also spent some time in China. His accent is perfectly understandable, but a lot of the time, if you ask a question, he can't understand. If you have questions, ask elsewhere
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: I can't speak for Professor Wang's upper level classes but I wouldn't recommend him for CSCI-200. He seems to forget or not know basic information such as indexing vectors with brackets or what an unordered map was. When asking questions for clarification he never really gives more information half the time his answer is just "because".

Zibo is a nice guy but his lectures are not. He doesn't understand student questions and students have to correct his answers half the time. As the course coordinator he constantly makes mistakes with due dates that negatively affect the students. His lectures do not help teach the material and he is hard to get information out of.

Zibo taught Machine Learning. His lectures were very motivated and you could tell in his office hours that he had a genuine desire to help students. Having taken him before in CS102, I was hesitant to take him again though he taught the class surprisingly well and was very lenient on grades. Like Read teaching database, Zibo's passion is this class

Zibo struggles with a language barrier but tries his best. His lectures are monotone, but he is happy to answer questions and wants to help when you try for it. He is very smart, extremely passionate about ML, and a real nice guy. The class is really easy to get an A in, but difficult to understand. He will help you understand if you try for it.
He's clearly a smart guy, but he's a terrible lecturer. He's not very engaging and basically just reads off the lecture slides from behind his computer without much elaboration.

Too smart to teach a lower level class, guys practically a genius so when he explained stuff he had to force himself to dumb it down a little bit. No bias against any students, good grader, quick at responding to emails, just too smart for teaching a 200 level class.

Dr. Tilton is a good professor and a nice person. Very accessible in office hours and answers questions thoroughly. He wrote the textbook which means he is very familiar with all the content and has clear lectures. HW can be decently hard, and exams are very hard. What content is going to be on the exam can sometimes be unclear or misleading.
Helped me out when I thought I was going to fail. The material is hard but he'll help anyone if you just ask. A real one

Dr. Tilton is the best professor I have ever taken. His ability to put himself in the viewpoint of a confused student when giving lectures and answering questions is extremely useful to us confused students.
Dr. Tilton is the best professor I have had in my academic career. Incredibly sharp and witty, but also caring and down-to-earth. Wish he taught every subject I need.
His lecture is one of the best I've taken at Mines. Very clearly and well organized.
Professor Tilton was super clear in the way he explained the material. I also found him funny during his lectures! Probably my favorite professor here! 10/10 would recommend.

Dr. Tilton is one of the best profs I've had at Mines. He explains everything thoroughly and clearly with no extra content to confuse you. He's super approachable and takes the time to sit down with you if you have questions. He works out derivations to show where equations come from and then applies them to examples which I find very very helpful.
He spent far too much time on theory and proofs and little to no time showing us how to actually solve problems. His lectures did almost nothing to help teach me Fluid Mechanics.

Dr. Vincent provides most of the materials needed to suceed in this class. Most of it consist of you applying your own knowledge and skill to designing the robot. I believe it really comes down to your group in this course that makes or break it. It is a signifcant time investment but it actually develops some workplace skill.

One interesting fact about this professor is that he never shows up in class except for demo days and lets us compete with each other for the robot project, which is essentially an over-engineered system that does the basic line following. It should never need any complex modeling in the first place but he just wants to overcomplicate things...

This was an open lab class where we had to design/build a robot to basically follow a path on the ground. The only times we saw him around were for the demo days and he would never have anything set up. It would be 30 minutes into a 50 minute class before the first people could test. Just inexcusably unorganized.

The whole class of EENG 350 is just a non-stop living hell with an unreasonable amount of work for 2-credit hour class. Vincent rarely comes to the class to teach anything useful but expects a whole lot from the robot in terms of its speed, accuracy and times of failure. He even went to the extreme where he disallowed us to cover up noises in lab!

This professor is clearly smart and knows his subject, Feedback Control Systems, very well. He is just particularly bad at teaching the subject. His lectures quite often don't make sense and he will make mistakes when he performs the rare example problem on the board. He will grade the group project HARD!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Group projects--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: I felt that Dr. Vincent did not do an adequate job of explaining the class material. Too often, he would go on tangents that mattered very little to the subject at hand. I felt that this course lacked any connection to other topics. He clearly knows all of the material for feedback & control, I just don't think he's very good at conveying it.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Dr. Vincent is awesome. His lectures for Feedback Controls are on point and he is willing to help with whatever homework problems you need. He does a great job of walking students through new concepts without telling them exactly what to do. He's also very accommodating for the exams and wants to see all of his students exceed. Bring your iClicker!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: He is a great professor. His tests aren't tough, if you do the homework problems you would ace the exams. His grading criteria are clear and gives you a chance to make up the lowest homework grade before each exam. would take him again for feedback.

Von Herrmann is extremely nice and loves to strike up conversations before classes and during lectures. He always keeps the mood light in the classroom. He often brings in his guide dog and treats for the class. He also can be very hard to understand because of his dialect and some may find his lectures hard to follow if you're not paying attention

Alan Von Herrmann is one of the nicest people I have ever met. He cares deeply about his students and is very understanding about assignments as long as you email him before hand. He brings his service dog Charlie into class and brings cookies and other treats to class periodically. 10/10 would take again (I am currently taking him for diffeq).
Dr. Von Herrmann, while he means well, he is not a good teacher. His thoughts and lectures are often felt fragmented, with to many assumptions made on our knowledge of the mathematical processes.

Von Herrmann is a nice guy, but his lectures are terrible. For context, he was deaf until he was 22 and only after that was able to hear, not very well either. He is great at math, but not at teaching it. His slides for lecture are poorly made, his handwriting is difficult to follow and its tough to know what he's saying. Avoid if possible.

Although he is a little difficult to understand, I feel that overall, I am much more successful in his class when compared to my friends in other 213 classes. In general, the lectures closely follow the assignments and exams, helping with preparedness. He can tend to be a bit strict to students who goof off in class, so it's best to stay focused!

Prof Von Herrmann makes an effort to get to know his students but is challenging to understand and you have to put extra focus into listening. He's a cool dude, tends to start class off with funny anecdotes, gives in-class time to work on worksheets, and participation is counted through collaborative exit quizzes.

Do you pay attention and take good notes? Yes? Then AVH is not for you, because you won't know what notes to take and you'll leave class more confused than you started. If you can self-teach, however, boy is AVH a fun one. His handwriting is *atrocious* and he's generally condescending, but he's hilarious, and you'll never forget his strange style!
He is a great person, but he doesn't know how to teach and prepare students well. Expecially if you haven't taken Calc you will struggle.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Not super clear about some report formatting specifics (and will dock you accordingly) but overall easy.
So boring, even if the material is interesting to me. It's impossible to study for exams- goes off power point for lectures. Get Shorey- it will save your life.

Horrible lecturer and teacher. Lectures are all powerpoint with small font and then large pictures. Often never posted the correct lecture notes and just puts you to sleep during lecture. Though he is quite helpful out of class.
He is terrible!
As long as you can stay awake in lectures, the class and getting an A is really easy.
Go in and talk to him about Alabama football or the Broncos... you'll get an A... seriously.
Planetary Geology is incredibly easy.  As long as you are able to stay awake in the lectures, you will pass without any difficulty.
His lectures are extremely boring.  They will put you to sleep.  Tests are fairly easy. Take Shoreys class instead.
I was new to the university and he just made me feel at home. His explanation skills are amazing and one would end up learning a lot from him!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: All time favorite teacher- for 3 classes. He just moved to Alabama- you're lucky to have him. He encourages the class to work together to solve problems. The problems don't always have a right answer but you will learn more in his classes than you anticipate. Most of his grading is based on effort. Use his office hours! Smartest person Ive ever met
He is a great professor. Highly recommend him for any class
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Get ready to read

comment: One of the best teachers I have ever had the pleasure of learning from. He is not great at grammar or technical words, however he knows his stuff. Hes also a very understanding individual. One study broke his leg while in my class and Dr. Amaro worked with him over a series of weeks to get him back on track.
really good teacher, but you need to show effort in his class. really helpful during office hours and over email
Homework. And lab. And homework. And lab. And homework. And test. And repeat. And repeat again. Nice guy though.
Awesome teacher with great real world experience in industry which helps students understanding. Hilarious stories. Helpful in and out of class. Nice to look at.

The best professor I had at Mines. Extremely helpful during office hours or through email. The lectures were full of content, personal experiences, and practical approaches. For HW, leave theory behind and be prepared to actually design systems. As long as you show effort, you'll get an A. If you usually don't give much effort, get prepared to.

This professor actually cares and is passionate in math. You can tell he actually wants to help you, not because he wants to be a good teacher, but because he wants to spread his knowledge and passion.

Brian is super awesome! He is a bit confusing at times and he didn't teach like the rest of the Math Department but he knows what he is doing. And if you ask he is more than willing to help. He is super down to earth and really connects with the students and super approachable. I suggest his class!
Good at explaining and working with students
Very fun teacher who loves his job and cares about his students. He made us do the work ourselves but when we really needed help he would help us out.
Brian was relatable and understood our course load. I would highly recommend him to everyone.

I attended Brian business statistics class during spring 2013 at RRRC. A great teacher that is willing to help students by tutoring before class or by appointment. Also, the lessons were plan very good and amazing work sheets that help me understand material. He makes the class very exciting and is very passion on teaching. Highly recommend

Very involved professor that is willing to help and will do best to provide understanding to problem or concept. Although its difficult to understand his reasoning sometimes since most of his notes are basically the textbook rewritten(which can be a bit confusing). In this way one really has to do homework, or you will be lost. Easy grader & cool.
Brian was an awesome teacher for my NHV ethics class, he was always helpful and fueled conversations

Took her a while back, but I still want to chime in. Attendance is required which I don't mind, except that she kept marking me absent despite not ever missing a day of class. She'll read off the sldies verbatim without any further explanation. Very bad professor to start off compsci with.

She is the worst teacher I've ever had in my university, she just teaches us the concepts of programming with her Power Point and NOTHING ELSE,  the programming assignments are super difficult and tricky since this is my first time to learn C++ ,so I just don't know how to deal with coding, I totally lost my mind in her class. Don't recommend .

The only good thing I have to say about her is that she is very willing to answer questions in class, whether or not her answers make sense is a different story. Her lectures are useless and the PowerPoints are too vague to rely on. The programming assignments are extremely difficult and require you to use code that is beyond the scope of the class

I take her CSCI class at University of Colorado at Denver and she is by far the worst instructor I ever had. She comes in with a PowerPoint and literally looks right at it and reads it to you, then asks if you understand it. She doesn't show you how it works and counts for attendance for reading PowerPoints that are posted on canvas.

Book is essential for this class because that's the only way you'll learn anything! Teacher is unorganized and contradicts herself in a single lecture.  Phrases 90% of her sentences as ?s, which is confusing and not helpful (it doesn't help that her grammar is rather poor). Class is entertaining because she has mood swings and is extremely rude.

Wait for another professor to teach OS.  She does not know how to teach.  Most students in her class are irritated with her.  She has mood swings that make it difficult to feel comfortable around her.  Wait for another professor.
Awful class.  Rude professor.  Don't recommend.

She is very disorganized. She is hard to understand and not a helpful teacher. She assumes that we already know everything about Operating Systems. If you don't have to take OS, don't!!! Unless Tracy Camp starts teaching again. She makes it very hard to get the material if you have to miss the class for any reason. She does not care if you fail.
Dealt with him at Dublin and am surprised he gets away with treating people so disrespectfully. Would avoid as a prof if he is still teaching or advising grad students.

Murray is rarely on campus and is also spread thin across a huge group of graduate students and consulting obligations. He complains heavily about his students writing skills and offers no constructive criticism for improvement. It seems his MO over the last decade has been use students to gather data for his own publication agenda.
Very helpful and knowledgeable
Good teacher and is very resourceful and well connected ... if you are interested in mineral deposits it is worth you time to take a class with him ...
Best professor I ever had!

Watch your back with these people, focus on YOUR work and do not volunteer to work for this prof or his various interests/companies. Remember you are in school to finish your degree, not add to his or anyone elses portfolio.
Excellent teacher
he was a great teacher and really loved what he did

Dr. Norrgran actively talked about my behind my back not knowing I could hear her. She was not responsive to emails and just read off of slides that were not even hers during class. It felt to me that she didn't like teaching the class at all. She's a cool person with an awesome story, but I wouldn't recommend taking her class if you can help it.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: this class can be pretty hard but i think it is very valuable and absolutely worth it, though you don't get a choice if you're a QBE major.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: No real lesson plan, lectures were just reading off slides that were later posted to canvas. Curriculum was purchased from a 3rd party and labs didn't connect very well to the material. Poor communication on expectations - and even when you cover all your bases TAs would still miss obvious things you would then have to go back and dispute.

Dr. Norrgran is an amazing professor. She can seem intimidating at first but is a super kind and knowledgeable human. The exams in this class are hard but she makes up for it by having them worth only a small portion of your grade. Highly recommend taking Bio 2 with her!
I loved Dr. Norrgran for BioMed. Her lectures are very interesting, she tells lots of stories and is just a fun energy. In BME she graded nicely & never let tests destroy you (they were
Good professor, with clear objectives before each test. Rogue memorization is your friend and will get you a B on exams. Think a little deeper for an A.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Don't ever take Norrgran if you can help it. Syllabus lists 6 exams not including the final, with the tests plus final totaling 80% of the overall grade. The homework is data analysis that doesn't show up on the exams, so it doesn't help you prepare for the exams at all. She doesn't prepare for lectures, and just reads off of the publisher slides.
TA's grade everything. Everything is basically completion except for the tests. Tests are not worth much (3-5% each) but are very hard. Easy B hard A

Professor Sparks is a good teacher, and she was accessible outside of class. I think the lectures could be a little clearer, and sometimes it feels like she's just reading verbatim off her lecture notes instead of teaching it to us.

I had Professor Sparks for Calc 2 and she was always very accessible outside of class, often staying long over her office hours to help students. Her classes were focused and covered everything you needed to know for tests. Would absolutely take again.

She really cares about students' success, including their wellbeing outside class. She's willing to make unofficial changes to make the course work for you.
