comment: Gets mad at students when they don't understand. Speaks down to students. Tests instead of teaches. Critical to a fault. Not an enjoyable experience at all, and with so many other professors available, I recommend looking elsewhere.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: People seem to love or hate Prof. Steele. Ask questions, be willing to accept feedback that may seem harsh on the surface. She seems to care about the success of people in her class.

While a very intelligent and accomplished woman, Robin Steele might be the most difficult instructor that I've ever had. Very high standards for all assignments, impossibly heavy course-load, and highly judgmental
She is the worst teacher ever. She is a tough grader, doesn't care enough to understand the material, and is downright mean.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Lenient but still learned a lot.
Does a great job with feedback and helps you to develop your ideas into reality.
Chill teacher
garrett is a real one and the most chill professor I've ever had. He always made it pretty clear what expectations for work was and is pretty forgiving with late work.

Garrett is a very fair professor for design. He treats it like the class is a design group at an actual job which gives a lot of freedom for creativity. He is also understanding and fairly chilax with grading. Just put in your best effort and you'll do well!

I had him for my design class and it was a good experience overall. He is very laidback for the most part and is very willing to help you succeed, especially if you ask for help. I think that design can be a really not fun class, but Professor Erickson made the class much more enjoyable and it turned out to not be too hard.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Graded by few things--Group projects

comment: Reza is a great professor. He gives great notes and he feels genuinely passionate about the material. He provides good materials for studying and is relatively forgiving surrounding exams. His homework is genuinely helpful and I feel like I have a greater grasp on the course material than I have gotten from other courses.

Reza is a really nice person who is passionate about his field of study. The class was very organized, and he sets up his students for success. He does a good job of giving real-world applications of the content. The exams are sometimes a little more challenging than expected. Lectures can be a little boring.
Professor Hedayat is a good professor. However, his lectures are extremely painful to sit through. He simply rewrites the textbook on the board and will occasionally do a practice problem.
I thought the lab with him was fun and informative. He's an nice professor that cares about what he teaches. Definitely one of the best professors in the CE department.

He's a great professor that is passionate about what he teaches. He is never in a bad mood and is extremely nice to everyone. His homework is easy and still teaches you the topic. If you go to his office hours, he is eager to re-teach something anything you might be confused about. He also answers any emails fairly quickly.

He is admittedly respected in his field, but this does not translate into competent teaching. His lecturing skills and materials are severely lacking, meaning most concepts had to be self taught. Exams were extremely difficult and he was not at all forgiving on grading. I would recommend taking ANY other professor for this course.

Professor Lu is a very nice person and an absolute master in his field. Unfortunately, he doesn't always do a good job lecturing. He can be disorganized and it's not always clear what parts of the lecture are important. The homework is helpful but graded harshly. You will be doing a lot of self-teaching from the textbook.

Terrible, Terrible lectures. Literally just buy the textbook and study on your own he won't teach you anything past what the textbook can. His slides literally are screenshots from the textbook with worse explanations.

Seemed hard to understand at first, but  I definitely got used to it. He doesn't post all lecture notes, so going to class and taking notes is important. Overall, very helpful and not condescending. He's a really smart guy with a lot of passion for what he teaches.
Not the easiest to understand, but you get used to it. Sometimes does flare up at students. Incredibly knowledgeable. Team teaches w/ Dr. Godt (USGS), who provides good balance to Dr. Lu's theory.

Prof. Mueller is a nice guy and is always willing to explain concepts after class. However, his lectures can sometimes be a bit confusing as it feels like he's just monotonously going through a bunch of examples and not always explaining the concepts behind them. Even though its a lot of content, you can still do well with a bit off effort.

His lectures are some of my more enjoyable ones, especially in math. His personality is great and he understands what he teaches and how to teach it. His class is lecture-heavy, but attendance was not taken. If you feel good about a topic, you don't need to go. Keep in mind we had a few ungraded pop quizzes for attendance purposes.

Professor Mueller does a great job in the lectures, giving a wide variety of examples for each topic, and is always willing to stay a few minutes after class to help you if you have any questions. His classes also had the highest average mean test scores compared to the other professors, which says a lot about him as a professor.
n/aaaaaaaaaaaaa

Lecture's skip all of the buffer things that you don't really need for the tests. Doesn't grade for attendance and is totally fine to not show up to some lectures if the topic is possibly something you know. However, expect some attendance pop quizzes—we did like five of them. Great for office hours and little work for the class.  Funny guy too.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Spann is the sort of professor to recommend you do something in an assignment and then give you a zero because you didn't follow his recommendation.
Super laid back professor as long as you turn in major projects on time. Pretty sarcastic in a funny way. Overall, interesting class.
Doesn't seem to know what he's talking about most of the time, requirements are confusing, generally just a bad teacher.
Not helpful, annoying, unclear requirements, ineffective instructor for an ineffective class.
She was kind
Pretty ok teacher.  She goes over quite a bit more material in more detail than you actually need.  The quizzes are hard, but if you do all the readings you will probably do fine.
Challenging, but at least she takes her students seriously. Won't put a questions on quizzes or exams that don't closely relate to what's in the book or discussed in class.
She is an okay teacher. She could be cute. She knew all of the material, but probably talked a little bit too much at times. I would recommend her.

Melissa is an inspiration to anyone looking to start a company. Very easy to talk to and approachable. Homework isn't bad, 0-1 assignments a week. Lectures aren't always the most interesting but overall a great class. An easy A if you put in the work.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Super disappointed with how this class went. She emphasized "student involvement" and active learning groups, and while that's great, class ended up feeling more like office hours with 80 people in there than a lecture.

Doesn't seem to know what is going on all the time. She also skips class a lot and likes to cancel office hours. Be prepared to learn all of the content outside of the class. A lot of busy work is assigned and the homework doesn't prepare you well for the tests or quizzes.

Could possibly be the worst teacher at CSM. Doesn't know the material well and isn't effective in the class. Class time is used for solving problems that we don't know how to do. With one teacher in a room of 70 it is almost impossible to learn anything
Great teacher, did well with a non-lecture type class.
Professor Hering is a very knowledgeable professor. Works with you if you're uncertain, and recognizes when you put effort in.
Hering is a great teacher. Very helpful and encouraging.I have very little interest in statistics but took more than one course because of her.
Pretty awful. Pacing was way off. Spent 3 months going over completely trivial concepts, only to rush through the last month of actually interesting content.
He can be really condescending, especially when the class does bad on a test. Other than that, he's pretty good. Sometimes he goes too fast though

This guy is awesome!He made this problem 3bc+0.567df=b/c all over 2 seem like pie! the answer is 2 DUH! i didnt know how to do this before his class and now i can just look at it and go "OMG how did i not know that before?"He is really funny.I die laughing every class but he kinda moves on before you can laugh.Also, he said he liked my cat slippers
I like this guy, he's really nice and tries to be funny. Has a way of simplifying even pretty tough problems. Tests in this class are really hard though...
Super helpful. Always willing to stay after to help with problem on homework. Really funny too...

I took Doug for 436 but it wasn't listed. Doug has been a fantastic professor, he can be a bit unorganized and his lectures can be lengthy, but if you can get survive that, you will learn a lot from him. He has managed to find the perfect balance between pushing you to try hard, and also being incredibly caring and understanding.

Nychka is one of my professors at Mines. He is clearly a genius and is caring and kind. His lectures can get long but they're very informative and I've learned a ton in both classes I've taken with him. His classes are challenging though, I think the hardest take home I've had at Mines was in Nychka's class.

Nycka is a genius but struggles to get all the brains on paper in an organized manner. His lectures are slow and he sits in the corner writing on his tablet and they are projected on the screen. It makes it feel very slow and not engaging. Super nice but I found it hard to learn the material

Prof. Nychka is a rare professor at Mines in that he pushes you hard with coursework while being understanding in recognizing that school-life balance is important. I'm leaving this course with the feeling that I have a solid handle on probability. Be prepared to work hard/seek support on this classes homework and tests - they are really tough.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Caring

comment: Dr. Sava was a fantastic professor for this class and really cared about you absorbing the material. His office hours are highly effective and a great learning resource. He is very good at debugging, and oftentimes will detect issues with your code that you didn't even notice. This class varies in difficulty depending on coding experience.
Paul Sava is one my favorite professors so far at Mines. He cares a lot about his student's learning and is very helpful when asking for help.

Professor Sava is a very nice guy and knows a lot about computer science. He explains material slow enough for everyone to understand, while also not being boring. He provides a lot of resources including online "notebooks". His grading policies are very fair and he allows for a long time to complete assignments. I would recommend him to anyone.

I take inversion class  GPGN409 class with Paul Save and he was an excellent lecturer. The course is mathematically- computationally heavy. He usually gives a week span to do the homework and I needed to start as early as possible because homework was longer than any other class work. No exams and midterms but he replaced them with weekly quizzes.
rating_tags: BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: I had lecture online and lab in person. She was very clear about the material and I enjoyed the class.

I absolutely love Professor Farris. I had some medical issues over the semester that caused me to get very behind on homework but Professor Farris did everything in her power to help me. She is very understanding and cares a great deal about you doing well and as long as you reach out she will do her best to help.
Taught better than many of the other full-time professors I've had at Mines and was always super willing to help at office hours.
Typical grad student teacher. Nothing special or particularly good. Sometimes does things well, but frequently leaves you to figure it out yourself for the most part.

Stevie Rea is a great professor who is really passionate about the material he teaches. He is clearly knowledgable and is very understanding of his students. Sometimes his classes can go a little off topic, but for the most part, his classes are meaningful and enjoyable.

Nice and passionate about subject. He docks you half a letter grade for every absence over the 4th. There are a few short writing activities every other week, and then weekly readings and worksheets that take 30-60 minutes, but you only have to do 15 of them throughout the semester. There's also a research paper and two tests-- they're manageable.

Stephen Rea is a gamer No really. He did research on gaming culture in Korea and he is the nicest dude you have ever met. His lectures are great even if you are not that invested. He gives excellent feedback (make use of it) and makes it super easy to pass his class if you put in a bit of effort. 10/10, probably the only HASS200 prof worth taking.

Dr. Rea made HASS200 quite bearable. I think he did the best that he could with a core humanities class at an engineering school. There were many lectures where his passion came through (especially when talking about his experience studying gaming culture in South Korea). There were exams and papers, but he is probably one of the best for HASS200.

Dr Gianquitto is amazing. Her American Gothic Literature class was very engaging, and the works we read were all relevant and interesting. Classes are mostly discussion-based.
Get ready to read a LOT out of class though!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback

comment: Professor Gianquitto is a stunning teacher and human being. The class topics were so interesting, and her passion is contagious. She knows how to respond to student comments in an encouraging way and is very open-minded. There was a lot of reading, but I always looked forward to it because the texts were fun. Take one of her classes if you can!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Inspirational

comment: Easily the best HASS professor I've had. Lectures were actually interesting and I learned a lot. Definitely a caring professor, willing to adapt the class to our needs. Readings are long but were rearranged when we said we were overwhelmed. Not many assignments and the writing assignments weren't graded too hard. Good with having open discussions.

She was passionate about what she taught but I think she was unable to inspire most of the class. You have to put in a lot of effort to get an A on any short essays and she never gave 100% on them, so most people get high B's. Finally, she only answers her emails about half of the time so be prepared to follow up on any emails.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: Healy is new to teaching and it definitely shows. He isn't confident and spends most of lecture talking into the whiteboard so nobody can hear him. Seems like a nice enough guy but just doesn't have the mechanics of teaching down.

By far the worst professor I have had at Mines. His lectures are extremely difficult to follow and are not engaging in the slightest. Avoid at all costs, the other calc professors here are MUCH more insightful and helpful. Coming from someone who got an A, I learned strictly from outside videos. I rarely skipped, but it was a huge waste of time
Very difficult to pay attention in his lectures. He was very quiet and it was often difficult to understand him. I used the outside videos to learn days before the exam because class wasn't helpful.

He is overall a solid choice for a teacher. I have no real complaints other than that he doesn't have notes on his lectures, so when I missed a few of them, there were no online notes and I had to get them from a classmate, and that his office hours are only 2 times a week for like 30 minutes. The only help is to go to him after lecture and ask.

Hilarious guy, interesting lectures, cares about his students. I was initially putting off this class, but really enjoyed it because of him. He is not a very hard grader either. If you participate in his class, he will like you a lot. He also will help his students in any way outside of class too (letter of recommendation, etc)

Great professor overall. Serious about his class, makes the lectures enjoyable and interesting. He is a very realistic and genuine person, he is very easy to talk to and gets straight to the point which in important in this class. Super understandable with issues if you are a good student and participate.
Solid professor. Lots of work in the course, but wasn't difficult to succeed.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: Dr. Brian Foley is a great person. He just takes the class very seriously. It's good, especially at a place like Mines where the students don't care about humanities. But, he knows that the students don't really care about this class. If you put effort into the class, Dr. Foley is great. If you don't, he'll become the professor you don't like.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Tessa is nice but...I don't think I learned anything in this class, despite getting a good grade. Lectures too fast and slides are cluttered. Canvas page is confusing. Quizzes/Homework ALWAYS ask about stuff we never learned. Unclear what our reading assignments were. Class is more of a brief review for those who already know about construction.
not a good professor

Constantly complaining about how much of an inconvenience it is for her to be teaching. Also does not seem to really understand the material as she constantly makes mistakes. Overall her attitude just makes an already boring class even worse to attend.
Only teaches from the board and makes lots of mistakes while teaching. Not helpful when you ask for help either

406 is a very hard and conceptual class but Prof Estelle did her best to make it clear and enjoyable. She is a genuinely awesome person who cared about every student and her own performance, listening to all feedback we gave. Fridays are optional and she typically uses them for homework/project tips or asks students what they would like to discuss.

Despite my appreciation for her effort in teaching the course, there were definitely some issues that needed improvement. Some topics were not clear when explaining. Moreover, some of her explanations led to confusion for the students.

Very caring professor, who is genuinely interested in the field and willing to engage with many fields of thoughts. Aims to empower students to think for themselves. The course structure was a little overwhelming, lots of assignments and readings, and the deadlines sneak up. Most assignments are justified, and overall worth taking.
Tired of reading all those papers. I got an A, but it wasn't a smooth journey!

Very understanding professor. She has a policy of a 2-week buffer on assignments. I've had some really good discussions with her. Super sweet and has given me so much motivation to get better at my writing and communication skills.

Other NHV professors are pretty stingy graders. Kim operates her class on a A,B,C checklist. If you do all the requirements for a B, you get a B and so on. Other NHV professors are relatively picky for grading and those small minuses do add up.  Kim will give you thoughtful feedback for your writing without hurting your success. Very understanding.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Graded by few things

comment: Super understanding of outside circumstances! Likes people who participate in the discussions, but if you're quiet she completely understands. She's great for NHV (it still sucks, but at least with Kim it's not because of the professor!)
rating_tags: Group projects--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: I had Kim for her very first semester at Mines and she did a pretty good job. She is very nice and caring and a relatively easy grader. You do have to show up to every lecture, but that's just how HASS 100 is structured so every prof will be that way.

I though he was an excellent instructor and nice. Like others have said, his lectures are very clear and concise. I would suggest trying to attend every lecture and taking notes. The textbook is also a helpful resource, but you aren't required to read it. Do the reviews and activities for exam prep. Overall, I highly recommend him for Probability.

He is what you need in a math professor: concise and to the point. You know what is expected on assignments and test and he properly prepares for them in class. You can tell he has a system down for lecture notes and they are perfect. His notes are clear and efficient. He also answers the dumbest of questions without judgment.

Dry lectures for the most part, he speaks in a relatively monotone voice. If you ask questions during class, he'll usually give you a vague answer. If you ask him after class or during office hours, he gives you a more structured answer. Just be ready to show up and take detailed notes if possible.

Dry lectures, sometimes hard to make it through the whole thing, but very effective as a teacher. Does not answer questions in class that well, but is very good in office hours in a more 1:1 environment. He will work with you. Random pop quizzes every week or so to encourage attendance; the textbook is actually useless, so you gotta go to lecture.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Good teacher and easy to understand. No complaints

Wendy does a great job of appearing to be on the side of her students, but leaves them to their own devices constantly without support. Her 'curriculum' consists of reusing ESRI's course materials, which would be fine, but the approach that ESRI uses is very much a 'one size fits this exact use case and will likely not be useful for your use.'

Wendy is SO helpful, if you can understand her thick Chinese accent. If not don't worry, EVERYTHING you need is in the assignment or slides or her walk-through during lecture. All you have to do to get an A in any of her classes (I've taken them all) is STAY after lecture is over and ask for help. She will walk you through ANYTHING.
Impossible to understand, unable to convey information or help students with problems.  If you have her, get to know your TA well.

Three words: "Werify the Wegetype." She has one THICK accent, if you can't understand what she says out loud, check the power point or assignment, it'll say it there as well. Overall, very helpful, really loves to see kids excel in GIS and always manages to have an excellent TA to help as well. DO beware, you need to know you stuff for final.
Really passionate about the material and accessible and approachable outside of class
She is overall great, but her exams were not. You might end up doing terribly in this course because of not knowing what to study for the exam.
Awesome Prof. She is really passionate about what she is teaching and has some of the most interesting lectures I have had here. Would recommend.
She took over for the last professor who left, she's pretty great and lectures are amusing but sometimes she seems unclear on what she's teaching, but that could be because she's new

Professor Osgood is a really nice guy but is the laziest professor I've ever had. 99% of the work for the class was done by his TA and he rarely graded anything himself. Even the students wrote the exams and answers, he just proof-read it. The class itself is an easy B. Also, he refused to round my 89.6% to an A. Cool dude, not a great professor.

Took Global Studies during the Fall semester of 2022. The format was very interactive, with teams of students forming mock National Security Council's and dealing with various hypothetical crisis situations around the globe. I really enjoyed this class much more than a lecture-essay based course.
Not a great professor, no structure to his class, can't teach, and makes you use model diplomacy instead to teach yourself. DO NOT TAKE
It's a mandatory humanities course at a STEM school. Class was good enough for what it was. Format was unique and made things interesting than what other sections had for this class.

Humphrey is an awesome professor, hilarious in class and makes fun of all sciences equally. The tests and homework are rare but more difficult, so you have to work for the grade you want. However, format doesn't change so old tests are good study guides. I love this class!
Not sure where these quality reviews are coming from. John is short-tempered, rude, and condescending.
Awesome professor, very informative and entertaining.  (Ask him about life choices ;)
Awesome Guy!

He is vague when answering questions on homework during office hours. He does not respond to emails. The old tests turned out to be online, so whoever happened to have the old tests got amazing grades and whoever did not have them did poorly. So it was extremely unfair. I guess if you have old tests from the internet, you would love this class lol.
I have never experienced a professor that was so unhelpful in my learning experience my entire life. His exams are awful and everyone seems to like him because they access to old exams.

Frequently unhelpful outside of class. Highly unwilling to provide guidance on how to solve problems beyond cryptic suggestions. Clearly worried about "solving it for you", to the detriment of actually helping struggling students learn. Good lecturer, but no help at all if you fall behind or struggle with the material.

Dr. Samaniuk does a great job taking the time to explain the principles in controls and why they matter. He teaches you everything you need to know without making things unnecessarily difficult. I would definitely take him again.

Professor Werner's lectures were really boring and unspecific. I had him for calc 1 and about half of the classes were in class lectures that he never went over, did not get graded, and he would not look over them or give feedback on them. Having taken calc 1 in high school, I knew what I was doing already but he really just confused me more!
Usually showed up late and unprepared. Lectures were frustrating and slow. Key points were not emphasized. His grading was alright, and he was helpful when you asked him a question.

Werner isnt a bad teacher. His lectures often went a few minutes over the end of class. He explains a lot of the reasons why we do stuff to solve a problem so if you like detailed reasons and stuff like that then Id recommend him, that just isnt something I particularly enjoy. He doesnt use MyMathLab so you have minimal HW and no book code to buy.
Brett is a genius, sometimes it is hard for him to get out what he means, but he gets his point across. He wants his students to LEARN the material, not just memorize things. Good teacher, good guy.

I had to take 3 classes with her and she made my college experience 10 times harder. Very arrogant, condescending, and a bad communicator.
She only cares about making it hard for students to get an A. Maybe Mines should bring someone else to teach this class that's more professional, in touch with the current field situation, and not scared of AI.

worst instructor ever! Doesn't care about education or learning, all she cares about is the manner in which you submit assignments. Stubborn, arrogant, and a show-off. She will brag about her law degree in every single class. Assignments are meaningless and don't help you with anything in life. If you can avoid her, do so. 100% don't recommend
Old school and makes it her life mission to not give A's. Treats a 1 credit as if it is 3. VERY harsh grader.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--So many papers

comment: Does not actually teach anything. Makes TA create all assignments and grade everything. Has guest speakers every class. Bad attitude and demeanor. Condescending. Would not recommend.

Gave very good and entertaining lectures. The class is mostly dictated by two take home exams, one midterm and a final. Only reason I downgraded to a 3 was because I did not even know my grade until the semester was over. I took the midterm in February and it was never graded, and I received homework grades back months later.

Professor Mathaudhu is a great professor if you want to do little work. The exams are take-home, even the final. You don't need to go to lectures; if you go, you don't need to take notes. All homework is graded on participation, you don't need to have it right. Beware, 30% of your grade is the midterm and 50% is the final!

Suveen is very knowledgable, humorous and entertaining. His lectures are just read off of powerpoints and they are very dull and dry, doesn't do any examples on the board. HW is graded for completion, Exams are take home, open book. While I learnt some interesting things in his class, I also don't feel like I didn't truly learn the course material.

Lectures were clear, engaging, and understandable. The workload was very light with only weekly quizzes (5-10 minutes) and exams. You have to be motivated to practice the material yourself as there is no work outside of class. The lack of reinforcement can lead to lack of understanding of the material, but his course is fun.

Just a boring class. It's easy to get a good grade, but the content is foreign and difficult to grasp initially. It's hard to get yourself to go, and for our semester personally messed up the grading all year on canvas up until the final exam then curved the class a ton
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Bo is a phenomenal teacher and describes such a complex topic such as computer engineering and simplifies it down into such digestible terms. He is so passionate about what he teaches and I would not choose any other teacher at mines to teach this class.

Bo Wu is a great guy! My personal opinion is that he is more passionate about research than teaching, so students who take his class can't rely on receiving assistance from him day-to-day. This class was supposed to suck and he made it great. Bo is a day one.

I personally liked Bo for comporg. He was very passionate about the material and enjoyed teaching, and he was also very open to feedback from the class. He also developed an AI TA for the class which was pretty nice for test/quiz review. Unfortunately, the grading for this class is skewed heavily towards the test, but they seem to grade leniently.

I have had so many great classes and teachers at Mines and it is very clear that this was not one of them. Bo was very disinterested in the class, only held office hours for one hour a week, had a TA lecture the entire class 2 times, and didn't even show up to the exam days. There is little study material, no tests of quizzes were ever returned.
Elijah really cares about everyone's learning and will go out of his way to make sure everyone is understanding the content
overall, hes really great. I enjoyed his class a lot and I highly recommend him.

Kuska is a super nice guy. I had him during his first semester here at Mines and he was a really good professor. He is very patient when you don't understand what's going on and really wants you to understand the material. But be ready for his playlist to be played on repeat and if you don't answer his questions he will wait until you do.
Not the biggest fan, nice guy but can be inconsiderate. Teaching is ok

Dr. Kuska is an academic gem.I genuinely cannot describe how amazing he is. Even though I had his class at the ripe hour of 9:30, he always came to class with a smile that could quickly brighten anyone's day. He also does his best to get to know his students, often cracking corny jokes to foster a friendly and inclusive atmosphere in the classroom.
Very clear at explaining things. Follow the examples she give you if you want a good grade. Spending some time on papers will go a long way in this class
Really really really clear. She wants stuff done a specific way, but if you write exactly according to her outline, you should get a good grade.
Found her to be one of the easier Epics teachers. Not a hard grader in my opinion and very willing to help.

EPICS is supposed to be one of the easiest freshman classes to boost your GPA. It's a simple team building class where you learn to use computer software and sketch. One of my friends has a 98% going into the final project, but has another professor. I have Natalie and I'm barely holding onto a B. Grades way too hard, and makes class uninteresting
Great at what she does, passionate about math.

You can kinda tell Professor Sawyer is new to teaching. She sometimes gets flustered and becomes unsure of herself, but it is still clear thats she knows the teaching material. She is available outside of class and very willing to help her students. Once she gets comfortable lecturing, she is going to be a great professor!
She is a charming professor and a good teacher. You can see that she very much cares about her students and is always accessible outside of class to help them.

Lecture days are mostly optional especially if you've taken calc in high school already. Activity days are not but the assignments usually can be completed in class. Super kind and always walks around to check up on everyone and answer questions. Understanding and not too much homework.

NHV with this professor is the definition of you get what you put in. McGovern definitely rewards hard work, participation, and clear interest. However, if you slack off, don't come to class, or fall behind on assignments, she won't seem that easy. She is very understanding with excused absences, however.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lots of homework

comment: Prof. McGovern understands the importance of class discussion in NHV and treats each person as if their voice is important. Papers are difficult so be sure to start them early and ask for help if you're struggling.

I really enjoyed taking NHV with her! She's super nice and the topics are interesting and thought provoking. As long as you don't try cramming a 3 weeks long paper in the night before it's due, you should be more than fine.
Highly recommend Professor McGovern.

He is absolutely NOT boring, although he does tend to pick naptime classes, and some people can't seem to stay awake.  You don't necessarily need to get the textbook for this class: I didn't and I did just fine.

Difficult to stay awake in class.  In order to do well on the tests, study every detail of the notes you take in class.  Most tests are true/false and multiple choice, but they are very subtle and nuanced.
He will bore you to tears, but as long as you pay attention and study really hard for his tests, you'll have a shot at passing with a decent grade.
No Comments
Tang needs to open his teeth and speak up!! I actually think he's very brilliant and knows his stuff, but his communicating of it isn't very good.

I really don't think he's a bad professor per say, he's just very hard to understand and follow and pay attention to because of his accent and quiet voice. He knows his stuff, but relaying it to students is where it's a little rough.
The worst, you cannot hear him when he is explaining. His voice is so low and his accent is hard to understand. Exams are hard
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: I took Mathematical Methods for Signals with Dr. Tang. Class Lectures were easy to follow and important information was presented clearly. Class notes were amazing and Dr. Tang himself is very helpful. He is also very good at answering questions in class and assignment were very relevant. One of my favorite professors ever.

I took this class with her over the summer and it was one of the best classes I've taken at Mines. Her lectures were never boring and though she has a specific idea of what papers should look like, she is always available outside of class and offers to read your papers multiple times until you get it right.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Wow aweful teacher. She completely makes up her own paper formating, and counts it against you when turnitin highlights stupid things as plagiarism, like your name or the word "the". She doesn't explain what she wants at all, but is then super picky on your work. She cancelled class like 7 times cuz she was busy, but expected our work to be prefect
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Group projects--So many papers

comment: I had high hope for Professor Roberts, because she comes off like she'll be a great professor, but she's anything but. She is so unbelievably unclear & impossible to please. She refuses to give any assignment specifics & says shes not picky, but then rips your work apart with her nasty little comments. Say goodbye to your self esteem if u take her
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Group projects--Tough grader

comment: Roberts takes a typical fact/memorization based class of history and turns it into one that demonstrates that history is not facts, but rather a bunch of hidden bias's. Depending on what your lense is, history can be completely different to two different people. Her approach is refreshing and actually engages the student to learn. TAKE HER CLASS.

Tissa is an alright teacher for fluid mechanics. He usually doesn't have enough time to cover all the lecture material but he follows the textbook pretty well. Tests and quizzes generally had low averages, but if you really work hard passing is manageable. He is funny and seems like a nice guy though.

Fluid Mechanics is definitely a complex subject, but Tissa does a pretty good job to explain everything. He is very approachable and kind, and will provide many complex and unique examples to work through to your benefit. Exams reflect the homework. Its a lot, but just do it and genuinely try to understand it and you will do very well in his course
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Tissa is an extremely smart professor and know his material super well. Fluid mechanics is hard, but he explains it well. His accent can be a little hard to understand, but overall great professor.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tests are tough

comment: A ridiculous amount of work. Every problem set takes days. But you will learn the material really well.
Great prof who will work with you and be a reasonable human.
Great professor. He explains everything great and is super funny. Will take as much time as needed to make sure you understand the material.
Great teacher. Helped answer all of my questions and was a very approachable teacher.

I really liked Bridgeman. He taught a portion of a first year honors course and he really helped me feel more confident about expressing my thoughts. He's super funny, very kind, and generally accessible. He's also just fun to be around. Hoping to get him for a math course soon.
Lauren is a great professor and person, she is super nice, leads great discussions, and will support you throughout the class. If your taking IDEAS I would recommend taking it with Lauren.

I wouldn't touch the IDEAS class with a 39 foot pole. Legitimate design/engineering students BEWARE. The class is designed to take all of your practical thinking and throws it to the wolves. There is no communication at all and Lauren fails to run the program in a meaningful way. I actively dread attending class.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--So many papers

comment: Lauren is one of my favorite professors. She truly cares about each and every one of her students and will make sure that you are doing well in class and in your own life. She is a very fair grader and IDEAS is a great class. She teaches it extremely well and provokes thoughtful discussions during class.

By far the best prof for IDEAS to have. She definitely cares about students and your progress in the class, but I definitely respect her and did have to put in effort for grades. Try to get in a section with her.

Qual is not an easy class and it's made that way on purpose. For the first time you have to do things more independently and that in itself is difficult but it is beyond important. It's definitely been the class most useful to my actual chemistry career. 

Dr. Yang is super knowledgable and a great resource but she is also trying to let you grow

Dr. Yang is very knowledgeable in organic chemistry. However, the problem comes when it gets to exams. The exams she writes seem to have little correlation to the homework and lecture material. You will likely encounter something on an exam that you have never seen before if you don't exhaust every resource. There isn't a Canvas page either.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Good power points, interesting lectures. Difficult tests
Her teaching style is stressful that ressourceful.

Would definitely label this guy as eccentric.
Graded pretty easy, and deadlines were super flexible (anything goes until semester grades are due).
Lecture videos and textbook readings were not at all necessary.
Spent a lot of class time working on other stuff.
He was super chill, turn in the assignments and you will get a good grade.
He was super chill
Dr. Hardaker cares and teaches a very interesting class while respecting your time.
Dr. Venturelli is awesome and really cares about her students. I loved this class.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: I did not like the class. Too simple.
She is an awesome teacher. Her lectures got me interested in geology. Awesome teacher, awesome class.

I had Dr. Venturelli for Earth and Environmental systems. She is a great teacher, gives engaging lectures, has passion about what she teaches, and gives take home tests rather than traditional exams. She does not count for attendance most days (Besides when there is an in-class activity) and she truly cares about her students.

This class is confusing and honestly I'm not sure I learned anything from it. That being said Persichetti will bend rules and give extra credit and make assignments as easy as possible to get you to pass. He is SUPER willing to work with his students to make sure they pass and this isn't a hiccup in the way to their degree. Always available!

Honestly nice guy with good intentions. However, very poor professor. As a senior chemE, he is, in my opinion, the least clear professor at Mines. His lectures are painful and confusing. We spent a month on bioreactor problems -- Wolden taught the same material better in two class periods. He is fine in a non-learning class (EPICS), but otherwise..

I really enjoyed taking EPICS 265 with Persichetti. The text book was helpful, but boring so he didn't stick to it. He also had a lot of small, easy assignments that were on-topic and very interesting.

Thermodynamics might have been an OK class, but Persichetti really doesn't explain the material well.  I barely understood anything he was trying to teach.  The other sections with Vestal and Dean had significantly better test scores.
Best Prof. He is very understand and kind hearted. Tries his best to help each and every student understand what, why, and how.
Great Class, use it when I'm doing my mine plans now.   He may be a tough grader, but skills add value and GPA's are overrated.
Very good professor
Kadri is brilliant...but not a great lecturer

Qin is a really nice guy. Theres really not much homework besides reading and two papers throughout the semester. Make sure you get to know him. He never posts rubrics or slides, so its hard to know what his expectations are and you have to take notes.

He did have us read from two books but you can get away with not reading them very much if you go to lecture and the books were really cheap. His english is good, although sometimes he'll say stuff that doesn't sound exactly right but he's still easy to understand. Really nice guy, I'd definitely recommend him to anyone.

Attendance isn't mandatory, but he does give "surprise" quizzes. He usually emails you whenever it's important to come to class, though, so you know when they are. He's really nice and wants you to do well. Probably the easiest class I've ever taken at Mines.

Took Qin for Human Systems during his second semester teaching at Mines. He is a very easy grader (for papers, the grades ranged from 18 - 20 points out of 20 points). Tests were easy too (most people were from 23 - 25 out of 25 points). I usually did other homework during his lectures. Not much homework, and he is a very sweet guy.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Probably a good teacher if you want to just teach yourself the material and skip class entirely. As another person noted his lectures are about as helpful as listening to someone else read a textbook. He can be more helpful one-on-one. More or less like a class with a TA and no instructor.
Best professor you will ever have at reading off the slides! Word for word! At some point it is questionable if he even knows what he is teaching. Also don't try asking for examples. he's got none.
Great guy! Math geek with a cynical wit to him

Lectures aren't helpful. You can skip class and review the slides online but you won't really learn anything beneficial for the homework or tests. He is somewhat helpful during in class worksheet days. Very much a stickler to the rules. Every other teacher has good notes but him. Choose another for MATH307!

She is a very, very good lady and in senior design she cares a lot about the 15-20 kids she's assigned. During SD2 she was also serving as assistant department head and running statics and SD (I think a bit overwhelmed with responsibilities) so if felt like she didn't give appropriate attention to SD, which is the place where she could slack a bit.

Dr. C does not care about students or teaching. She also struggles to get through content in lectures. She is also never on campus and is hard to get ahold of. This is one of my worst experiences at Mines.

Class was partially done with book readings and short video lectures, and the rest was real-time guided examples. Not a whole lot of assignments, but they were sometimes difficult. A few easy quizzes with chances for a regrade. Ability to get bonus points for completing written homework. All in all, helpful and lenient, but I still learned a lot.
Dr. C was nice, but she made us learn everything on our own. She graded tough, and was unclear about assignments.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Osborne gave very comprehensive lectures that were helpful on the homework, but he also went extremely fast. He was very knowledgeable about the subject as well. I gave him a 4 because he is a very hard professor to work with one on one when you have questions, but he tries his best.

He was a nice guy and did try to help students as much as he could but the class is just very difficult and the grading is terrible. Exams that are 4 questions each dictate a large amount of your grade and EES hw/projects make up the rest. He does like to throw equations around in lectures but he posts notes online.
rating_tags: Group projects--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: His teaching style consists of writing everything down on paper and talking about it which is not bad, but can be very boring. He does have a passion about it and tries to put things in perspective, but that perspective is usually related to nuclear reactors. Really good guy and will make you understand it if you attend office hours.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: I took Osborne for the MechE version of Thermodynamics. He is a kind and caring person but his teaching style wasn't what I needed to grasp a topic as difficult as thermodynamics.

Fairly nice person, not the greatest teacher. She flies through content and relies on group work in breakout rooms. Be prepared to teach yourself from the textbook and chegg all of your homework for help. The exams and tests are very stressful and unforgiving. Start on the group project early, it is more work than it is worth. Must go to class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: The most useless person to teach at mines I've ever seen.

Seems nice but she absolutely FLIES through lectures to the point you cant even understand what's going on. She also is just really poor at explaining things and makes simple concepts seem like rocket science. Invest in chegg and be ready to teach yourself the course material.

She zoomed through material and explanations weren't ideal. There is a small language barrier because she has a strong accent, not her fault really but pairing that with the fast paced nature of the course makes for a lot of work outside of class. Invest in chegg.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: He was a good professor and available outside of class. The big issue is he tended to focus on proofs that led to the equation rather than using the equation, and then you would end up with no clue how it worked for the homework.

Very easy to approach and incredibly helpful in office hours, dense course but if you have an easy time with programming and math in the past this course is very straightforward. Thorough explanation for questions that come up, and ensures that he is not feeding any false information by verifying things he is unsure of and encouraging questions.

The class as a whole is very dense content-wise and the coding assignments are tricky but fair. Samy lectures fast, but most of the content is available in pre-class videos so you can go back and look over proofs again. He was clearly very passionate about math and made the class interesting!

Samy is great teacher, but he is FAST, goes over advanced topics quickly. The format of the class: there are preclass vids, and that same info is reviewed during lecture time. Exams are tough because of the density/difficulty of the course material. Be prepared to come to TA hours for all the homeworks.
Programming portions were tough as well.

Gary Nave was a great professor. He included real-world applications to dynamics concepts and had a great balance between theoretical concepts and time to solve practice problems. I felt very prepared for tests in his class due to his teaching style.

One of the best professors I have ever had. He so clearly cares about each student. When I was struggling, he made time outside of his normal office hours to meet. He is encouraging and so understanding. He would give me extensions for no reason other than "Im super busy this week." I took an 8am to have him and it was 100% worth it. Best prof

Gary is such a nice person, and he genuinely cares so much about every student. He always asks for feedback and wants to get better. I think his teaching style can be a bit confusing. We will go over challenging content very quickly and then be asked to work on it on our own before we're ready. Homework is WAY harder than lecture.

If ANYONE gives Dr. Nave a bad review, they are either lying, joking, or payed off. Nave was easily one of the best professors I've had. He is engaging and energetic during lectures and presents at a pace anyone can follow. He is very open to questions and suggestions, and cares very much about students. His office hours are extremely helpful too.

Leamen was super awesome, had a very laid back environment that encouraged everyone to take part. He allowed you to think creatively and twist assignments into something that interested you rather than just something he assigned.

Makes all of the classes super engaging and the best class of my day by far. He always states his opinion and allows everyone else to do so  too. Makes the classes more about big ideas as opposed to the reading and what we should have interpreted from it. Would 100% take this class again, by far the best professor you can have for this class.
We love Dan

Dan is awesome! He genuinely cares about his students and wants them to learn about the content and themselves. He's not afraid to bring up discussions about controversial things, with the intent that we can learn more from them. Class is good to attend as he will always have something new to talk about and you will be engaged.

I had Chuck from PHGN 100 studio, and man he's a rambler. Most of us would just start the studio before he even finished talking and we tried to avoid asking him for help cause he would get very off-task! He's a super sweet guy, but if you take his class or go to his office hours, only expect to be talking about physics for half of it.

Chuck Stone is one of the best PHGN100 professors at Mines. I took him for a summer course and he really took the time to build a community in the classroom & explained physics concepts carefully and in a digestible manner. I struggled with this course before & taking it with Chuck Stone was the best thing I could've done. He is wacky & wonderful!

He wastes the most time perhaps out of any teacher I've ever met. He's a good guy but spends 90% of the class rambling or trying to be funny, teaches horribly, and his slides are very light in actual information.

He was one of the worst professors I've taken. Lectures were completely helpless because he never linked them with any of the homework questions or test questions. He is also insane and wastes precious lecture time to go over things like playing guitar or watching basketball. Class is boring. His lack of ingenuity matches his lack of capability.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--TEST HEAVY

comment: Worst physics teacher at Mines hands down. Very smug and unhelpful in studio. Lectures are terrible.

Worst teacher I have had in college.  Lectures are badly taught and entirely useless to your learning.  She very much enjoys to give trick questions, and when the entire class get a question wrong, she is quite smug about it, and doesn't explain how to actually do it.  The best part is those are the test questions.  So if you take her. R.I.P.

Worst teacher i've ever had, horrible at explaining the material during lecture and she enjoys giving us trick questions and not explaining why almost everyone gets the answer wrong...then the question comes up on the test and you have no idea what the answer is.
Not helpful at all. Explainations during class are not helpful at all. You are better off getting help from a TA in studio. Would not recommend to anyone.
There's only so much you can do with a thermodynamics course, but Dr. Braun does it well.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria

comment: Braun is a very good professor. Though his classes are hard, he does a good job of explaining the subject if you pay attention. His lectures are long and can get boring, but are very helpful. Pay attention and you'll do just fine.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I've heard things about Dr. Braun,  Heat Transfer nightmares, thus I was nervous. However, I have been pleasantly surprised. The lectures are useful and informative and give you the information needed to solve the homework. Exams are fair. He's really excited about Thermo II and is willing to provide help, if you can get a hold of him that is...
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Braun doesn't seem like he is "into it" w.r.t. teaching. Also, he didn't give much of a heads-up for the 1st exam, i.e., these are extremely difficult exams in a very complex topic (heat transfer) and the class had few ideas as to the possible questions that would be on the test. Polar opposite to J. Porter, who is tough, but a fantastic professor.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: James Studhome worked with me day after day when I was struggling to get my papers done on time. He was always willing to extend the due date and give any feedback I needed. I highly recommend him if you're willing to communicate and ask for help.

As far as NHV teachers go, he is the one you want. Homework is by no means overbearing and he is fair in his grading. Papers are all very well spread out. Definitely take especially if you like birds.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Studholme is exactly what any Mine's student would expect out of an NHV teacher, not an engineer, lives in Boulder, and presents a very clearly stated and frequently used bias that comes out every lecture. While he is not a hard grader and talks about controversial and current events, he is not what I would consider mines material.

If you get Dr. Studholme for NHV, be prepared to receive mediocre grades on your papers if he doesn't agree with your conclusions. If he doesn't like your conclusions it's very doubtful you'll get better than a B on the assignment. On top of that his lectures are random and meandering, it doesn't seem like he planned out any of his lectures. Avoid.

If you want an easy grade for 202, don't take Lowe. He is incredibly passionate about the material, so he goes into quite a bit of depth that other sections likely won't. That being said if you're an MME or want to go into manufacturing, he will make every class after this SO MUCH EASIER.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I am not exaggerating when I say we have twice the amount of reading as other sections. We cover more than a chapter a week, occasionally a chapter a day. Because the material covered does not build on itself, the class just feels like memorization unless you are willing to spend an unbelievable amount of time conceptually understanding everything
Thought this class was a easy A but I was wrong. Other friends took this class with different professors and they had to do less work , had easier exams and less HW than me.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: If you are passionate about materials, then Dr. Lowe is great. However, the other sections had their first test 3 weeks after ours (which covers the same material). We have more & harder homework and quizzes. Other sections is an easy A. Avg of our first test was a 78. Professor also goes too fast in class. & have to read the book
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Painfully boring and somewhat confusing lecturer. Clearly didn't want to be teaching us any more than we wanted to be learning. Rarely explained concepts to everyone's satisfaction, but very clearly an expert. As a person, he was considerate and well meaning, but should have let a TA teach his class.
This was the most confusing, meddled class I had ever taken. Lectures were theoretical, there were only two exams and five homework, and his help was not useful, avoid him as much as you can!
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: He will drone on and on during his lectures with information that is over everyone's head. He dives so deeply into the theoretical and when it comes time to do the homework or tests, you are essentially teaching yourself. There were only 3 homeworks and 2 tests and he was gone 2 week for conferences and made the class stay long to make up the time.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: Had D V Griffiths for a couple classes. Overall he is EXTREMELY knowledgeable and is generally nice/seems to care about students learning. However... his lectures are 92% background/derivation and 8% how to solve the actual problems you'll be graded/tested on. He missed about 20% of the classes to attend conferences, rushed the rest of the syllabus
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Be prepared to do more writing in this class than pretty much any English class, and with Karen definitely expect to have no idea what is going on. I am an attentive student, but her rubrics were consistently terrible and left out vital info that she would grade you harshly on. Decently nice person but bad professor
rating_tags: Lots of homework--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: She's a good professor, but is much harder grading than most other EPICS professors. The feedback she gives on assignments is very helpful, showing she actually reads the assignments and cares about helping a student fix their mistakes.

I think Professor Wylie is great at explaining design and gives great feedback. She also makes the grading criteria very clear. She is not one of the easier EPICS professors, but she's very fair and I learned a lot from her.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: This class is poorly designed and provides very little insight to engineering. Grading is ridiculous unless you get one of the teachers that hands out As. Karen is not one of these teachers.

He made the course enjoyable by grading class projects generously. My only problem was with his book which had a few typos in the homework problems (which are pretty heavily weighted). However he was quick to respond to any questions I had by email. I would definitely recommend Professor Haupt.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: He was pretty good. Lectures were pretty boring. He records them and puts them on Canvas, so really no need for going to class? Homeworks were pretty tedious and sometimes hard to work through, but he's quick in answering questions through email and he grades fairly easy.

His book that is required that he wrote himself is awful. The homeworks barely reflect what's in the book/what he teaches and they're pretty annoying to figure out/work through. He grades those hard, too. He needs to provide more guidance on matlab and homeworks. On the bright side, he does answer questions thru email quickly.
Very entertaining. Fair. Hard homework, but easy exams. Great explainer. Described complicated subjects in a simple, easy to understand way. Would strongly recommend.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria--Hilarious

comment: Great professor, sometimes lectures have little too much content but is very accessible outside of class and great explainer

Try to learn the vast majority of the concepts by yourself and get practice through internship if you can. You will not get a grade for your exam nor the final paper. So, if you actually care about learning, either take laser physics elsewhere or teach yourself. You will save a lot of time and money.
No.
One of the nicest professors ever. Really cares about his students and can explain physics very well!

I took Prof. Cuneo for Diff Eq. I found the material itself pretty difficult but her lectures were informative with lots of examples. Her test reviews were also good, and she usually planned time to work on things that students requested.

She's a new teacher to Mines this year but she's great. I love her spirit and personality and she is really willing to help and work with her students. Her lectures are not the best, but she will always help you after class or re-explain stuff. She also really helps us understand what to expect for the exams.

In the beginning she seemed a bit frazzled because she was a new teacher but once she got into the swing of things the lectures went very well. She has a great sense of humor and is incredibly smart. Our class scored above average on all of the midterms so I think she is a pretty good teacher.

She can go off topic but she is brilliant and invested in her students. She happily stayed over an hour after class (many times) to help me understand the content. Ive always struggled with math and she knows how to relate/present the concepts in a way that I understand. Truly caring and willing to help, Im very grateful to have her for calc 2.

In futures, Dr. Wigner tried to make the class as simple and easy as possible and yet simultaneously made sure we learned what we needed to. He often presented himself as more of a person than a teacher, making class so much more enjoyable than some other professors. His grading policy is "turn it in whenever, get full credit," which was very nice.
This guy is just awesome, really cares about his students and has no ego, he's just there to make everyone better, himself included. One of the best teachers I've ever had.
Design 1 isn't really a great course but Dr. Wigner definitely makes it better. He definitely cares about teaching and is willing to help you out in whatever way he can.
One of the best teachers I have ever had. He gives really good feedback and is super understanding with late assignments as long as you communicate. Made Design 1 actually enjoyable.

Provided good feedback and was always in a good mood for class. Made sure we understood the projects without taking too much time for lectures. Doesn't grade too hard and allows for adjustments based on feedback.
Super easy professor for design, especially if you are in a group that is willing to put in work on the project. Bright ball of sunshine.
Pretty easy grader compared to what I have heard from other design professors. Also super nice and very helpful.

Great professor, understanding and sympathetic with my issues throughout the semester. Grading comments were sometimes vague. Listened to student feedback and was very knowledgeable and understanding of content. Love prof A!

I didn't love Melanie. The content she gave in the class felt way too fast paced, and I didn't see a lot of connection between the content we had to prepare for the class and what her goals of discussion and learning were. Speaking of prep, the prep every week was 4+ hours minimum; just so much work. More than any of my academic classes.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: I took HNRS 315 with prof. Brandt and enjoyed myself a lot. She's very caring and accessible outside of class. She has a more iterative grading system than most. (She lets you rewrite papers and at the end of the semester, you decide your grade together.) Overall, I really enjoyed her and I would highly recommend.

For HNRS315 we had moderate to heavy but enjoyable assignments each week, and our classes mostly consisted of Socratic semesters that were very enjoyable. Melanie gives great and valuable feedback, and her trust in the students to care about her class enables the class to be more student-driven, which was a breath of fresh air.

Melanie is a good professor. She made NHV tough but I improved because of it. She is very accessible outside of class and it is very helpful to go see her outside of class. She is a tough grader but it is worth it. Some say that she played favorites but I did not see this.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: i begged my TA's in my homework programs to give me a good grade because Glen Oberhauser teaches material that he himself does not know ..you will hear the phrase "I don't know if this is correct, but it should work" a thousand times.  Good at getting chalk on himself though

Does not know what he is teaching. Writes incorrect code on board then tells you to figure it out in the homework(which he does not know how to do). Uses wrong terminology, so when taking a test you don't know what is being ask for. You will be teaching C++ to yourself if you take this teacher. Nice guy, HORRIBLE at teaching.

A really excellent teacher. Helpful, knows his C++ (and is willing to admit when he doesn't remember something), very approachable. Actually makes demo programs about zombies! If you're going to take C++, take it from him -- if the above description doesn't do it for you, perhaps the fact that his section typically scores highest on the exams will.
Very unjust grader and not professional with his policies. Does not value students input on his methods. Reacts poorly to criticism, hence this post.
horrible.

Changed the syllabus mid-way through the semester. Not upfront about grading policies. Make sure you attend class or else he will start grading you harder. Fairly knowledgeable about the topics, however, that does not excuse his behavior.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Super passionate and knowledgable about the subject. He has real-world experience in environmental policy. Had him for Global Studies Environment. 10/10 would have him as a professor again.

He ditches the typical course material to teach things that are interesting and matter. Much of his teaching is from his work history and his stories are amazingly interesting. He cares much more about kids learning and enjoying the class than the actual grade and he gives by far the best grades of NHV teachers.

A really great professor. NHV is hated by most of the students at Mines for its writing and reading heavy aspect but Brunsdale really helps out. He will help you out personally through-out every essay and structures the class so you will have to do bare minimum. His lectures are very interesting to listen to as he has a fascinating background.

Hi sclass was harder than other NHV classes I've heard but not that bad for a 4 credit. Try to take someone else but if you end up with him you won't be disappointed. Make sure you participate in class because he will view you in a better light than kids who do not particicpate.

Professor Brakefield is a great professor! He's relaxed, a good listener, and gives clear instructions. Make sure you read the syllabus and look at it frequently! That's where he puts all of the assignments and due dates. If you participate in his class, it will be way more enjoyable too!

Prof. Brakefield is one of my favorite teachers this year and I would definitely have him again. He is clear with his expectations and lenient. He is always respectful and makes sure that students are respectful to eachother. The course material was interesting. A lot of reading though - get ready to become a good skimmer in this class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Caring

comment: Solid Professor, she just moved very fast, even for someone with CAD experience. I didn't mind it too much, it just became frustrating at times. If you fall behind in one of the classes, be ready to go to office hours to have one of the TA's teach it to you.

I had her for lab, she is a very nice person and extremely knowledgeable in what she does but when she is showing the class how to do something in Solidworks for example, she goes way too quickly and you can get lost fairly quickly

I'm a TA for this course- Melissa is a good teacher, explains things well and goes into detail, sometimes goes a little longer than the other teachers but it's easy to follow along and not miss anything. She's nice, and a solid choice for lab.

Prof James was/is a bit outside the box in the best possible ways. His writing prompts were interesting and helpful. His class structure was well done. He successfully navigated tough topics in class discussions while avoiding current political swamps. 
One of my favorite professors ever.

Professor James is an excellent educator and amazing person. He was always understanding with accommodations. He gives great feedback and loves to help students succeed. The class is reading-heavy, but the quizzes are open-note, so they're not too hard. Prof. James also writes great recommendation letters!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: Dr. James is probably one of the most inspirational and passionate professors I've had at Mines. He's open-minded, humorous, and helpful, and he personalizes discussions to the best of his ability. His class was one of the few that I had motivation to go to; I highly recommend taking his course.

The outline of the class makes it hard to succeed. No partial credit on tests. Only a homework assignment a week. Which makes it tough to get points in the class. But he is lefty and writes cursive making it hard to get and understand the notes.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Helwig is a really great guy. The class was based 80% on exams so they're very important. One homework every week that maybe took an hour to do max. Exams can be a bit confusing but not too bad if you review his in-class examples well. Would often let class out early and wouldn't go over too much content every class.

Dr Helwig cares deeply about you as a student beyond just the grade you receive in class. He's extremely approachable and will talk about more than just Econ if you ask. He is very strict about deadlines, so don't fall behind.
Engaging Professor, Be in class though as examples are not posted online. Pay Attention in class to succeed. No Late Work Accepted, No Exceptions.

She cares a lot for her students, but the class just sucks. If I were to sum it up as simply as possible it would just be that you don't learn anything in the class. A full year is dedicated to basically nothing.

Carrie, AKA CJ, runs the first-year Grandey honors program. If she is teaching it, don't take it. The grading is extremely inconsistent, rubrics are vague, and you will learn less than you would taking the classes it replaces. So much needs to be done outside of class that your free time is gone, and it all feels for naught. Don't take her classes!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: I had CJ for HNRS198A in 2022-2023 and it was brutal.  For being called "Leadership by Design" I don't feel like I gained much leadership skills.  It felt more like an English or Art class with all of the creative interpretation.  The engineering projects were basic and we learned less than the regular design class. Also, prepare for harsh grading!
super passive aggressive and arrogant
Harsh grader
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Professor Lambert was an amazing HASS teacher! Definitely the best you could get at Mines.

Had him for Design for Optimization, Spring '14. He doesn't provide ANY material outside of lecture, and expects the class to code full algorithms...Doesn't realize this is a class full of MECHANICAL engineers, and not CS students.
This course can be tedious, repetitive, and time consuming; but overall greatly improved my confidence as an engineer.
Coordinator of Senior Design, one of the worst coordinated classes at school. Students spent over 70% of the time writing reports rather than doing the real works.
LOVE GYSI! Sad to see him go. He's a character and a real gem(pun intended) in the geo department at Mines. Very knowledgable and passionate.

Great professor, especially if interested in pursuing mineralogy track. GEGN206 gives a good overview of mineralogy. Quizzes require a good amount of studying, however will help for the test since they are very tough.

At the time I took the course with him, he was the only option (for future readers.) Requires a bit of work, not a lot, but still, a B grade is almost certain unless you do no work at all before the quizzes and the exams, and no effort put in the lab assignments, which every single one of them can be done in a night before the due day.

He was ill-prepared for most of the lectures as he consistently had to jump back and forth to change information to be correct (clearly uses old notes that he doesn't review until right when class starts). His lack of organization madem it hard to follow him, he constantly canceled or changed his office hours. He fails to explain things thoroughly.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: Very helpful outside of class and in office hours. Always willing to help students understand the material and pass the class. At first he seems like a tough person but once you get to know him he is super nice and a chill guy.
Spends more time drinking than preparing for lecture. Probably steals lecture notes from Professor Marr. If you're a male student don't bother asking students because he won't care.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--TEST HEAVY

comment: Dr Davis is easily one of the worst HASS professors I've ever encountered. She grades off of personal preference and refuses to hear your reasoning for whatever you've done. Weekly discussion topics are often unclear or don't relate to anything we've learned in class. Midterms are 100 or 75 questions to be completed in 50 minutes. Avoid her

She gives a rubric for grading assignments but never uses it for the grading and when asked about it just deflects the question. She also gave tests that had 100 questions in 50 minutes during a pandemic. She did not respect the students time or needs.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: Her class is pretty easy; not a ton of work as Human Systems goes. Her lectures might put you to sleep. Would recommend as a professor for this LAIS200, though.

I had Harry for IDEAS and he is a really great guy and wants to see his students succeed. IDEAS as a class is annoying and tedious, but Harry really tries to make it better for his section. I seriously recommend him if you're taking IDEAS, but I don't reccomend taking IDEAS at all, lol.

This is my 2nd time taking a class w/ Prof. Archer. He is a great and chill professor, lectures are enjoyable and interesting, and feedback is super helpful. He is very understanding and lenient with deadlines. Prof was available for office hours on many occasions. He communicated everything clearly which made the class even easier. 100% recommend!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: Harry is one of the chillest professors. He really respects his student's time, and makes it very clear as to how he will grade his papers. As long as you show up to his class and put in a slight amount of effort, you will get an A.
She was a great teacher.

I'm not sure why she has such a low score here. She's very accessible if you go to her office hours and will personally work with you if you are confused about anything if you reach out to her! She takes attendance, but honestly you should go to class, it's tough to figure out the material if you aren't there.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: If you want to find a lazier professor, go to the cemetery. She uses lectures a year old, doesn't write her own homework, and uses TAs to grade. Impossible to schedule a time to meet with because she "forgets" her other meetings. The only thing she has to do is grade the parts of the semester project, which she doesn't get done before class' end.
